description: The Windows Server 101 show is meant for those who have little to no experience in managing and maintaining Windows Server.  It fills in the gap for the desktop support technician who wants some basic and practical Window Server Skills, for the IT professional who may work in other areas and want learn more about Windows Server Administration as well as for the A+ and Network+ certified who need the learn just some Window Server Management and Maintenance before they dive into the MCSA to MCSE certification tracks. The goal is introduction and immediate skill development to manage Windows Server.   This is not for the professional who already has years of experience.

episodes.description: The Windows Server 101 show is meant for those who have little to no experience in managing and maintaining Windows Server. It fills in the gap for the desktop support technician who wants some basic and practical Window Server Skills, for the IT professional who may work in other areas and want learn more about Windows Server Administration as well as for the A+ and Network+ certified who need the learn just some Window Server Management and Maintenance before they dive into the MCSA to MCSE certification tracks. The goal is introduction and immediate skill development to manage Windows Server. This is not for the professional who already has years of experience. The ebook can be downloaded here https://itprotv-notes-bucket.s3.amazonaws.com/Windows_Server_101_by_Brian_Svidergol.pdf
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:05.672
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.672 --> 00:00:07.433
Welcome to ITProTV.

3
00:00:07.433 --> 00:00:11.964
I'm here to introduce to you a new
show that we're producing on

4
00:00:11.964 --> 00:00:13.767
Windows Server 101.

5
00:00:13.767 --> 00:00:17.045
Now if you're wondering,
what the heck is Windows Server 101 about?

6
00:00:17.045 --> 00:00:18.052
That's a great question.

7
00:00:18.052 --> 00:00:22.156
What we found out is that there is a
knowledge gap that you may have if you've

8
00:00:22.156 --> 00:00:24.590
just come from studying A+ and Network+.

9
00:00:24.590 --> 00:00:27.752
And say, hey,
I'm about to jump into the MCSA track.

10
00:00:27.752 --> 00:00:30.204
But then you feel
a little bit overwhelmed,

11
00:00:30.204 --> 00:00:34.790
because there is a ton of knowledge
right there inside of that MCSA track.

12
00:00:34.790 --> 00:00:39.185
Well, this is going to fill in that gap of
the server knowledge that you'll need as

13
00:00:39.185 --> 00:00:40.660
you go in to that training.

14
00:00:40.660 --> 00:00:43.975
Also, you may be doing
desktop support right now in

15
00:00:43.975 --> 00:00:47.860
which you haven't had any
real server experience.

16
00:00:47.860 --> 00:00:51.368
This show will at least help you get
settled and started, and feeling

17
00:00:51.368 --> 00:00:55.556
comfortable in that server knowledge, and
provide you the skills that you need.

18
00:00:55.556 --> 00:01:00.413
Now this particular show is going to
be produced around a book by one of

19
00:01:00.413 --> 00:01:04.880
our subject matters that we had
come in called Brian Sviderol.

20
00:01:04.880 --> 00:01:07.266
Brian Svidergol wrote a book
called Windows Server 101.

21
00:01:07.266 --> 00:01:10.500
Let me show you what I'm
talking about right here.

22
00:01:10.500 --> 00:01:13.938
So here on my screen, it is an e-book and

23
00:01:13.938 --> 00:01:17.489
the great thing is it will be free for
you.

24
00:01:17.489 --> 00:01:20.476
So, Brian has actually released
this out into the public.

25
00:01:20.476 --> 00:01:25.413
And here at ITProTV, we've obtained
permission to also produce a show

26
00:01:25.413 --> 00:01:30.620
giving the content or surrounding
the content of this book as well.

27
00:01:30.620 --> 00:01:33.667
And you'll actually see
right here in his abstract,

28
00:01:33.667 --> 00:01:38.610
aimed as an introduction to Windows Server
provides an overview of administration and

29
00:01:38.610 --> 00:01:43.487
management for Windows Server operating
system without any prerequisite knowledge

30
00:01:43.487 --> 00:01:46.830
of Windows Server is necessary and
that is the whole goal.

31
00:01:46.830 --> 00:01:51.212
So if you are actually saying,
I need to learn more about Windows Server,

32
00:01:51.212 --> 00:01:52.708
this is the show for you.

33
00:01:52.708 --> 00:01:54.839
If you're getting ready
to take the MCSA or

34
00:01:54.839 --> 00:01:58.033
to take that track on, well,
this is the show for you as well that

35
00:01:58.033 --> 00:02:02.520
we'll get you comfortable with the
knowledge and the material that you need.

36
00:02:02.520 --> 00:02:07.910
Now, this particular show though is not
based around any particular exam at all.

37
00:02:07.910 --> 00:02:10.428
So, there are no real
objectives that are met.

38
00:02:10.428 --> 00:02:11.616
Here at ITProTV,

39
00:02:11.616 --> 00:02:16.960
we wanted to make sure that we gave you
the best possible chance at exceeding.

40
00:02:16.960 --> 00:02:22.140
And of course, succeeding on
your MCSA skills as you move on.

41
00:02:22.140 --> 00:02:24.640
So, what are some of the things
that we'll be covering?

42
00:02:24.640 --> 00:02:28.719
Well, Brian's book is actually divided
up into five different parts and

43
00:02:28.719 --> 00:02:31.970
there's actually 24
different chapters in it.

44
00:02:31.970 --> 00:02:35.614
We tried to actually produce,
well, either a single a show or

45
00:02:35.614 --> 00:02:39.970
multiple shows around those particular
chapters that will help you out.

46
00:02:39.970 --> 00:02:44.325
So what you'll actually see in this
particular show that's coming up is that

47
00:02:44.325 --> 00:02:48.613
you'll see different episodes based
on just basic server fundamentals and

48
00:02:48.613 --> 00:02:52.298
this is where we get you familiar
with Windows Server itself, and

49
00:02:52.298 --> 00:02:55.380
understanding the functions,
and the features, and

50
00:02:55.380 --> 00:02:59.600
how to do a few things that you
may not have actually done before.

51
00:02:59.600 --> 00:03:03.913
You're also of course, going to see the
idea of networking components that we find

52
00:03:03.913 --> 00:03:07.750
in Windows Server itself and we'll
talk about some of the details there.

53
00:03:07.750 --> 00:03:08.543
And o course,

54
00:03:08.543 --> 00:03:12.843
your basic Network+ knowledge is going
to be of tremendous help for you as you

55
00:03:12.843 --> 00:03:18.160
continue to go through those particular
sections that we'll cover in there.

56
00:03:18.160 --> 00:03:21.530
Then we'll expose you to
the basics of Active Directory,

57
00:03:21.530 --> 00:03:24.644
directory services as well
along with group policy.

58
00:03:24.644 --> 00:03:28.180
And we'll talk about managing user
accounts and computer accounts.

59
00:03:28.180 --> 00:03:32.784
We'll even see the use of group policy and
how we actually apply them, and

60
00:03:32.784 --> 00:03:38.240
where to apply the as well as getting
everything set up for what we need to do.

61
00:03:38.240 --> 00:03:39.650
We'll also see in the fourth part.

62
00:03:39.650 --> 00:03:44.760
We'll see services covered storage
as well as NTFS permissions.

63
00:03:44.760 --> 00:03:49.054
One of the big topics that you'll see that
will be throughout everything that you'll

64
00:03:49.054 --> 00:03:52.108
do in your MCSA or MCSE track
as you continue to move forward.

65
00:03:52.108 --> 00:03:54.606
So make sure you do take a look at those,
as well.

66
00:03:54.606 --> 00:03:57.414
And then finally, our last section,

67
00:03:57.414 --> 00:04:02.590
we'll be covering file services
as well as print services.

68
00:04:02.590 --> 00:04:08.063
Now once you actually have that and
everything is good, that will give

69
00:04:08.063 --> 00:04:13.905
you a solid foundation for, of course,
you to proceed on to well deeper and

70
00:04:13.905 --> 00:04:18.670
more advanced topics that you'll
see inside MCSA and MCSE.

71
00:04:18.670 --> 00:04:23.950
So, this will give you at least a broad
breadth of knowledge to help you do so.

72
00:04:23.950 --> 00:04:27.889
Now for you to obtain Brian's e-book,
you can go out there and

73
00:04:27.889 --> 00:04:29.462
search on the internet.

74
00:04:29.462 --> 00:04:36.538
Use your favorite browser engine, type in
Brian Sviderol's name, S-V-I-D-E-R-O-L.

75
00:04:36.538 --> 00:04:40.634
I know it's kind of a long name to spell
out there, but you can actually type in

76
00:04:40.634 --> 00:04:45.370
Windows Server 101 and you'll probably
see that there'll be a link there.

77
00:04:45.370 --> 00:04:50.236
Now if you're actually an ITProTV member
though, you'll also see a link directly to

78
00:04:50.236 --> 00:04:54.831
this particular overview video as well and
that will also give you that access and

79
00:04:54.831 --> 00:04:57.618
that chance to be able to
download that book too.

80
00:04:57.618 --> 00:04:59.982
Now, this is not a light book.

81
00:04:59.982 --> 00:05:07.300
So even as an overview, it is,
electronically about 353 pages.

82
00:05:07.300 --> 00:05:09.890
So, you plus or minus about 50 pages for

83
00:05:09.890 --> 00:05:13.160
table of contents and
then some indexing at the end.

84
00:05:13.160 --> 00:05:16.250
But overall though,
it's still about 300 pages.

85
00:05:16.250 --> 00:05:17.989
So, it is a great book.

86
00:05:17.989 --> 00:05:20.220
It's a great base of knowledge.

87
00:05:20.220 --> 00:05:24.423
Combine that along with your own study
skills, along with the labs that you can

88
00:05:24.423 --> 00:05:28.768
actually follow in Brian's book as well
as labs that we present here at ITProTV.

89
00:05:28.768 --> 00:05:33.467
It will get you prepared for
what you need in Windows Server knowledge.

90
00:05:33.467 --> 00:05:36.643
So if you're ready to proceed,
make sure you stay tuned for

91
00:05:36.643 --> 00:05:38.940
the first video following this overview.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee brief talk about purpose of this show. The team discuss the basic premise of Windows Server and it’s use and setup for a Windows Server Environment.  They dive into some of the hardware considerations we should understand and know as a Server Administrator.  Cherokee also shows the beginning of installation and the choices you must make before the installation completes.  Lastly, she reviews the minimum hardware requirement for getting the installation of Window Server completed.
episodes.title: A Peek into Windows
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.441
Welcome to ITPRo TV.

2
00:00:01.441 --> 00:00:06.295
I'm your host, Don [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.295 --> 00:00:08.300
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.300 --> 00:00:13.615
>> You're watching ITPRo TV
>> Welcome to another great

5
00:00:13.615 --> 00:00:18.401
episode right here on ITPRO TV, you're
watching the Windows Server 101 show

6
00:00:18.401 --> 00:00:19.969
>> I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:19.969 --> 00:00:22.742
And today we're taking
a peek into Windows and

8
00:00:22.742 --> 00:00:26.167
here to help us with that is
gonna be Miss Cherokee Boose.

9
00:00:26.167 --> 00:00:27.351
Cherokee, welcome to the show.

10
00:00:27.351 --> 00:00:28.535
>> Hey Ronnie, how's it going?

11
00:00:28.535 --> 00:00:32.151
>> It is going well, glad we're
actually starting this particular show.

12
00:00:32.151 --> 00:00:33.421
>> I know, this is a real cool one.

13
00:00:33.421 --> 00:00:37.730
Didn't you just finish some shows with Mr.
Brian Svidergol, did I say that right?

14
00:00:37.730 --> 00:00:38.466
>> Svidergol.

15
00:00:38.466 --> 00:00:40.289
>> And then he gave you a book to use so

16
00:00:40.289 --> 00:00:43.821
that we're gonna be actually
mapping this series to that book.

17
00:00:43.821 --> 00:00:46.887
>> Yeah, and this is actually a very
interesting show for us where,

18
00:00:46.887 --> 00:00:49.474
what we're doing is we're
kind of filling in the gap.

19
00:00:49.474 --> 00:00:52.252
If you pretty much just finished
A plus and Network plus and

20
00:00:52.252 --> 00:00:54.349
you don't have any real server knowledge,

21
00:00:54.349 --> 00:00:58.327
this is the one that's gonna give us
some practical, hands-on administration.

22
00:00:58.327 --> 00:01:02.613
Management skills as well, to get us
involved in the server right away.

23
00:01:02.613 --> 00:01:07.360
And Brian Svidergol has really graciously
provided this as a resource to

24
00:01:07.360 --> 00:01:08.898
the ITProTV Members.

25
00:01:08.898 --> 00:01:12.306
So we're glad to be able to
have him help us out with that,

26
00:01:12.306 --> 00:01:14.722
as well as the exchange show that he did.

27
00:01:14.722 --> 00:01:17.645
So this is a great place for
us to get started.

28
00:01:17.645 --> 00:01:21.625
>> It really is a good place to get
started, Ronnie, because I've hosted shows

29
00:01:21.625 --> 00:01:25.729
before, when we're looking at a little
bit more higher level skill sets here,

30
00:01:25.729 --> 00:01:27.522
when we are talking about server.

31
00:01:27.522 --> 00:01:30.562
So when you look at the title of
this show, we've got Server 101.

32
00:01:30.562 --> 00:01:34.480
And we really should take a moment
to define and understand, well,

33
00:01:34.480 --> 00:01:35.522
what a server is.

34
00:01:35.522 --> 00:01:39.277
So we think about this concept
of client versus server.

35
00:01:39.277 --> 00:01:44.060
If you wanna go ahead and take a look
at my screen we can see that typically

36
00:01:44.060 --> 00:01:49.111
a server is going to be a machine offering
some type of service to a network.

37
00:01:49.111 --> 00:01:53.618
Whereas end users, here we've got laptops,
desktops, tablets,

38
00:01:53.618 --> 00:01:56.194
all sorts of mobile devices nowadays.

39
00:01:56.194 --> 00:02:00.955
But the operating systems and the machines
that the end users are interacting with

40
00:02:00.955 --> 00:02:04.269
directly, those are gonna be
your client side systems.

41
00:02:04.269 --> 00:02:07.981
So this show is really gonna
be focusing about our servers.

42
00:02:07.981 --> 00:02:12.109
And if you take a look at this diagram,
this chart over here on the right.

43
00:02:12.109 --> 00:02:16.141
And so we were just talking about this
show does map to Brian's book, and you

44
00:02:16.141 --> 00:02:20.567
guys have access to that, so if you wanna
follow along this will be perfect for you.

45
00:02:20.567 --> 00:02:24.919
And here we just see a couple of
different things such as multiple,

46
00:02:24.919 --> 00:02:27.650
physical components like CPUs, right?

47
00:02:27.650 --> 00:02:33.687
In our normal systems, the end user client
systems, we typically just have one CPU.

48
00:02:33.687 --> 00:02:38.307
Some people out there, hobbyists, they
might have more, but on the server side of

49
00:02:38.307 --> 00:02:42.007
things it's rare that we would ever
see a server with just one CPU.

50
00:02:42.007 --> 00:02:45.932
Because when we're talking about
working in a production environment we

51
00:02:45.932 --> 00:02:48.855
really can't risk having
any kind of downtime there.

52
00:02:48.855 --> 00:02:52.226
So hardware,
we're always gonna see redundancies.

53
00:02:52.226 --> 00:02:57.463
When we look at ECC memory, this is even
another example of the type of redundancy

54
00:02:57.463 --> 00:03:02.562
by utilizing memory that has integrated or
built-in error correcting code.

55
00:03:02.562 --> 00:03:06.124
It's gonna be more expensive so
we typically don't see that on our

56
00:03:06.124 --> 00:03:09.314
client-side systems, but
servers, it's the way to go.

57
00:03:09.314 --> 00:03:12.684
Now, when we talk about optimized for
applications and

58
00:03:12.684 --> 00:03:15.120
then you think about the little games and

59
00:03:15.120 --> 00:03:19.149
maybe shopping apps that you may
use on your iPad, or your laptop.

60
00:03:19.149 --> 00:03:23.212
Our client-side systems really
are optimized for applications, and

61
00:03:23.212 --> 00:03:27.693
then the work environment you may have
line of business applications as well.

62
00:03:27.693 --> 00:03:30.256
But servers kind of have
a different stance or

63
00:03:30.256 --> 00:03:34.168
outlook on things because you don't
wanna have all that frivolous or

64
00:03:34.168 --> 00:03:37.687
unnecessary components,
software running on your system.

65
00:03:37.687 --> 00:03:41.636
We'll take a look a little bit later
about how security affects servers, but

66
00:03:41.636 --> 00:03:45.646
we really wanna harden them and really
keep them as streamlined as possible for

67
00:03:45.646 --> 00:03:47.607
security and performance purposes.

68
00:03:47.607 --> 00:03:51.095
And then lastly,
wait we've got two more things here.

69
00:03:51.095 --> 00:03:53.261
Optimize for background services.

70
00:03:53.261 --> 00:03:57.080
So, client computers, yes there
are a lot of services that run in

71
00:03:57.080 --> 00:04:02.018
client-side computers, but servers really
have a lot going on behind the scenes.

72
00:04:02.018 --> 00:04:05.876
And as we continue through this series,
we'll take a look at how we can install

73
00:04:05.876 --> 00:04:09.570
roles and features, and we'll take
a look at those supporting services.

74
00:04:09.570 --> 00:04:14.306
And lastly on our chart here
we have hardware redundancies.

75
00:04:14.306 --> 00:04:17.783
That kind of goes with the first one like
I spoke about with the CPUs because you

76
00:04:17.783 --> 00:04:19.347
know you're looking at servers.

77
00:04:19.347 --> 00:04:22.373
You wanna have multiple
network interface cards,

78
00:04:22.373 --> 00:04:24.845
you wanna have multiple power supplies.

79
00:04:24.845 --> 00:04:29.192
Whereas we really don't see that on the
client desktop side of things, laptops or

80
00:04:29.192 --> 00:04:30.526
whatever we have there.

81
00:04:30.526 --> 00:04:33.152
So that's just kind of
a brief description, and

82
00:04:33.152 --> 00:04:36.813
knowing the difference between
client-side versus server side.

83
00:04:36.813 --> 00:04:40.378
>> Now, Cherokee, that makes a lot of
sense, when we really get started in

84
00:04:40.378 --> 00:04:43.138
trying to differentiate
between a client and a server.

85
00:04:43.138 --> 00:04:46.874
What we're looking for, in server
knowledge of course is that ability to

86
00:04:46.874 --> 00:04:49.766
say hey, servers are really
designed to handle, well,

87
00:04:49.766 --> 00:04:52.175
more than just one human
interaction at a time,

88
00:04:52.175 --> 00:04:55.693
whereas we're normally sitting
behind the client desktop as well.

89
00:04:55.693 --> 00:04:59.905
So being able to provide redundancies,
being able to actually have the power that

90
00:04:59.905 --> 00:05:04.178
we're talking about and things operating
the background really lend itself to not

91
00:05:04.178 --> 00:05:07.191
really being optimized for
that individual user so much.

92
00:05:07.191 --> 00:05:11.432
But as much as actually being able to
configure that one machine, get it up and

93
00:05:11.432 --> 00:05:15.234
operating, and then letting it do
the job that it really needs to do.

94
00:05:15.234 --> 00:05:17.229
So Cherokee,
where are we gonna go from here?

95
00:05:17.229 --> 00:05:20.397
>> So Ronnie, I thought we would start
at the beginning with an installation.

96
00:05:20.397 --> 00:05:24.180
So, what I have access to, and
if we take a look at my screen right here,

97
00:05:24.180 --> 00:05:25.896
you have access to this as well.

98
00:05:25.896 --> 00:05:27.266
This is gonna be our practice labs.

99
00:05:27.266 --> 00:05:31.405
Now, Brian has done a really great job
of integrating labs throughout his book.

100
00:05:31.405 --> 00:05:35.277
But you guys also have your practice
labs available to you as well.

101
00:05:35.277 --> 00:05:40.070
So what we're gonna do Instead of me
having a server sitting here on the desk,

102
00:05:40.070 --> 00:05:42.432
we're gonna be utilizing Hyper-V,

103
00:05:42.432 --> 00:05:46.446
a virtualization technology to
emulate an installation here.

104
00:05:46.446 --> 00:05:48.394
So we're looking at Server Manager here.

105
00:05:48.394 --> 00:05:53.176
And if I go down to the drop-down menu and
select Tools, and over here,

106
00:05:53.176 --> 00:05:57.657
if I can kind of zoom in for you,
you're gonna see HyperV Manager.

107
00:05:57.657 --> 00:06:03.609
And what we'll be doing,
if I can get it over there, all right.

108
00:06:03.609 --> 00:06:07.475
What we're gonna be doing is
selecting HyperV Manager,

109
00:06:07.475 --> 00:06:11.107
again just to emulate
a physical installation here.

110
00:06:11.107 --> 00:06:13.443
So we'll pull that up.

111
00:06:13.443 --> 00:06:18.099
I'm going to select the machine that
I want from the list of available

112
00:06:18.099 --> 00:06:22.851
virtual machines that have been
prestaged within this environment.

113
00:06:22.851 --> 00:06:28.710
So, this machine right here, PALBSA02,
if I can zoom in a little bit for

114
00:06:28.710 --> 00:06:32.899
you we just right-click,

ahead and start to get going here.

00:20:02.415 --> 00:20:06.022
And like I said, NANO install is
gonna be a little bit different, so

343
00:20:06.022 --> 00:20:08.690
there is specific documentation for that.

344
00:20:08.690 --> 00:20:11.490
>> All right, so Cherokee,
now that we've got a lot of information,

345
00:20:11.490 --> 00:20:13.430
what are you gonna show us here?

346
00:20:13.430 --> 00:20:16.720
>> Okay, so Ronnie I did want to
show you something specifically

347
00:20:16.720 --> 00:20:18.560
that Brian had called out in the book.

348
00:20:18.560 --> 00:20:20.220
If we take a look at my machine.

349
00:20:20.220 --> 00:20:24.290
We can expand upon the concept
on memory a little bit further.

350
00:20:24.290 --> 00:20:27.964
So I'm just gonna select one of
these pre-staged virtual machines,

351
00:20:27.964 --> 00:20:30.630
right-click and select Settings.

352
00:20:30.630 --> 00:20:34.010
So if you're not familiar with
a virtual environment and

353
00:20:34.010 --> 00:20:38.330
using Hyper-V,
I just wanted to show you something here.

354
00:20:38.330 --> 00:20:43.210
Now what we're looking at this is
an example of where I would go

355
00:20:43.210 --> 00:20:48.190
to allocate my hardware resources
to my individual virtual machines.

356
00:20:48.190 --> 00:20:51.352
So let's take a look here at memory,
because Brian specifically calls out

357
00:20:51.352 --> 00:20:53.674
different types of memory
which is important to know.

358
00:20:53.674 --> 00:21:00.385
So I can specify a specific amount of
RAM noted here, all right, in megabytes.

359
00:21:00.385 --> 00:21:05.249
So we've got about 1.5 GB of RAM allocated
to this particular machine here.

360
00:21:05.249 --> 00:21:09.780
If I enable dynamic memory which is
a cool feature, I can go ahead and

361
00:21:09.780 --> 00:21:13.436
set the minimum amount of RMA
versus the maximum amount

362
00:21:13.436 --> 00:21:18.390
of RAM that I will allow this virtual
machine at any given time to utilize.

363
00:21:18.390 --> 00:21:22.090
It has to fall within that upper and
lower control limits there.

364
00:21:22.090 --> 00:21:25.220
So here I set my minimum at 512.

365
00:21:25.220 --> 00:21:27.050
And if you recall a few seconds ago,

366
00:21:27.050 --> 00:21:31.198
when we looked at the website to the
system requirements provided by Microsoft,

367
00:21:31.198 --> 00:21:34.138
they said, look these are your
absolute minimums here.

368
00:21:34.138 --> 00:21:36.580
So we really don't wanna
deviate from that.

369
00:21:36.580 --> 00:21:39.490
We need to at least have
those minimums there.

370
00:21:39.490 --> 00:21:44.530
And maximum RAM, if your system
could support it, then go for it.

371
00:21:44.530 --> 00:21:47.910
But there is also something else
to consider, because you may have,

372
00:21:47.910 --> 00:21:50.950
like I have here,
multiple virtual machines running.

373
00:21:50.950 --> 00:21:54.890
So you could also set a memory wait here.

374
00:21:54.890 --> 00:22:01.210
So over to the left is going to give
a lower priority to this virtual machine.

375
00:22:01.210 --> 00:22:04.000
However if I slide this scale
all the way to the right,

376
00:22:04.000 --> 00:22:08.330
it's gonna set this machine with a higher
priority, which means if there is

377
00:22:08.330 --> 00:22:12.920
additional memory available, then it's
gonna be giving it to this machine first.

378
00:22:12.920 --> 00:22:17.110
And also we see the memory
buffer is gonna be set at 20%,

379
00:22:17.110 --> 00:22:20.880
and you also wanna keep in
mind paging files there.

380
00:22:22.000 --> 00:22:24.650
Which we'll probably talk about
a little bit more when we dive

381
00:22:24.650 --> 00:22:26.460
deeper into our hardware components.

382
00:22:26.460 --> 00:22:29.870
But I think for now, this is a good start
when we start thinking about hardware.

383
00:22:29.870 --> 00:22:33.150
And we'll need to kind of take a shift and
look at software.

384
00:22:33.150 --> 00:22:35.090
But I do think we are out of time.

385
00:22:36.190 --> 00:22:37.010
>> All right.

386
00:22:37.010 --> 00:22:42.060
Well thank you again Cherokee, for
helping us to take a peek into Windows and

387
00:22:42.060 --> 00:22:43.940
showing us the beginning
of the installation.

388
00:22:43.940 --> 00:22:46.990
We'll see that of course in
a part two as we continue on

389
00:22:46.990 --> 00:22:49.740
with this peek into Windows,
but Cherokee's right.

390
00:22:49.740 --> 00:22:52.420
This is a great place for
us to take the time to sign off.

391
00:22:52.420 --> 00:22:55.898
So for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong

392
00:22:55.898 --> 00:22:56.943
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

393
00:22:56.943 --> 00:23:00.206
>> Stay tune for more Server 101

394
00:23:00.206 --> 00:23:06.823
[MUSIC]

395
00:23:06.823 --> 00:23:10.026
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee take a look at the software side of Windows Server.  The break down of the operating system is described by Cherokee.   The team briefly differentiates between physical and virtual servers as well as workgroups vs. domains..   Cherokee introduces the basics of how Window Server is secured.  They discuss briefly the nature of Windows Server in the cloud.  Lastly, Cherokee previews some of the other networking topics Server Admins will need to be familiar with as they work with Windows Servers.
episodes.title: A Peek into Windows Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:06.285
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.285 --> 00:00:08.250
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.250 --> 00:00:12.660
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.660 --> 00:00:15.290
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.290 --> 00:00:19.010
You're watching the Windows
server 101 show.

6
00:00:19.010 --> 00:00:22.960
>> I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
we're taking a look at a peek into Windows

7
00:00:22.960 --> 00:00:25.950
part two, where we're about to
talk about some of the software.

8
00:00:25.950 --> 00:00:29.260
We've already covered some of
the hardware side inside of the part one.

9
00:00:29.260 --> 00:00:33.050
Now, we're actually gonna take a look
at the other side here with Ms.

10
00:00:33.050 --> 00:00:33.920
Cherokee Boose.

11
00:00:33.920 --> 00:00:35.190
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:35.190 --> 00:00:36.310
>> Thanks for having me, Ronnie.

13
00:00:36.310 --> 00:00:39.250
Yeah, we definitely took a look at
our different types of hardware.

14
00:00:39.250 --> 00:00:43.780
And so we're now kind of taking a shift
and we'll be looking at software.

15
00:00:43.780 --> 00:00:47.220
So, software's going to be
the coding aspect of it.

16
00:00:47.220 --> 00:00:50.680
So the first thing I wanna talk
about is going to be the kernel, and

17
00:00:50.680 --> 00:00:54.350
the kernel is the low level portion of
the operating system that really keeps

18
00:00:54.350 --> 00:00:56.038
Windows running behind the scenes.

19
00:00:56.038 --> 00:01:00.210
So we talk about our hardware abstraction
layer, we'll be talking about drivers.

20
00:01:00.210 --> 00:01:03.380
But just knowing that we're starting
there at that low level and

21
00:01:03.380 --> 00:01:06.030
then we'll be talking about other
supporting components as well.

22
00:01:07.170 --> 00:01:09.898
The next thing he wants us to
call out is system processes.

23
00:01:09.898 --> 00:01:12.190
So there are certain
processes that the system,

24
00:01:12.190 --> 00:01:15.850
the operating system, needs in order
to stay functioning and running.

25
00:01:15.850 --> 00:01:20.720
So a lot of times we'll see different
components of the operating system

26
00:01:20.720 --> 00:01:23.070
hidden so that someone doesn't
accidentally delete them or

27
00:01:23.070 --> 00:01:26.890
modify them and
corrupt them in any kind of way.

28
00:01:26.890 --> 00:01:29.190
And we also want to take
a look at services.

29
00:01:29.190 --> 00:01:33.820
Just like with your client side systems,
your servers have services as well.

30
00:01:33.820 --> 00:01:35.760
So if we can take a look
at my screen real quick,

31
00:01:35.760 --> 00:01:39.080
I'd like to show you a shortcut,
or quick way just to go ahead.

32
00:01:39.080 --> 00:01:42.920
And if you utilize your run command,
and you could also, if you're in

33
00:01:42.920 --> 00:01:46.660
front of a system with a keyboard there,
use your Windows-r shortcut.

34
00:01:46.660 --> 00:01:49.120
But because I'm working in this virtual
environment, I'm going to go ahead and

35
00:01:49.120 --> 00:01:53.990
select run, and
then just type in services.msc.

36
00:01:53.990 --> 00:01:56.060
Well, look, it's already in there.

37
00:01:56.060 --> 00:02:01.560
And if I can navigate for you guys,
you can see that it's in the Run line,

38
00:02:01.560 --> 00:02:06.590
we'll hit Enter and this'll bring up
our services page, our Services window.

39
00:02:06.590 --> 00:02:09.100
Quite a lot of different
services we have going on here,

40
00:02:09.100 --> 00:02:11.269
if I can zoom out a little bit for you.

41
00:02:13.180 --> 00:02:14.140
Oops, other way.

42
00:02:15.190 --> 00:02:18.510
And let's see, move it around.

43
00:02:18.510 --> 00:02:21.220
This is also going to be
where you would wanna go and

44
00:02:21.220 --> 00:02:24.150
see which services are running,
because in this column right here,

45
00:02:24.150 --> 00:02:27.120
we can see the actual status of
the services, running or not.

46
00:02:27.120 --> 00:02:31.830
You do wanna check to make sure before
you just, we don't recommend randomly or

47
00:02:31.830 --> 00:02:35.630
haphazardly stopping and restarting
a service because you have different

48
00:02:35.630 --> 00:02:39.420
applications and different components
that rely on these services.

49
00:02:39.420 --> 00:02:43.580
Sometimes they'll stop or stop
functioning, and you may need to stop and

50
00:02:43.580 --> 00:02:44.750
restart them.

51
00:02:44.750 --> 00:02:48.860
And you just simply right-click, and
this one's selected as disabled.

52
00:02:48.860 --> 00:02:51.450
But in this portion right here,
you can see that it's grayed out.

53
00:02:51.450 --> 00:02:54.050
You would simply just select start or
stop.

54
00:02:54.050 --> 00:02:56.020
You can pause and resume.

55
00:02:56.020 --> 00:03:00.500
But that's going to be the portion there
where we take a look at our services.

56
00:03:00.500 --> 00:03:03.210
A couple other things that we need to
mention when we're talking about our

57
00:03:03.210 --> 00:03:05.780
software would be our applications.

58
00:03:05.780 --> 00:03:09.760
Now it's kind of interesting,
when I first started working in IT,

59
00:03:09.760 --> 00:03:12.850
we always called software
programs programs.

60
00:03:12.850 --> 00:03:16.240
And a lot of days now you'll hear
this term applications, apps.

61
00:03:16.240 --> 00:03:20.790
So applications are gonna be any kind of
piece of software that are servicing,

62
00:03:20.790 --> 00:03:23.970
usually third party, but
applications can also be integrated.

63
00:03:23.970 --> 00:03:25.261
You got a Windows store and

64
00:03:25.261 --> 00:03:28.702
different various resources in
which you can obtain applications.

65
00:03:28.702 --> 00:03:30.106
Firmware.

66
00:03:30.106 --> 00:03:35.164
Firmware is kind of a funny one because
firmware is in between hardware and

67
00:03:35.164 --> 00:03:35.770
software.

68
00:03:35.770 --> 00:03:38.770
It's almost like a translator,
if you will, between the two.

69
00:03:38.770 --> 00:03:41.710
So, your firmware is telling

70
00:03:41.710 --> 00:03:45.500
the operating system how to communicate
with your hardware and visa-versa.

71
00:03:45.500 --> 00:03:48.390
So your firmware can be up to date,
your manufacturers for

72
00:03:48.390 --> 00:03:52.140
your hardware equipments can release
firmware updates, and it's a good idea to

73
00:03:52.140 --> 00:03:57.390
keep those up to date because they're
normally gonna be releasing updates to

74
00:03:57.390 --> 00:04:02.830
overcome any kind of security breaches or
any bug fixes that they may have.

75
00:04:02.830 --> 00:04:05.930
And another thing we need to
consider is going to be drivers.

76
00:04:05.930 --> 00:04:11.245
So, if you're working on
a client side system,

77
00:04:11.245 --> 00:04:15.325
you have the option of running a 32-bit or
64-bit operating system.

78
00:04:15.325 --> 00:04:19.685
So when we look at our sever operating
systems, those are all gonna 64-bit.

79
00:04:19.685 --> 00:04:24.590
However, keep in mind there may be
some situations in your environment

80
00:04:24.590 --> 00:04:29.750
where you are servicing drivers to
clients on 32-bit operating systems.

81
00:04:29.750 --> 00:04:32.190
For instance,
if you have a print server set up,

82
00:04:32.190 --> 00:04:36.920
you may need to consider installing
32-bit drivers on that print server.

83
00:04:36.920 --> 00:04:40.010
So you just kinda have to modify or

84
00:04:40.010 --> 00:04:44.500
change the way that you think whenever
you're setting up an entire network or

85
00:04:44.500 --> 00:04:49.075
servers to these servers and you are not
just dealing with just one client here.

86
00:04:49.075 --> 00:04:50.240
So, keep that in mind as well.

87
00:04:51.745 --> 00:04:54.375
All right, Ronnie, so what are we
gonna take a look at next here?

88
00:04:54.375 --> 00:04:58.165
We've got physical servers
versus virtual servers.

89
00:04:58.165 --> 00:05:02.605
In the last episode, we were playing
around with Hyper-V, a little bit.

90
00:05:02.605 --> 00:05:06.030
But this is, really,
I don't even want to use the term trend,

91
00:05:06.030 --> 00:05:10.350
but I would say the shift in the way
that computing is headed nowadays.

92
00:05:10.350 --> 00:05:13.370
In the past,
we think about our servers, and

93
00:05:13.370 --> 00:05:17.980
they were just these either rack mounted
or boxes, custom builds, and you would

94
00:05:17.980 --> 00:05:21.930
have your physical magnetics spindle
drives that you would insert into them.

95
00:05:21.930 --> 00:05:26.560
Add all that hardware, and really,
if we're talking about dedicated server,

96
00:05:26.560 --> 00:05:27.740
you might have a box for DHCP.

97
00:05:27.740 --> 00:05:30.210
You might have a box for DNS.

98
00:05:30.210 --> 00:05:32.010
But nowadays, we see a big shift.

99
00:05:32.010 --> 00:05:33.490
We see a lot of virtualization.

100
00:05:33.490 --> 00:05:35.820
And what do we get with virtualization?

101
00:05:35.820 --> 00:05:38.280
We get a more secure system.

102
00:05:38.280 --> 00:05:44.360
Less coding means less chances for
an attacker to break into that coding or

103
00:05:44.360 --> 00:05:48.272
to expose or take advantage of any
vulnerabilities or weaknesses.

104
00:05:49.570 --> 00:05:53.510
Instead of having five different boxes
sitting here in a server closet,

105
00:05:53.510 --> 00:05:54.610
I may only have one.

106
00:05:54.610 --> 00:05:58.240
So I only, I have less amount
of power consumption, so

107
00:05:58.240 --> 00:06:03.540
that's going to be more cost effective for
my organization.

108
00:06:03.540 --> 00:06:08.140
And if we think about places like New
York City where the rent is astronomical,

109
00:06:08.140 --> 00:06:12.280
I may also really consider
the physical cost reduction as well.

110
00:06:12.280 --> 00:06:16.720
So virtualization is definitely
the way we're heading,

111
00:06:16.720 --> 00:06:21.895
and we don't really focus too
much on this particular show.

112
00:06:21.895 --> 00:06:23.645
But if you are gonna be
working with server,

113
00:06:23.645 --> 00:06:26.950
then you definitely wanna get
acclimated with that in the future.

114
00:06:26.950 --> 00:06:30.615
>> And the key component here when we deal
with server, right, is to realize that

115
00:06:30.615 --> 00:06:34.335
you're gonna run into both if you're
not really experienced with either one.

116
00:06:34.335 --> 00:06:37.775
You're gonna find inside of a shop or
wherever you end up working,

117
00:06:37.775 --> 00:06:41.215
there will be physical machines that
will end up running Windows Server,

118
00:06:41.215 --> 00:06:44.720
which is great and
that works the way that we want it to.

119
00:06:44.720 --> 00:06:48.953
But also, within those servers themselves,
you may find that there is gonna be

120
00:06:48.953 --> 00:06:53.519
another component that's gonna allow you
to create virtual servers in them as well.

121
00:06:53.519 --> 00:06:56.183
And that means it's gonna
all be done in software.

122
00:06:56.183 --> 00:07:00.592
So, servers are not only physical devices
that are running one operating system.

123
00:07:00.592 --> 00:07:03.976
They can be physical devices
running a piece of software which

124
00:07:03.976 --> 00:07:07.790
is running multiple operating
systems on top of them as well.

125
00:07:07.790 --> 00:07:10.820
And you're gonna see any one of
those different environments

126
00:07:10.820 --> 00:07:12.140
wherever you end up working.

127
00:07:12.140 --> 00:07:13.560
The virtualization, of course,

128
00:07:13.560 --> 00:07:17.990
has become more popular because
it save companies money overall.

129
00:07:17.990 --> 00:07:23.780
When I can run five or six, or
10 servers, on one big super solid,

130
00:07:23.780 --> 00:07:27.810
high performance hardware, rather than
just buying that super high performance

131
00:07:27.810 --> 00:07:31.766
machine and saying, well, I can only
run one of these operating systems, and

132
00:07:31.766 --> 00:07:33.370
I can only do so much with it.

133
00:07:33.370 --> 00:07:35.460
So it brings up what we
call high optimization,

134
00:07:35.460 --> 00:07:38.730
that's kind of a key element
that you're gonna run into.

135
00:07:38.730 --> 00:07:43.450
Now, before we move on from
the idea of software here,

136
00:07:43.450 --> 00:07:48.094
we also need to talk about some management
perspectives of server as well.

137
00:07:48.094 --> 00:07:51.720
So, Cherokee, talk to us about
the difference between what we call

138
00:07:51.720 --> 00:07:54.070
a domain versus a work group environment.

139
00:07:54.070 --> 00:07:58.016
>> Sure, so if we take a look at my screen
here, I actually have a diagram and

140
00:07:58.016 --> 00:07:59.716
we can kind of compare the two.

141
00:07:59.716 --> 00:08:01.324
So Workgroup.

142
00:08:01.324 --> 00:08:07.212
Workgroup is going to be a feature that
Microsoft provides that will allow,

143
00:08:07.212 --> 00:08:10.460
I guess it's less complicated to setup.

144
00:08:10.460 --> 00:08:12.730
It's really for a smaller environment.

145
00:08:12.730 --> 00:08:16.807
You don't wanna be using this, I wouldn't
say more than ten users setup for

146
00:08:16.807 --> 00:08:17.630
workgroup.

147
00:08:17.630 --> 00:08:20.360
And all of those users have
to be on the same network,

148
00:08:20.360 --> 00:08:24.640
whereas domains are gonna be created for
larger enterprise environment,

149
00:08:24.640 --> 00:08:29.260
you do not have to be on the same network
to be joined to a particular domain.

150
00:08:29.260 --> 00:08:33.830
And Microsoft does a really
great job of organizing things.

151
00:08:33.830 --> 00:08:37.810
So if you think about a way
you can organize a company,

152
00:08:37.810 --> 00:08:40.340
then domains would be
a great way to do that.

153
00:08:40.340 --> 00:08:45.770
So there is one concept that is a little
bit more holistic than a domain and

154
00:08:45.770 --> 00:08:47.530
that would be a forest.

155
00:08:47.530 --> 00:08:50.540
So that would be all encompassing.

156
00:08:50.540 --> 00:08:53.040
You can have multiple domains
within your forest, but

157
00:08:53.040 --> 00:08:57.020
they're all related in some particular
way, which is great, like Ronnie says,

158
00:08:57.020 --> 00:09:02.180
for management, because it can
simplify and really just help

159
00:09:02.180 --> 00:09:07.110
me understand logically how I'm
managing my particular organizations.

160
00:09:07.110 --> 00:09:09.940
So, if we take a look here at number one,

161
00:09:09.940 --> 00:09:12.500
the computers can be located
on different networks.

162
00:09:12.500 --> 00:09:15.430
In the workgroup, no, domain based, yes.

163
00:09:15.430 --> 00:09:17.320
Computers are centrally managed.

164
00:09:17.320 --> 00:09:20.136
Like we spoke about, yeah,
it's gonna make my job a lot easier,

165
00:09:20.136 --> 00:09:21.120
your job a lot easier.

166
00:09:21.120 --> 00:09:25.770
I can manually manage them
in one central location.

167
00:09:25.770 --> 00:09:27.270
Valid for many servers?

168
00:09:27.270 --> 00:09:29.090
No, not when we're
talking about workgroups.

169
00:09:29.090 --> 00:09:31.595

00:22:06.690 --> 00:22:14.290
And 99.999 equates to like what,
5.05 seconds of down time, annually?

398
00:22:14.290 --> 00:22:16.243
So that's not a lot of wiggle room.

399
00:22:16.243 --> 00:22:21.145
And so we want to have multiple
redundancies in place so that

400
00:22:21.145 --> 00:22:25.835
if something were to fail, we've always
thought about a plan B, if you will.

401
00:22:25.835 --> 00:22:30.085
So that we can maintain that
continuity for our organizations.

402
00:22:30.085 --> 00:22:34.760
So earlier, in the previous episode,
we started an installation.

403
00:22:34.760 --> 00:22:37.590
I do wanna check on that before
we head out for this show.

404
00:22:37.590 --> 00:22:38.470
So if we could, please,

405
00:22:38.470 --> 00:22:42.050
jump to my screen and let's just
take a look at that Virtual Machine.

406
00:22:42.050 --> 00:22:45.692
I believe that one was
going to be PLABSA01.

407
00:22:45.692 --> 00:22:50.796
And we'll just go ahead and
relaunch that system.

408
00:22:50.796 --> 00:22:54.178
Now that installation has
completed successfully, but

409
00:22:54.178 --> 00:22:57.270
there are a few things
that we do need to do.

410
00:22:57.270 --> 00:23:01.140
So for the administrator name, we need
to go ahead and type in a password.

411
00:23:01.140 --> 00:23:05.950
And for the sake of this show,
I'll use my top secret password here.

412
00:23:05.950 --> 00:23:08.014
Hopefully, it's the same, and,

413
00:23:12.178 --> 00:23:16.350
You don't wanna do as we say,
you wanna [LAUGH].

414
00:23:16.350 --> 00:23:19.171
Or don't do as we do,
do as we say when it comes to passwords.

415
00:23:19.171 --> 00:23:21.140
And if you've taken any CompTIA classes,

416
00:23:21.140 --> 00:23:25.670
then I'm sure you've been reminded of
that and how to create secure passwords.

417
00:23:25.670 --> 00:23:29.800
In the next episode, we'll also talk
about naming your computers and

418
00:23:29.800 --> 00:23:32.150
creating a logical naming convention.

419
00:23:32.150 --> 00:23:35.535
But really, that's it for
this particular system here,

420
00:23:35.535 --> 00:23:38.168
because I'm in a virtual environment here.

421
00:23:38.168 --> 00:23:42.145
This is our little Alt+Ctrl+Delete button,
and you guys will get familiar with that

422
00:23:42.145 --> 00:23:44.269
if you are logging in to
your lab environment or

423
00:23:44.269 --> 00:23:46.250
working with virtualization.

424
00:23:46.250 --> 00:23:47.900
But Ronnie, I think that's about it.

425
00:23:47.900 --> 00:23:52.180
A good starting point for
us to go ahead and call it a show.

426
00:23:52.180 --> 00:23:54.499
>> Yeah,
even that last screen that you showed us,

427
00:23:54.499 --> 00:23:57.620
the idea of connecting to the cloud
a little bit, is kind of neat.

428
00:23:57.620 --> 00:24:00.480
Where you see it's kind of painting in and
doing all of that.

429
00:24:00.480 --> 00:24:02.810
A lot has to do with latency that
we're talking about, as well.

430
00:24:02.810 --> 00:24:04.890
It may take a little bit longer time for

431
00:24:04.890 --> 00:24:07.300
things to finish before we realize it,
too.

432
00:24:07.300 --> 00:24:11.130
But that's a good peek into,
of course, what Windows Server,

433
00:24:11.130 --> 00:24:13.220
if you don't have a lot
of experience in it.

434
00:24:13.220 --> 00:24:18.420
Where we did take a look at some of the
software requirements that are out there.

435
00:24:18.420 --> 00:24:20.250
And some of the ways that
software does break down

436
00:24:20.250 --> 00:24:21.860
what we talked about the kernel.

437
00:24:21.860 --> 00:24:25.990
Some of the different services as well as
security elements that we need to address.

438
00:24:25.990 --> 00:24:30.440
And even a look into the future of
what this show is gonna bring us.

439
00:24:30.440 --> 00:24:34.210
To help make sure that we understand from
the server adminstration side, right?

440
00:24:34.210 --> 00:24:37.692
From the managing as well as
the maintenance type of things that

441
00:24:37.692 --> 00:24:40.040
we're expected to be able to do.

442
00:24:40.040 --> 00:24:44.330
But Cherokee's right, it is a great place
for us to also go ahead and sign off then.

443
00:24:44.330 --> 00:24:46.822
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Ronnie Wong.

444
00:24:46.822 --> 00:24:48.281
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

445
00:24:48.281 --> 00:24:51.036
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Windows Server 101 shows

446
00:24:51.036 --> 00:24:59.267
[MUSIC]

447
00:24:59.267 --> 00:25:06.600
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce the Server Manager in Windows Server.  Cherokee shows what the Server Manager help the System Admin to do for the local computer and multiple computers.  She takes the time to explore the different elements and mention why it’s an important part of the Sys Admin’s management to use.  She demonstrates creating a group and showing some of the different elements can be managed from using the Server Manager.
episodes.title: Introduction to Server Manager
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.880
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.880 --> 00:00:05.165
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.165 --> 00:00:07.507
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.507 --> 00:00:12.295
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:12.295 --> 00:00:15.002
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:15.002 --> 00:00:16.978
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today,

7
00:00:16.978 --> 00:00:19.651
you're watching
the Windows Server 101 show.

8
00:00:19.651 --> 00:00:22.401
We're about to dive in the realm
of the server manager,

9
00:00:22.401 --> 00:00:26.159
something that every system administrator
is gonna have to learn how to do.

10
00:00:26.159 --> 00:00:29.550
And here to help us out is gonna be Ms.
Cherokee Boose.

11
00:00:29.550 --> 00:00:30.790
Cherokee welcome to the show.

12
00:00:30.790 --> 00:00:31.960
>> Thanks for having me Ronnie.

13
00:00:31.960 --> 00:00:34.980
Yeah, so server manager is
going to be your one stop shop.

14
00:00:34.980 --> 00:00:39.040
It's a very easy place, in order to
provide that centralized management.

15
00:00:39.040 --> 00:00:42.410
We can even manage servers remotely,
by using Server Manager so

16
00:00:42.410 --> 00:00:43.470
this is pretty cool.

17
00:00:43.470 --> 00:00:46.840
Let's go ahead and get acclimated,
if you take a look at my screen, just so

18
00:00:46.840 --> 00:00:48.940
we can get familiar with the layout here.

19
00:00:48.940 --> 00:00:52.668
So by default Server Manager is
going to pop-up automatically,

20
00:00:52.668 --> 00:00:56.869
if that's something you don't want to
happen then you can also go head and

21
00:00:56.869 --> 00:01:00.821
change that under manage,
over here on the top right-hand corner.

22
00:01:00.821 --> 00:01:03.468
And if you go under
Server Manager Properties,

23
00:01:03.468 --> 00:01:06.857
you really have the ability to
customize your environment.

24
00:01:06.857 --> 00:01:10.327
If you don't want it to come up again,
you would just go ahead and

25
00:01:10.327 --> 00:01:13.380
select that, but
I'm gonna hit Cancel for now.

26
00:01:13.380 --> 00:01:15.940
So what are some things you
can do with Server Manager?

27
00:01:15.940 --> 00:01:20.440
Well, you can provide that
centralized management, but

28
00:01:20.440 --> 00:01:23.080
you can also configure your
local machine as well.

29
00:01:23.080 --> 00:01:25.560
So that's kind of what we're looking at

30
00:01:25.560 --> 00:01:28.840
here with this first button to
configure this local server.

31
00:01:28.840 --> 00:01:32.890
You can also add roles and features which
is going to be a significant portion of

32
00:01:32.890 --> 00:01:35.060
what you do as a server admin.

33
00:01:35.060 --> 00:01:37.570
So we dedicated an entire show for that.

34
00:01:37.570 --> 00:01:40.570
We won't really talk about
that too much in this episode.

35
00:01:41.650 --> 00:01:44.290
Now, another thing add
servers to manage and

36
00:01:44.290 --> 00:01:48.130
in the previous episode I mentioned how
Microsoft does a really great job at

37
00:01:48.130 --> 00:01:53.600
allowing you to logically
organize your environments.

38
00:01:53.600 --> 00:01:58.270
So by providing they build
to add other servers,

39
00:01:58.270 --> 00:02:02.390
we don't want just add them, and
add them to this main dashboard view here.

40
00:02:02.390 --> 00:02:07.500
We can even create groups to
help minimize that influx of

41
00:02:07.500 --> 00:02:12.770
notifications that we may see with
all of them in this front page here.

42
00:02:12.770 --> 00:02:15.960
So we have the ability to
also create server groups.

43
00:02:15.960 --> 00:02:18.760
And so we'll talk about why
we would want to do that and

44
00:02:18.760 --> 00:02:22.070
how we really should
logically approach it because

45
00:02:22.070 --> 00:02:25.770
you wanna make sure that not only you
understand it, but people that you're

46
00:02:25.770 --> 00:02:30.990
working with within your environment
understand your concepts as well.

47
00:02:30.990 --> 00:02:34.070
You also have the ability to
connect to Cloud services,

48
00:02:34.070 --> 00:02:36.580
like we mentioned in
the previous show as well.

49
00:02:36.580 --> 00:02:40.010
So what we wanna start with first is this
view that we're looking at right here.

50
00:02:40.010 --> 00:02:42.340
This is going to be our dashboard.

51
00:02:42.340 --> 00:02:45.930
And like I said, you can go ahead and
disable this if you need to.

52
00:02:45.930 --> 00:02:49.700
But over on the left-hand side, actually
let's just take a look here first.

53
00:02:49.700 --> 00:02:52.210
What you originally see, right?

54
00:02:52.210 --> 00:02:53.810
You see information.

55
00:02:53.810 --> 00:02:57.520
Down here I can see the roles and
services that are already installed.

56
00:02:57.520 --> 00:03:00.120
So this machine that I'm on right now,

57
00:03:00.120 --> 00:03:03.320
have it brought up on, is going to
be at file and storage services,

58
00:03:03.320 --> 00:03:07.760
have already been turned on and
enabled, as well as Hyper-V.

59
00:03:07.760 --> 00:03:08.510
And then here,

60
00:03:08.510 --> 00:03:12.400
any kind of notifications would be
displayed in this portion as well.

61
00:03:13.710 --> 00:03:17.130
They kind of stick with the whole green,
yellow,

62
00:03:17.130 --> 00:03:19.030
red, pretty universal convention as well.

63
00:03:19.030 --> 00:03:22.400
So you could handle and
take care of some minor adjustments and

64
00:03:22.400 --> 00:03:25.000
issues right here from
within the dashboard.

65
00:03:25.000 --> 00:03:27.490
But if we kind of move on
over to the left pane and

66
00:03:27.490 --> 00:03:32.220
click on Local Server, this is where you
can really configure our first machine and

67
00:03:32.220 --> 00:03:35.296
we'll take a look at
the different options here.

68
00:03:35.296 --> 00:03:38.530
So, the first thing and I know I'm
jumping out of order here Ronnie, so

69
00:03:38.530 --> 00:03:41.120
if you're looking at this
I'm just gonna kind of go

70
00:03:41.120 --> 00:03:45.440
down the order of what you see when you're
looking at this particular section.

71
00:03:45.440 --> 00:03:51.407
Now the machine that I'm on if you
notice this name, it's P-L-A-B-D-M 01.

72
00:03:52.490 --> 00:03:55.010
Let's stop and
think about that for a second.

73
00:03:55.010 --> 00:04:00.130
The virtualization lab environment that
I'm using is called practice labs.

74
00:04:00.130 --> 00:04:04.900
So that's where that first portion
P-L-A-B comes in practice lab, okay.

75
00:04:04.900 --> 00:04:06.320
It makes a little sense.

76
00:04:06.320 --> 00:04:08.360
I can understand it,
you can understand it.

77
00:04:08.360 --> 00:04:09.750
Let's move on.

78
00:04:09.750 --> 00:04:12.660
Now actually, this one is DM.

79
00:04:12.660 --> 00:04:17.660
I'm not on a domain controller,
I'm actually on a domain member.

80
00:04:17.660 --> 00:04:21.650
So DC, Domain Controller,
DM, Domain Member.

81
00:04:21.650 --> 00:04:24.920
And then we're also noted a zero one here,
right?

82
00:04:24.920 --> 00:04:28.150
So this would be like,
domain member number one.

83
00:04:28.150 --> 00:04:33.420
In the book, there are actually
a couple of explanations or

84
00:04:33.420 --> 00:04:37.520
examples of how you might want
to go ahead and name a system.

85
00:04:37.520 --> 00:04:39.450
So here we are two different sites.

86
00:04:39.450 --> 00:04:45.060
On the left side, we have San Diego and
on the right side we have New York City.

87
00:04:45.060 --> 00:04:49.230
And by looking at theses
names we have SDDCO1.

88
00:04:49.230 --> 00:04:54.330
So,Ronnie if yo were working at
the same company I was, just by looking

89
00:04:54.330 --> 00:05:00.291
at the particular at the particular name,
what could you extract from that title?

90
00:05:00.291 --> 00:05:02.277
>> SC.

91
00:05:02.277 --> 00:05:04.170
>> SC for the San Diego.
>> SC, some type of server configuration.

92
00:05:04.170 --> 00:05:07.838
>> Well, if it's San Diego, so SD, sorry.

93
00:05:07.838 --> 00:05:09.928
>> SD.
>> I'm sorry SD, that was my fault.

94
00:05:09.928 --> 00:05:10.878
>> I can't really see it that well.

95
00:05:10.878 --> 00:05:12.691
>> Okay, it is tiny.
>> I see it would be San Diego.

96
00:05:12.691 --> 00:05:13.195
>> San Diego, so

97
00:05:13.195 --> 00:05:16.106
you could automatically infer that we're
talking about the San Diego location.

98
00:05:16.106 --> 00:05:17.330
>> Right.

99
00:05:17.330 --> 00:05:19.425
>> And then the next one, DC,
what do you think that one?

100
00:05:19.425 --> 00:05:20.880
>> Domain Controller
>> Domain Controller, right?

101
00:05:20.880 --> 00:05:24.460
And then 01, so
that would be just my numbering scheme.

102
00:05:24.460 --> 00:05:27.000
I could have several domain
controllers if I choose to do so.

103
00:05:27.000 --> 00:05:30.230
I should have that for redundancy there.

104
00:05:30.230 --> 00:05:33.177
And if we look on the other side,
we've got NYC, what do you think?

105
00:05:33.177 --> 00:05:35.287
>> New York City.

106
00:05:35.287 --> 00:05:36.649
>> New York City, and WEB?

107
00:05:36.649 --> 00:05:38.100
>> I'm gonna assume a web server.

108
00:05:38.100 --> 00:05:39.721
>> [LAUGH] Right.

109
00:05:39.721 --> 00:05:41.750
So, it's pretty simple you can understand.

110
00:05:41.750 --> 00:05:45.800
So we've got a web-01, so
that's just an example there.

111
00:05:47.320 --> 00:05:51.870
You really don't wanna deviate too far
from something logical, it's just gonna be

112
00:05:51.870 --> 00:05:55.860
a little confusing and difficult for
others within your environment.

113
00:05:55.860 --> 00:05:59.707
>> Now a lot of times Cherokee if we're
just really getting started with this

114
00:05:59.707 --> 00:06:03.506
the naming convention might not even
be ours to choose from or pick from.

115
00:06:03.506 --> 00:06:04.400
>> Exactly.

116
00:06:04.400 --> 00:06:09.020
>> So the key here right is to be able to
understand whatever naming convention is

117
00:06:09.020 --> 00:06:10.490
put before you.

118
00:06:10.490 --> 00:06:14.790
So whether somebody does it by site and
then what the role of the server is and

119
00:06:14.790 --> 00:06:16.910
what number that particular server is.

120
00:06:16.910 --> 00:06:20.290
That's a great convention and
a lot of people do follow that or

121
00:06:20.290 --> 00:06:23.780
they choose to come up with
wildly speculative names.

122
00:06:23.780 --> 00:06:29.390
I've even see a whole network named after
planets inside of Star Wars before.

123
00:06:29.390 --> 00:06:30.572
So-
>> Interesting.

124
00:06:30.572 --> 00:06:32.719
>> Go figure.
>> I came across dragons before, but

125
00:06:32.719 --> 00:06:36.740
since I'm not too fluent on dragon lingo,
it was difficult for me.

126
00:06:36.740 --> 00:06:39.730
And that's what you really just hopeful
you don't have to encounter really.

127
00:06:39.730 --> 00:06:40.630
So.

128
00:06:40.630 --> 00:06:44.950
>> Your next Dungeons and Dragons
network that you build there Cherokee,

129
00:06:44.950 --> 00:06:46.400
it should be fun.

130
00:06:46.400 --> 00:06:49.420
>> Yeah, and so we are gonna be
talking about DNS a little bit later,

131
00:06:49.420 --> 00:06:52.450
which falls under this portion here for
our domain name.

132
00:06:52.450 --> 00:06:58.160
We wanna keep a logical concept when we're
choosing the names of our domains as well.

133
00:06:59.560 --> 00:07:03.880
For this particular domain,
you can see how it's practicelabs.com.

134
00:07:03.880 --> 00:07:08.980
So in previous episodes we spoke
about work groups versus domains.

135
00:07:08.980 --> 00:07:12.480
This is where you could go ahead and
add a computer to your domain or

136
00:07:12.480 --> 00:07:16.330
add a computer to a work group,
we could remove it from a domain.

137
00:07:16.330 --> 00:07:21.022
Couple of things though, because I am on a
domain member I could easily just come in

138
00:07:21.022 --> 00:07:23.477
and change this computer name right here.

139
00:07:23.477 --> 00:07:29.471
If I'm working on a domain controller for
underpinning technology reasons,

140
00:07:29.471 --> 00:07:34.980
I really don't want to be changing
the name of a domain controller.

141
00:07:34.980 --> 00:07:38.050
So if you are tasked with coming
up with a naming convention,

142
00:07:38.050 --> 00:07:39.600
you wanna kinda think long and
hard about it,

143
00:07:39.600 --> 00:07:42.480
because it's not something you
should be going back and changing.

144
00:07:42.480 --> 00:07:44.960
It's possible, not recommended.

145
00:07:44.960 --> 00:07:50.145
So here, if I wanted to go ahead and
switch from my practice labs domain,

146
00:07:50.145 --> 00:07:54.322
I could go ahead and join a work group,
if I choose to do so.

147
00:07:54.322 --> 00:07:57.095
But let's just step back and
think about that for a minute.

148
00:07:57.095 --> 00:07:58.929
So, I have to have a couple of things.

149
00:07:58.929 --> 00:08:04.179
I have to have administrative capabilities
in order to Join a computer to a domain,

150
00:08:04.179 --> 00:08:08.280
I have to have domain admin rights and
same goes for the inverse.

151
00:08:08.280 --> 00:08:12.840
If I'm removing a computer from a domain,
I would want to make sure

152
00:08:12.840 --> 00:08:17.070
that I had administrative credentials for
a local accounts there.

153
00:08:17.070 --> 00:08:19.860
Because when I'm removing
it from the domain,

154
00:08:19.860 --> 00:08:22.460
I'm cutting ties with my domain account.

155
00:08:22.460 --> 00:08:24.090
So that's important to note, as well.

156
00:08:25.410 --> 00:08:26.980
And so you would just simply go ahead and

157
00:08:26.980 --> 00:08:31.200
change these radio buttons to the work
group and specify if you chose to do so.

158
00:08:31.200 --> 00:08:35.910
Again, all easily accessible
right here from server manager.

159
00:08:35.910 --> 00:08:38.290
If we take a look at our Windows firewall,
all right?

160
00:08:38.290 --> 00:08:40.840
So this is an easy way to go ahead and
connect here.

161
00:08:40.840 --> 00:08:42.683
Just click on firewall,

162
00:08:42.683 --> 00:08:48.140
now originally are in the center pane
here we see our different profiles.

163
00:08:48.140 --> 00:08:52.449
We have our domain networks profile,
private networks and guest or

164
00:08:52.449 --> 00:08:57.830
public networks, very similar to what we
see on our client side operating systems.

165
00:08:57.830 --> 00:09:00.680
With our client side systems,
you may be working with a laptop,

166
00:09:00.680 --> 00:09:03.110
a tablet, a lot more mobility.

167
00:09:03.110 --> 00:09:06.300
With our servers are usually,
stationary or

168
00:09:06.300 --> 00:09:11.160
static, so
we do have these profiles to be aware of.

169
00:09:11.160 --> 00:09:14.220
And again,
we can also spoke about group policy,

170
00:09:14.220 --> 00:09:16.260
we'll get to that in the later shows.

171
00:09:16.260 --> 00:09:21.470
You can really just customize these
settings with advanced computer settings,

172
00:09:21.470 --> 00:09:24.330
you can allow an app or
feature through a firewall.

173
00:09:24.330 --> 00:09:28.740
If I wanted to hear Cortana,

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee embrace the pervasive command based management tool called PowerShell. Ronnie explains the syntax verb noun structure and offers several examples to set the tone and familiarize the layout of commands and commandlets.
