But let's talk about some of the symbols
that we'll end up using inside of

462
00:26:03.513 --> 00:26:04.670
PowerShell, as well.

463
00:26:04.670 --> 00:26:08.672
So there's a few symbols that you
are going to encounter when it comes

464
00:26:08.672 --> 00:26:10.450
across PowerShell.

465
00:26:10.450 --> 00:26:17.219
Sometimes, you will end up seeing, let me
bring up that that CS, that ISE again.

466
00:26:17.219 --> 00:26:21.520
So you will end up seeing symbols
like the back tick mark, okay?

467
00:26:21.520 --> 00:26:25.819
So when you do something like
with the back tick mark here,

468
00:26:25.819 --> 00:26:28.555
this allows you, okay on a command.

469
00:26:28.555 --> 00:26:32.120
Let's say that you wanted it all on one
line, but it doesn't fit on one line.

470
00:26:32.120 --> 00:26:34.310
So it allows us to, to do that.

471
00:26:34.310 --> 00:26:36.401
So used in a long command.

472
00:26:39.510 --> 00:26:47.435
That is to be continued, All on one line.

473
00:26:47.435 --> 00:26:51.943
Sometimes, the commands that you type out,
they're really long, and you might go,

474
00:26:51.943 --> 00:26:55.370
did I just hit Enter and
did that break the command inside itself-

475
00:26:55.370 --> 00:26:56.853
>> Looks like they kinda wrap around.

476
00:26:56.853 --> 00:27:00.240
>> Yep, it allows you to do that,
that idea of the wrap around.

477
00:27:00.240 --> 00:27:03.657
>> The other one of course is actually,
well a dollar sign and

478
00:27:03.657 --> 00:27:08.608
you saw that on this one, when I type that
dollar sign, something else inside the ISE

479
00:27:08.608 --> 00:27:12.404
popped up which says look,
that’s a command that I recognize.

480
00:27:12.404 --> 00:27:16.360
So let me go ahead and show you that
you can just simply use that as well.

481
00:27:16.360 --> 00:27:21.964
Well this one declares a variable, okay.

482
00:27:21.964 --> 00:27:26.675
And then there's a couple of other ones
that's a little bit more confusing here.

483
00:27:26.675 --> 00:27:30.600
There of course are the fancy brackets,
or the Carly brackets here.

484
00:27:30.600 --> 00:27:36.702
And this encloses a block of code.

485
00:27:36.702 --> 00:27:39.710
Okay, clode, a block of clode.

486
00:27:39.710 --> 00:27:42.535
>> And this one can really get
you too if you're not careful.

487
00:27:42.535 --> 00:27:44.985
You think you went through and
typed all of your syntax and

488
00:27:44.985 --> 00:27:47.970
then, you forgot the closing bracket or
something like that.

489
00:27:47.970 --> 00:27:52.507
So you need both of them to go ahead and
complete that, those brackets.

490
00:27:52.507 --> 00:27:54.336
>> Yes you do, and
normally when you see this,

491
00:27:54.336 --> 00:27:57.140
especially in the scripting
that you see in PowerShell.

492
00:27:57.140 --> 00:27:59.811
They'd only put this on
an individual line and

493
00:27:59.811 --> 00:28:03.312
then the closing one on its own
line outside the code as well.

494
00:28:03.312 --> 00:28:04.416
So you'll see that too.

495
00:28:04.416 --> 00:28:07.013
And we normally see that
with the word where, okay.

496
00:28:09.811 --> 00:28:15.298
With where, and then, of course, there
are, well, the regular parenthesis, right.

497
00:28:15.298 --> 00:28:22.230
So if I want to run this first
before the rest of whatever I see.

498
00:28:22.230 --> 00:28:23.941
>> Kind of like our order of operations.

499
00:28:23.941 --> 00:28:25.152
>> It is an order of operations.

500
00:28:25.152 --> 00:28:27.540
That's exactly what
ends up happening here.

501
00:28:27.540 --> 00:28:31.878
So if you want to execute something first,
or a group expression, or whatever it is,

502
00:28:31.878 --> 00:28:34.185
you can also use that
inside of there as well.

503
00:28:34.185 --> 00:28:35.347
And then there's a couple of other ones.

504
00:28:35.347 --> 00:28:38.250
Now some of these I haven't
really needed to use.

505
00:28:38.250 --> 00:28:41.284
For example like a semicolon here right.

506
00:28:41.284 --> 00:28:43.039
So if I wanted to use a semicolon,

507
00:28:43.039 --> 00:28:46.070
this allows me to run multiple
commands on a single line.

508
00:28:52.481 --> 00:28:56.154
On a single line, and then there's
just a couple of other ones, too,

509
00:28:56.154 --> 00:28:58.040
that we want to point out.

510
00:28:58.040 --> 00:29:03.793
So if you're using a percent sign, this
is if you're actually gonna use an alias,

511
00:29:03.793 --> 00:29:08.640
okay, inside of a little bit of
a programming thing here inside of a for

512
00:29:08.640 --> 00:29:10.959
each object, so using an alias,

513
00:29:17.150 --> 00:29:20.302
In a for each object, oops, for each.

514
00:29:20.302 --> 00:29:24.861
[BLANK AUDIO].

515
00:29:24.861 --> 00:29:26.736
-Object, there it is.

516
00:29:29.910 --> 00:29:33.595
You can also click and do that, and the
last one that we really want to point out,

517
00:29:33.595 --> 00:29:36.235
of course, is just a question
mark which is another one.

518
00:29:36.235 --> 00:29:42.880
It's an alias, in a where-object Itself.

519
00:29:42.880 --> 00:29:48.861
So those are all pretty decent things that
you should be a little bit familiar with.

520
00:29:48.861 --> 00:29:50.773
But, to tell you the truth,
in some of the ones,

521
00:29:50.773 --> 00:29:54.086
even though I can memorize all these and,
at some point, when you start working with

522
00:29:54.086 --> 00:29:57.600
it more, it's something you're going
to end up doing, which is great.

523
00:29:57.600 --> 00:30:00.324
But, the only,
I shouldn't say the only one,

524
00:30:00.324 --> 00:30:04.551
the one that I would be most concerned
with right away at the very beginning

525
00:30:04.551 --> 00:30:07.211
is I'm gonna start noticing
that when I want to

526
00:30:07.211 --> 00:30:11.459
connect remotely to things it's gonna
require me to authenticate a lot.

527
00:30:11.459 --> 00:30:16.940
So, what I can do, and I'm gonna use this
dollar one instead to try to help us out.

528
00:30:16.940 --> 00:30:20.332
Is I can go ahead and

529
00:30:20.332 --> 00:30:25.845
set up let's say for example,

530
00:30:25.845 --> 00:30:32.639
a credential equals get credential.

531
00:30:32.639 --> 00:30:37.325
When I do something like that
it's going to ask me for

532
00:30:37.325 --> 00:30:43.719
those credentials initially and
if I use joeyofficeprodemocode.com

533
00:30:43.719 --> 00:30:47.890
microsoft .com if I can
actually type it out.

534
00:30:50.670 --> 00:30:54.255
Sometimes my mouse gets stuck
here when I'm in the zoom.

535
00:30:57.380 --> 00:31:00.214
Then I enter in the super secret password.

536
00:31:02.670 --> 00:31:08.792
Which I forgot [LAUGH] I did forget it,
let me see.

537
00:31:08.792 --> 00:31:10.453
[LAUGH]
>> So Ronnie,

538
00:31:10.453 --> 00:31:14.196
when we take a look at PowerShell and it's
almost like, I don't know if you've ever

539
00:31:14.196 --> 00:31:17.254
spent a little bit of time learning
a particular piece of software and

540
00:31:17.254 --> 00:31:19.190
then that software kinda vanishes.

541
00:31:19.190 --> 00:31:21.500
And you kind of feel like,
hey, I just lost all this or

542
00:31:21.500 --> 00:31:24.290
I have all this unusable knowledge.

543
00:31:24.290 --> 00:31:28.320
But that's not necessarily the case
whenever we take a look at PowerShell

544
00:31:28.320 --> 00:31:32.350
because if we look back to some of
those old school command line commands,

545
00:31:32.350 --> 00:31:36.063
some of those can be brought in use
into PowerShell as well, right?

546
00:31:36.063 --> 00:31:40.203
>> Yeah, they definitely are going to
be brought in in that way, to try and

547
00:31:40.203 --> 00:31:40.827
help out.

548
00:31:40.827 --> 00:31:43.610
So the great thing is the more often
you use it the better it's gonna be.

549
00:31:43.610 --> 00:31:45.836
Let me show you the result of
what I just typed in here.

550
00:31:45.836 --> 00:31:47.390
Just wanna make sure it got in.

551
00:31:47.390 --> 00:31:51.530
Now even if I type in the wrong password,
it would still take it.

552
00:31:51.530 --> 00:31:56.433
But every time you end up running
into a command that says, look.

553
00:31:56.433 --> 00:31:58.419
You need to offer credentials or

554
00:31:58.419 --> 00:32:03.199
whatever it might be Instead of me having
to type out Joey's email address and

555
00:32:03.199 --> 00:32:07.608
then his password, all I have to do at
the end of that is actually type out

556
00:32:07.608 --> 00:32:14.275
the Credential along with that, and
that will substitute for the whole thing.

557
00:32:14.275 --> 00:32:19.048
So adding that in as a variable is
one of the key components that I've

558
00:32:19.048 --> 00:32:22.170
used often and often, and so much so.

559
00:32:22.170 --> 00:32:26.658
And just recently, we were doing
an Office 365 show, where I was

560
00:32:26.658 --> 00:32:31.725
connecting in remotely to multiple
services, you know, out in the cloud.

561
00:32:31.725 --> 00:32:35.631
I didn't have to retype in my
password a thousand times.

562
00:32:35.631 --> 00:32:37.838
I simply created the credential one time,
and

563
00:32:37.838 --> 00:32:40.470
I was able to reuse that
in multiple locations.

564
00:32:40.470 --> 00:32:44.216
So all these different
symbols are really great.

565
00:32:44.216 --> 00:32:47.100
That one though was probably
by far the most helpful.

566
00:32:47.100 --> 00:32:50.784
And not that you can't use the other ones,
but you'll use them in specific contexts,

567
00:32:50.784 --> 00:32:53.680
whereas that one you'll probably
use more often than you realize.

568
00:32:53.680 --> 00:32:58.360
Well, Cherokee there is still a bit for
us to cover but I think I ran out of time.

569
00:32:58.360 --> 00:32:59.223
>> That's all right.
I think we

570
00:32:59.223 --> 00:33:01.030
got a pretty good handle on things so far.

571
00:33:01.030 --> 00:33:05.321
A good start with Powershell, but
we could go on for days with Powershell.

572
00:33:05.321 --> 00:33:08.699
So ladies and gentlemen, stay tune for
more Powershell headed your way.

573
00:33:08.699 --> 00:33:10.440
For this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

574
00:33:10.440 --> 00:33:12.141
Remember I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

575
00:33:12.141 --> 00:33:13.067
>> And I'm Ronnie Wang.

576
00:33:13.067 --> 00:33:14.966
>> See you next time here ITProTV.

577
00:33:14.966 --> 00:33:22.079
[MUSIC]

578
00:33:22.079 --> 00:33:25.148
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee continue to discuss PowerShell. Specifically, they explain what type of administrative functions can be executed to make work more efficient. Ronnie demonstrates how to verify Hotfix installs, troubleshoot network connectivity and invoke history all thru PowerShell.
episodes.title: Get Started with PowerShell Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:01.581
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.581 --> 00:00:06.470
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.470 --> 00:00:08.380
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.380 --> 00:00:12.032
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.032 --> 00:00:14.980
>> Welcome, ladies and gentlemen,
to your Server 101 series.

6
00:00:14.980 --> 00:00:17.130
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.130 --> 00:00:19.850
In this episode, we'll continue
taking a look at PowerShell.

8
00:00:19.850 --> 00:00:23.630
Previously, Ronnie came in the studios and
showed us, really, how to get started,

9
00:00:23.630 --> 00:00:25.790
showing us that verb-noun syntax.

10
00:00:25.790 --> 00:00:28.370
But now we're kind of having
this conundrum about, well,

11
00:00:28.370 --> 00:00:29.960
what do we do with PowerShell?

12
00:00:29.960 --> 00:00:31.740
So, back in the studios today, Mr.

13
00:00:31.740 --> 00:00:35.300
Ronnie Wong's gonna show us
what we can actually perform.

14
00:00:35.300 --> 00:00:40.490
>> That's true, in our previous episode,
as we got started here with PowerShell.

15
00:00:40.490 --> 00:00:42.830
We were really just showing
you a couple of examples,

16
00:00:42.830 --> 00:00:46.030
of what can be done just briefly.

17
00:00:46.030 --> 00:00:52.380
Just examples of what PowerShell
syntactically does, right?

18
00:00:52.380 --> 00:00:56.160
In other words, the verb itself,
and the verb noun agreement, and

19
00:00:56.160 --> 00:00:57.620
what we can get out of it.

20
00:00:57.620 --> 00:00:59.550
But what are we gonna do?

21
00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:03.910
Remember I told you that the focus of
it was normally IT administration, so

22
00:01:03.910 --> 00:01:05.170
that's where we want to get to.

23
00:01:05.170 --> 00:01:09.130
We wanna get to that point where we're
focusing in on the IT administration.

24
00:01:09.130 --> 00:01:11.780
The skills that we're supposed
to develop here is all

25
00:01:11.780 --> 00:01:14.780
about practicality on some of
the things that we need to do.

26
00:01:14.780 --> 00:01:19.140
So let's show you some of the first things
that need to happen when we start here.

27
00:01:19.140 --> 00:01:23.250
So on my screen, I went ahead and
kind of loaded up a table and

28
00:01:23.250 --> 00:01:28.360
you'll find this inside of Brian
Svidergol's book on Windows Server 101.

29
00:01:28.360 --> 00:01:32.820
But I just went ahead and just
reproduced it here on the screen for us.

30
00:01:32.820 --> 00:01:36.430
One of the things that we have to do is we
need to setup what we call an execution

31
00:01:36.430 --> 00:01:41.090
policy as what needs to be done,
when we're starting to take a look at it.

32
00:01:41.090 --> 00:01:43.210
Now, you don't have to
memorize all of these,

33
00:01:43.210 --> 00:01:46.510
but there are times when you
might need to change them.

34
00:01:46.510 --> 00:01:48.340
And so, when you start to take a look,

35
00:01:48.340 --> 00:01:52.020
there's a default policy that's
normally setup inside of server.

36
00:01:52.020 --> 00:01:54.700
When you get to that,
it's easy to find out.

37
00:01:54.700 --> 00:01:56.920
So let me log back into this machine, so

38
00:01:56.920 --> 00:02:02.640
I can show you how easy it is to be
able to find out what's running.

39
00:02:02.640 --> 00:02:08.230
Now I'm connected over to dc01, which
you see right over here, which is fine.

40
00:02:08.230 --> 00:02:16.080
And if I now type in,
Get- ExecutionPolicy and I press Enter.

41
00:02:16.080 --> 00:02:22.270
You can now see where it says, hey this
one is RemoteSigned, is what we have.

42
00:02:22.270 --> 00:02:25.270
Now, for most of us that
doesn't mean anything at all.

43
00:02:26.330 --> 00:02:32.600
And you might even see that your's doesn't
say RemoteSigned as you type this in too.

44
00:02:32.600 --> 00:02:34.320
So you might see some other options.

45
00:02:34.320 --> 00:02:37.870
The other options that you'll
see are one of these particular

46
00:02:37.870 --> 00:02:41.490
six that we have available to us.

47
00:02:41.490 --> 00:02:44.290
We just want to make sure that you
understood what would normally

48
00:02:44.290 --> 00:02:46.010
happen when you see these.

49
00:02:46.010 --> 00:02:52.460
And why your PowerShell commands may be
working or may not be working here too.

50
00:02:52.460 --> 00:02:56.060
So when we start to take a look
here at the very top, Restricted.

51
00:02:57.070 --> 00:03:01.380
All of your configuration files and
scripts, they won't load or

52
00:03:01.380 --> 00:03:04.210
run if everything is set to restricted.

53
00:03:04.210 --> 00:03:07.300
It's perfectly fine if somebody
doesn't want you doing anything and

54
00:03:07.300 --> 00:03:10.670
you don't have the permission to
launch the administrative PowerShell.

55
00:03:10.670 --> 00:03:13.050
You probably are gonna be restricted then.

56
00:03:13.050 --> 00:03:15.680
The other option of course is All Signed.

57
00:03:15.680 --> 00:03:18.360
Now this one says config files and

58
00:03:18.360 --> 00:03:23.810
scripts must be digitally signed
regardless of where they were created.

59
00:03:23.810 --> 00:03:27.230
And this is a secured type of connection

60
00:03:27.230 --> 00:03:30.330
that we want to have on
our machines as well.

61
00:03:30.330 --> 00:03:34.300
Remember that scripts that come
in from outside of your machine,

62
00:03:34.300 --> 00:03:38.360
outside of your environment,
you don't know who may have written them.

63
00:03:38.360 --> 00:03:39.890
So instead what you want to do,

64
00:03:39.890 --> 00:03:42.890
you wanna make sure that there's
a digital signature attached.

65
00:03:44.060 --> 00:03:45.750
Either those configuration files or

66
00:03:45.750 --> 00:03:50.500
scripts, regardless of where they're
actually created, make sure it's there.

67
00:03:50.500 --> 00:03:52.800
If they aren't signed they won't run.

68
00:03:52.800 --> 00:03:54.960
That's the way that you could see it.

69
00:03:54.960 --> 00:03:58.750
Remoted Signed, this should say
RemoteSigned is what it should say.

70
00:03:58.750 --> 00:04:03.000
Just a typo on my end here
is what we have as well.

71
00:04:03.000 --> 00:04:07.070
The idea of RemoteSigned
here config files and

72
00:04:07.070 --> 00:04:11.440
and scripts from the Internet,
must be digitally signed, but

73
00:04:11.440 --> 00:04:15.850
local scripts will normally run
without real hesitation at all.

74
00:04:15.850 --> 00:04:19.110
Now this is probably what will you'll see
as a default just like what I showed you

75
00:04:19.110 --> 00:04:21.090
on the serve ready.

76
00:04:21.090 --> 00:04:24.980
There's not a lot that we tend to change,
but If there is one and

77
00:04:24.980 --> 00:04:27.410
you do need to change it,
it's gonna be right here.

78
00:04:27.410 --> 00:04:28.313
The RemoteSigned,

79
00:04:28.313 --> 00:04:31.775
this is normally the default that's
installed on Windows Server 2016.

80
00:04:31.775 --> 00:04:37.260
I think even in 2012 R2 is actually
going to be this RemoteSigned.

81
00:04:37.260 --> 00:04:41.100
Normally that will allow us to run just
about anything that we locally create

82
00:04:41.100 --> 00:04:41.709
on our own.

83
00:04:41.709 --> 00:04:44.379
We don't have to worry about any
type of restriction on the execution

84
00:04:44.379 --> 00:04:45.600
of these policies.

85
00:04:45.600 --> 00:04:46.930
We're fine.

86
00:04:46.930 --> 00:04:51.640
This one right here is normally
something you do not want to run.

87
00:04:51.640 --> 00:04:56.600
And I want to warn everybody about this,
before you get into this habit of just

88
00:04:56.600 --> 00:05:01.360
saying, I don't care, I just want
it to run, and you set it to this.

89
00:05:01.360 --> 00:05:03.820
Unrestricted is exactly like it sounds.

90
00:05:03.820 --> 00:05:06.650
It will run without any signing, but

91
00:05:06.650 --> 00:05:09.960
the only kind of warning that you
have is if it's from the internet,

92
00:05:09.960 --> 00:05:13.530
it's gonna tell you, this is from the
internet are you sure you want to run it?

93
00:05:13.530 --> 00:05:15.660
Well, then you can do that.

94
00:05:15.660 --> 00:05:18.850
If you set up either one of these two,
bypass will do the same thing and

95
00:05:18.850 --> 00:05:23.390
we'll look for the signature,
bypass won't even warn anything okay?

96
00:05:23.390 --> 00:05:26.860
So config files and scripts will run
without any restrictions at all,

97
00:05:26.860 --> 00:05:30.840
not exactly best practice at
all to actually do any of this.

98
00:05:30.840 --> 00:05:33.980
And the reason why I wanted to warn you
about this, especially from the Internet,

99
00:05:33.980 --> 00:05:35.090
is this.

100
00:05:35.090 --> 00:05:39.980
If you see scripts out there from blogs
and from different ones besides Microsoft,

101
00:05:39.980 --> 00:05:44.860
and they tell you you should set
your execution policy to these two,

102
00:05:44.860 --> 00:05:46.220
I wouldn't do it, okay?

103
00:05:46.220 --> 00:05:51.310
I'm not saying you can't, you obviously
can do it, but I just wouldn't do it.

104
00:05:51.310 --> 00:05:55.070
You know, if they need it,

mean that DMS is wrong, but

327
00:19:32.370 --> 00:19:34.390
it means that I typed it in wrong.

328
00:19:34.390 --> 00:19:37.520
That's when it says,
DMS name does not exist.

329
00:19:37.520 --> 00:19:39.338
Well, it means that I have
to check that out and

330
00:19:39.338 --> 00:19:42.650
realize that there's some other
things that are happening too.

331
00:19:42.650 --> 00:19:46.357
So just two examples of some
administrative tasks that we have

332
00:19:46.357 --> 00:19:47.540
available.

333
00:19:47.540 --> 00:19:51.170
That we can also use PowerShell 4 as well.

334
00:19:51.170 --> 00:19:52.440
Now other things of course,

335
00:19:52.440 --> 00:19:56.240
are about administrative efficiencies
on things that we end up doing.

336
00:19:56.240 --> 00:19:59.940
So let's show you another helpful command
that will also help you out here.

337
00:19:59.940 --> 00:20:04.710
So let me do this, get dash, History here.

338
00:20:04.710 --> 00:20:06.668
Let me clear this off, so
that we can see it a little bit better.

339
00:20:06.668 --> 00:20:10.134
Get-history.

340
00:20:10.134 --> 00:20:14.520
And now check this out right here, okay?

341
00:20:14.520 --> 00:20:18.550
So these are all the commands that
I've just used in this show so far.

342
00:20:18.550 --> 00:20:20.960
From the session that I'm in right now

343
00:20:20.960 --> 00:20:25.610
you can see that here is the commands that
I've used right here in this one session

344
00:20:25.610 --> 00:20:28.360
where I type in all
these different things.

345
00:20:28.360 --> 00:20:33.070
If I want to run them again it's
actually fairly easy to do so.

346
00:20:33.070 --> 00:20:37.700
So if you've ever had where there's like
40 or 50 commands that you've run instead

347
00:20:37.700 --> 00:20:39.680
well let's say that you
don't remember the syntax,

348
00:20:39.680 --> 00:20:41.330
especially if it's really, really long.

349
00:20:41.330 --> 00:20:43.670
You know I just need to
invoke that command again.

350
00:20:43.670 --> 00:20:49.515
Well here you just type in invoke-history.

351
00:20:50.690 --> 00:20:53.890
And then you tell it the actual
number that you want.

352
00:20:53.890 --> 00:20:56.559
So let's take, for
an example, number 10 here.

353
00:20:58.961 --> 00:21:00.740
And there it goes.

354
00:21:00.740 --> 00:21:02.720
I don't have to re-type
in that whole command,

355
00:21:02.720 --> 00:21:07.562
especially if I've strung a lot of these
on, and different measures as well.

356
00:21:07.562 --> 00:21:08.920
All right.

357
00:21:08.920 --> 00:21:13.130
The other thing of course is getting
a little bit more information.

358
00:21:13.130 --> 00:21:17.010
So let's do that get dash service command
that we've been taking a look at.

359
00:21:17.010 --> 00:21:19.850
Cherokee I want to be
able to find out well,

360
00:21:19.850 --> 00:21:23.660
the number of services
that maybe running too.

361
00:21:23.660 --> 00:21:31.563
So instead of just getting everything
which is a lot I can now do a Pipe again,

362
00:21:31.563 --> 00:21:36.470
measured object.

363
00:21:36.470 --> 00:21:37.530
Oops, let me see.

364
00:21:37.530 --> 00:21:38.570
What did I do wrong here?

365
00:21:38.570 --> 00:21:40.242
Get dash service.

366
00:21:45.625 --> 00:21:46.900
Did I misspell something?

367
00:21:48.100 --> 00:21:48.600
Measured.

368
00:21:50.430 --> 00:21:51.850
Measure object not measured.

369
00:21:51.850 --> 00:21:53.740
I was like, what is that.

370
00:21:53.740 --> 00:21:55.289
See?
See, once again misspelling on

371
00:21:55.289 --> 00:21:56.410
mine end here.

372
00:21:56.410 --> 00:21:57.170
Measured.

373
00:21:57.170 --> 00:21:58.970
I was like I know that that's correct.

374
00:21:58.970 --> 00:22:00.999
>> You know what, I'm gonna do
the same thing Ryan, just wait.

375
00:22:00.999 --> 00:22:02.360
>> [LAUGH]
>> I can't say anything.

376
00:22:02.360 --> 00:22:04.080
I can't pick on you because
I'm gonna do it, too.

377
00:22:04.080 --> 00:22:04.605
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

378
00:22:04.605 --> 00:22:05.200
>> So there it is.

379
00:22:05.200 --> 00:22:09.010
So here's the count of the actual
services that we're seeing.

380
00:22:09.010 --> 00:22:10.940
You can see that you can
actually do other things,

381
00:22:10.940 --> 00:22:15.220
like instead, look some maximum and
minimum properties here.

382
00:22:15.220 --> 00:22:17.960
So if you needed to,
you could return a number of objects.

383
00:22:17.960 --> 00:22:20.880
Now, I'm just doing services,
but you could do this with

384
00:22:20.880 --> 00:22:24.700
the users that we're looking at,
like the Get-ADUsers and stuff.

385
00:22:24.700 --> 00:22:27.630
You can do this with a lot if
you actually put your mind

386
00:22:27.630 --> 00:22:31.480
to seeing some of the different things
that you have available as well.

387
00:22:31.480 --> 00:22:34.710
Now, I've used a pipeline
throughout this show,

388
00:22:34.710 --> 00:22:40.070
and really never mentioned what the idea
of the pipeline really helps us to do.

389
00:22:40.070 --> 00:22:44.750
When we start to need to do something
like what we're doing here, get -service,

390
00:22:44.750 --> 00:22:47.180
like we showed you, shows a lot.

391
00:22:47.180 --> 00:22:52.090
We can also use another command to
help us to do some other things.

392
00:22:52.090 --> 00:22:56.090
So instead,
in this particular example that we have,

393
00:22:56.090 --> 00:23:00.000
right, get-service gives us
everything that I want and

394
00:23:00.000 --> 00:23:05.600
then I'm gonna pipe that into, well go
ahead and count those objects out for me.

395
00:23:05.600 --> 00:23:08.300
And let's go ahead and do that as well.

396
00:23:08.300 --> 00:23:11.300
So it allows us to connect
multiple commands together,

397
00:23:11.300 --> 00:23:15.960
to produce really a single result
is what we have the ability to do.

398
00:23:15.960 --> 00:23:21.180
So if I run a get-process,
let's take that, for example.

399
00:23:21.180 --> 00:23:24.110
Wow, look there's a ton
of different processes

400
00:23:24.110 --> 00:23:25.798
that are actually available to me.

401
00:23:25.798 --> 00:23:31.950
And I wanna find out lets say on
this CPU side that I want to sort

402
00:23:31.950 --> 00:23:37.001
by the CPU,
I can do that get dash process and now,

403
00:23:37.001 --> 00:23:41.566
I can pipe that into
something else as well.

404
00:23:41.566 --> 00:23:46.390
So lets see, sort.

405
00:23:46.390 --> 00:23:50.134
Object CPU.

406
00:23:50.134 --> 00:23:53.914
And now we can see where
I've sorted that object, and

407
00:23:53.914 --> 00:23:58.450
you can actually see where it's
actually building up, right,

408
00:23:58.450 --> 00:24:03.742
because I didn't actually put descending
In ascending, you can see where

409
00:24:03.742 --> 00:24:09.056
it's counting up the actual CPU
utilization all the way to that end there.

410
00:24:09.056 --> 00:24:12.135
And then if I choose,
is it gonna be descending?

411
00:24:12.135 --> 00:24:15.472
And now you can see where it
actually lists it backward,

412
00:24:15.472 --> 00:24:17.790
or descending order instead.

413
00:24:17.790 --> 00:24:21.830
Right at the top here,
you see this MsMpEng.

414
00:24:21.830 --> 00:24:24.205
Right here where it actually shows you,

415
00:24:24.205 --> 00:24:30.240
46.5% of the CPU is being
eaten up by that as well.

416
00:24:30.240 --> 00:24:31.050
All right, so

417
00:24:31.050 --> 00:24:36.720
there's a couple of different ones that
really do help us in the idea of piping.

418
00:24:36.720 --> 00:24:40.075
It's two commands where we're normally
putting one, the result of one.

419
00:24:40.075 --> 00:24:44.090
And feeding that into the command of the
other, to produce the result that we want.

420
00:24:44.090 --> 00:24:48.408
One other thing that I also want to
be able to do, is talk about the idea

421
00:24:48.408 --> 00:24:53.690
of installing just a simple Windows
feature that we might have available.

422
00:24:53.690 --> 00:24:59.800
If I do a get -windowsFeatures here.

423
00:25:00.840 --> 00:25:04.110
That's going to give me
a ton of different features

424
00:25:04.110 --> 00:25:06.970
that are absolutely available to me.

425
00:25:06.970 --> 00:25:08.220
And I keep scrolling up.

426
00:25:08.220 --> 00:25:13.130
Let me see, there's a Display Name,
here's a Name, here's an Install State.

427
00:25:13.130 --> 00:25:18.619
But if I scroll all the way down to
the bottom, I'm just picking one, almost.

428
00:25:18.619 --> 00:25:24.050
And so let's just say something like here,
on SMTP server and services, etc.

429
00:25:25.090 --> 00:25:28.220
Now that's not all that's
actually available, sometimes.

430
00:25:28.220 --> 00:25:31.910
What we can do is, we can again use
the pipe command to help us out.

431
00:25:31.910 --> 00:25:36.498
So if I do a get -windowsFeatures,

432
00:25:38.839 --> 00:25:44.110
I'm now hitting my, Tab,
to help us out here.

433
00:25:45.320 --> 00:25:52.741
I want to limit this down,
by the name, to anything

434
00:25:52.741 --> 00:25:56.710
that has SMTP in it.

435
00:25:59.386 --> 00:26:03.002
>> All right, so we're specifically
looking for simple mail transfer

436
00:26:03.002 --> 00:26:07.010
protocol-associated features,
that's what we're really doing here.

437
00:26:07.010 --> 00:26:10.270
>> Right, so whether it begins with
something else and has SMTP in it, or

438
00:26:10.270 --> 00:26:13.600
whether ends with it, or whatever it is,
SMTP should be in the name.

439
00:26:14.960 --> 00:26:18.050
Now I can see where I can do this.

440
00:26:18.050 --> 00:26:22.438
Where SMTP Server Tools,
as well as the SMTP Server,

441
00:26:22.438 --> 00:26:27.050
fairly simple to be able
to get once we get that.

442
00:26:27.050 --> 00:26:33.540
Now if I wanted to, now that I have
that one feature, I can take this.

443
00:26:34.990 --> 00:26:39.932
Let's just do the RSAT-SMTP,

444
00:26:39.932 --> 00:26:45.057
then I can pipe that directly into

445
00:26:45.057 --> 00:26:50.191
the Install-WindowsFeature.

446
00:26:50.191 --> 00:26:54.210
And when I do this, it allows me
to do this all in one command.

447
00:26:54.210 --> 00:26:56.110
Instead of me having to go through and
go, all right,

448
00:26:56.110 --> 00:26:58.200
now I know what the name
of the feature is.

449
00:26:58.200 --> 00:27:02.380
As long as I can figure this out,
notice it's really one command.

450
00:27:02.380 --> 00:27:05.425
I've took the result of saying,
I know what the name is,

451
00:27:05.425 --> 00:27:09.250
I want to get that feature, and
now I want to install that feature.

452
00:27:09.250 --> 00:27:11.700
And that's what we're seeing
is happening right here.

453
00:27:11.700 --> 00:27:16.080
So it really is kind of very easy for
us, as we start working it,

454
00:27:16.080 --> 00:27:18.240
to pipe more and more commands together.

455
00:27:18.240 --> 00:27:20.920
As much as single commands,
where we like to stay,

456
00:27:20.920 --> 00:27:23.360
because we think of them as being simple.

457
00:27:23.360 --> 00:27:23.970
>> Safe zones.
>> Yeah,

458
00:27:23.970 --> 00:27:25.920
safe zone, it's not gonna be that way.

459
00:27:25.920 --> 00:27:28.690
You're gonna see the more
power to PowerShell,

460
00:27:28.690 --> 00:27:32.510
when you start doing more piping, and
more of the information in there.

461
00:27:32.510 --> 00:27:38.040
And then you should see at the end,
no restart needed, the success was true.

462
00:27:38.040 --> 00:27:41.322
Exit code Success, and
you are now ready to go.

463
00:27:41.322 --> 00:27:46.170
So there's a lot that is available to you,
to get started.

464
00:27:46.170 --> 00:27:48.330
And don't forget,
we've mentioned it before,

465
00:27:48.330 --> 00:27:51.820
that you can also use the idea
of the help command as well.

466
00:27:51.820 --> 00:27:55.440
But if I wanted to get help for
a particular command, let's say for

467
00:27:55.440 --> 00:28:01.711
anything that has eventlog in
it I can simply just type in,

468
00:28:01.711 --> 00:28:06.128
just by using some of the syntax that
we've been learning here, right.

469
00:28:06.128 --> 00:28:11.330
The wildcard at the beginning, and
then of course, the wildcard at the end.

470
00:28:11.330 --> 00:28:17.730
I can actually see the specific commands
that are associated with this, too.

471
00:28:17.730 --> 00:28:25.020
The other ones, such as get-module,
that I might want to do.

472
00:28:25.020 --> 00:28:27.072
I might want to see what's
actually available to me.

473
00:28:29.571 --> 00:28:31.067
So we can do a get-module,

474
00:28:31.067 --> 00:28:34.980
and then list what's actually available
in terms of the modules here.

475
00:28:36.560 --> 00:28:41.590
And then you can see, wow, there's quite
a few modules that are actually out there,

476
00:28:41.590 --> 00:28:42.890
and ready for us too.

477
00:28:44.260 --> 00:28:48.604
So there are many different ways that,
if we're not exactly sure what to do.

478
00:28:48.604 --> 00:28:52.006
Where PowerShell itself has not only
the help features that are there.

479
00:28:52.006 --> 00:28:55.295
But just learning and
using that tab completion helps you,

480
00:28:55.295 --> 00:28:58.800
in the spelling mistakes
that I traditionally make.

481
00:28:58.800 --> 00:29:01.500
It helps you in a lot of
different ways as well.

482
00:29:01.500 --> 00:29:05.420
But it's a utility that you're not
going to be able to run away from.

483
00:29:05.420 --> 00:29:06.566
There is coming that point,

484
00:29:06.566 --> 00:29:09.499
where I think what you're going to
end up seeing is that, more and more.

485
00:29:09.499 --> 00:29:13.458
They even recommend this in
the Windows Server 2016, right,

486
00:29:13.458 --> 00:29:16.460
that the default installation is what?

487
00:29:16.460 --> 00:29:20.358
It really is just a command prompt,
it kind of brings you out there.

488
00:29:20.358 --> 00:29:21.530
Or it's saying if you don't need it-
>> Well that's saying a lot.

489
00:29:21.530 --> 00:29:23.817
>> Yeah, if you don't need it,
then do this.

490
00:29:23.817 --> 00:29:27.190
And so they're gonna expect you
to work more and more with it.

491
00:29:27.190 --> 00:29:30.064
So don't avoid it,
jump in a little bit into the shallow end,

492
00:29:30.064 --> 00:29:31.902
like what we've just showed you here.

493
00:29:31.902 --> 00:29:35.045
And that will go a long way,
as you keep learning more, but

494
00:29:35.045 --> 00:29:36.851
there is no avoiding it anymore.

495
00:29:36.851 --> 00:29:39.158
>> [LAUGH]
>> There used to be that point where you

496
00:29:39.158 --> 00:29:43.943
could, just go, that's for another day,
you're passed that other day part now.

497
00:29:43.943 --> 00:29:48.059
And it means you've just gotta
kind of put your head down and go,

498
00:29:48.059 --> 00:29:50.510
let me learn at least the basics here.

499
00:29:50.510 --> 00:29:51.180
>> So true, Ronnie.

500
00:29:51.180 --> 00:29:55.330
I mean, this was a PowerShell show,
the last couple episodes were.

501
00:29:55.330 --> 00:29:58.360
But moving forward, even in the next
show and throughout this series,

502
00:29:58.360 --> 00:29:59.660
we're gonna be using it quite a bit.

503
00:29:59.660 --> 00:30:03.700
So we'll also try to incorporate
our PowerShell commands,

504
00:30:03.700 --> 00:30:07.300
as well as showing you how to
do things through the GUI.

505
00:30:07.300 --> 00:30:08.140
But like Ronnie said,

506
00:30:08.140 --> 00:30:12.050
you really do need to go ahead and
bite that proverbial bullet here.

507
00:30:12.050 --> 00:30:15.480
But for this show, we are out of time,
so we're gonna go ahead and sign out.

508
00:30:15.480 --> 00:30:17.390
Remember, I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

509
00:30:17.390 --> 00:30:18.140
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

510
00:30:18.140 --> 00:30:20.240
>> See you next time here at ITProTV

511
00:30:20.240 --> 00:30:27.260
[MUSIC]

512
00:30:27.260 --> 00:30:29.877
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee demonstrate how to add server roles and features in Windows Server.  They discuss what a server role is and what must be done to install the role  using the GUI and PowerShell.  Cherokee demonstrates the installation of 2 separate roles and then how to uninstall an installed role.  They emphasize the best practice of only installing the services and features needed and not haphazardly installing every role and feature available.
episodes.title: Adding Server Roles and Features
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:06.083
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:06.083 --> 00:00:08.033
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.033 --> 00:00:12.261
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.261 --> 00:00:15.577
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.577 --> 00:00:18.516
You're watching
the Windows Server 101 show.

6
00:00:18.516 --> 00:00:20.161
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

7
00:00:20.161 --> 00:00:24.220
today we're gonna be diving into taking
a look at adding roles and features.

8
00:00:24.220 --> 00:00:26.480
And here to help us with that
is gonna be Miss Cherokee Boose.

9
00:00:26.480 --> 00:00:28.070
Cherokee, welcome back to the studios.

10
00:00:28.070 --> 00:00:29.380
>> Hey, Ronnie, how's it going?

11
00:00:29.380 --> 00:00:30.290
>> It's going well.

12
00:00:30.290 --> 00:00:34.980
Now, before we dive directly into
what we're going to be doing,

13
00:00:34.980 --> 00:00:38.850
there may be people out there that
have not taken the time to actually

14
00:00:38.850 --> 00:00:40.580
figure out what a role or feature is.

15
00:00:40.580 --> 00:00:42.370
So let's start with that, Cherokee.

16
00:00:42.370 --> 00:00:43.970
What do we talk about when
we talk about roles or

17
00:00:43.970 --> 00:00:45.600
features inside of Windows Server?

18
00:00:45.600 --> 00:00:50.200
>> All right, so if we take a look at
the operating system as a whole, and

19
00:00:50.200 --> 00:00:54.810
we've already mentioned this idea,
this notion of hardening our servers.

20
00:00:54.810 --> 00:00:58.860
We're kind of restricting them, we don't
wanna have any kind of frivolous or

21
00:00:58.860 --> 00:01:02.060
unnecessary coding running on them.

22
00:01:02.060 --> 00:01:04.200
We wanna keep it as slim as possible.

23
00:01:04.200 --> 00:01:09.300
So Microsoft is in line with this concept,
this theory, and they say, look,

24
00:01:09.300 --> 00:01:14.450
we're going to provide you
the capability of customizing and

25
00:01:14.450 --> 00:01:18.600
picking and choosing what components you
wanna run on this particular server.

26
00:01:18.600 --> 00:01:20.860
We're not just gonna give you
everything out of the box.

27
00:01:20.860 --> 00:01:26.100
So by taking a look at different roles,
roles are going to be

28
00:01:26.100 --> 00:01:29.490
like different functionalities
that Microsoft is providing us.

29
00:01:29.490 --> 00:01:32.860
So different servers, well,
if you think about the term, servers,

30
00:01:32.860 --> 00:01:36.690
servers offer some kind of service to
your network, to your environment.

31
00:01:36.690 --> 00:01:42.920
And we typically see roles
supporting a service like DHCP, DNS.

32
00:01:42.920 --> 00:01:45.630
Perhaps, we're running
as a domain controller.

33
00:01:45.630 --> 00:01:50.990
And we have the ability to add multiple
roles to one particular machine.

34
00:01:50.990 --> 00:01:56.110
But we also have the ability to
just create an individual machine,

35
00:01:56.110 --> 00:02:01.700
whether it be physical or virtual, and
kinda dub it as a dedicated server.

36
00:02:01.700 --> 00:02:05.760
And what that means is that's the sole
function of that particular machine,

37
00:02:05.760 --> 00:02:06.513
that server.

38
00:02:06.513 --> 00:02:10.182
>> All right, so, Cherokee, when you
start talking about that idea of a role,

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee dive into reviewing the networking fundamentals.  Cherokee reviews the quick history of networking and an overview of subnetting basics.  She provides a scenario on where we would use subnetting and a practical application  of it when creating DHCP scopes.  Lastly, she gives a few minutes providing some review of port number and how they are used.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue with additional the networking fundamentals.  Cherokee demonstrates how to provide some networking redundancy and even performance using the NIC teaming.  She distinguishes the 2 type of NIC Teaming used and demonstrates how to configure the independent mode.  She also reviews some of the technology used to help secure the networking communications between the server and other devices.
episodes.title: Networking Fundamentals Part 2

And whenever, if that one were to fail,

00:03:36.790 --> 00:03:44.110
