To close any kind of unopen ports,

205
00:13:45.310 --> 00:13:49.662
remove any software that's not needed.

206
00:13:49.662 --> 00:13:52.440
Kind of how we had been looking when
we were looking at our rules and

207
00:13:52.440 --> 00:13:55.710
features, using features on demand.

208
00:13:55.710 --> 00:13:56.510
We wanna go ahead.

209
00:13:56.510 --> 00:13:59.260
We had the ability to
restrict access through

210
00:13:59.260 --> 00:14:01.140
our Internet Explorer interface there.

211
00:14:01.140 --> 00:14:03.690
You saw how we can go ahead and
configure that.

212
00:14:03.690 --> 00:14:04.630
What else can we do?

213
00:14:04.630 --> 00:14:07.040
Make sure we keep our systems up to date.

214
00:14:07.040 --> 00:14:09.320
Have good patch management strategies.

215
00:14:09.320 --> 00:14:10.960
So, there are a lot of different things.

216
00:14:10.960 --> 00:14:15.270
It's not just one thing that we
can do to make our systems secure.

217
00:14:15.270 --> 00:14:19.970
But when we talk about SSL versus TLS and

218
00:14:19.970 --> 00:14:23.260
you're asked to go ahead and
configure certain things it's important to

219
00:14:23.260 --> 00:14:26.460
understand why we would
choose one versus the other.

220
00:14:26.460 --> 00:14:30.210
And even looking at our different
protocols it's important to know why we

221
00:14:30.210 --> 00:14:32.130
would choose one versus the other or

222
00:14:32.130 --> 00:14:35.760
what can we do to make
an unsecure protocol secure.

223
00:14:35.760 --> 00:14:39.610
By adding them together in
a protocol suite if you look at

224
00:14:40.770 --> 00:14:41.970
tunneling protocol L2TP.

225
00:14:43.500 --> 00:14:47.000
You take that by itself that
tunneling protocol is not secure but

226
00:14:47.000 --> 00:14:50.480
then when you go ahead and
utilize it with something like IPsec,

227
00:14:50.480 --> 00:14:54.650
then that will allow you an encrypted
tunnel to go ahead and communicate.

228
00:14:54.650 --> 00:14:59.780
So, really setting your ports,
brushing up on your port numbers,

229
00:14:59.780 --> 00:15:01.850
and then just keeping
those systems hardened.

230
00:15:01.850 --> 00:15:09.240
Because if we talk about SSL and TLS, and
I say that because it's used as a base for

231
00:15:09.240 --> 00:15:15.810
PKI within the Internet and
we have seen various iterations over time.

232
00:15:15.810 --> 00:15:18.280
Was it SSL originally by Netscape?

233
00:15:18.280 --> 00:15:23.070
And over the years, we've progressed into
TLS and a lot of times you'll hear people

234
00:15:23.070 --> 00:15:29.420
say if they are talking about HTTPS,
they may say it's HTPP with SSL.

235
00:15:29.420 --> 00:15:35.236
But nowadays it's most likely going to
be HTTP bundled or coupled with TLS.

236
00:15:35.236 --> 00:15:38.920
The current version that we have
out there is gonna be TLS1.3.

237
00:15:38.920 --> 00:15:45.150
There are subsequent versions that your
systems can be backwards compatible with,

238
00:15:45.150 --> 00:15:46.830
but just keep in mind
that if you go ahead,

239
00:15:46.830 --> 00:15:51.230
it may seem like one little tiny
configuration option that you're checking.

240
00:15:51.230 --> 00:15:54.709
Yeah I'll be backwards compatible
with the SSL version whatever.

241
00:15:55.790 --> 00:15:59.520
Keep that in mind you're reducing
the overall security for that particular

242
00:15:59.520 --> 00:16:03.260
system, for that particular network
just by making that one little decision.

243
00:16:03.260 --> 00:16:07.580
So, I guess when it comes to security,

244
00:16:07.580 --> 00:16:12.510
transport layer security,
any kind of security really I would highly

245
00:16:12.510 --> 00:16:15.180
recommend taking some time if that's
something you're interested in and

246
00:16:15.180 --> 00:16:18.030
it's not something that's just
gonna be easy to understand.

247
00:16:18.030 --> 00:16:22.140
Security is not for the faint of heart but
we do have tons of shows on that and

248
00:16:22.140 --> 00:16:23.580
I would just urge you to go ahead and
take a look.

249
00:16:23.580 --> 00:16:26.570
I mean, we've got CEH,
we've got all sort of shows,

250
00:16:26.570 --> 00:16:29.550
we've got our Security+,
quite a few in there.

251
00:16:29.550 --> 00:16:32.210
>> Yeah, the other thing that we
may think about in terms of network

252
00:16:32.210 --> 00:16:36.600
communication and securing that is
also things like VPN tunnels and

253
00:16:36.600 --> 00:16:39.440
some of the different technology
that's involved there too.

254
00:16:39.440 --> 00:16:43.780
The great thing is Windows Server normally
does give you that ability to configure

255
00:16:43.780 --> 00:16:47.190
not only things like what Cherokee was
talking about but also that ability to

256
00:16:47.190 --> 00:16:51.460
create those types of tunneling protocols
that are normally secured as well for

257
00:16:51.460 --> 00:16:53.510
that type of traffic that we have.

258
00:16:53.510 --> 00:16:54.490
All right, so Cherokee,

259
00:16:54.490 --> 00:17:00.730
if that pretty much covers it that's gonna
end our particular episode for today.

260
00:17:00.730 --> 00:17:02.500
Remember that what you saw here, right,

261
00:17:02.500 --> 00:17:08.080
is that Cherokee showed us how we can
configure NIC teaming to provide a basis,

262
00:17:08.080 --> 00:17:12.070
right, of either being able to do
load balancing across those NICs or

263
00:17:12.070 --> 00:17:17.810
being able to provide redundancy in
case of one NIC and switch failing.

264
00:17:17.810 --> 00:17:21.160
As well as talking about some of these
different protocols that we tend to see

265
00:17:21.160 --> 00:17:25.490
that we have to secure the communication
between our server and some place else.

266
00:17:25.490 --> 00:17:28.170
Well, that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

267
00:17:28.170 --> 00:17:31.870
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

268
00:17:31.870 --> 00:17:32.880
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

269
00:17:32.880 --> 00:17:37.385
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of Windows Server 101 shows.

270
00:17:37.385 --> 00:17:43.229
[MUSIC]

271
00:17:43.229 --> 00:17:46.992
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee take us through configuring the DHCP server for use.  Cherokee shows how to setup a scope and scope options.  She explains each step and the shows the end result of the setup.  She explains that even though configured, it may not be ready for use until the server is authorized in your domain environment.  She discusses with Ronnie the use of dynamic IPs and configures reserved IPs within the DHCP scope.  Lastly, she shows how to backup and restore the DHCP database through the GUI.
episodes.title: Managing a DHCP Server Role
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:02.856
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.856 --> 00:00:08.439
>> [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.439 --> 00:00:08.939
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.390 --> 00:00:15.776
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:15.776 --> 00:00:18.630
You're watching
the Windows Server 101 show.

6
00:00:18.630 --> 00:00:20.530
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

7
00:00:20.530 --> 00:00:25.350
today we'll be taking a look at
managing a DHCP server role.

8
00:00:25.350 --> 00:00:28.483
And here to help us get started with
that is gonna be Ms. Cherokee Boose.

9
00:00:28.483 --> 00:00:30.050
Cherokee, welcome back to the studios.

10
00:00:30.050 --> 00:00:31.890
>> Thank you for having me today, Ronnie.

11
00:00:31.890 --> 00:00:36.855
Yeah, so we're gonna be talking about
DHCP, Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol.

12
00:00:36.855 --> 00:00:41.643
And although the name says dynamic in it,
we can also think

13
00:00:41.643 --> 00:00:46.740
about DHCP utilizing static IP
addresses and reservations.

14
00:00:46.740 --> 00:00:49.320
And so
we'll take a look at that idea as well.

15
00:00:49.320 --> 00:00:53.430
So if we think about DHCP,
well, what is it, right?

16
00:00:53.430 --> 00:00:59.090
DHCP is a service within our
networks that can provide addresses.

17
00:00:59.090 --> 00:01:02.620
So in a previous show I
showed you how to subnet and

18
00:01:02.620 --> 00:01:06.280
we created different networks and
we were looking for those networks ranges.

19
00:01:07.510 --> 00:01:10.561
Here I can take those numbers,
the output from that math, and

20
00:01:10.561 --> 00:01:13.390
then I can plug it into
what are called scopes.

21
00:01:13.390 --> 00:01:18.250
So a scope is going to be
an address pool that I can use to

22
00:01:18.250 --> 00:01:22.570
assign to individuals systems,
or printers,

23
00:01:22.570 --> 00:01:26.894
or whatever,
on my network within that scope.

24
00:01:26.894 --> 00:01:30.010
We're gonna look at how to go ahead and
create that.

25
00:01:30.010 --> 00:01:35.980
But let's think about any exclusions or
reservations that we may want to add.

26
00:01:35.980 --> 00:01:38.200
Because if we talk about workstations,
Ronnie, and

27
00:01:38.200 --> 00:01:41.140
we look at the average lease
duration is eight days.

28
00:01:41.140 --> 00:01:44.510
Which should give us enough time
if someone's out of the office,

29
00:01:44.510 --> 00:01:47.910
they go on vacation,
that lease may expire.

30
00:01:47.910 --> 00:01:51.840
Because we're not obtaining
permanent IP addresses all the time,

31
00:01:51.840 --> 00:01:55.720
we're sharing them with others
within that particular scope.

32
00:01:55.720 --> 00:02:00.720
So when would we want to go ahead and
create a static IP address so that if

33
00:02:00.720 --> 00:02:04.790
I go on vacation, I come back on, I get
a new address, but what about the printer?

34
00:02:04.790 --> 00:02:07.620
The printer doesn't go on vacation,
and everyone uses the printer, so

35
00:02:07.620 --> 00:02:09.492
they want to know that IP address.

36
00:02:09.492 --> 00:02:13.250
So we'll also take a look at that and
how to actually configure it.

37
00:02:13.250 --> 00:02:18.120
A couple things first, when we walked
through setting up the DHCP role with

38
00:02:18.120 --> 00:02:22.990
our Add Roles and Features wizard, and
I said that you always needed to have

39
00:02:22.990 --> 00:02:27.820
at least one static IP address on
the machine that was hosting that role.

40
00:02:27.820 --> 00:02:32.120
Reason being the other machines still do
need to know how to communicate with it.

41
00:02:32.120 --> 00:02:35.780
But if you think about
the DHCP process in general,

42
00:02:35.780 --> 00:02:38.090
we're really starting at layer two there,
right?

43
00:02:38.090 --> 00:02:43.198
So if we take a look at my screen,
I do wanna just remind you of this little

44
00:02:43.198 --> 00:02:49.011
Dora process down here, the Discover,
Offer, Request and Acknowledgement.

45
00:02:49.011 --> 00:02:53.547
And if you think about the Discover frame,
that original communication,

46
00:02:53.547 --> 00:02:56.470
that broadcast that's being sent out.

47
00:02:56.470 --> 00:03:00.015
And then the DHCP server, since
they're Offer packet and then you get

48
00:03:00.015 --> 00:03:04.483
the Request and then the Acknowledgement,
and you see that communication happening.

49
00:03:04.483 --> 00:03:08.240
So we need to at least be able
to have that information there.

50
00:03:09.540 --> 00:03:14.360
So let's go ahead and get started here and
create a particular scope.

51
00:03:14.360 --> 00:03:17.370
Now, this system already
had DHCP installed.

52
00:03:17.370 --> 00:03:20.915
If you don't, you'll need to go back and
watch that show and just

53
00:03:20.915 --> 00:03:25.304
walk through the wizard or use PowerShell
to go ahead and install that DHCP role.

54
00:03:25.304 --> 00:03:29.743
From the top right-hand portion, and you
can see even over on the left-hand side

55
00:03:29.743 --> 00:03:33.151
that DHCP is installed here, but
we're just gonna go ahead and

56
00:03:33.151 --> 00:03:36.720
use the drop-down menu and
pull up our DHCP management console.

57
00:03:36.720 --> 00:03:38.250
I'm gonna go ahead and

58
00:03:38.250 --> 00:03:42.840
expand this out, give myself a little bit
of room to see what I'm working with here.

59
00:03:42.840 --> 00:03:45.212
You may choose to do the same.

60
00:03:45.212 --> 00:03:51.010
And I can see my particular DHCP server
here over on the side, and expand it out.

61
00:03:51.010 --> 00:03:54.741
Now, you'll notice that I have
the ability to configure IPv4 and

62
00:03:54.741 --> 00:03:58.749
IPv6 addresses all within one utility
here, so that's kind of cool.

63
00:03:58.749 --> 00:04:02.300
I'm only focusing on IPv4 for
this particular demonstration.

64
00:04:03.780 --> 00:04:08.280
So what we're gonna go ahead and do here
is, notice how, I guess if I zoom in,

65
00:04:08.280 --> 00:04:10.980
you can see that there's
a little blue exclamation point.

66
00:04:10.980 --> 00:04:15.920
My current scope is down,
it's not authorized yet, it's not running.

67
00:04:15.920 --> 00:04:18.450
But we're gonna go ahead and
create a new scope here.

68
00:04:18.450 --> 00:04:22.399
So if you just right-click on top
of that and then select New Scope,

69
00:04:22.399 --> 00:04:25.118
it'll go ahead and
bring up the wizard for us.

70
00:04:25.118 --> 00:04:27.372
So let's say I have a particular range,

71
00:04:27.372 --> 00:04:31.880
like one of those networks that we looked
at in a previous episode, in my mind.

72
00:04:31.880 --> 00:04:36.380
And say, hey, I wanna go ahead and create
this network, this scope if you will, but

73
00:04:36.380 --> 00:04:39.000
there are couple of printers that
I wanna go ahead and reserve.

74
00:04:39.000 --> 00:04:40.310
Let's start at the beginning here.

75
00:04:40.310 --> 00:04:45.084
So this is just the welcome page,
we'll go ahead and hit Next.

76
00:04:45.084 --> 00:04:49.715
And maybe this particular network or
this scope is going to be for

77
00:04:49.715 --> 00:04:51.359
my sales department.

78
00:04:51.359 --> 00:04:57.001
So I'll just go ahead and type in Sales,
and then maybe put in Sales,

79
00:04:57.001 --> 00:05:03.154
and then I might even add maybe Florida
Sales Group or something like that.

80
00:05:10.043 --> 00:05:10.770
And then hit Next.

81
00:05:12.430 --> 00:05:16.006
Now, for this particular portion
you do have to coincide with

82
00:05:16.006 --> 00:05:19.459
the networking scheme that
you've already been getting.

83
00:05:19.459 --> 00:05:24.847
So here I'm gonna go ahead and
do 192.168, and just by following along,

84
00:05:24.847 --> 00:05:29.539
you have all of these steps listed
in the book that Brian has provided.

85
00:05:29.539 --> 00:05:32.295
So we'll go ahead and kind of keep
in line with what he's showing, so

86
00:05:32.295 --> 00:05:34.940
that if you choose to do this on your own,
that's fine.

87
00:05:34.940 --> 00:05:37.348
You guys also have access
to these practice labs, and

88
00:05:37.348 --> 00:05:40.840
I highly encourage you to go ahead and
get in there and play around with those.

89
00:05:40.840 --> 00:05:47.380
For this particular one we're gonna
go ahead and set this as .1.101.

90
00:05:47.380 --> 00:05:50.110
And you have to have an end in sight here.

91
00:05:50.110 --> 00:05:53.872
You have to have a beginning and
end IP address for this particular range.

92
00:05:53.872 --> 00:05:59.409
So we're gonna go ahead and
type in 192.168.1,

93
00:05:59.409 --> 00:06:02.990
we'll just say here 200.

94
00:06:02.990 --> 00:06:08.140
And you can see your subnet mask
information down here at the bottom.

95
00:06:08.140 --> 00:06:12.138
We're gonna be working with 100 different
IP addresses here within this pool, and

96
00:06:12.138 --> 00:06:13.683
we'll go ahead and select Next.

97
00:06:15.009 --> 00:06:18.500
Now, this is where you can
add any kind of exclusions.

98
00:06:18.500 --> 00:06:23.300
So let's say there was a particular
range within that scope, and

99
00:06:23.300 --> 00:06:27.280
I said maybe I have, I don't know,
five printers or something like that.

100
00:06:27.280 --> 00:06:29.789
And I wanna go ahead and
reserve those IP addresses or

101
00:06:29.789 --> 00:06:31.849
exclude them from this particular scope.

102
00:06:31.849 --> 00:06:34.283
Or maybe there's just some reason
I don't wanna use that address,

103
00:06:34.283 --> 00:06:35.700
whatever that reason may be.

104
00:06:35.700 --> 00:06:41.189
So I could go ahead and say 192.168.

105
00:06:41.189 --> 00:06:44.180
We'll just go ahead and
put in one exclusion here.

106
00:06:44.180 --> 00:06:46.780
And we'll just use the first one .101.

107
00:06:46.780 --> 00:06:52.087
And then well, .168.1.101,

108
00:06:52.087 --> 00:06:55.732
and go ahead and select Add.

109
00:06:55.732 --> 00:06:58.880
And then you also have the option
to ahead and delay in milliseconds.

110
00:06:58.880 --> 00:07:01.820
But we're just gonna keep it like this and
hit Next.

111
00:07:03.240 --> 00:07:06.270
Now, this is where,
I don't know if you can see this,

112
00:07:06.270 --> 00:07:11.000
but there is a number eight here in this
default option for the lease duration.

113
00:07:11.000 --> 00:07:15.096
So let's talk about that for a moment.

114
00:07:15.096 --> 00:07:20.014
When I'm calling out that little
Dora process to the DHCP server and

115
00:07:20.014 --> 00:07:23.570
I accept that offer,
I send my acknowledgment.

116
00:07:23.570 --> 00:07:25.410
That's my IP address, right?

117
00:07:25.410 --> 00:07:27.070
For at least eight days.

118
00:07:27.070 --> 00:07:31.800
If I wanna go ahead and extend that lease,
I have an option to do so.

119
00:07:31.800 --> 00:07:34.500
So, there's a process that happens.

120
00:07:34.500 --> 00:07:41.442
You'll approach a 50% timer, so
day four, what's known as a T1 timer...

121
00:07:41.442 --> 00:07:45.960
Where the DHCP server tries to initiate
communication with that particular node

122
00:07:45.960 --> 00:07:49.160
to say, hey, do you wanna go ahead and
keep this IP address and extend it?

123
00:07:49.160 --> 00:07:52.695
Well, what if, day four,
I'm still on my vacation, and

124
00:07:52.695 --> 00:07:55.522
I don't respond to that
DHCP communication?

125
00:07:55.522 --> 00:07:59.125
Well, that DHCP server will then again,
at a later time,

126
00:07:59.125 --> 00:08:01.345
create what's called a T2 timer.

127
00:08:01.345 --> 00:08:05.491
And that's gonna be at 87.5% of
that lease duration to still,

128
00:08:05.491 --> 00:08:09.579
if you're interested, And
retaining that particular address.

129
00:08:09.579 --> 00:08:14.230
If that DHCP server does not hear back
from that node by the time it has fully

130
00:08:14.230 --> 00:08:17.249
reached its pre-determined lease duration.

131
00:08:17.249 --> 00:08:20.369
Then it'll go ahead and
take the IP address back,

132
00:08:20.369 --> 00:08:23.713
put it back into the pool
of available addresses, and

133
00:08:23.713 --> 00:08:28.300
potentially assign it to another
node within that network.

134
00:08:28.300 --> 00:08:31.413
So anytime you receive an address of

135
00:08:31.413 --> 00:08:36.711
169.254.whatever within
that particular range,

136
00:08:36.711 --> 00:08:42.546
that means you're not able to
communicate with that DHCP server.

137
00:08:42.546 --> 00:08:47.840
And Windows will provide you with an APIPA
address, an automatic IP address.

138
00:08:47.840 --> 00:08:50.741
In other operating systems they call
it something different like a link

139
00:08:50.741 --> 00:08:51.428
local address.

140
00:08:51.428 --> 00:08:55.956
But essentially, what that does for
you it's kind of like a little crutch it

141
00:08:55.956 --> 00:09:00.180
will allow you to communicate
with others within your network.

142
00:09:00.180 --> 00:09:03.614
You won't be able to traverse your
network and go through a router,

143
00:09:03.614 --> 00:09:05.732
speak to anyone outside of your network.

144
00:09:05.732 --> 00:09:11.200
But it'll still get you going along
there and let you limp on your way.

145
00:09:11.200 --> 00:09:13.170
So we're just going to leave
this at our default here for

146
00:09:13.170 --> 00:09:17.050
this particular lease duration,
and then go ahead and hit Next.

147
00:09:18.541 --> 00:09:22.190
All right, let's talk about scope options.

148
00:09:22.190 --> 00:09:24.824
On this screen,
they're giving me the options, say, hey,

149
00:09:24.824 --> 00:09:26.815
do you want to go ahead and
configure that now?

150
00:09:26.815 --> 00:09:30.080
Or do you want to go ahead and
configure it later?

151
00:09:30.080 --> 00:09:33.940
There are a lot of different things that
I can add, components that I can add.

152
00:09:33.940 --> 00:09:38.890
If you think about what DHCP provides to
the clients, let's think about that for

153
00:09:38.890 --> 00:09:40.030
a second.

154
00:09:40.030 --> 00:09:43.290
Number one, the IP address,
like I just mentioned to you.

155
00:09:43.290 --> 00:09:44.788
Number two, the subnet masks so

156
00:09:44.788 --> 00:09:47.350
that it can communicate with
everyone on the network.

157
00:09:47.350 --> 00:09:51.659
And the third most common thing
that DHCP will provide for

158
00:09:51.659 --> 00:09:55.170
client will be the default
gateway address.

159
00:09:55.170 --> 00:09:59.250
So your default gateway will
allow you to leave your network,

160
00:09:59.250 --> 00:10:02.070
will allow you to go through
that gateway router.

161
00:10:02.070 --> 00:10:03.450
It's not a necessity.

162
00:10:04.610 --> 00:10:07.450
You can still communicate,
locally, on your subnet,

163
00:10:07.450 --> 00:10:09.920
without a default gateway router address.

164
00:10:09.920 --> 00:10:13.510
But just keep that in mind,
because when you go and check,

165
00:10:13.510 --> 00:10:18.760
under your IP configurations, someone may,
accidentally, have typed that in wrong.

166
00:10:18.760 --> 00:10:20.290
So when you're going through
your troubleshooting

167
00:10:20.290 --> 00:10:23.610
process you have to logically think
about okay, who can I communicate with?

168
00:10:23.610 --> 00:10:25.380
Who can I not communicate with?

169
00:10:25.380 --> 00:10:27.490
What could potentially
be the problem there?

170
00:10:27.490 --> 00:10:31.900
Check those three things first, but
just know that DHCP can offer so

171
00:10:31.900 --> 00:10:32.800
much more than that.

172
00:10:32.800 --> 00:10:34.200
There are a ton of options.

173
00:10:34.200 --> 00:10:37.420
And even with Server 2016
Microsoft has released and

174
00:10:37.420 --> 00:10:41.660
expanded upon those options
that it can provide you.

175
00:10:41.660 --> 00:10:43.910
So we're gonna go ahead and
click Yes now so

176
00:10:43.910 --> 00:10:46.190
that you can see what
options are available.

177
00:10:47.260 --> 00:10:49.100
The first one is, it says,

178
00:10:49.100 --> 00:10:53.640
to add an IP address here for a router
used by a clients enter the address below.

179
00:10:53.640 --> 00:10:56.550
This is what I was talking
about with our default gateway.

180
00:10:56.550 --> 00:11:05.298
So for the particular one right here
we'll just go ahead and [COUGH] 192.168.

181
00:11:05.298 --> 00:11:11.140
Let's say .0.1 for
this particular router address.

182
00:11:11.140 --> 00:11:13.830
You can hit Add and then select Next.

183
00:11:15.290 --> 00:11:19.440
And you will also see these little
options here, up and down options.

184
00:11:19.440 --> 00:11:22.048
You can add additional components here for
redundancy.

185
00:11:22.048 --> 00:11:26.489
And then by selecting up or
down you're selecting the priority for

186
00:11:26.489 --> 00:11:28.720
those particular IP addresses.

187
00:11:31.120 --> 00:11:33.170
You could also do that with DNS servers.

188
00:11:33.170 --> 00:11:39.080
So it's recommended to have at least two
DNS servers within your environment for

189
00:11:39.080 --> 00:11:40.510
that exact reason.

190
00:11:40.510 --> 00:11:45.650
So if you are running, let's say,
on this machine, I decide that I also

191
00:11:45.650 --> 00:11:50.640
want DNS to be running on this machine
that is offering DHCP, that's fine.

192
00:11:50.640 --> 00:11:55.724
But you should probably have another DNS,
a dedicated DNS server there,

193
00:11:55.724 --> 00:12:00.562
or maybe shared with other roles or
services that you want for backup.

194
00:12:00.562 --> 00:12:03.580
So we don't have to put anything here for
now.

195
00:12:03.580 --> 00:12:07.150
You can see that my current IP
address is already listed here.

196
00:12:07.150 --> 00:12:10.834
But if I wanted to, I could add
additional IP addresses right here.

197
00:12:10.834 --> 00:12:13.608
And I again would have
that prioritization,

198
00:12:13.608 --> 00:12:17.770
that priority in the order of
precedence there to move it up or down.

199
00:12:17.770 --> 00:12:20.873
And then I go ahead and select Next.

200
00:12:20.873 --> 00:12:23.663
Now when we talk about WINS servers,

201
00:12:23.663 --> 00:12:28.730
WINS servers is an alternative
naming convention to DNS.

202
00:12:28.730 --> 00:12:30.090
It is quite old.

203
00:12:30.090 --> 00:12:32.952
Ronnie, do you know of any systems or
networks that may be using WINS or

204
00:12:32.952 --> 00:12:34.467
that you've worked with recently?

205
00:12:34.467 --> 00:12:38.288
>> Not in the last 15 years,
yeah I don't think so.

206
00:12:38.288 --> 00:12:42.369
>> All right so most commonly you're not
gonna be inputting anything here, but

207
00:12:42.369 --> 00:12:45.884
if you are I'm sure someone in your
network will have already given

208
00:12:45.884 --> 00:12:48.890
you the heads up as to why you
would be working with WINS.

209
00:12:48.890 --> 00:12:51.050
So we'll just go ahead and
skip that for now.

210
00:12:52.410 --> 00:12:53.730
And then this is kind of cool.

211
00:12:53.730 --> 00:12:56.800
It ask you, hey do you wanna go ahead and
activate this scope now?

212
00:12:58.170 --> 00:13:00.340
Yes, we'll go ahead and activate it.

213
00:13:00.340 --> 00:13:02.790
But that's not the only
thing that we need to do.

214
00:13:02.790 --> 00:13:07.102
In addition to activating the scope,
we also mean to authorize our DHCP server.

215
00:13:07.102 --> 00:13:10.465
But let's just go ahead and
finish this Wizard out and we'll say Yes,

216
00:13:10.465 --> 00:13:12.633
I wanna go ahead and
activate this scope now.

217
00:13:14.320 --> 00:13:18.520
All right, and then here you have just
your page saying that you were successful,

218
00:13:18.520 --> 00:13:20.670
you've created your new scope here.

219
00:13:20.670 --> 00:13:26.270
And you can see that my scope,
my sales scope, is noted here as active.

220
00:13:26.270 --> 00:13:30.876
But like I said, we do need to go ahead
and continue to configure a little bit.

221
00:13:30.876 --> 00:13:34.613
So let's go ahead and make sure that for

222
00:13:34.613 --> 00:13:40.800
my particular DHCP my IPv4 server
is going to be authorized.

223
00:13:40.800 --> 00:13:42.710
So we do need to go ahead and do that.

224
00:13:42.710 --> 00:13:45.410
>> All right, so Cherokee now
that we've got it configured and

225
00:13:45.410 --> 00:13:48.850
we're about to walk through the wizard and
everything is done.

226
00:13:48.850 --> 00:13:51.845
Does it just work, are we now set,
we don't have to worry about it anymore?

227
00:13:51.845 --> 00:13:56.317
>> Well this particular machine is already
authorized, but if we take a look at my

228
00:13:56.317 --> 00:14:00.946
screen here, we can see that there is an
option to go ahead and unauthorize here.

229
00:14:00.946 --> 00:14:05.560
It would be grayed out, and
I would have the option to authorize.

230
00:14:05.560 --> 00:14:09.950
There are a couple different ways you can
do that, and why would you wanna do it?

231
00:14:09.950 --> 00:14:15.220
If you ever wanted to, perhaps,
decommission a particular server or

232
00:14:15.220 --> 00:14:18.270
during a migration and
things of that nature.

233
00:14:18.270 --> 00:14:21.040
So just knowing that
that option is available.

234
00:14:21.040 --> 00:14:23.370
But I do want to point
something else out as well.

235
00:14:23.370 --> 00:14:28.770
We do have another notion,
an idea of precedence here.

236
00:14:28.770 --> 00:14:33.037
Just like we were looking at previously
with the different machines we could set

237
00:14:33.037 --> 00:14:36.231
the IP precedents, but
here it's a little bit different.

238
00:14:36.231 --> 00:14:41.627
When we look at our configurations,
this first portion over here on the left,

239
00:14:41.627 --> 00:14:46.230
this first little segment,
this is going to be our scope options.

240
00:14:46.230 --> 00:14:50.400
Whereas the section underneath
will be our server options.

241
00:14:50.400 --> 00:14:55.120
So when you go in to configure most likely
people in to configure scope options

242
00:14:55.120 --> 00:15:00.610
instead of server options and it really
just depends on your environment.

243
00:15:00.610 --> 00:15:05.590
But scope options are going to be
overriding those server options.

244
00:15:05.590 --> 00:15:08.970
So it's probably a good idea just to
keep that in mind and if we look and

245
00:15:08.970 --> 00:15:11.660
see what kind of scope
options are set here.

246
00:15:11.660 --> 00:15:13.977
Scope options have
different numerical values.

247
00:15:13.977 --> 00:15:16.592
So for here, 003 for our routers.

248
00:15:16.592 --> 00:15:18.593
006 for our DNS servers.

249
00:15:18.593 --> 00:15:21.250
You don't need to know every
single numerical value.

250
00:15:21.250 --> 00:15:25.000
But it's a good idea to understand
the most common ones there.

251
00:15:26.080 --> 00:15:30.700
And knowing where to look for those scope
options here within GUI because if you do

252
00:15:30.700 --> 00:15:34.180
have some kind of conflict here with,
let's go ahead and

253
00:15:34.180 --> 00:15:36.390
take a look at our server options.

254
00:15:36.390 --> 00:15:41.680
So if I have any kind of options here I do
not, but if I did and they were different

255
00:15:41.680 --> 00:15:48.990
like an IP address was different
here before our DNS servers.

256
00:15:48.990 --> 00:15:51.790
And I thought they didn’t match up and
it wasn't boding well,

257
00:15:51.790 --> 00:15:54.070
then I would have some
kind of conflict there.

258
00:15:54.070 --> 00:15:58.050
So I just want to check that and
make sure everything is good to go there.

259
00:15:58.050 --> 00:16:03.063
We can go through here and take a look
at our different address pools there,

260
00:16:03.063 --> 00:16:07.931
the ones that we had created,
the ones that Was already existing there.

261
00:16:07.931 --> 00:16:12.371
Address leases, currently there are no
leases but you can go ahead and if I was

262
00:16:12.371 --> 00:16:18.120
connected to a production network, I would
be able to see that information there.

263
00:16:18.120 --> 00:16:22.670
Reservations, this should have our
one particular reservation there,

264
00:16:22.670 --> 00:16:24.100
I don't see that in there.

265
00:16:25.240 --> 00:16:30.420
To go on the Action > New Reservation, you
can also go through and select it there.

266
00:16:31.810 --> 00:16:36.347
Policies, you could go ahead and
attach any kind of configuration

267
00:16:36.347 --> 00:16:41.400
policies here for your DHCP as well,
and also apply different filters.

268
00:16:41.400 --> 00:16:43.800
So we're gonna go ahead and

269
00:16:43.800 --> 00:16:47.200
take a look at how we can also
do things within PowerShell.

270
00:16:47.200 --> 00:16:50.300
>> All right, Cherokee, since that
reservation didn't show up, why don't we

271
00:16:50.300 --> 00:16:54.260
go ahead and just create a reservation,
cuz that's something that more than likely

272
00:16:54.260 --> 00:16:57.870
a server technician or a server
administrator will have to be able to do.

273
00:16:57.870 --> 00:17:01.150
>> Okay, Ronnie, you are right we did
not actually create that reservation,

274
00:17:01.150 --> 00:17:02.490
we just set an exclusion.

275
00:17:02.490 --> 00:17:06.040
So let's go ahead and create
a reservation now and see how that works.

276
00:17:06.040 --> 00:17:07.740
So if we take a look at my screen here,

277
00:17:07.740 --> 00:17:11.560
you just simply right click
over your reservation portion.

278
00:17:11.560 --> 00:17:15.570
Currently I have nothing in the center
pane, we don't have any reservations.

279
00:17:15.570 --> 00:17:17.630
So by right clicking, I can go ahead and

280
00:17:17.630 --> 00:17:20.840
launch the wizard that will enable
me to create a reservation.

281
00:17:20.840 --> 00:17:24.600
So let's say we have a printer and
we want to reserve an IP address for that.

282
00:17:24.600 --> 00:17:32.200
We can just type in sales printer, and
then go ahead and assign it a MAC address.

283
00:17:32.200 --> 00:17:33.443
>> Or an IP address.

284
00:17:33.443 --> 00:17:34.905
>> Or, excuse me, an IP address,

285
00:17:34.905 --> 00:17:38.499
I was thinking MAC address because I'm
thinking we gotta fake this part here.

286
00:17:38.499 --> 00:17:43.002
I really don't have a printer with
a MAC address so we'll just say,

287
00:17:43.002 --> 00:17:48.224
123456789, 10, you have to have
at least ten characters there.

288
00:17:48.224 --> 00:17:52.496
And then the description,
we'll just put sales printer.

289
00:17:52.496 --> 00:17:56.225
[COUGH] And
then we'll say maybe floor three,

290
00:17:56.225 --> 00:18:01.040
to help identify that if you
have several sales printers.

291
00:18:01.040 --> 00:18:06.252
Now when we go ahead and select Add,
the operating system is asking me hey,

292
00:18:06.252 --> 00:18:11.826
our unique identifier, our MAC address
that I've entered may not be correct.

293
00:18:11.826 --> 00:18:15.767
Well I definitely did not enter a correct
MAC address here and it's just notifying

294
00:18:15.767 --> 00:18:19.306
me of that, but for this particular
example we're just gonna hit OK, but

295
00:18:19.306 --> 00:18:22.760
you really would wanna verify you
are putting the right MAC address in.

296
00:18:22.760 --> 00:18:27.010
We'll hit Yes and then go ahead and
close out of here.

297
00:18:27.010 --> 00:18:31.390
Now you can see that my sales printer
reservation has been included here.

298
00:18:31.390 --> 00:18:34.230
If it doesn't show up
automatically you may just need to

299
00:18:34.230 --> 00:18:38.680
refresh the Management Console page,
sometimes it gets stuck like that.

300
00:18:38.680 --> 00:18:44.810
But let's also, I wanna show you one other
thing we can do here within the GUI before

301
00:18:44.810 --> 00:18:48.930
we also look at PowerShell cmdlets that
we can use to perform functions as well.

302
00:18:50.230 --> 00:18:54.445
If I left click on my actual server
over here on the left pane, and

303
00:18:54.445 --> 00:19:00.110
then right click, I really need to think
about backing up and creating backups.

304
00:19:00.110 --> 00:19:04.240
Because let's say I go into my DHCP
server and I configure all these options,

305
00:19:04.240 --> 00:19:08.290
my my reservations, and
then something happens to that machine,

306
00:19:08.290 --> 00:19:11.010
I'm kinda hosed, I'd have to go back and
redo all that work.

307
00:19:11.010 --> 00:19:14.280
So what I can do here is go ahead and
create a backup.

308
00:19:15.580 --> 00:19:22.610
By default under the C drive, under the
System 32, you'll have a DHCP folder, and

309
00:19:22.610 --> 00:19:26.820
then a backup folder, that's the default
location, you can change that if you like,

310
00:19:26.820 --> 00:19:30.020
but we're just gonna leave it in
the default for now, we'll hit OK.

311
00:19:32.210 --> 00:19:34.460
And let's change things up a bit.

312
00:19:34.460 --> 00:19:38.810
Let's go back to our reservation, go ahead
and right click on it, select Delete, and

313
00:19:38.810 --> 00:19:40.990
we're gonna delete out this reservation.

314
00:19:40.990 --> 00:19:46.784
And now let's say someone accidentally
deleted something, one of your sysadmins,

315
00:19:46.784 --> 00:19:52.108
well if we go back onto our server and
then right click, we can select Restore.

316
00:19:52.108 --> 00:19:56.410
And this is the default
location that we had selected

317
00:19:56.410 --> 00:20:01.121
here under the System32 > DHCP > Backup,
all right.

318
00:20:01.121 --> 00:20:05.457
Just make sure you are pulling back in
the correct version if you have multiple

319
00:20:05.457 --> 00:20:09.794
versions, points in time of those
particular backups, and then go ahead and

320
00:20:09.794 --> 00:20:10.480
select OK.

321
00:20:12.280 --> 00:20:17.660
Now, you're gonna be notified of a stop
and a restart here for that service.

322
00:20:17.660 --> 00:20:23.300
And if you think about the way DHCP works,
you might be okay with stopping and

323
00:20:23.300 --> 00:20:27.140
restarting it during normal business
hours, because unless you have

324
00:20:27.140 --> 00:20:31.300
a really short least duration time, and
you have people constantly pegging and

325
00:20:31.300 --> 00:20:35.020
requesting the DHCP server for
an address, that may be an issue.

326
00:20:35.020 --> 00:20:38.550
But for this demonstration, I think
we'll be okay if we just go ahead and

327
00:20:38.550 --> 00:20:39.200
select Yes.

328
00:20:40.830 --> 00:20:44.490
And then here we see our ancient
little ticker just stopping and

329
00:20:44.490 --> 00:20:46.350
restarting that service there for us.

330
00:20:47.680 --> 00:20:51.697
It should only take a moment, we don't
have a lot of information in here.

331
00:20:51.697 --> 00:20:56.148
All right, now it says the database
was restored successfully, so

332
00:20:56.148 --> 00:21:00.538
let's check our work here and
verify that in fact it actually was.

333
00:21:00.538 --> 00:21:04.904
If we look under our IPv4 for
our scope options here,

334
00:21:04.904 --> 00:21:10.159
let's go ahead and expand that out and
check for reservations.

335
00:21:10.159 --> 00:21:13.770
And let's see,
I don't have a reservation there?

336
00:21:17.418 --> 00:21:21.330
Let me make sure it wasn't under,
we didn't create it under R, there it is,

337
00:21:21.330 --> 00:21:22.666
it was-
>> [LAUGH] I was gonna say wow.

338
00:21:22.666 --> 00:21:26.220
>> It was under our server options
here and not our scope, or

339
00:21:26.220 --> 00:21:30.233
wait it is our scope,
that was my other scope, I'm sorry guys.

340
00:21:30.233 --> 00:21:32.172
This scope was not the one
that we had created,

341
00:21:32.172 --> 00:21:35.206
this was the one that was there already
and I should have seen the little,

342
00:21:35.206 --> 00:21:38.010
that little down arrow means
that it is not active there.

343
00:21:38.010 --> 00:21:39.500
So I just looked in the wrong section, but

344
00:21:39.500 --> 00:21:44.400
that is the correct reservation and the
restoration process did, in fact, work.

345
00:21:44.400 --> 00:21:47.710
So we know it's a good,
functioning backup copy,

346
00:21:47.710 --> 00:21:50.080
and that's something that you
definitely wanna check also.

347
00:21:50.080 --> 00:21:53.490
Because creating backups every
single week, or month, or

348
00:21:53.490 --> 00:21:56.570
whatever your scheme may be is fine,
but you also need to test them and

349
00:21:56.570 --> 00:21:59.520
making sure you're actually backing up
the information that you want to back up.

350
00:22:00.850 --> 00:22:04.745
>> All right, Cherokee, well thank you for
helping us out in getting started

351
00:22:04.745 --> 00:22:09.860
in terms of setting up the DHCP
scope as well as the reservation.

352
00:22:09.860 --> 00:22:13.450
Showing us of course not only backing up
is important, but also how to restore that

353
00:22:13.450 --> 00:22:18.930
as well using the actual regular web
interface that we normally have here.

354
00:22:18.930 --> 00:22:22.620
Now there is still a lot more to go cuz
we're about to get into some PowerShell,

355
00:22:22.620 --> 00:22:24.580
but we're running out of time, so

356
00:22:24.580 --> 00:22:29.100
that means we are going to stop and
get a part two out of this show as well.

357
00:22:29.100 --> 00:22:33.300
So for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

358
00:22:33.300 --> 00:22:34.195
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

359
00:22:34.195 --> 00:22:38.906
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Windows Server 101 shows.

360
00:22:38.906 --> 00:22:44.673
[MUSIC]

361
00:22:44.673 --> 00:22:48.261
Thank you for watching, ITPRO TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee show configuring the DHCP server role using powershell.  Cherokee shows how to create a scope with scope options and a scope reservation here.  The team emphasizes the goal of using powershell to automate multiple scope, option and reservation creations.  They demonstrate also some simple powershell commands to also show the DHCP utilization too.
episodes.title: Managing a DHCP Server Role Part 2

WEBVTT

1

I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

[MUSIC]

5

>> Welcome to another great

6
00:00:15.050 --> 00:00:18.580
You're watching
the Windows Server 101 show.

7
00:00:18.580 --> 00:00:20.350
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

8

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce managing client name resolution.  Cherokee mentions the different types of name resolution available to Windows Clients: DNS, HOSTS and LMHOSTS files and WINS.  She turns her attention onto describing form and function of the FQDN, Fully Qualified Domain Name and the DNS resolution process from the client. Lastly, she demonstrates of the powershell and command line utilities can be used to discover DNC functionality for a client computer.
episodes.title: Managing Client Name Resolution

00:15:36.954 --> 00:15:39.472
This host file has been around for
a very long time.

255
00:15:39.472 --> 00:15:41.019
I don't even know,

256
00:15:41.019 --> 00:15:46.570
it probably came out with a very early
version of the operating systems,

257
00:15:46.570 --> 00:15:52.857
and what I'm doing here is I'm actually
going to be overwriting the DNS process.

258
00:15:52.857 --> 00:15:55.516
So I'm overwriting that local cache and

259
00:15:55.516 --> 00:16:00.210
I'm overwriting whatever my
DNS server has to offer me.

260
00:16:00.210 --> 00:16:03.439
Simply by having some
entries within this document.

261
00:16:03.439 --> 00:16:09.177
So here I have two different examples,
here I see my home address,

262
00:16:09.177 --> 00:16:16.900
my looped back address of 127.0.0.1 my
local host for IPv4, as well as IPv6.

263
00:16:16.900 --> 00:16:22.733
So let's say I wanted to go in here and
create another entry.

264
00:16:22.733 --> 00:16:28.910
I could type in 127.0.1.1 and

265
00:16:28.910 --> 00:16:33.782
type in www.facebook.com.

266
00:16:33.782 --> 00:16:38.216
So what I'm doing is I'm telling basically
I'm trying to block someone from

267
00:16:38.216 --> 00:16:40.000
going to Facebook right here.

268
00:16:40.000 --> 00:16:43.450
Because that's not the correct
IP address for facebook.com.

269
00:16:43.450 --> 00:16:47.420
So if someone were to type
facebook.com in to their browser then

270
00:16:47.420 --> 00:16:52.133
theoretically it should and it had been
that way for a very long time Ronnie.

271
00:16:52.133 --> 00:16:56.938
But this morning I was playing around
in here because some of the browsers

272
00:16:56.938 --> 00:17:01.710
nowadays are not actually looking
at this host file anymore.

273
00:17:01.710 --> 00:17:07.050
Because attackers have used this
as a vector for malware so often,

274
00:17:07.050 --> 00:17:11.800
and admins really don't use that much,
this method of name resolution.

275
00:17:11.800 --> 00:17:16.600
So, they see it more as
a security risk to enable this

276
00:17:16.600 --> 00:17:21.120
particular functionality which is kind of
interesting because for a very long time.

277
00:17:21.120 --> 00:17:25.534
And as I was an admin running really
only legitimately ever had to use

278
00:17:25.534 --> 00:17:27.867
this type of name resolution once.

279
00:17:27.867 --> 00:17:32.503
And that was, Was because the customer
had incorrectly registered

280
00:17:32.503 --> 00:17:35.395
their domain name with the registrar.

281
00:17:35.395 --> 00:17:38.295
Like there was a typo whenever
they filled out the paperwork.

282
00:17:38.295 --> 00:17:42.975
So until they were able to contact that
registrar, that CA certificate authority,

283
00:17:42.975 --> 00:17:44.960
to fix that information.

284
00:17:44.960 --> 00:17:46.920
We had to manually override that.

285
00:17:46.920 --> 00:17:48.814
So just be aware of that,

286
00:17:48.814 --> 00:17:53.600
a lot of people will consider this
a way to manually override but

287
00:17:53.600 --> 00:17:58.864
certain browsers are now compensating for
that potential malware.

288
00:17:58.864 --> 00:18:02.110
>> Cherokee, it looks like you added in
one to many zeros inside of your 127.

289
00:18:02.110 --> 00:18:04.600
>> Yeah, yeah,
that's not gonna work anyways.

290
00:18:04.600 --> 00:18:07.814
>> And also to make this work,
don't forget, you need

291
00:18:07.814 --> 00:18:10.803
to remove that pound sign in front of it-
>> Yeah,

292
00:18:10.803 --> 00:18:13.852
the syntax here it really doesn't matter.

293
00:18:13.852 --> 00:18:18.688
What you really have to focus on
is at least if you have one space

294
00:18:18.688 --> 00:18:22.330
between the address and
the domain name here.

295
00:18:22.330 --> 00:18:25.130
So as long as you have one space,
that's really all it's looking for.

296
00:18:25.130 --> 00:18:29.048
You don't even have to line it up With
everything else there that's just to make

297
00:18:29.048 --> 00:18:31.800
things look a little bit pretty,
not too pretty there.

298
00:18:31.800 --> 00:18:35.900
And you would just go ahead and file and
save that in order to make that change.

299
00:18:35.900 --> 00:18:37.330
But I'm not gonna go ahead and

300
00:18:37.330 --> 00:18:41.600
save that because maybe I do wanna
go to Facebook on this laptop.

301
00:18:41.600 --> 00:18:44.514
So that's gonna be your host file.

302
00:18:44.514 --> 00:18:46.462
The LM host file.

303
00:18:46.462 --> 00:18:48.664
And let's talk about that for
a second okay?

304
00:18:48.664 --> 00:18:51.940
Let's go back again,
I told you host was old school.

305
00:18:51.940 --> 00:18:56.010
But bringing it back even further,
something called LM host, which is gonna

306
00:18:56.010 --> 00:19:00.808
be associated with our LAN Man, back
in that older authentication mechanism.

307
00:19:00.808 --> 00:19:06.003
What we were talking about utilizing
net bios names with our win servers.

308
00:19:06.003 --> 00:19:12.250
So win servers are going to be
an alternative to a pre-DNS option.

309
00:19:12.250 --> 00:19:14.060
So pre-internet also.

310
00:19:14.060 --> 00:19:18.400
So if you think about, although the name
implies Windows internet naming system,

311
00:19:18.400 --> 00:19:20.580
it's not used on the Internet.

312
00:19:20.580 --> 00:19:25.582
So it's gonna be use for local resolution
if you're running a legacy system.

313
00:19:25.582 --> 00:19:29.740
So let me go ahead and
let me just show where you can see that.

314
00:19:29.740 --> 00:19:31.660
If we go full screen for a second, so

315
00:19:31.660 --> 00:19:35.650
behind my head here, if we pull up
network and sharing center on my client.

316
00:19:36.990 --> 00:19:40.860
And then on the left-hand side
select change adapter settings.

317
00:19:40.860 --> 00:19:46.749
And then when I go into my IP version
four settings underneath this adapter,

318
00:19:46.749 --> 00:19:49.320
let me zoom in slightly.

319
00:19:49.320 --> 00:19:53.720
I'm gonna go ahead and
select that and hit Properties.

320
00:19:53.720 --> 00:19:58.030
And down here at the bottom is where
I can add my DNS server IP addresses.

321
00:19:58.030 --> 00:20:01.850
So currently I'm obtaining my DNS
server address automatically.

322
00:20:01.850 --> 00:20:05.482
So I'm just getting my DNS
information from our ISP.

323
00:20:05.482 --> 00:20:08.843
But if I had a specified DNS
server that I wanted to use,

324
00:20:08.843 --> 00:20:11.160
I can go ahead and input that here.

325
00:20:11.160 --> 00:20:15.850
There are two fields, two boxes,
by default because we should always

326
00:20:15.850 --> 00:20:19.660
have at least two DNS servers
available within a network.

327
00:20:19.660 --> 00:20:22.960
But I can add DNS servers
on my advance tab.

328
00:20:22.960 --> 00:20:27.411
So let's take a look at that advance
tab and see what we have here.

329
00:20:27.411 --> 00:20:29.100
Let me just get that out of the way.

330
00:20:30.950 --> 00:20:32.410
Here's my DNS tab.

331
00:20:32.410 --> 00:20:35.482
This is where I would add
additional DNS IP addresses.

332
00:20:35.482 --> 00:20:39.613
And then I could go ahead and
set the priority utilizing these

333
00:20:39.613 --> 00:20:43.906
arrows on the right hand side and
hitting this add button here.

334
00:20:43.906 --> 00:20:46.153
Now if we look at this wins button,

335
00:20:46.153 --> 00:20:50.816
we can see here that I currently
don't have anything designated here.

336
00:20:50.816 --> 00:20:56.131
Most of you will not, but if your IT
department should definitely clue you

337
00:20:56.131 --> 00:21:01.533
in as to why you would want to have that
enabled versus not because typically

338
00:21:01.533 --> 00:21:07.215
we're gonna even be disabling net Bios
names if we're not using those there.

339
00:21:07.215 --> 00:21:13.035
So you also see your import,
your LM host files as well.

340
00:21:13.035 --> 00:21:14.711
So you can see how they're all related,
but

341
00:21:14.711 --> 00:21:17.936
that's not really something you'll be
seeing on a production environment today.

342
00:21:19.617 --> 00:21:23.611
>> Now Cherokee, we did have somebody
in the chat also mention that as for

343
00:21:23.611 --> 00:21:26.105
the host file or even the LM host file.

344
00:21:26.105 --> 00:21:29.912
Remember that if you do try to save this
because you're trying to do some type of

345
00:21:29.912 --> 00:21:32.235
manipulation, just like
what you were shown.

346
00:21:32.235 --> 00:21:34.538
To make sure that as you save it,
it can't save with an extension.

347
00:21:34.538 --> 00:21:36.350
>> That's right,
it's gonna want to go ahead and save.

348
00:21:36.350 --> 00:21:40.070
Like you saw guys, in my window,
it saved it with a .txt extension.

349
00:21:40.070 --> 00:21:41.857
You don't want it to have an extension.

350
00:21:41.857 --> 00:21:45.490
It should be a file with no
extension there for that host file.

351
00:21:45.490 --> 00:21:46.030
So, thank you.

352
00:21:46.030 --> 00:21:48.144
Good point for that.

353
00:21:48.144 --> 00:21:53.165
Now, let's take a look here at
PowerShell has, and we've been stressing

354
00:21:53.165 --> 00:21:58.997
PowerShell throughout this series, there's
a lot that we can do within PowerShell.

355
00:21:58.997 --> 00:22:02.562
But I kinda wanna give an example and just
note there are a lot of different tools

356
00:22:02.562 --> 00:22:04.680
that we can use when
we're talking about DNS.

357
00:22:04.680 --> 00:22:07.531
We're not gonna be able to get
to all of them within this show.

358
00:22:07.531 --> 00:22:11.460
But at first let's go ahead and

359
00:22:11.460 --> 00:22:15.548
type in get-DnsClientCache.

360
00:22:17.835 --> 00:22:22.955
Now what we're gonna be seeing is a
display of the cache on my local machine,

361
00:22:22.955 --> 00:22:24.840
like I was talking about.

362
00:22:24.840 --> 00:22:28.730
So any kind of mappings
that I have stored here.

363
00:22:28.730 --> 00:22:31.489
My host names,
my fully qualified domain names too

364
00:22:31.489 --> 00:22:34.641
my IP addresses are gonna be
stored in this local machine.

365
00:22:34.641 --> 00:22:37.520
So I can see that here within PowerShell.

366
00:22:37.520 --> 00:22:42.100
Now have I ever been yeah I've
been to Microsoft okay to log on.

367
00:22:42.100 --> 00:22:44.950
But let's say I don't see
something like CNN on here.

368
00:22:44.950 --> 00:22:48.752
So, if I were to go ahead and

369
00:22:48.752 --> 00:22:54.590
ping www.cnn.com and hit Enter.

370
00:22:54.590 --> 00:22:57.820
So now I hadn't been to cnn.com before but

371
00:22:57.820 --> 00:23:03.666
because of ping I'm forcing this process
here and I can see I do have my reply.

372
00:23:03.666 --> 00:23:09.151
So if I go back and
check my get-DNSclient cache again,

373
00:23:09.151 --> 00:23:15.351
I should see, and you can see
these entries here for CNN.com.

374
00:23:15.351 --> 00:23:20.805
So that means that this information
is now stored within my cache.

375
00:23:20.805 --> 00:23:24.869
That's not the only utility that can
perform a similar function like this.

376
00:23:24.869 --> 00:23:30.359
So if we go ahead even taking it back
a little further and pull up a command

377
00:23:30.359 --> 00:23:36.380
prompt, you still have that ability
here to go ahead and do that as well.

378
00:23:36.380 --> 00:23:41.870
So within the command prompt you're
gonna be typing in the command tool.

379
00:23:41.870 --> 00:23:43.880
So let's go ahead and type in ipconfig.

380
00:23:45.140 --> 00:23:50.784
Space /displayDNS, I'm making

381
00:23:50.784 --> 00:23:55.655
up my own commands here okay.

382
00:23:55.655 --> 00:23:59.694
So a little bit different
of an output here but

383
00:23:59.694 --> 00:24:05.558
you can see that it's going to
show you that information as well.

384
00:24:05.558 --> 00:24:07.222
Let' see.

385
00:24:07.222 --> 00:24:09.424
Let's pick another website here.

386
00:24:09.424 --> 00:24:11.440
Maybe like Pandora.com.

387
00:24:11.440 --> 00:24:15.143
So again if I were to go ahead and

388
00:24:15.143 --> 00:24:19.822
just ping www.pandora.com.

389
00:24:21.070 --> 00:24:23.122
Okay, I'm forcing this process.

390
00:24:23.122 --> 00:24:24.196
I'm storing this now.

391
00:24:24.196 --> 00:24:28.990
I can see this information 208.85.40.20.

392
00:24:28.990 --> 00:24:33.756
And if I go ahead and
display my DNS again.

393
00:24:35.800 --> 00:24:39.290
I should have Pandora
in this list somewhere.

394
00:24:39.290 --> 00:24:44.500
Now, the only caviatte to that would
also be to note, here's my pandora.com.

395
00:24:44.500 --> 00:24:50.710
Would be to note that there are TTLs,
like we spoke about.

396
00:24:50.710 --> 00:24:56.490
So, it doesn't mean that if you don't see
a particular mapping within your cache,

397
00:24:56.490 --> 00:24:59.490
it doesn't mean that, that computer
has never been to that site before.

398
00:24:59.490 --> 00:25:03.802
It means that, that record may have
exceeded it's time to live and

399
00:25:03.802 --> 00:25:08.812
it's just kind of being a little more
dynamic and refreshing in that aspect.

400
00:25:08.812 --> 00:25:13.854
We do have additional tools that I
wanna talk about like NS look up and

401
00:25:13.854 --> 00:25:18.904
show you how not only can we perform
hostname to IP address queries.

402
00:25:18.904 --> 00:25:22.899
But also th reverse, but Ronnie I think
we are getting short on time for that,

403
00:25:22.899 --> 00:25:23.769
what do you say?

404
00:25:23.769 --> 00:25:27.080
>> yap there's no doubt that there
is plenty to actually go and

405
00:25:27.080 --> 00:25:31.990
see more on DNS and we've just really
introduced at least the basic topics here.

406
00:25:31.990 --> 00:25:35.368
Of understanding how the FQDN works,
as well as the process and

407
00:25:35.368 --> 00:25:38.746
how we're gonna see the name
resolution end up happening, But

408
00:25:38.746 --> 00:25:41.932
there's a lot more details but
we are running out of time for

409
00:25:41.932 --> 00:25:45.849
this particular episode, which means
we are going to go into a part two.

410
00:25:45.849 --> 00:25:49.368
So we're actually gonna save that for
another episode then.

411
00:25:49.368 --> 00:25:52.946
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

412
00:25:52.946 --> 00:25:54.195
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

413
00:25:54.195 --> 00:25:58.648
>> Stay right here for
more Windows Server 101 shows.

414
00:25:58.648 --> 00:26:04.642
[MUSIC]

415
00:26:04.642 --> 00:26:07.574
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue with client name resolution.  Cherokee emphasizes the importance of isolating where the DNS issue is occurring: locally or on the server.  She uses and discusses different tools to aid in troubleshooting DNS on the client.
episodes.title: Managing Client Name Resolution Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:01.555
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.555 --> 00:00:02.072
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.072 --> 00:00:07.058
>> [CROSSTALK]
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.058 --> 00:00:08.778
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:08.778 --> 00:00:15.670
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:15.670 --> 00:00:20.100
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today we're
taking a look at Windows Server 101.

7
00:00:20.100 --> 00:00:21.770
We're specifically going into a part two,

8
00:00:21.770 --> 00:00:24.760
taking a look at client
side name resolution.

9
00:00:24.760 --> 00:00:26.900
And here to help us out is gonna be Ms.
Cherokee Boose.

10
00:00:26.900 --> 00:00:27.820
Cherokee, welcome back.

11
00:00:27.820 --> 00:00:28.610
>> Thanks for having me, Ronnie.

12
00:00:28.610 --> 00:00:29.480
How are you doing today?

13
00:00:29.480 --> 00:00:30.690
>> I'm doing great, Cherokee.

14
00:00:30.690 --> 00:00:34.026
So we've done a lot in our part one.

15
00:00:34.026 --> 00:00:35.576
Where are we picking up
inside of part two here?

16
00:00:35.576 --> 00:00:40.580
>> Yeah, so in part one, we were taking
a look at a PowerShell commandlet where

17
00:00:40.580 --> 00:00:46.320
we can look within our PowerShell utility
to look at that client side cache.

18
00:00:46.320 --> 00:00:49.400
PowerShell is not the only tool
that we do have available for

19
00:00:49.400 --> 00:00:53.700
that client side
troubleshooting process as well.

20
00:00:53.700 --> 00:00:56.950
So something, I do wanna go ahead and
pull up PowerShell again.

21
00:00:56.950 --> 00:01:04.110
And I wanna remind you that you can
utilize older commands, that you

22
00:01:04.110 --> 00:01:08.100
might have used, and been more comfortable
with within PowerShell as well.

23
00:01:08.100 --> 00:01:14.000
So, one of the things I wanted
to take a look at here was,

24
00:01:14.000 --> 00:01:16.360
if we talk about ipconfig right.

25
00:01:16.360 --> 00:01:20.150
So, I see config as a tried,
and true commands,

26
00:01:20.150 --> 00:01:23.870
that we may be familiar with already,
and take a look at ipconfig

27
00:01:25.590 --> 00:01:30.270
Space /displaydns I think
we looked at this earlier.

28
00:01:31.980 --> 00:01:35.200
This is going to give us our
records within our actual clients.

29
00:01:35.200 --> 00:01:37.000
So we're talking client side here.

30
00:01:37.000 --> 00:01:42.130
Now Ronnie, whenever there's an issue
within DNS you kind of have to have this

31
00:01:42.130 --> 00:01:46.410
trouble shooting process this methodology
that will help you determine.

32
00:01:46.410 --> 00:01:49.910
if the issue lies on the client side,
or if it's a server issue.

33
00:01:49.910 --> 00:01:54.278
So if there is one individual that's not
able to resolve, then you might want and

34
00:01:54.278 --> 00:01:58.389
everyone else on the network or on that
particular segment is working fine,

35
00:01:58.389 --> 00:02:02.590
then you might wanna isolate and look
at more of these client side utilities.

36
00:02:02.590 --> 00:02:06.031
Whereas if an entire portion
of your network that and

37
00:02:06.031 --> 00:02:08.170
you find something in common.

38
00:02:08.170 --> 00:02:12.725
And that particular variable that's common
is going to be the DNS server then that's

39
00:02:12.725 --> 00:02:16.142
when you kind of shift your
troubleshooting skills towards that

40
00:02:16.142 --> 00:02:16.660
server.

41
00:02:16.660 --> 00:02:21.196
So it could be something as
simple as an incorrect record

42
00:02:21.196 --> 00:02:26.540
that's stored here locally on
this machine within my cache.

43
00:02:26.540 --> 00:02:31.335
So if that's the case, I could simply
just go ahead and type in ipconfig

44
00:02:31.335 --> 00:02:38.570
/flushdns and what that's gonna do for
me is just clear out my cache here.

45
00:02:38.570 --> 00:02:42.230
If I go ahead and
type properly that will help.

46
00:02:44.540 --> 00:02:48.750
And you can see here, it says Successfully
flushed the DNS Resolver Cache.

47
00:02:48.750 --> 00:02:50.610
So that's great.

48
00:02:50.610 --> 00:02:52.455
But on the server side,

49
00:02:52.455 --> 00:02:56.755
if you think about what is the function
of the server and then the cache.

50
00:02:56.755 --> 00:02:59.585
Remember how we spoke about
how the servers also retain

51
00:02:59.585 --> 00:03:03.335
that information within their cache
which helps speeds up that network?

52
00:03:03.335 --> 00:03:06.580
So instead of flushing out
the entire server cache and

53
00:03:06.580 --> 00:03:10.617
on the server side you'd want to go
in granularly and if you suspect

54
00:03:10.617 --> 00:03:15.326
a particular issue with an IP address,
maybe a website has changed their IP.

55
00:03:15.326 --> 00:03:16.322
Then you can go in and

56
00:03:16.322 --> 00:03:20.308
change that one, because you wouldn't
want to hurt yourself and work backwards

57
00:03:20.308 --> 00:03:25.140
in that way of getting rid of everything
that that server's been working for there.

58
00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:30.110
Now another core utility that you can
use within PowerShell or command prompt

59
00:03:30.110 --> 00:03:33.515
is another oldie but goodie and
this one is going to be called nslookup.

60
00:03:34.900 --> 00:03:39.766
So nslookup actually has two different
modes, there's an interactive mode and

61
00:03:39.766 --> 00:03:44.070

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee take a look at skills resolving around the DNS Server Role on Windows Server.  Cherokee takes the time to guide through the different properties on 8 different tabs.  She also shows how to stop and restart the DNS Server as well as the use of the Server Cache and describes forwarders and conditional forwarding.  Cherokee describes some of the different resource records that Server Admins should become familiar with in the day to day operations of DNS.  Lastly, she describes the use of Round Robin DNS.
episodes.title: Managing the DNS Server Role

>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue with the DNS Server management first by demonstrating the default round robin configuration of DNS.  Cherokee also goes on to describe the use of scavenging and shows how to identify the timestamp and TTL used in the process.  She also demonstrates the ability to force scavenging to occur too.
episodes.title: Managing the DNS Server Role Part 2

That's kind of a creepy term?

Not as creepy as you might think.

There's a lot of information associated

85

so I wanna just take a second and

86
00:05:19.157 --> 00:05:22.920
Every time a resource record is created.

87
00:05:22.920 --> 00:05:25.488
So here, I have my little resource record.

88
00:05:25.488 --> 00:05:30.380
There's gonna be a time stamp that's

89
00:05:30.380 --> 00:05:35.093
So, To make sure that that

90
00:05:35.093 --> 00:05:39.460
up to date there's communications

91
00:05:39.460 --> 00:05:44.340
So we haven't really talked about dynamic
updating with DNS, but what happened

92
00:05:44.340 --> 00:05:49.290
is those clients configured with dynamic
updating are going to be reaching out to

93
00:05:49.290 --> 00:05:53.080
that DNS server to say, hey I'm Still
here, this is my information.

94
00:05:53.080 --> 00:05:56.010
So that's gonna be
generating network traffic.

95
00:05:56.010 --> 00:05:59.060
And depending on your

96
00:05:59.060 --> 00:06:02.160
amount of bandwidth that you have

97
00:06:02.160 --> 00:06:03.932
That could be something

98
00:06:03.932 --> 00:06:07.682
So Microsoft came up with this idea of,

99
00:06:07.682 --> 00:06:12.740
let's kind of reduce that flow

100
00:06:12.740 --> 00:06:16.527
So we have two different intervals here.

101
00:06:16.527 --> 00:06:21.103
We have a no refresh interval and
a refresh interval that assist with

102
00:06:21.103 --> 00:06:25.036

103

that there aren't any older,
stale records within that DNS server,

104
00:06:29.771 --> 00:06:33.600
they're like those records you just saw,

105
00:06:33.600 --> 00:06:38.960
So, I really wanted to break these two

106
00:06:38.960 --> 00:06:43.320
intervals that Microsoft calls out,
and those are gonna be settings there.

107
00:06:43.320 --> 00:06:47.627
So one is called the No Refresh interval.

108
00:06:47.627 --> 00:06:51.632
So both of these intervals by default are
set for seven days which are completely

109
00:06:51.632 --> 00:06:54.670
configurable you can change

110
00:06:54.670 --> 00:06:57.450
But during this first increment

111
00:06:57.450 --> 00:07:00.666
during this no refresh interval

112
00:07:00.666 --> 00:07:05.910
Then the time stamping information can't
be changed but service information

113
00:07:05.910 --> 00:07:11.710
such as IP addresses and ports can be
modified on that particular record.

114
00:07:11.710 --> 00:07:14.900
Once we exceed that no
refresh interval and

115
00:07:14.900 --> 00:07:20.660
move into our refresh interval which
by default again is another seven days,

116
00:07:20.660 --> 00:07:25.728
I can also I have the ability to

117
00:07:25.728 --> 00:07:30.547
So here, I'm not gonna be changing any
kind of IP address or service information.

118
00:07:30.547 --> 00:07:36.060
But I do have the ability to go ahead and
change the time stamp.

119
00:07:36.060 --> 00:07:38.982
So what I wanted to do is kinda
break that down for you, so just,

120
00:07:38.982 --> 00:07:42.291
here we have an example, let's say
we had a record that was created on,

121
00:07:42.291 --> 00:07:44.301
we're going into the future here Ronnie.

00:07:44.301 --> 00:07:45.930
>> Into the future.

123
00:07:45.930 --> 00:07:48.190
>> So, December 1st of 2017,

124
00:07:48.190 --> 00:07:53.230
and we'll keep the defaults let's just

00:07:53.230 --> 00:07:57.930
changes can be made to that particular
record up until December 7 of 2017.

126
00:07:57.930 --> 00:08:03.440
But only time stamp changes can be
made thereafter and if no changes have

127
00:08:03.440 --> 00:08:08.300
been made by the 14th then the settings
and, and, that's a big and right here.

128
00:08:08.300 --> 00:08:09.952
I should have made it extra bold.

129
00:08:09.952 --> 00:08:13.210
And the settings have been
configured correctly.

130
00:08:13.210 --> 00:08:19.063
Then the record can be scavenged or

131
00:08:19.063 --> 00:08:24.982
All right, so remember, DNS cache and

Cache, volatile,
we do have the ability to go ahead and

134
00:08:33.387 --> 00:08:35.918
but it's two separate concepts here.

135
00:08:35.918 --> 00:08:37.290
So scavenging as well.

136
00:08:38.520 --> 00:08:41.510
All right, so where do we go ahead and

137
00:08:41.510 --> 00:08:45.984
Let me make sure I reset lab so

And then we can go ahead and

All right.

There're a lot of different

So just keep that in mind, that's a weird

But this is where that timestamp that

That's not a lot of time, as your TTL

I could go ahead and increase that TTL for

Because if that record had the incorrect,

their incorrect IP address, and
you couldn't connect to me,

00:12:06.390 --> 00:12:09.920
Ronnie, big deal,
that's only one user, right?

186
00:12:09.920 --> 00:12:12.770
So, if I wasn't able,
if I had stale information.

187
00:12:12.770 --> 00:12:17.892
Say, I changed the IP address for

00:12:17.892 --> 00:12:24.282
hours I should be able to know that

189
00:12:24.282 --> 00:12:27.648
Yes, they're generating more traffic,
but that's just kind of a trade-off or

190
00:12:27.648 --> 00:12:30.820
hand-off that you kinda have to

191
00:12:30.820 --> 00:12:33.811
So, same thing goes here for

192
00:12:33.811 --> 00:12:36.369
So, let's say I'm closing in lets

193
00:12:36.369 --> 00:12:41.000
say we kept those seven day
defaults that I just showed you.

194
00:12:41.000 --> 00:12:46.412
And I'm in my second interval period

195
00:12:46.412 --> 00:12:50.266
I said you know I wanna go ahead and
extend my time stamp so

00:12:50.266 --> 00:12:53.552

197
00:12:53.552 --> 00:12:57.645
Or, I could go ahead and shorten that

00:12:57.645 --> 00:12:59.460
that particular record.

199
00:12:59.460 --> 00:13:01.260
And that's something discretionary,

200
00:13:01.260 --> 00:13:03.820
just an option that we have the ability
to go ahead and change there.

201
00:13:05.092 --> 00:13:06.029
All right, so now what do we doe here?

202
00:13:06.029 --> 00:13:09.528
So, we saw our time stamp information.

Now there's gonna be this tick box
right here that says delete this
