205
00:13:16.820 --> 00:13:21.330
So like I said, by default dynamic
records will have that tick box enable,

206
00:13:21.330 --> 00:13:23.290
manual records like this one will not, so

207
00:13:23.290 --> 00:13:26.080
we'll definitely make sure that
that that is checked there.

208
00:13:26.080 --> 00:13:30.260
And then we'll go ahead and If you wanted
to keep this window open, you could.

209
00:13:30.260 --> 00:13:32.810
But we're just gonna go ahead and
select OK here.

210
00:13:32.810 --> 00:13:36.840
>> So that tick box, essentially, is what
allows us to scavenge that record, right?

211
00:13:36.840 --> 00:13:38.290
>> Yeah, it's giving it the go-ahead.

212
00:13:38.290 --> 00:13:40.305
But that's not all we have to do here.

213
00:13:40.305 --> 00:13:42.090
There're a couple other
things that we need to do.

214
00:13:42.090 --> 00:13:45.679
We also need to configure this option for
that zone as well.

215
00:13:45.679 --> 00:13:49.923
So If you go ahead and
right-click on your zone,

216
00:13:49.923 --> 00:13:55.100
then this is going to be
listed under Properties.

217
00:13:55.100 --> 00:13:59.340
And then, they call it here it's
just going to be under Aging.

218
00:13:59.340 --> 00:14:03.418
So let me zoom in a little bit, so you'll
see that's where you're actually gonna be

219
00:14:03.418 --> 00:14:06.587
studying that scavenging here
under Properties and then Aging.

220
00:14:06.587 --> 00:14:09.760
And you'll also need to make sure
that this is selected just by making

221
00:14:09.760 --> 00:14:13.261
sure that tick box is selected is not
gonna be, you're not finished there so

222
00:14:13.261 --> 00:14:15.170
it's important to note that.

223
00:14:15.170 --> 00:14:15.922
All right so,

224
00:14:15.922 --> 00:14:19.630
here this is the second tick box that
you have to make sure is selected.

225
00:14:19.630 --> 00:14:24.630
Up in the top left hand corner it says,
Scavenge stale resource records.

226
00:14:24.630 --> 00:14:27.970
And here you can see those
no refresh interval, again,

227
00:14:27.970 --> 00:14:33.320
are seven day default, whereas our
refresh interval, seven day default.

228
00:14:33.320 --> 00:14:35.870
And then it tells you when you
can actually be scavenged.

229
00:14:35.870 --> 00:14:38.730
So we'll hit OK here.

230
00:14:38.730 --> 00:14:43.330
And at this point in
time you're good to go.

231
00:14:43.330 --> 00:14:47.406
You do also have the ability
to go ahead and right click,

232
00:14:47.406 --> 00:14:51.939
and configure it for sets aging and
scavenging for all zones.

233
00:14:51.939 --> 00:14:56.692
In the past, in older versions
of Microsoft like Server,

234
00:14:56.692 --> 00:14:59.319
I think it was Server 2012.

235
00:14:59.319 --> 00:15:04.638
It was kind of strange how they
had it configured because the name

236
00:15:04.638 --> 00:15:09.280
would imply server aging and
scavenging for all zones.

237
00:15:09.280 --> 00:15:12.030
But it was only set for
active directory zones.

238
00:15:12.030 --> 00:15:15.090
So just to be on the safe
side I would go through, and

239
00:15:15.090 --> 00:15:17.450
those first two steps that I showed you,
I would go in and

240
00:15:17.450 --> 00:15:21.210
set them individually like that instead of
just relying on that one configuration.

241
00:15:21.210 --> 00:15:24.580
Because, even if you set just
that one configuration but

242
00:15:24.580 --> 00:15:26.740
you don't have the actual
tickbox to verify.

243
00:15:26.740 --> 00:15:31.052
And within that particular record it's
not going to be set to be purged or

244
00:15:31.052 --> 00:15:35.025
scavenged from that DNS server, so
just keep that in mind as well.

245
00:15:35.025 --> 00:15:35.890
>> All right, Cherokee.

246
00:15:35.890 --> 00:15:36.535
So thank you for

247
00:15:36.535 --> 00:15:39.724
showing us the idea of being able to
scavenged those according to schedule.

248
00:15:39.724 --> 00:15:43.615
Is there a way that we can actually
control that scavenging better such as I

249
00:15:43.615 --> 00:15:44.819
wanna do it right now?

250
00:15:44.819 --> 00:15:48.214
>> Yeah, so good question Ronnie if we
take a look at my screen here we can see

251
00:15:48.214 --> 00:15:50.848
that if I go ahead and
right-click on top of the server.

252
00:15:50.848 --> 00:15:55.470
There's an option to go ahead and
let's see here.

253
00:15:55.470 --> 00:15:59.791
Scavenge stale resource records, so by
selecting that you're gonna go ahead and

254
00:15:59.791 --> 00:16:01.555
force that scavenging process.

255
00:16:01.555 --> 00:16:05.094
And I also wanted to
clarify something here.

256
00:16:05.094 --> 00:16:09.307
You do need to have scavenging
enabled at the server level as well or

257
00:16:09.307 --> 00:16:10.745
it's not gonna work.

258
00:16:10.745 --> 00:16:14.917
And so in those three places there you
definitely wanna just verify that.

259
00:16:14.917 --> 00:16:17.890
And I did remember about one
other thing here, Ronnie.

260
00:16:17.890 --> 00:16:23.010
If we take a look here at those different
records, the reason why we didn't see that

261
00:16:23.010 --> 00:16:28.140
TTL or time stamp for those static records
are records that I had created here.

262
00:16:28.140 --> 00:16:33.194
You see that these ones are missing that
time stamp over here in this column and

263
00:16:33.194 --> 00:16:36.324
that's because we had
manually created them.

264
00:16:36.324 --> 00:16:40.511
But if we were to select the one right
above it, and you can see all those listed

265
00:16:40.511 --> 00:16:45.090
on the right side here, they do have that
information that's brought in there, but

266
00:16:45.090 --> 00:16:46.400
we just didn't see it.

267
00:16:48.160 --> 00:16:49.232
From our end because we had made those.

268
00:16:49.232 --> 00:16:51.960
But I think that's about
it at this level for

269
00:16:51.960 --> 00:16:56.290
DNS when we're talking about
these topics and scavenging.

270
00:16:56.290 --> 00:17:00.200
>> All right Cherokee, well thank you for
helping us here as we take a look at that

271
00:17:00.200 --> 00:17:06.090
idea of using round robin to help us
to set this up for those records,

272
00:17:06.090 --> 00:17:09.580
making sure of course that we can
divide up the resources as we need to.

273
00:17:09.580 --> 00:17:14.530
It is a poor man's type of load balancing,
but it can work effectively especially

274
00:17:14.530 --> 00:17:18.520
when you do have an organization
hitting that server all at one time.

275
00:17:18.520 --> 00:17:20.590
So it may be an easy way to do that.

276
00:17:20.590 --> 00:17:23.390
Also the idea of scavenging
is a good thing for

277
00:17:23.390 --> 00:17:27.410
most Active Directory networks, in the
very fact that it allows us not to keep

278
00:17:27.410 --> 00:17:31.280
those stale records which could
point to a wrong machine at times.

279
00:17:31.280 --> 00:17:36.220
So getting that set up, remembering it's
not only a tick box in one location, but

280
00:17:36.220 --> 00:17:38.873
remembering that you have to
do it per record at times,

281
00:17:38.873 --> 00:17:43.240
you may have to do it per the zone and
maybe even for the server as well.

282
00:17:43.240 --> 00:17:45.860
And that way, getting it configured
the way that you want to is a little bit

283
00:17:45.860 --> 00:17:48.100
beyond what we're gonna see
right here in Server 101.

284
00:17:48.100 --> 00:17:52.070
But for those of you that are actually
going forward towards your MCSA

285
00:17:52.070 --> 00:17:54.280
you'll see those settings also there and

286
00:17:54.280 --> 00:17:56.830
you'll talk about them much more in
depth than what we've covered here.

287
00:17:56.830 --> 00:18:00.201
But at least you've been exposed to
the idea of scavenging right here as well.

288
00:18:00.201 --> 00:18:03.026
Alright, well that's a great place for
us to take this time and

289
00:18:03.026 --> 00:18:04.799
opportunity to end this episode then.

290
00:18:04.799 --> 00:18:08.320
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

291
00:18:08.320 --> 00:18:10.918
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose
>> Stay tuned right here for

292
00:18:10.918 --> 00:18:12.909
more Windows Server 101.

293
00:18:12.909 --> 00:18:18.978
[MUSIC]

294
00:18:18.978 --> 00:18:22.033
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee show how to create and work with standard DNS zones.  Cherokee explains the use of the Primary Zones and Secondary Zones.  She also creates them through the DNS Console.  She explains also how the secondary DNS zone gets its zone transfer and the differences between full zone transfers and incremental zone transfers.
episodes.title: Working with DNS Zones
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.019 --> 00:00:01.619
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.619 --> 00:00:06.078
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.078 --> 00:00:08.224
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.224 --> 00:00:11.323
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.323 --> 00:00:14.853
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.853 --> 00:00:16.681
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

7
00:00:16.681 --> 00:00:19.717
today you're watching
the Windows Server 101 show.

8
00:00:19.717 --> 00:00:22.474
We're about to dive into using DNS zones,

9
00:00:22.474 --> 00:00:27.157
and here to help us get started with
them is gonna be Miss Cherokee Boose.

10
00:00:27.157 --> 00:00:28.153
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:28.153 --> 00:00:29.059
>> Yeah, thanks for having me.

12
00:00:29.059 --> 00:00:29.953
How are you doing today, Ronnie?

13
00:00:29.953 --> 00:00:34.300
>> I am almost doing fine today,
so great to be here.

14
00:00:34.300 --> 00:00:39.090
Cherokee, help us out, DNS is one
of the biggest topics that we have.

15
00:00:39.090 --> 00:00:41.295
Help us by giving us
a little bit of a rundown,

16
00:00:41.295 --> 00:00:45.079
as we've gone through a lot of DNS so
far, and then help us out with the zones.

17
00:00:45.079 --> 00:00:48.131
>> We really have, and
I know it seems like a lot, but

18
00:00:48.131 --> 00:00:50.037
DNS is a very important topic.

19
00:00:50.037 --> 00:00:53.117
So I just kinda wanna recap some of
the topics that we have covered,

20
00:00:53.117 --> 00:00:55.260
that you have learned already.

21
00:00:55.260 --> 00:00:59.791
We've covered quite a bit, so we've
looked at things like name resolution,

22
00:00:59.791 --> 00:01:04.474
actually performing, going through that
process and how that actually works.

23
00:01:04.474 --> 00:01:06.228
Starting with our route servers and

24
00:01:06.228 --> 00:01:09.981
then propagating all the way down to
our clients, we've spoke about that.

25
00:01:09.981 --> 00:01:13.131
We've also looked at the different
kinds of queries out there,

26
00:01:13.131 --> 00:01:16.937
recursive versus iterative queries,
and the differences between the two.

27
00:01:16.937 --> 00:01:21.719
We've also talked about manual
ways in which we can override

28
00:01:21.719 --> 00:01:26.312
this DNS process with our host file and
our LAN host file for

29
00:01:26.312 --> 00:01:32.100
older naming systems,
like utilizing BIOS with our Win servers.

30
00:01:32.100 --> 00:01:36.261
We've also talked about caching on both
the client side as well as the server

31
00:01:36.261 --> 00:01:40.226
side, and how we can clear out our cache,
why we would want to do that, or

32
00:01:40.226 --> 00:01:43.763
why we wouldn't want to go ahead and
clear out the entire cache.

33
00:01:43.763 --> 00:01:48.700
We've also talked about different
types of tools that we can use.

34
00:01:48.700 --> 00:01:52.853
Of course you guys have seen us, through
the DNS server manager, using the GUI,

35
00:01:52.853 --> 00:01:54.883
we've used a lot of PowerShell so far.

36
00:01:54.883 --> 00:01:59.755
We've talked about using older commands
that have been around within your command

37
00:01:59.755 --> 00:02:00.319
prompt.

38
00:02:00.319 --> 00:02:03.754
We can even import those into our,
and use them within PowerShell.

39
00:02:03.754 --> 00:02:08.261
DNS, CMD, we even spoke about
different operating systems and

40
00:02:08.261 --> 00:02:11.320
tools that they may be able to use.

41
00:02:11.320 --> 00:02:14.141
We also talked about using
the DNS server service,

42
00:02:14.141 --> 00:02:18.671
we've looked at different things like
forwarders and conditional forwarders,

43
00:02:18.671 --> 00:02:22.621
and we're gonna kind of bring that
into this discussion today as well.

44
00:02:22.621 --> 00:02:26.812
And we've spoke about round robin and
scavenging, and

45
00:02:26.812 --> 00:02:31.016
then also looking at,
talking about different zones.

46
00:02:31.016 --> 00:02:34.956
But that's where we're going to
start today, is really defining and

47
00:02:34.956 --> 00:02:36.705
discussing different zones.

48
00:02:36.705 --> 00:02:39.050
There are gonna be four
different types of zones.

49
00:02:39.050 --> 00:02:44.623
So we've got our primary, and then
primary with Active Directory integrated.

50
00:02:44.623 --> 00:02:49.900
Although people really don't say primary
with Active Directory integrated.

51
00:02:49.900 --> 00:02:55.040
You really wanna distinguish the
difference between a primary standard and

52
00:02:55.040 --> 00:02:57.400
a primary with
Active Directory integrated.

53
00:02:57.400 --> 00:03:00.668
So normally people will just say
Active Directory integrated, so those two.

54
00:03:00.668 --> 00:03:05.033
You also have secondary, and
then we will also cover stub zones.

55
00:03:05.033 --> 00:03:09.519
So let's go ahead and start at
the beginning with standard primary zones.

56
00:03:09.519 --> 00:03:12.746
So if we could go ahead and take a look
at my screen, that would be great.

57
00:03:12.746 --> 00:03:16.681
And I know this doesn't seem like
very a lot of information here, so

58
00:03:16.681 --> 00:03:20.010
I'm gonna try to explain this
to you as best as I can here.

59
00:03:20.010 --> 00:03:25.556
Ronnie, have you ever been to a social
setting where, maybe like a barbecue or

60
00:03:25.556 --> 00:03:31.117
something like that, and there's always
this one loud, obnoxious person?

61
00:03:31.117 --> 00:03:34.217
>> Well, I'm probably the loud,
obnoxious person.

62
00:03:34.217 --> 00:03:36.179
>> I know, me too,
I probably am that person, too.

63
00:03:36.179 --> 00:03:39.829
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, yes I have.

64
00:03:39.829 --> 00:03:43.939
>> Let's just say we got really lucky,
you and I were both at this same event.

65
00:03:43.939 --> 00:03:48.702
There were two loud and obnoxious people,
and then, let's say you were to go

66
00:03:48.702 --> 00:03:52.751
ahead and approach Ronnie and I,
and you had to use the restroom.

67
00:03:52.751 --> 00:03:55.933
And you said, hey guys,
where's the restroom?

68
00:03:55.933 --> 00:03:58.646
And Ronnie starts yelling at you,
I start yelling at you.

69
00:03:58.646 --> 00:04:02.895
And the thing is, I tell you, you gotta go
down the hall, and Ronnie said no, no, no,

70
00:04:02.895 --> 00:04:05.287
that one's out of order,
you have to go upstairs.

71
00:04:05.287 --> 00:04:08.511
And you just start to get confused and
it's just too much, and

72
00:04:08.511 --> 00:04:09.814
things start to happen.

73
00:04:09.814 --> 00:04:13.031
And hopefully you don't have an accident,
right?

74
00:04:13.031 --> 00:04:17.222
So that's not what we want to have
happen when we're talking about DNS.

75
00:04:17.222 --> 00:04:21.470
So, [LAUGH] Ronnie's laughing at me here,
hold on, I'm going somewhere with this,

76
00:04:21.470 --> 00:04:22.063
I promise.

77
00:04:22.063 --> 00:04:23.723
>> Yeah you are, literally.

78
00:04:23.723 --> 00:04:26.534
[LAUGH]
>> So if we can look back at my screen,

79
00:04:26.534 --> 00:04:30.155
that's what we don't want to have
happen when we're talking about DNS.

80
00:04:30.155 --> 00:04:32.314
So if I had two individuals, or

81
00:04:32.314 --> 00:04:36.966
two primary zones in which clients
were requesting information,

82
00:04:36.966 --> 00:04:42.381
they're not always going to be synched
up and contain the same information.

83
00:04:42.381 --> 00:04:45.751
So I might get conflicting information,
so that's not something we want to have,

84
00:04:45.751 --> 00:04:47.303
it's not even something we can have.

85
00:04:47.303 --> 00:04:50.260
So by the architecture here is,

86
00:04:50.260 --> 00:04:54.978
we're going to go ahead and
have one primary zone.

87
00:04:54.978 --> 00:04:57.447
And a zone, if you think about it, so

88
00:04:57.447 --> 00:05:02.760
it's a DNS server that contains a rule
set of how information is shared.

89
00:05:02.760 --> 00:05:04.569
And that's kinda what that term means,
a zone.

90
00:05:04.569 --> 00:05:07.933
So if you think about it like that, so

91
00:05:07.933 --> 00:05:12.824
here I have my primary zone,
I can only have one here.

92
00:05:12.824 --> 00:05:17.551
Now this is a read, write, copy, and
that's important because when we

93
00:05:17.551 --> 00:05:22.276
talk about our secondary zones,
those are only going to be read copies,

94
00:05:22.276 --> 00:05:25.859
because I don't want
conflicts within information.

95
00:05:25.859 --> 00:05:30.887
So I wanna make sure the information that
I'm giving out is true and accurate.

96
00:05:30.887 --> 00:05:33.927
So let's say this
individual PC right here,

97
00:05:33.927 --> 00:05:37.760
this client had some kind
of IP address change.

98
00:05:37.760 --> 00:05:41.337
So they would go ahead,
any kind of information change,

99
00:05:41.337 --> 00:05:43.505
I would send to this primary zone.

100
00:05:43.505 --> 00:05:48.067
This is the read, write, copy, so
this is where those changes would happen.

101
00:05:48.067 --> 00:05:52.994
From that, my primary zone
would propagate those changes

102
00:05:52.994 --> 00:05:56.725
to secondary zones within my environment.

103
00:05:56.725 --> 00:06:01.351
And that helps because end
users could go ahead and

104
00:06:01.351 --> 00:06:05.547
receive information from secondary zones.

105
00:06:05.547 --> 00:06:09.800
But then they would be able to
send their changes to the primary.

106
00:06:09.800 --> 00:06:14.970
So we're kind of offsetting
that work balance or

107
00:06:14.970 --> 00:06:19.400
that load there, so we're implementing
a form of load balancing here.

108
00:06:19.400 --> 00:06:23.995
If you think about it,
we're also implementing fault tolerance,

109
00:06:23.995 --> 00:06:29.328
because if this machine were to go down,
okay, well, who would be affected?

110
00:06:29.328 --> 00:06:33.098
Well, anyone who wanted to make a machine
would not be able to make a machine,

111
00:06:33.098 --> 00:06:34.200
a change, excuse me,

112
00:06:34.200 --> 00:06:37.692
anyone would not be able to make a change
to this machine if it were down.

113
00:06:37.692 --> 00:06:42.504
But they still would be able to
obtain DNS information while that

114
00:06:42.504 --> 00:06:47.800
primary was down, because there
are copies of the secondaries.

115
00:06:47.800 --> 00:06:52.152
So, I don't know if that makes sense, but
it's a good start for you, because we're

116
00:06:52.152 --> 00:06:55.676
gonna go through and look at how we
can go ahead and set all of these up.

117
00:06:55.676 --> 00:06:58.687
And just make sure that this
concept is really there for

118
00:06:58.687 --> 00:07:00.329
you because it is important.

119
00:07:01.884 --> 00:07:05.618
All right, let's go ahead and

120
00:07:05.618 --> 00:07:10.320
take a look at my machine here again.

121
00:07:10.320 --> 00:07:12.606
And let's see what machine
are we working with.

122
00:07:17.286 --> 00:07:22.760
All right, so this is going to be
domain controller, plabdc01, and what

123
00:07:22.760 --> 00:07:28.422
I wanna do at this time is, I wanna go
ahead and create a standard primary zone.

124
00:07:28.422 --> 00:07:34.419
So I can go ahead and
pull up my DNS Management Console here.

125
00:07:34.419 --> 00:07:40.526
And currently, I can see that I
do have my machine listed here.

126
00:07:40.526 --> 00:07:44.950
But we can just right-click on
top of that, and select New Zone.

127
00:07:44.950 --> 00:07:49.682
And it brings up a wizard for
us, which is really nice.

128
00:07:49.682 --> 00:07:54.993
It's really easy to go ahead and
set these up, so we're just going to go

129
00:07:54.993 --> 00:08:01.031
through this to make sure you understand,
and let me zoom in a little bit for you.

130
00:08:01.031 --> 00:08:03.004
Did that zoom?

131
00:08:03.004 --> 00:08:04.730
No, okay, there we go.

132
00:08:04.730 --> 00:08:09.201
So this is a very small portion
down here but it's very important.

133
00:08:09.201 --> 00:08:13.123
It's almost like, you really want to
pay attention here because it says,

134
00:08:13.123 --> 00:08:15.760
what kind of zone are you going to create?

135
00:08:15.760 --> 00:08:18.350
And these are the different types
of zones that I mentioned to you.

136
00:08:18.350 --> 00:08:23.000
Our primary zone,
our secondary zone, our stub zone.

137
00:08:23.000 --> 00:08:25.880
But that primary zone integrated
with Active Directory,

138
00:08:25.880 --> 00:08:30.150
this is that check box down here
that you wanna be cognizant of.

139
00:08:30.150 --> 00:08:31.830
Currently I'm gonna uncheck that,

140
00:08:31.830 --> 00:08:34.760
because we're not creating
an Active Directory Integrated Zone,

141
00:08:34.760 --> 00:08:38.880
we'll speak more on that later,
we're creating a standard zone.

142
00:08:38.880 --> 00:08:40.480
All right, so we'll just hit Next.

143
00:08:42.290 --> 00:08:46.060
I will also show you how to create
a reverse lookup zone, but remember,

144
00:08:46.060 --> 00:08:49.080
forward lookup zones are going
to be taking that hostname and

145
00:08:49.080 --> 00:08:51.380
resolving that to IP addresses.

146
00:08:51.380 --> 00:08:55.059
Reverse lookup zones are simply
the transverse, the opposite of that so

147

00:23:40.160 --> 00:23:42.270
Now, this is gonna take a second,

376
00:23:42.270 --> 00:23:45.790
especially depending on the size
in that particular zone.

377
00:23:45.790 --> 00:23:50.686
We don't have a lot noted here, but you'll
see that it still does take a few moments,

378
00:23:50.686 --> 00:23:52.669
even if I go up under my action tab.

379
00:23:52.669 --> 00:23:54.212
This information is grayed here,

380
00:23:54.212 --> 00:23:57.734
grayed out because it's actually
performing this action, the background.

381
00:23:57.734 --> 00:24:02.022
But just give it a second and
you may even need to hit refresh.

382
00:24:02.022 --> 00:24:06.960
And you'll see that option
come back whenever it's ready.

383
00:24:06.960 --> 00:24:09.470
See now how the refresh option is there?

384
00:24:09.470 --> 00:24:11.160
And it wasn't there
just a few seconds ago.

385
00:24:11.160 --> 00:24:15.398
Now if I hit refresh,
I can see the information propagate.

386
00:24:15.398 --> 00:24:19.840
These are gonna be the clients we had
created previously from our primary zone.

387
00:24:19.840 --> 00:24:21.360
But I do wanna show you something.

388
00:24:21.360 --> 00:24:23.145
Let's say let's go ahead and
click on Client01.

389
00:24:24.460 --> 00:24:29.630
Whenever I look at this information,
this is also grayed out, okay?

390
00:24:29.630 --> 00:24:34.280
And that's because I cannot make any
changes to a secondary zone, right?

391
00:24:34.280 --> 00:24:38.563
This is only a readable copy,
so I can't make any changes,

392
00:24:38.563 --> 00:24:41.057
I can't create new host records.

393
00:24:41.057 --> 00:24:44.935
So if I right-click here, I don't have
that option to go ahead and create new.

394
00:24:44.935 --> 00:24:48.165
So hopefully,
you can understand how that works.

395
00:24:48.165 --> 00:24:50.162
We've got our primary and
we got our secondary.

396
00:24:50.162 --> 00:24:54.497
Our secondary receives that
information from our primary or

397
00:24:54.497 --> 00:24:56.370
however we configure it.

398
00:24:56.370 --> 00:24:59.877
We had to specify who we
wanted to get that from,

399
00:24:59.877 --> 00:25:03.309
but that's one way we
can use standard zones.

400
00:25:03.309 --> 00:25:06.986
>> All right, Cherokee, so the idea
here of creating the standard zones for

401
00:25:06.986 --> 00:25:10.958
what we're actually doing does give us
that different way of making sure that we

402
00:25:10.958 --> 00:25:14.841
can not have to be worried about whether
or not we're on a domain controller.

403
00:25:14.841 --> 00:25:17.040
Or whether we need to integrate
in with other things.

404
00:25:17.040 --> 00:25:21.098
Being able to use the primary and the
secondary zones are actually good things

405
00:25:21.098 --> 00:25:23.795
for us to be able to understand and
setting up here.

406
00:25:23.795 --> 00:25:27.959
And seeing all the tabs, it does look like
a fairly complex thing at the beginning,

407
00:25:27.959 --> 00:25:29.639
but don't be intimidated by it.

408
00:25:29.639 --> 00:25:34.171
And go, make sure you at least understand
the concepts of those standard types

409
00:25:34.171 --> 00:25:34.796
of zones.

410
00:25:34.796 --> 00:25:39.710
Now, Cherokee, what makes the standard
zone different than, let's say,

411
00:25:39.710 --> 00:25:40.850
that other zone?

412
00:25:40.850 --> 00:25:45.600
Where is this normally gonna be stored,
the information that we find here?

413
00:25:45.600 --> 00:25:49.050
>> So the information that you find,
the standard zone,

414
00:25:49.050 --> 00:25:53.040
like I said, it's gonna be
stored on that local machine.

415
00:25:53.040 --> 00:25:56.450
And one thing we can do
is modify it directly.

416
00:25:56.450 --> 00:25:59.422
So it stored within that hard drive and
it's stored within a DNS file.

417
00:25:59.422 --> 00:26:00.699
So let's see here.

418
00:26:00.699 --> 00:26:01.918
I can show you guys actually.

419
00:26:01.918 --> 00:26:03.800
This is the domain member.

420
00:26:03.800 --> 00:26:06.956
Let me get on the other machine,
and we'll show you.

421
00:26:10.336 --> 00:26:14.945
All right,
this is going to be the domain controller.

422
00:26:14.945 --> 00:26:21.816
Okay, so if I go ahead and navigate
down and pull up my C drive here and

423
00:26:21.816 --> 00:26:26.416
then let's go under Windows, System32.

424
00:26:30.526 --> 00:26:32.395
And then there's a DNS folder.

425
00:26:35.530 --> 00:26:38.690
Okay, and let me zoom in a little bit so
you guys can see this.

426
00:26:38.690 --> 00:26:42.344
Now this is that particular zone
that we had created, right?

427
00:26:42.344 --> 00:26:47.411
So if I go ahead and right-click and
select Open with, I can see,

428
00:26:47.411 --> 00:26:52.124
let's see, you can't open this
type of file, one second.

429
00:26:52.124 --> 00:26:53.203
>> It's not an Apple, that's PC.

430
00:26:53.203 --> 00:26:55.525
>> Yeah, but
we wanna open it with Notepad.

431
00:26:55.525 --> 00:26:59.091
And sometimes you can use
another tool like Notepad++ and

432
00:26:59.091 --> 00:27:03.166
it has additional integrated features
that are built just for DNS.

433
00:27:03.166 --> 00:27:05.880
But this is just regular
old Notepad right here.

434
00:27:07.440 --> 00:27:11.200
And this is where that information
is stored, it's just a regular file.

435
00:27:11.200 --> 00:27:13.610
That is something that we
should be concerned with.

436
00:27:13.610 --> 00:27:16.630
Because just like any other
kind of file on a system,

437
00:27:16.630 --> 00:27:21.185
it can be modified, it can be viewed.

438
00:27:21.185 --> 00:27:24.625
So we do need to consider that when
we're thinking about security.

439
00:27:24.625 --> 00:27:26.225
You can see our clients right here.

440
00:27:26.225 --> 00:27:30.219
We have client 01, we have client 02 with
those A records, and as a matter of fact,

441
00:27:30.219 --> 00:27:32.816
let's go ahead and
let's create another client here.

442
00:27:32.816 --> 00:27:36.823
So let's just say, being super creative,

443
00:27:36.823 --> 00:27:40.514
we'll say client 03 with an A record.

444
00:27:40.514 --> 00:27:46.517
And the IP address there
will be 192.168.0.8 and

445
00:27:46.517 --> 00:27:50.173
we'll go ahead and hit File > Save.

446
00:27:50.173 --> 00:27:53.675
What's really cool about
these standard zones too is I

447
00:27:53.675 --> 00:27:55.891
had mentioned that flexibility.

448
00:27:55.891 --> 00:28:00.573
So the syntax, the layout, the typing
of this particular Notepad file looks

449
00:28:00.573 --> 00:28:05.256
the same regardless of what other type
of DNS service, if you're on a Unix and

450
00:28:05.256 --> 00:28:09.384
you're using BIND or something else,
the syntax will be the same.

451
00:28:09.384 --> 00:28:13.180
So that's what allows that
simplicity there, the flexibility.

452
00:28:13.180 --> 00:28:17.347
All right, so we'll go ahead and
close and back on up here and

453
00:28:17.347 --> 00:28:20.716
let's go back into our
DNS Management Console.

454
00:28:20.716 --> 00:28:22.876
And I think I have it up, yeah.

455
00:28:22.876 --> 00:28:26.824
All right, it'll take a second to go
ahead and propagate that information.

456
00:28:26.824 --> 00:28:32.878
I may even need just to go in here and
hit refresh so I can see that client 03.

457
00:28:32.878 --> 00:28:34.700
And I might have to talk more, but

458
00:28:34.700 --> 00:28:39.610
it will eventually propagate more in there
because I had manually modified that file.

459
00:28:39.610 --> 00:28:42.398
And then it'll go ahead and show up
right here, but let's try it again.

460
00:28:46.276 --> 00:28:48.265
All right, so
it's just taking a little bit.

461
00:28:48.265 --> 00:28:50.869
But this is where that information,
and you can do all sorts of things.

462
00:28:50.869 --> 00:28:55.771
You can even modify that particular
text file using the dnsmd command

463
00:28:55.771 --> 00:28:59.334
without actually going
through a GUI interface.

464
00:28:59.334 --> 00:29:04.262
So if you have DMS stored or
running on a Server Core installation,

465
00:29:04.262 --> 00:29:07.606
you could essentially
be performing the same

466
00:29:07.606 --> 00:29:13.130
function just via commandline
interface instead of a GUI as well.

467
00:29:13.130 --> 00:29:15.794
All right, I have to check one
more time to see if it's in there.

468
00:29:15.794 --> 00:29:19.543
Okay, I still don't see it in there,
but you get the point.

469
00:29:19.543 --> 00:29:24.617
That's where he should be, and I just
don't have any more patience, Ronnie.

470
00:29:24.617 --> 00:29:25.825
I think we're out of time for this show.

471
00:29:25.825 --> 00:29:28.504
[LAUGH]
>> All right, Cherokee, there's no doubt

472
00:29:28.504 --> 00:29:31.874
we are up against a hard break for
us at this particular point in time.

473
00:29:31.874 --> 00:29:35.080
But what we did get to see
in this episode, of course,

474
00:29:35.080 --> 00:29:38.235
is that idea of creating
a standard type of DNS zone.

475
00:29:38.235 --> 00:29:42.469
Whether we're talking about doing
a primary or a secondary, well,

476
00:29:42.469 --> 00:29:46.557
that the idea of zones here is really
a database of those domain name

477
00:29:46.557 --> 00:29:50.430
records that we actually want
linked up to those IP addresses.

478
00:29:50.430 --> 00:29:54.130
And those are essential things
when it comes to setting up DNS.

479
00:29:54.130 --> 00:29:56.921
Now there's a lot more to go, we haven't
even covered the other two zones that

480
00:29:56.921 --> 00:29:59.340
Cherokee mentioned at
the beginning of this episode.

481
00:29:59.340 --> 00:30:01.360
So that brings us back for part two and

482
00:30:01.360 --> 00:30:05.730
maybe we'll also be able to see the update
that happens in that zone as well.

483
00:30:05.730 --> 00:30:07.585
>> I actually just did it now so, yeah.

484
00:30:07.585 --> 00:30:08.837
>> Okay.
>> I do wanna show you, though.

485
00:30:08.837 --> 00:30:11.540
Because there's one extra step
that you may need to perform here.

486
00:30:11.540 --> 00:30:16.776
And if you hit reload for that particular
zone, reload and then refresh.

487
00:30:16.776 --> 00:30:20.180
I'm gonna hit No because you can
see that my client is right here.

488
00:30:20.180 --> 00:30:21.628
So I reloaded, and then hit Refresh.

489
00:30:21.628 --> 00:30:27.410
And there's [LAUGH] client03,
so, yep, patience, my young one.

490
00:30:27.410 --> 00:30:29.675
[LAUGH] But that's it for this show.

491
00:30:29.675 --> 00:30:32.136
We do have more DNS,
though, for sure, Ronnie.

492
00:30:32.136 --> 00:30:35.283
>> All right, well, great place for
us to end this episode, then.

493
00:30:35.283 --> 00:30:38.440
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

494
00:30:38.440 --> 00:30:39.336
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

495
00:30:39.336 --> 00:30:42.671
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Windows Server 101 shows.

496
00:30:42.671 --> 00:30:49.769
[MUSIC]

497
00:30:49.769 --> 00:30:52.706
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue working with 2 additional zone types:  Stub Zones and Active-Directory integrated zones.  These types of zones are more prevalent in a Windows Active Directory Environment, according to Cherokee.  She also discusses the different benefits of using these zone types that include replication, secure updates  and dynamic management.
episodes.title: Working with DNS Zones Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.350 --> 00:00:03.542
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.542 --> 00:00:04.655
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.655 --> 00:00:08.095
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.095 --> 00:00:10.721
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.721 --> 00:00:15.054
>> Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.054 --> 00:00:20.130
You're watching the Windows Server 101
show, and I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:20.130 --> 00:00:24.077
Today we're taking a look at part
two on working with DNS zones.

8
00:00:24.077 --> 00:00:27.661
We already talked about covering some
primary zones and some secondary zones,

9
00:00:27.661 --> 00:00:29.704
but there's still a bit more for
us to cover.

10
00:00:29.704 --> 00:00:33.262
And here to help us to make sure that we
understand more about this topic is Ms.

11
00:00:33.262 --> 00:00:34.110
Cherokee Boose.

12
00:00:34.110 --> 00:00:35.256
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

13
00:00:35.256 --> 00:00:36.278
>> Thanks for having me, Ronnie.

14
00:00:36.278 --> 00:00:41.017
Yeah, so we took a look at primary and
we also saw our secondary zones, but

15
00:00:41.017 --> 00:00:45.462
I wanted to talk about stub zones,
beginning in this conversation.

16
00:00:45.462 --> 00:00:48.948
And it's kind of interesting because
stub zones are very, very similar to

17
00:00:48.948 --> 00:00:53.510
something that we've already spoke about,
and that would be conditional forwarding.

18
00:00:53.510 --> 00:00:57.730
So, remember, forwarding is just
going to be like an always on,

19
00:00:57.730 --> 00:01:00.278
always happening type of forwarding.

20
00:01:00.278 --> 00:01:03.638
Conditional forwarding adds an if,
then parameter.

21
00:01:03.638 --> 00:01:08.398
So it says if you're querying for this
particular domain, and I think we had used

22
00:01:08.398 --> 00:01:13.171
an example for like Contoso domain or
something on a diagram we've seen before.

23
00:01:13.171 --> 00:01:17.915
So it says if you're querying an IP
address for a device within the Contoso

24
00:01:17.915 --> 00:01:22.353
domain, then I'm gonna forward you
to the authoritative server for

25
00:01:22.353 --> 00:01:26.505
that Contoso domain to help speed up and
expedite this process.

26
00:01:26.505 --> 00:01:29.826
So I don't have to go through that
iterative process all the way up to my

27
00:01:29.826 --> 00:01:31.587
root hands and then go through that.

28
00:01:31.587 --> 00:01:36.312
So we have efficiency, but there's
a slight problem with our conditional

29
00:01:36.312 --> 00:01:42.040
forwarders because I manually input where
I created that conditional forwarder.

30
00:01:42.040 --> 00:01:44.424
I have manually input the IP address for

31
00:01:44.424 --> 00:01:48.116
that authoritative DNS server
within that Contoso domain.

32
00:01:48.116 --> 00:01:52.852
So what happens if that DNS server goes
down or they change their IP address,

33
00:01:52.852 --> 00:01:56.750
maybe that network interface
card has to be replaced.

34
00:01:56.750 --> 00:02:00.564
And they forget to let me know about it,
because maybe we are just business

35
00:02:00.564 --> 00:02:03.530
partners, and
I'm not too high on their priority list.

36
00:02:03.530 --> 00:02:07.710
Well, now that conditional forwarder
is not goinna be working properly.

37
00:02:07.710 --> 00:02:12.145
So stub zones take this concept to,
I guess, another level.

38
00:02:12.145 --> 00:02:15.655
So it's the same concept but
they're retaining, or

39
00:02:15.655 --> 00:02:19.009
they're getting this
information dynamically so

40
00:02:19.009 --> 00:02:22.920
that if that IP address did
change it would know about that.

41
00:02:22.920 --> 00:02:27.024
And it would be able to reflect those
changes to all the individuals or

42
00:02:27.024 --> 00:02:29.232
the machines that were querying it.

43
00:02:29.232 --> 00:02:33.330
And it's not any kind of
sensitive top secret information,

44
00:02:33.330 --> 00:02:36.704
the information that it is
obtaining from that DNS

45
00:02:36.704 --> 00:02:40.605
server Is not the full copy
of everything that is stored.

46
00:02:40.605 --> 00:02:43.140
It's only a handful of records.

47
00:02:43.140 --> 00:02:46.865
So the type of records that you're gonna
be getting with a stub zone are gonna be

48
00:02:46.865 --> 00:02:47.380
your SOA.

49
00:02:47.380 --> 00:02:51.085
Remember your SOA is your start of
authority, and that's gonna include your

50
00:02:51.085 --> 00:02:54.394
configuration information,
who to contact if there's a problem.

51
00:02:54.394 --> 00:02:58.056
It's sets the TTLs for
your specific records.

52
00:02:58.056 --> 00:03:00.753
It's also gonna contain the NS server.

53
00:03:00.753 --> 00:03:05.569
So those are gonna be your name
server records to help specify those

54
00:03:05.569 --> 00:03:07.720
authoritative servers, and

55
00:03:07.720 --> 00:03:12.967
then it'll also have the corresponding
A records for those NS servers,

56
00:03:12.967 --> 00:03:18.240
and those are Interesting,
they're called glue host records.

57
00:03:18.240 --> 00:03:22.366
So what that means is that it's
helping glue everything together.

58
00:03:22.366 --> 00:03:26.350
It's helping this process work so
that we know who to find.

59
00:03:26.350 --> 00:03:30.283
So we have the correct fully qualified
domain name to the IP address for

60
00:03:30.283 --> 00:03:31.824
those name servers there.

61
00:03:31.824 --> 00:03:35.500
So that's really all that's in there,
you don't need permission like we saw.

62
00:03:35.500 --> 00:03:39.813
In that last demo, where we created
that secondary server, we had to jump

63
00:03:39.813 --> 00:03:44.212
back to that primer or that master to
go ahead and authorize that transfer.

64
00:03:44.212 --> 00:03:47.500
Here, we don't have that because
it's all public information.

65
00:03:47.500 --> 00:03:50.092
So let's go ahead and
take a look at a diagram.

66
00:03:50.092 --> 00:03:52.740
Brian had a diagram similar
to this in his book.

67
00:03:52.740 --> 00:03:57.151
I kind of just copied his steps here, but
laid them out a little bit differently.

68
00:03:57.151 --> 00:03:59.426
So let me walk through those with you.

69
00:03:59.426 --> 00:04:02.578
Here we have the client here.

70
00:04:02.578 --> 00:04:04.430
We have two separate domains,
first of all.

71
00:04:04.430 --> 00:04:08.789
We have a contoso.com domain and
then we alpineskihouse.

72
00:04:08.789 --> 00:04:12.000
That sounds nice,
some kind of Colorado vacation.

73
00:04:12.000 --> 00:04:16.123
So let's say this client
wants to go ahead and

74
00:04:16.123 --> 00:04:23.622
resolve an address within this
alpineskihouse, alpineskihouse.net domain.

75
00:04:23.622 --> 00:04:27.965
So the first step here is
going to be step number one,

76
00:04:27.965 --> 00:04:33.495
where the client sends a DNS query
to the contoso.com DNS server,

77
00:04:33.495 --> 00:04:38.770
and asks for the address of
intranet.alpineskihouse.com.

78
00:04:38.770 --> 00:04:40.392
There is one thing that I would
like to point out, though.

79
00:04:40.392 --> 00:04:45.154
Remember, there is one other thing that
happens at the very beginning here

80
00:04:45.154 --> 00:04:50.067
that's not noted in those steps, and
that's it will check its local cache,

81
00:04:50.067 --> 00:04:54.546
this device, to see if that record
has been stored in its local cache.

82
00:04:54.546 --> 00:04:58.957
If it's not stored locally,
then it will proceed to go ahead and

83
00:04:58.957 --> 00:05:02.670
check the cache of that DNS server for
contoso.com.

84
00:05:02.670 --> 00:05:05.857
The next step would be here,
the DNS server checks its cache,

85
00:05:05.857 --> 00:05:09.001
that's what's happening now,
to see if it has that entry.

86
00:05:09.001 --> 00:05:13.225
But if it doesn't have that entry,
then it's gonna go ahead and

87
00:05:13.225 --> 00:05:17.059
use the NS records in the stub
zone to contact one of the name

88
00:05:17.059 --> 00:05:22.220
servers that are listed here within
the alpineskihouse.net domain.

89
00:05:22.220 --> 00:05:26.559
And then that can send a query to
that name server to go ahead and

90
00:05:26.559 --> 00:05:29.990
resolve for internet.alpineskihouse.net.

91
00:05:29.990 --> 00:05:34.860
So step number four it's gonna be checking
their zone there, the primary zone.

92
00:05:34.860 --> 00:05:38.073
So the DNS server is gonna
be checking its cache, and

93
00:05:38.073 --> 00:05:43.198
the configuration there in it finds that
it hosts the primary zone for that domain.

94
00:05:43.198 --> 00:05:47.513
So it will go ahead and now respond
back to this server and say hey,

95
00:05:47.513 --> 00:05:51.270
I found that information and
got that IP address.

96
00:05:51.270 --> 00:05:56.013
And then lastly it will go ahead and
send that to the original client that was

97
00:05:56.013 --> 00:06:00.096
requesting now that client is

00:09:21.934 --> 00:09:23.943

00:09:23.943 --> 00:09:25.370

00:09:25.370 --> 00:09:26.520

00:09:31.330 --> 00:09:34.590

00:09:34.590 --> 00:09:37.190

00:09:45.530 --> 00:09:50.620

00:09:54.060 --> 00:09:56.710

00:09:56.710 --> 00:10:02.500

00:10:02.500 --> 00:10:06.446
And if it's an incremental,

00:10:14.760 --> 00:10:17.160
I'm not gonna be pulling that

that would just waste my bandwidth, right?

00:10:19.210 --> 00:10:21.220
So only those incremental
changes will be pushed out,

168
00:10:21.220 --> 00:10:25.010
and that's going to be an IXFI for

00:12:00.430 --> 00:12:04.360

topologies, it just simplifies that.

00:19:19.670 --> 00:19:20.380
>> Yeah.

330
00:19:20.380 --> 00:19:23.800
So the simplification along with
that is actually part of the deal

331
00:19:23.800 --> 00:19:26.450
on why you tend to see it a little
bit more often as well, and

332
00:19:26.450 --> 00:19:29.440
of course that secure updating
is also a good thing too.

333
00:19:29.440 --> 00:19:30.930
So along with that,

334
00:19:30.930 --> 00:19:35.250
remember we're just kind of diving into
the realm of what we're actually gonna see

335
00:19:35.250 --> 00:19:37.860
in future episodes if you're
following along with the book.

336
00:19:37.860 --> 00:19:40.550
You'll see as we go along
into Active Directory,

337
00:19:40.550 --> 00:19:42.130
we'll take a brief look in there.

338
00:19:42.130 --> 00:19:45.940
But if you want to learn more about DNS,
make sure you check out

339
00:19:45.940 --> 00:19:50.740
our entire library as you head
on towards the MCSA, MCSE shows.

340
00:19:50.740 --> 00:19:52.690
You're gonna see much more
on Active Directory and

341
00:19:52.690 --> 00:19:56.050
how to configure every little
part of it there as well.

342
00:19:56.050 --> 00:19:58.050
So, don't take it for granted.

343
00:19:58.050 --> 00:20:00.000
We've just really scratched the surface.

344
00:20:00.000 --> 00:20:03.000
But that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

345
00:20:03.000 --> 00:20:06.210
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

346
00:20:06.210 --> 00:20:07.586
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.
>> Stay tuned right here for

347
00:20:07.586 --> 00:20:09.360
more Windows Server 101 shows.

348
00:20:09.360 --> 00:20:17.602
[MUSIC]

349
00:20:17.602 --> 00:20:19.778
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee show some of the basic network troubleshooting utilities that Server Admins should be familiar with in a domain environment.  Cherokee shows some of the different options with ping to get results.  These can be used to to determine the latency, round trip time and connectivity.  Even though this works very effectively, it is limited in options compared to test-connection—a powershell cmdlet, according to Cherokee.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Network Connections
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:01.655
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.655 --> 00:00:03.205
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.205 --> 00:00:05.254
[CROSSTALK].

4
00:00:05.254 --> 00:00:08.071
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.071 --> 00:00:11.272
>> You are watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.272 --> 00:00:14.917
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.917 --> 00:00:17.070
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:17.070 --> 00:00:20.230
And today you are watching
the Windows Server 101 show.

9
00:00:20.230 --> 00:00:23.738
We're about to dive into troubleshooting
network connections at the server level.

10
00:00:23.738 --> 00:00:26.910
And here to help us out is gonna be Ms.
Cherokee Boose.

11
00:00:26.910 --> 00:00:28.080
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:28.080 --> 00:00:29.460
>> Thanks for having me, Ronnie.

13
00:00:29.460 --> 00:00:32.530
Yeah, so networking, this is a big
topic and it's kind of funny,

14
00:00:32.530 --> 00:00:36.200
if you look at the term networking
it's one letter away from not working.

15
00:00:36.200 --> 00:00:38.890
And it's kind of ironic because there
really are a ton of things that

16
00:00:38.890 --> 00:00:39.830
could be wrong.

17
00:00:39.830 --> 00:00:44.330
So let's go ahead In this show and take a
look at what some of those issues could be

18
00:00:44.330 --> 00:00:49.208
and then how you could really define that
scope of the problem and narrow that down.

19
00:00:49.208 --> 00:00:53.960
So I don't know if you guys
have been working in IT, but

20
00:00:53.960 --> 00:00:57.870
you get sort of strange requests
at times from the help desk.

21
00:00:57.870 --> 00:01:01.940
Sometimes people, if they're not
familiar with information technology,

22
00:01:01.940 --> 00:01:05.200
they may even say something like,
hey, the Internet's broken.

23
00:01:05.200 --> 00:01:06.340
And that's what you have to go by.

24
00:01:06.340 --> 00:01:11.160
So at those times, you really
wanna hone in on your skills, and

25
00:01:11.160 --> 00:01:12.620
a lot of it comes with experience.

26
00:01:12.620 --> 00:01:16.390
But there are certain things that you can
do, different approaches that you can take

27
00:01:16.390 --> 00:01:20.250
that'll help guide you in determining
where this problem may lie.

28
00:01:20.250 --> 00:01:23.980
So for instance, and a lot of it's
knowing your environment, too.

29
00:01:23.980 --> 00:01:27.740
So let's say Ronnie calls me every week
saying that the Internet's broken but

30
00:01:27.740 --> 00:01:32.380
then we come to find out that he's
trying to log into his system here, but

31
00:01:32.380 --> 00:01:34.780
he forgets his password and
he's not able to authenticate.

32
00:01:34.780 --> 00:01:35.990
So that's completely different.

33
00:01:35.990 --> 00:01:38.770
And you really just have to assess
the situation in that manner.

34
00:01:38.770 --> 00:01:40.950
So you might wanna go ahead and

35
00:01:40.950 --> 00:01:44.920
try to utilize a particular tool
that's been around for a very,

36
00:01:44.920 --> 00:01:50.000
very long time, since 1983, as a matter
of fact, and that's the ping utility.

37
00:01:50.000 --> 00:01:54.852
And originally that was used just with
a command line interface in a Windows

38
00:01:54.852 --> 00:01:59.330
environment, but it can be used
across multiple platforms as well.

39
00:01:59.330 --> 00:02:03.950
It was developed by Mike Muuss,
and if I said his name right.

40
00:02:03.950 --> 00:02:05.055
I'm sorry if I didn't.

41
00:02:05.055 --> 00:02:09.580
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it's a very universal tool.

42
00:02:09.580 --> 00:02:14.810
It's very helpful to assist you in
determining where that problem may lie.

43
00:02:14.810 --> 00:02:19.350
So for instance, if Ronnie called me and
said that he wasn't

44
00:02:19.350 --> 00:02:23.240
able to log in, if I was at his work
station, I could try to go ahead and

45
00:02:23.240 --> 00:02:27.630
ping that domain controller to test for
connectivity and different approaches.

46
00:02:27.630 --> 00:02:32.430
So let's go ahead and, let's see here,
I have a link from Microsoft,

47
00:02:32.430 --> 00:02:35.640
if I'll go ahead and pull that up.

48
00:02:35.640 --> 00:02:37.030
They give an approach.

49
00:02:38.480 --> 00:02:41.340
Brian Switerval, also from this book,

50
00:02:41.340 --> 00:02:45.060
this course that we're going with here,
he also has an approach listed as well.

51
00:02:45.060 --> 00:02:45.965
They're very similar.

52
00:02:45.965 --> 00:02:51.450
Brian does note to try to ping
the DNS server first, but

53
00:02:51.450 --> 00:02:52.490
there are a couple different tools.

54
00:02:52.490 --> 00:02:56.840
We'll talk about utilities within the show
that we can use and sometimes if you check

55
00:02:56.840 --> 00:03:01.350
ipconfig, it'll actually perform
that resolution process.

56
00:03:01.350 --> 00:03:04.402
So it's not completely necessary.

57
00:03:04.402 --> 00:03:07.361
In my opinion, I like to kind
of go with the OSI model, and

58
00:03:07.361 --> 00:03:09.410
think about it from that perspective.

59
00:03:09.410 --> 00:03:13.360
Now that's not like every single time I'm
not gonna directly follow that model.

60
00:03:13.360 --> 00:03:15.082
You do have to use some intuition there.

61
00:03:15.082 --> 00:03:17.900
And so if you assume where the problem is,

62
00:03:17.900 --> 00:03:23.070
then you can bypass a certain or
just like go in a different order.

63
00:03:23.070 --> 00:03:25.560
Let's take a look here and
see what Microsoft has to say.

64
00:03:25.560 --> 00:03:30.636
So their step, what they have listed here
for number one as to who you should ping.

65
00:03:30.636 --> 00:03:31.750
And let me just clarify.

66
00:03:31.750 --> 00:03:35.690
So ping is going to be
sending an ICMP packet and

67
00:03:35.690 --> 00:03:37.610
echo request out to a particular node.

68
00:03:37.610 --> 00:03:43.440
So from a node to a node, and you're
expecting to receive that echo back.

69
00:03:43.440 --> 00:03:46.910
So a normal ping will go ahead and
send out four packets.

70
00:03:48.070 --> 00:03:52.732
The ping packets are gonna be smaller in
size, or they're kind of small in size.

71
00:03:52.732 --> 00:03:56.320
I think they're about 54 bytes,
excluding the IP header information.

72
00:03:56.320 --> 00:03:59.420
And we'll take a look at what you can do
to increase that size if you wanted to

73
00:03:59.420 --> 00:04:00.270
as well.

74
00:04:00.270 --> 00:04:02.500
But we normally send out
four ping packets, and

75
00:04:02.500 --> 00:04:04.633
then you should expect
to receive four back.

76
00:04:04.633 --> 00:04:09.174
But a lot of information
can be determined from

77
00:04:09.174 --> 00:04:14.070
the results of that echo request,
so that reply.

78
00:04:14.070 --> 00:04:17.796
[COUGH] The first option that Microsoft
recommends is to go ahead and

79
00:04:17.796 --> 00:04:19.770
ping the loopback address.

80
00:04:19.770 --> 00:04:25.520
So if you recall, if you've taken any kind
of CompTIA exams, you should know or even

81
00:04:25.520 --> 00:04:31.390
just working in the field our loopback
address is 127.0.0.1, that range there.

82
00:04:31.390 --> 00:04:35.550
So what you're doing essentially when
you're pinging that loopback address

83
00:04:35.550 --> 00:04:37.060
is you're testing your hardware.

84
00:04:37.060 --> 00:04:39.300
You're testing your
network interface card.

85
00:04:39.300 --> 00:04:42.450
So if you compare that to the OSI model,
right, and

86
00:04:42.450 --> 00:04:44.970
we think about layer one we're
talking about our physical layer.

87
00:04:44.970 --> 00:04:47.150
And you're talking about your hardware.

88
00:04:47.150 --> 00:04:50.140
Your hardware will reside
within that physical layer.

89
00:04:50.140 --> 00:04:53.260
And swapping out that network
interface card that's easy.

90
00:04:53.260 --> 00:04:55.160
A hardware goes bad, we know that.

91
00:04:55.160 --> 00:04:56.990
It does have a life expectancy.

92
00:04:56.990 --> 00:05:02.120
So kind of grabbing that lower
hanging fruit first is my methodology,

93
00:05:02.120 --> 00:05:06.410
unless, like I said, unless I know I have
a suspicion that it may be an application,

94
00:05:06.410 --> 00:05:08.630
I might start at application layer or
something like that.

95
00:05:08.630 --> 00:05:13.560
A particular application keeps hanging, or
whatever, whatever that situation may be.

96
00:05:13.560 --> 00:05:17.601
So they say to go ahead and
check for that hardware, all right.

97
00:05:17.601 --> 00:05:21.985
[COUGH] If the loopback step fails and
the IP stack is not responding,

98
00:05:21.985 --> 00:05:25.070
then that should be an indication
to go ahead and check the hardware.

99
00:05:25.070 --> 00:05:30.220
So the next thing you want to do is
go ahead and you can ping someone,

100
00:05:30.220 --> 00:05:32.590
I usually like to try to ping
someone within my local address.

101
00:05:32.590 --> 00:05:35.904
And again, think about the OSI model here.

102
00:05:35.904 --> 00:05:38.400
We're staying within
someone on your switch.

103
00:05:38.400 --> 00:05:39.544
Think about layer two.

104
00:05:39.544 --> 00:05:41.720
So I have a diagram here.

105
00:05:43.592 --> 00:05:45.550
Somewhere, let me zoom out.

106
00:05:47.230 --> 00:05:49.470
So here I have a switch, and

107
00:05:49.470 --> 00:05:52.290
I have different nodes connected
to that particular switch.

108
00:05:52.290 --> 00:05:55.830
I have a wireless access point,
which my laptops are connecting as well.

109
00:05:55.830 --> 00:05:59.404
So you kind of wanna approach
it in the sense like, okay,

110
00:05:59.404 --> 00:06:02.244
let's say computer A, 10.0.1.1.

111
00:06:02.244 --> 00:06:05.993
Someone calls you from that
particular work station, says hey,

112
00:06:05.993 --> 00:06:07.500
the Internet's broken.

113
00:06:07.500 --> 00:06:10.630
Maybe they're trying to get out to
a website out here on the Internet, right?

114
00:06:10.630 --> 00:06:13.250
So you might wanna go
through that first step.

115
00:06:13.250 --> 00:06:16.140
Ping that loopback adapter, see if
their network interface card is bad.

116
00:06:16.140 --> 00:06:20.170
So they're able to go ahead and
ping themselves, all right, let's move on.

117
00:06:20.170 --> 00:06:23.106
So let's go ahead and try to ping someone
else like node D over here, 10.0.1.4.

118
00:06:23.106 --> 00:06:28.235
So depending on the result of that
particular ping, if you're not able to

119
00:06:28.235 --> 00:06:33.300
ping that person, then you're gonna
need to try to examine the switch.

120
00:06:33.300 --> 00:06:35.290
Maybe there's an issue
with that particular port.

121
00:06:35.290 --> 00:06:37.250
Try a couple other people
within that switch.

122
00:06:37.250 --> 00:06:41.290
And see if you get a couple
different calls from

123
00:06:41.290 --> 00:06:44.910
the person sitting at node A and
the person sitting at node C.

124
00:06:44.910 --> 00:06:49.060
And then you get a ticket for node D,
or even one of those wireless devices.

125
00:06:49.060 --> 00:06:51.510
That should be an indication
to you that hey,

126
00:06:51.510 --> 00:06:54.560
maybe I should go investigate
this particular switch.

127
00:06:54.560 --> 00:06:57.470
So you can try to find
correlations depending on

128
00:06:57.470 --> 00:07:01.000
how your network is configured
using the ping utility.

129
00:07:01.000 --> 00:07:05.240
For instance, if no one within
your environment can get out,

130
00:07:05.240 --> 00:07:08.610
maybe let's go ahead and
try to ping that default gateway.

131
00:07:08.610 --> 00:07:09.920
And maybe that router's down.

132
00:07:09.920 --> 00:07:11.110
Maybe it needs to be reset.

133
00:07:11.110 --> 00:07:13.020
Maybe you just had a hardware failure.

134
00:07:13.020 --> 00:07:15.550
So you wouldn't be able to
reach out to the Internet.

135
00:07:15.550 --> 00:07:18.910
Maybe there's a problem on the actual
server out on the Internet.

136
00:07:18.910 --> 00:07:20.180
It does happen.

137
00:07:20.180 --> 00:07:23.480
Maybe it's a problem within one
of the routes, one of the routers

138
00:07:23.480 --> 00:07:27.660
connecting you from your default gateway
to the final destination on the Internet.

139
00:07:27.660 --> 00:07:32.284
So there are a lot of different tools that
we can use to really help, like they said,

140
00:07:32.284 --> 00:07:35.474
define that scope and
isolate where that problem may be.

141
00:07:35.474 --> 00:07:36.790
>> All right, Cherokee.

142
00:07:36.790 --> 00:07:39.960
When we start taking a look at using ping,
though,

143
00:07:39.960 --> 00:07:44.177
the whole goal behind it is to
really verify connectivity, right?

144
00:07:44.177 --> 00:07:47.320
That my machine is gonna be
connected to the network and

145
00:07:47.320 --> 00:07:52.169
at that point the use of your ping allows
us to see whether we're connecting inside,

146
00:07:52.169 --> 00:07:55.818
even out to the edge of our network and
even beyond that as well.

147
00:07:55.818 --> 00:07:56.586
So Cherokee,

148
00:07:56.586 --> 00:08:00.830
what are some of the different response
that I may get in terms of ping?

149
00:08:00.830 --> 00:08:03.120
>> Yes, so
sometimes you may get errors back.

150
00:08:03.120 --> 00:08:06.220
And sometimes you may get
messages that seem like errors.

151
00:08:06.220 --> 00:08:08.110
But aren't always going to be that case.

152
00:08:08.110 --> 00:08:12.470
So sometimes you'll see a message that
says, destination host unreachable.

153
00:08:12.470 --> 00:08:15.430
And what that means is that local machine

154
00:08:15.430 --> 00:08:18.190
was not able to communicate
to your final destination.

155
00:08:18.190 --> 00:08:21.920
So that packet was never actually
delivered or placed onto the wire.

156
00:08:23.430 --> 00:08:27.250
Sometimes if it says destination
host unreachable, and

157
00:08:27.250 --> 00:08:30.080
if it's a reply from
a particular IP address,

158
00:08:30.080 --> 00:08:33.410
then that IP address which is
going to be a hop along the way.

159
00:08:33.410 --> 00:08:37.180
And I use this term hop and
I hope you understand it.

160
00:08:37.180 --> 00:08:40.210
If not then remember a hop
is just going to be one stop

161
00:08:40.210 --> 00:08:44.110
along that path whenever you're
talking about your route, right, so

162
00:08:44.110 --> 00:08:49.730
if a particular router is not able to find
the correct path to that final destination

163
00:08:49.730 --> 00:08:54.430
then that router is going to reply with
that destination host unreachable.

164
00:08:54.430 --> 00:08:56.770
So there may be something
wrong with that router.

165
00:08:58.060 --> 00:09:01.148
That's, it just means you weren't able
to get from point A to point B there.

166
00:09:01.148 --> 00:09:04.520
Now another error message
that you may receive here,

167
00:09:04.520 --> 00:09:07.910
this is going to be
your request timed out.

168
00:09:07.910 --> 00:09:09.960
So if you think about our packets.

169
00:09:09.960 --> 00:09:13.050
We have TTLs within our hops.

170
00:09:13.050 --> 00:09:17.400
And remember, your TTL when we're talking
about network transmission here is going

171
00:09:17.400 --> 00:09:22.190
to be how many hops can you transverse
before you reach your final destination.

172
00:09:22.190 --> 00:09:27.190
So, we do that, send a TTL so
that if there is a routing problem we just

173
00:09:27.190 --> 00:09:30.790
don't have packets circulating
throughout the network for infinity.

174
00:09:30.790 --> 00:09:35.060
So depending on a lot of different things.

175
00:09:35.060 --> 00:09:39.970
That doesn't mean that the particular
device is down functioning out of order.

176
00:09:39.970 --> 00:09:43.430
It just means again, hey, we weren't
able to get to that final destination.

177
00:09:43.430 --> 00:09:46.960
Some common reasons could
be network congestion,

178
00:09:46.960 --> 00:09:48.980
it could be even a firewall setting.

179
00:09:48.980 --> 00:09:52.130
And if you think about it,
I said that ping,

180
00:09:52.130 --> 00:09:56.200
the underlying protocol that the ping
packets are utilizing is gonna be ICMP,

181
00:09:56.200 --> 00:09:59.160
all right,
internet controlled message protocol.

182
00:09:59.160 --> 00:10:04.715
Some firewalls will go ahead and
block ICMP messages as a security,

183
00:10:04.715 --> 00:10:07.645
for security reasons,
as well as performance reasons.

184
00:10:07.645 --> 00:10:10.505
Because their routers may
be just performing routing.

185
00:10:10.505 --> 00:10:14.775
And they don't want to have them being
bothered responding to these ICMPV's echo

186
00:10:14.775 --> 00:10:16.220
requests, right.

187
00:10:16.220 --> 00:10:19.690
So it could be turned off in nature,

188
00:10:19.690 --> 00:10:24.920
or if it's actual problem, then you
would probably be seeing that other

189
00:10:24.920 --> 00:10:27.930
error message there,
the destination host unreachable.

190
00:10:27.930 --> 00:10:29.570
So those are some responses.

191
00:10:29.570 --> 00:10:30.760
There are a couple others.

192
00:10:30.760 --> 00:10:33.010
You might get some additional
detailed information.

193
00:10:33.010 --> 00:10:37.850
But I think that's a really good start
to go ahead and know that for now.

194
00:10:37.850 --> 00:10:42.210
But let's take a look at my machine and
see what we're talking about here, right?

195
00:10:42.210 --> 00:10:46.190
So I'm gonna go ahead and use PowerShell.

196
00:10:46.190 --> 00:10:48.970
I don't think there's anything that
I wanna show you today that I'm

197
00:10:48.970 --> 00:10:50.950
not gonna be able to do within PowerShell.

198
00:10:50.950 --> 00:10:52.170
So in the past.

199
00:10:53.240 --> 00:10:55.260
We would use command prompts a lot.

200
00:10:55.260 --> 00:10:58.510
But now you can use these same
commands within PowerShell.

201
00:10:58.510 --> 00:11:01.090
And I also wanna show you
some PowerShell commands so

202
00:11:01.090 --> 00:11:03.590
it'll just be easier if
we work from within here.

203
00:11:03.590 --> 00:11:08.360
And you'll probably find that as a habit
when you're working in the field as well.

204
00:11:08.360 --> 00:11:13.190
So if you just go ahead and type in ping

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue with some additional tools like ipconfig, get-netipconfiguration, tracert, pathping, arp and nslookup.  Cherokee shows the basic information found from ipconfig and compares it with powershell cmdlet ‘get-netipconfiguration’.  She also uses tracert and compares the output to pathping.  Lastly, she uses arp and nslookup to review some layer 2 and layer 3 issues.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Network Connections Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee wrap troubleshooting networking connections by take a look at a couple of additional command line based utilities:  Netstat and telnet.  Cherokee shows multiple options with Netstat to demonstrate the different results can be seen with it.  As a live statistical tool, it allows us to verify many things including the ports that are connecting or connected and other information.  She also uses telnet to demonstrate TCP connections are working.  Though primary used a tool for remote access, it can be used to test a connection to specific port to see if it’s up and connected too, according to the team.  She also demonstrates powerhshell cmdlet test-netconnection.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Network Connections Part 3

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie begin a discussion surrounding Active Directory.  Ronnie explains the structure of an Active Directory environment and the terms used to describe the components. Ronnie demonstrates how to configure Remote Management to run commands on a remote server. Ronnie also demonstrates how create a customized Microsoft Management Console (MMC).
episodes.title: Active Directory Basic Administration

00:21:01.010 --> 00:21:05.420
you're also limiting access to that
machine in a couple of different ways.

352
00:21:05.420 --> 00:21:09.920
There's only two remote desktop
connections allowed at any one time.

353
00:21:09.920 --> 00:21:13.337
So if you're logged in and
another person's logged in, but

354
00:21:13.337 --> 00:21:17.893
let's say that somebody really does need
to make a chain, a change, excuse me,

355
00:21:17.893 --> 00:21:20.789
inside of your Active Directory
structure there.

356
00:21:20.789 --> 00:21:25.250
But now you, or the other person, or both
people are logged in at the same time.

357
00:21:25.250 --> 00:21:28.507
And if you're like me,
you end up finding out something.

358
00:21:28.507 --> 00:21:30.362
Which I know I've seen this happen.

359
00:21:30.362 --> 00:21:33.990
Where someone says, yeah, just log
in to domain control and change us.

360
00:21:33.990 --> 00:21:38.170
And I try and make the connection and it
says, hey, there's no sessions available.

361
00:21:38.170 --> 00:21:39.710
You can't log in.

362
00:21:39.710 --> 00:21:42.080
Well that now becomes frustrating

363
00:21:42.080 --> 00:21:45.630
because I don't know if the person's
actively doing something or

364
00:21:45.630 --> 00:21:48.939
if they just did, when I find out when
I go and ask them like, are logged into

365
00:21:48.939 --> 00:21:50.680
domain controllers on premises, they go
>> Yeah.

366
00:21:50.680 --> 00:21:51.485
>> No I just forgot.

367
00:21:51.485 --> 00:21:52.530
>> [LAUGH]
>> I just forgot.

368
00:21:52.530 --> 00:21:53.650
>> Yeah, about that.

369
00:21:53.650 --> 00:21:55.750
>> Yeah, and so now you're wondering like,

370
00:21:55.750 --> 00:21:59.335
is there anything that you need
to save before I disconnect you?

371
00:21:59.335 --> 00:22:01.610
Or what is going on, are you in
the middle of installing something?

372
00:22:01.610 --> 00:22:03.800
Are you in the middle
of changing something?

373
00:22:03.800 --> 00:22:08.989
That can become very much something
that can be damaging if we do that.

374
00:22:08.989 --> 00:22:12.130
So we wanna make sure
that we understand this.

375
00:22:12.130 --> 00:22:16.570
That idea of logging on really does
limit what the domain controller can do,

376
00:22:16.570 --> 00:22:19.520
especially if two people just
stay logged in all the time.

377
00:22:19.520 --> 00:22:24.570
The other thing, of course, is that when
you use remote desktop connection and

378
00:22:24.570 --> 00:22:29.460
the protocol, everything that you do is
gonna be powered on the server itself.

379
00:22:29.460 --> 00:22:33.037
So not just retrieving the information and
crunching the data on your end,

380
00:22:33.037 --> 00:22:36.555
it really is having to do everything
that it's having to do on this side and

381
00:22:36.555 --> 00:22:38.224
now sending you just the results.

382
00:22:38.224 --> 00:22:42.724
So that sounds cool, probably on a super
big beefy machine, but it's really

383
00:22:42.724 --> 00:22:47.168
not something you want to do on your
domain controller if you don't need it.

384
00:22:47.168 --> 00:22:50.160
Now, inside a lab environment,
right, it doesn't matter.

385
00:22:50.160 --> 00:22:55.150
The domain controller's really not gonna
be super critical in a lab environment.

386
00:22:55.150 --> 00:22:59.808
But inside of a business that's really
busy, that's constantly having people log

387
00:22:59.808 --> 00:23:03.427
in, log off, changes in terms of hires and
whatever it might be.

388
00:23:03.427 --> 00:23:07.960
This becomes more critical and it's
something we don't want to actually do.

389
00:23:07.960 --> 00:23:11.940
So we wanna make sure that we
understand that this is really

390
00:23:11.940 --> 00:23:16.900
a critical aspect of the way that things
should be done in terms of best practice.

391
00:23:16.900 --> 00:23:19.014
So make sure you kind of remember that.

392
00:23:19.014 --> 00:23:24.290
Now let me tell you the [LAUGH]
reality of a lot of things, right?

393
00:23:24.290 --> 00:23:26.475
In the administrative world,

394
00:23:26.475 --> 00:23:29.988
it's really gonna depend on who
your network administrator is.

395
00:23:29.988 --> 00:23:33.640
So if you're just coming up into the ranks
where you're now starting to work with

396
00:23:33.640 --> 00:23:38.470
servers, you may just be told, just go
ahead and remote desktop into the server.

397
00:23:38.470 --> 00:23:42.070
Now does that mean, Cherokee, that I
should say, no I should never do that.

398
00:23:42.070 --> 00:23:43.057
>> Ronnie told us.
>> Yeah,

399
00:23:43.057 --> 00:23:46.002
Ronnie said that I should never do that.

400
00:23:46.002 --> 00:23:50.839
It means you got to do what you got to do,
but in reality, right, the best practice

401
00:23:50.839 --> 00:23:54.854
is to leave the domain controller
alone and use these remote tools.

402
00:23:54.854 --> 00:23:59.349
Because that is really, especially in
today's environment of compliance and

403
00:23:59.349 --> 00:24:03.520
in today's environment of security
worries that we have to worry about.

404
00:24:03.520 --> 00:24:06.596
We wanna make sure that we
are limiting the access that we can,

405
00:24:06.596 --> 00:24:09.270
but still being able to do
the stuff that we need to do.

406
00:24:09.270 --> 00:24:13.388
So, it's a balance of the functionality
as well as security and

407
00:24:13.388 --> 00:24:15.660
some of the other thing
we have to think about.

408
00:24:15.660 --> 00:24:19.220
>> Now, Ronnie it seems like a lot
responsibility when we're talking about

409
00:24:19.220 --> 00:24:20.750
managing multiple servers.

410
00:24:20.750 --> 00:24:25.180
And I don't want you to feel like
it's something that you can't do,

411
00:24:25.180 --> 00:24:26.460
like it's overwhelming.

412
00:24:26.460 --> 00:24:28.510
So Ronnie,
do you have any suggestions or tips, or

413
00:24:28.510 --> 00:24:31.070

this process easier?

414
00:24:31.070 --> 00:24:33.547
>> Yeah, there's a few things
that we can do, right?

415
00:24:33.547 --> 00:24:34.510
I just showed you one.

416
00:24:34.510 --> 00:24:38.934
Using that remote server adminstration
tool Is probably the easiest thing that

417
00:24:38.934 --> 00:24:41.360
you can actually end up doing.

418
00:24:41.360 --> 00:24:45.740
But there are times, though, you need to
have more than just something like that

419
00:24:45.740 --> 00:24:48.300
to be able to do everything
that you wanna do.

420
00:24:48.300 --> 00:24:51.460
But if you don't have that, you can
actually change it around a little bit.

421
00:24:51.460 --> 00:24:54.600
So let's go back to my machine
here just for a moment.

422
00:24:54.600 --> 00:24:55.640
And that way, we'll see something.

423
00:24:55.640 --> 00:24:57.540
I just minimized the PowerShell.

424
00:24:57.540 --> 00:25:01.790
There is something else you can do to
help customize the enviroment that you're

425
00:25:01.790 --> 00:25:03.120
in to help you out.

426
00:25:03.120 --> 00:25:07.550
So here I am on
a Windows Server 2016 machine.

427
00:25:07.550 --> 00:25:11.490
I'm going to click on the little search
window here, I'm gonna type in MMC.

00:25:11.490 --> 00:25:15.270
And that's gonna bring up

00:25:15.270 --> 00:25:18.680
Microsoft Management Console.

00:25:18.680 --> 00:25:21.370
And inside of this
Microsoft Management Console,

00:25:21.370 --> 00:25:27.020
you're gonna see that there's not any

432
00:25:27.020 --> 00:25:30.210
Well this great because I can actually

433
00:25:30.210 --> 00:25:33.350
fill this particular column

00:25:33.350 --> 00:25:35.710
And not only is it great because of that.

435
00:25:35.710 --> 00:25:39.830
I can also connect to a remote
machine to do this for us as well.

00:25:39.830 --> 00:25:43.070
So let me click on file to show

437
00:25:43.070 --> 00:25:47.230
If I select file, and

438
00:25:47.230 --> 00:25:50.840
Notice I have these different
snap ins that I can add in.

439
00:25:50.840 --> 00:25:54.610
So for example,
let's say that I wanted to be able to take

440
00:25:54.610 --> 00:25:57.330
a look at some of
the different services here.

441
00:25:57.330 --> 00:26:00.440
Let's just do computer management,
for example, here.

442
00:26:00.440 --> 00:26:02.090
I can click on add.

443
00:26:02.090 --> 00:26:03.105
And if I do this,

00:26:03.105 --> 00:26:07.326
now notice that it gives me the option

445
00:26:07.326 --> 00:26:11.504
So let me select another computer,

446
00:26:11.504 --> 00:26:16.247
and then here I can do the o365dco1.

447

Let me zoom out for a moment.

00:26:18.322 --> 00:26:21.840
It gets locked in my zoom sometimes.

00:26:21.840 --> 00:26:24.410
And now notice I get

450
00:26:24.410 --> 00:26:27.240
I can come down here to,

451
00:26:27.240 --> 00:26:30.423
And I wanted to make sure

452
00:26:32.440 --> 00:26:33.600
Oops that's a zero I did.

00:26:34.770 --> 00:26:35.510
No, that is an O.

00:26:35.510 --> 00:26:36.689
Okay, I just wanted to make sure.

455
00:26:39.526 --> 00:26:44.124
DC01 That zoom has really

456
00:26:46.990 --> 00:26:49.006
So in a moment, it's connecting, so

00:26:49.006 --> 00:26:51.910

458
00:26:51.910 --> 00:26:54.290
So this one looks like it's

459
00:26:54.290 --> 00:26:58.010
But it gives me this ability to continue

460
00:26:58.010 --> 00:26:59.170
Hopefully it's not gonna fail, but

461
00:26:59.170 --> 00:27:00.830
it looks like it's just

462
00:27:00.830 --> 00:27:04.820
>> And we can add different tools into

463
00:27:04.820 --> 00:27:06.120
our management console.

464
00:27:06.120 --> 00:27:07.520
>> Right, so let's see.

465
00:27:07.520 --> 00:27:10.370
This one says it can't be connected.

466
00:27:10.370 --> 00:27:11.050
All right.

467
00:27:11.050 --> 00:27:11.980
Well, let's try another one.

468
00:27:11.980 --> 00:27:14.190
Just let's see what we can do for
right now.

469
00:27:14.190 --> 00:27:15.420
So local computer.

470
00:27:15.420 --> 00:27:17.590
Let's see if I can do that.

471
00:27:17.590 --> 00:27:19.495
Let's do this on another computer.

472
00:27:31.326 --> 00:27:32.930
The username, okay?

473
00:27:32.930 --> 00:27:34.754
So yeah, I'm just kind of picking and

474
00:27:34.754 --> 00:27:37.837
choosing some different ones that
are out there and available.

475
00:27:37.837 --> 00:27:39.404
But that's how you do it, right?

476
00:27:39.404 --> 00:27:43.510
So I was just gonna add in a different
one, but right now it looks like it's

477
00:27:43.510 --> 00:27:48.550
having a sweet time in trying to do
anything else but this one machine.

478
00:27:48.550 --> 00:27:49.537
Let me do this.

479
00:27:49.537 --> 00:27:52.056
365DCO1.

480
00:27:52.056 --> 00:27:53.473
Let's try one more here.

481
00:27:53.473 --> 00:27:54.550
There we go.

482
00:27:54.550 --> 00:27:58.536
So now, I'm just adding in some
different tools to help us out.

483
00:27:58.536 --> 00:28:02.970
Notice that all of this is connecting
into another machine to allow us to do

484
00:28:02.970 --> 00:28:04.270
that as well.

485
00:28:04.270 --> 00:28:07.920
So the combination of using the remote
server administration tools

486
00:28:07.920 --> 00:28:11.650
on a client computer, using something

487
00:28:11.650 --> 00:28:15.400
allows us to be able to set
something like this if we choose to.

488
00:28:15.400 --> 00:28:18.247
And that way, we can then save this.

489
00:28:19.700 --> 00:28:23.526
So if I select save as,
notice it's gonna save it underneath

490
00:28:23.526 --> 00:28:27.990
the Windows Administrative Tools,
and we can call it Ronnie's oop.

491
00:28:27.990 --> 00:28:29.420
Whatever I call it, Ronnie.

492
00:28:29.420 --> 00:28:33.720
So at that point, you can always do a
search and find that particular tool kit,

493
00:28:33.720 --> 00:28:37.210
and it will bring it right up, and
you'll be able to manage that again.

494
00:28:37.210 --> 00:28:40.680
So it allows us to work
with some different

495
00:28:40.680 --> 00:28:43.020
ways to manage that remote machine.

496
00:28:43.020 --> 00:28:45.760
So whether we're actually talking about
the physical machine, which is what I'm

00:28:45.760 --> 00:28:49.350
doing right here in the MMC, or using
the remote server administration tool.

498
00:28:49.350 --> 00:28:52.470
Let me switch on over,
the toolkit over here.

499
00:28:52.470 --> 00:28:59.240
And let me show you one more

500
00:28:59.240 --> 00:29:03.200
You can see that there is
a lot available right here for

00:29:03.200 --> 00:29:06.194

502
00:29:06.194 --> 00:29:11.166
So there is DHCP, DNS,
event viewer, you name it,

503
00:29:11.166 --> 00:29:15.110
group policy management as well.

504
00:29:15.110 --> 00:29:20.010
And on this machine, you can even create
that MMC to add all those utilities in

505
00:29:20.010 --> 00:29:27.350
there as one unit, too, instead of having
to see them inside of that menu instead.

506
00:29:27.350 --> 00:29:30.700
So remote management,
it is kind of the beginning and

507
00:29:30.700 --> 00:29:34.690
the essential part of understanding

508
00:29:34.690 --> 00:29:37.950
But now that we have that in hand,
we really need to

509
00:29:37.950 --> 00:29:43.120

510
00:29:43.120 --> 00:29:43.850
But Cherokee,

511
00:29:43.850 --> 00:29:47.790
it looks like that I've ran us out of time
in just talking about remote management.

512
00:29:47.790 --> 00:29:50.980
So I guess we need to kind
of cut that off right now.

513
00:29:50.980 --> 00:29:51.820
>> That's all right, Ronnie.

514
00:29:51.820 --> 00:29:54.900
That can definitely happen when you're
talking about Active Directory,

515
00:29:54.900 --> 00:29:56.020
like you had mentioned.

516
00:29:56.020 --> 00:29:58.310
We could go for days on Active Directory.

517
00:29:58.310 --> 00:30:01.240
But for this show,

00:30:01.240 --> 00:30:03.130
Remember, I'm your host Cherokee Boose.
