00:30:03.130 --> 00:30:03.862
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

520
00:30:03.862 --> 00:30:07.221
>> See you next time here at ITPROTV.

521
00:30:07.221 --> 00:30:12.999
[MUSIC].

522
00:30:12.999 --> 00:30:20.030
>> Thank you for watching ITPROTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie begin discussing Organizational Units (OU's).  Ronnie explains why OU's should be used. He also shows how to create, manage and delete one.
episodes.title: Active Directory Basic Administration Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:03.478
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.478 --> 00:00:07.184
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.184 --> 00:00:08.466
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.466 --> 00:00:12.126
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.126 --> 00:00:16.865
>> Welcome back to your to your Server 101
series, I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:16.865 --> 00:00:17.615
In this episode,

7
00:00:17.615 --> 00:00:21.555
we'll continue taking a look at our
basic Active Directory functions.

8
00:00:21.555 --> 00:00:23.815
With us today, in studios, we have Mr.

9
00:00:23.815 --> 00:00:25.995
Ronnie Wong, thank you for
joining us today, Ronnie.

10
00:00:25.995 --> 00:00:28.695
>> Thank you for having me back for
the Part 2 after I ran on so

11
00:00:28.695 --> 00:00:30.295
long with the Part 1.

12
00:00:30.295 --> 00:00:36.260
We are back and we are ready to take a
look at the administrative side of things.

13
00:00:36.260 --> 00:00:39.220
I know I spend a good deal of time
on just focusing in on the remote

14
00:00:39.220 --> 00:00:40.350
administration, but

15
00:00:40.350 --> 00:00:45.080
it is something that we should be doing in
the real world as much as we can, right?

16
00:00:45.080 --> 00:00:48.460
But remember that, wherever you go,
if you're just getting hired on,

17
00:00:48.460 --> 00:00:50.220
you're gonna do it their way.

18
00:00:50.220 --> 00:00:54.700
But keep in mind the best practice as you
start to move forward into your career

19
00:00:54.700 --> 00:00:56.740
working with servers.

20
00:00:56.740 --> 00:01:00.310
Next unit that we want to talk
about of course is this breakdown

21
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:03.480
of the administrative side
of things a little bit more.

22
00:01:03.480 --> 00:01:07.589
So let's go back to my screen as I
re-emphasize something I did in Part 1,

23
00:01:07.589 --> 00:01:11.701
where I essentially showed you the
breakdown of how some of the terminology

24
00:01:11.701 --> 00:01:12.693
ends up working.

25
00:01:12.693 --> 00:01:15.718
When you start talking about
the idea of a forest, right,

26
00:01:15.718 --> 00:01:19.640
remember that that is the security
boundary of Active Directory.

27
00:01:19.640 --> 00:01:21.420
So when you set up everything,

28
00:01:21.420 --> 00:01:26.130
right, that is when we start setting
security, we're talking about that.

29
00:01:26.130 --> 00:01:30.290
Remember that a single domain can
also be a forest unto itself.

30
00:01:30.290 --> 00:01:34.460
It doesn't have to be where there's always
multiple domains that creates a forest.

31
00:01:34.460 --> 00:01:37.610
But a single domain can also
be a single forest as well.

32
00:01:37.610 --> 00:01:40.330
So we can set up security boundaries for
that too.

33
00:01:40.330 --> 00:01:44.090
Administratively though, even though
this is essentially our administrative

34
00:01:44.090 --> 00:01:48.530
boundary, it's a gigantic
administrative boundary, right?

35
00:01:48.530 --> 00:01:52.053
And my domain is large,
and I have 5,000 users and

36
00:01:52.053 --> 00:01:57.130
7,000 computers and
1,000 plus servers out there, right?

37
00:01:57.130 --> 00:02:00.360
That's a huge domain to have to try and
manage.

38
00:02:00.360 --> 00:02:04.440
What if I have 16, 17, or
100 different departments?

39
00:02:04.440 --> 00:02:10.600
It becomes much more difficult to
manage everything at a domain level,

40
00:02:10.600 --> 00:02:15.310
especially when people start to say, hey,
we need certain requirements over here.

41
00:02:15.310 --> 00:02:18.690
We need certain security,
different type of security over here.

42
00:02:18.690 --> 00:02:23.850
We need this requirement, and here's what
the machine should look like when they log

43
00:02:23.850 --> 00:02:26.600
on to my domain or
my department over here.

44
00:02:26.600 --> 00:02:30.000
When you start doing that, now you
have to break it down even further.

45
00:02:30.000 --> 00:02:33.750
Now I didn't do that here because
we're about to talk about this idea

46
00:02:33.750 --> 00:02:39.020
of what we call organizational units,
is what we're about to talk about here.

47
00:02:39.020 --> 00:02:40.368
So that's where we're going.

48
00:02:40.368 --> 00:02:44.254
>> All right, so Ronnie, I'm assuming you
are gonna be talking about why we would

49
00:02:44.254 --> 00:02:48.380
wanna go ahead to create and actually
utilize organizational units, right?

50
00:02:48.380 --> 00:02:51.664
>> Right, now this is where we do get
some, I remember I was a little bit

51
00:02:51.664 --> 00:02:55.140
confused about it the first time
that I learned about it here.

52
00:02:55.140 --> 00:02:58.570
When it was being explained to me,
I always thought organizational units,

53
00:02:58.570 --> 00:03:02.690
it's just about the idea of,
well, organization, right?

54
00:03:02.690 --> 00:03:09.060
The term organizational unit, it means
how I want stuff to be structured and

55
00:03:09.060 --> 00:03:13.880
to be filed correctly and to be placed,
categorized, and stuff like that.

to be able to do this.

286
00:16:50.860 --> 00:16:52.830
It doesn't like the name.

287
00:16:52.830 --> 00:16:55.950
So, if I were to do this, it's actually
requiring me to do the identity.

288
00:16:58.470 --> 00:17:00.940
So this is where you have to
do that whole identity again.

289
00:17:06.142 --> 00:17:15.991
=GNV, DC=Officeprodemoco,DC=

290
00:17:15.991 --> 00:17:21.259
onmicrosoft,DC.

291
00:17:21.259 --> 00:17:24.920
So, you can see why some
people don't really like

292
00:17:24.920 --> 00:17:27.771
the PowerShell cuz I'm starting
to not appreciate it myself.

293
00:17:27.771 --> 00:17:29.460
>> [LAUGH]
>> At this particular point.

294
00:17:29.460 --> 00:17:30.696
>> It is a lot of typing Ronnie.

295
00:17:30.696 --> 00:17:33.935
>> It is a lot of typing.

296
00:17:33.935 --> 00:17:41.260
-ProtectedFromAccidentalDeletion $false
here.

297
00:17:41.260 --> 00:17:48.260
And now that I have it set like this,
now I can go back and see if, there we go,

298
00:17:48.260 --> 00:17:54.860
cuz now I gotta change this
up using that same command.

299
00:17:54.860 --> 00:17:58.620
But now I simply type
remove if I can do remove.

300
00:18:00.660 --> 00:18:01.980
Organization unit the identity.

301
00:18:04.587 --> 00:18:08.217
I'm gonna get rid of the protected here.

302
00:18:08.217 --> 00:18:10.060
And now do a confirm.

303
00:18:14.406 --> 00:18:21.310
Colon, make sure I'm doing this
right here, equals false, right?

304
00:18:21.310 --> 00:18:21.970
Yep.

305
00:18:21.970 --> 00:18:23.480
Dollar sign, false.

306
00:18:23.480 --> 00:18:24.860
>> So, you're just omitting or

307
00:18:24.860 --> 00:18:28.470
bypassing that confirmation
notification that would pop up?

308
00:18:28.470 --> 00:18:30.950
>> Right, at least,
that's what I'm hoping I'm doing here.

309
00:18:30.950 --> 00:18:34.590
So, now that I've removed
the accidental protection here,

310
00:18:34.590 --> 00:18:36.200
notice that it gives that.

311
00:18:36.200 --> 00:18:39.420
And now, we actually have it open,
and we are ready to go.

312
00:18:39.420 --> 00:18:40.110
>> All right, Ronnie.

313
00:18:40.110 --> 00:18:42.110
I didn't see any kind
of notification there.

314
00:18:42.110 --> 00:18:44.310
So, is there any way we can go back and
check our work?

315
00:18:44.310 --> 00:18:45.590
>> Yes, definitely.

316
00:18:45.590 --> 00:18:50.670
So, that's one of the benefits of actually
being able to add in that confirmation.

317
00:18:50.670 --> 00:18:53.200
Saying, yes,
let's verify that everything is done.

318
00:18:53.200 --> 00:18:58.600
But, if we wanted to see this,
it's just get-adorganizational,

319
00:18:58.600 --> 00:19:00.980
If I can spell organizational unit.

320
00:19:00.980 --> 00:19:05.210
Once we have that, I'm gonna filter
everything to well, everything.

321
00:19:05.210 --> 00:19:09.100
Then I'm gonna just format it as
a table list is what I'm going to do.

322
00:19:09.100 --> 00:19:12.380
So from here,
you can see under distinguished name,

323
00:19:12.380 --> 00:19:17.570
notice that there's nothing actually
with GNV listed in it at all.

324
00:19:17.570 --> 00:19:20.910
The other things are still here and
what we have available to us.

325
00:19:20.910 --> 00:19:24.020
But it gives us that chance
to be able to delete that.

326
00:19:24.020 --> 00:19:28.540
So the great thing is if you
set it through the GUI, through

327
00:19:28.540 --> 00:19:32.040
the Graphical User Interface, it's just
a simple check box when you create it.

328
00:19:32.040 --> 00:19:36.387
Whether you want to add in the accidental
deletion protection or not,

329
00:19:36.387 --> 00:19:39.048
if you do,
then you simply add it in there.

330
00:19:39.048 --> 00:19:43.404
With the PowerShell and the way that we
did without any other additional options,

331
00:19:43.404 --> 00:19:45.614
such as doing it where
I told it to be true,

332
00:19:45.614 --> 00:19:49.930
under the protection of the accidental
deletion, it went in and set it anyways.

333
00:19:49.930 --> 00:19:53.720
So, those are some of the things that
you may actually choose to look out for.

334
00:19:53.720 --> 00:19:56.700
But either way,
that should at least help you get started

335
00:19:56.700 --> 00:20:01.190
in setting up an organization unit,
as well as deleting it too.

336
00:20:01.190 --> 00:20:05.610
And that should be pretty much enough
to get you a little bit more familiar.

337
00:20:05.610 --> 00:20:09.030
Now in terms of the organization and
the way that you do it,

338
00:20:09.030 --> 00:20:12.410
in other words the planning and the
structure of all that, that's when you do

339
00:20:12.410 --> 00:20:18.490
dive into the realm of where those classes
come in, right, for the MCSA or MCSE.

340
00:20:18.490 --> 00:20:21.420
That's where you actually end up
seeing more of that on how to make

341
00:20:21.420 --> 00:20:22.900
sure that those are organized.

342
00:20:22.900 --> 00:20:26.430
We just simply created them, we showed
you of course how to delete them, and

343
00:20:26.430 --> 00:20:30.130
what are some of the things that you
can do in PowerShell as well as a GUI.

344
00:20:30.130 --> 00:20:32.090
>> Our work's not finished yet
though, Ronnie.

345
00:20:32.090 --> 00:20:35.100
We still have to,
we've created this organization unit, but

346
00:20:35.100 --> 00:20:37.530
then what are we gonna put in
those organizational units?

347
00:20:37.530 --> 00:20:40.810
Well ladies and gentlemen stay tuned
because when you come back we'll

348
00:20:40.810 --> 00:20:44.470
be looking at creating those
user accounts with Ronnie.

349
00:20:44.470 --> 00:20:48.660
And also taking a look at what we can
do with these organizational units.

350
00:20:48.660 --> 00:20:50.748
But for this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

351
00:20:50.748 --> 00:20:52.206
Remember I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

352
00:20:52.206 --> 00:20:53.180
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

353
00:20:53.180 --> 00:20:54.958
>> See you next time here on ITProTV.

354
00:20:54.958 --> 00:21:02.540
[MUSIC]

355
00:21:02.540 --> 00:21:05.500
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: One of the most common tasks to perform in Active Directory is the creation of user accounts. Ronnie and Cherokee demonstrate the different ways you can create users and the options you can include for that object.  First Ronnie shows how to create one user then he  shows what it takes to create several users at once.
episodes.title: Create User Accounts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.190 --> 00:00:01.190
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.190 --> 00:00:08.229
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.229 --> 00:00:11.423
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.423 --> 00:00:14.480
>> Welcome to your Server 101 series.

5
00:00:14.480 --> 00:00:16.450
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:16.450 --> 00:00:17.240
In this episode,

7
00:00:17.240 --> 00:00:21.130
we'll be taking a look at how to create
user accounts within Active Directory.

8
00:00:21.130 --> 00:00:23.750
With us today back in studios
we have Mr Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:23.750 --> 00:00:25.390
Thanks for joining us today Ronnie.

10
00:00:25.390 --> 00:00:28.840
>> Well thank you for having me back
as we continue to take a look at some

11
00:00:28.840 --> 00:00:33.320
Active Directory skills that we need
to develop right here in Server 101.

12
00:00:33.320 --> 00:00:36.780
Just to get us familiar with working
inside of Active Directory a little bit

13
00:00:36.780 --> 00:00:41.090
more, one of the key things that we'll
actually have to do on the routine basis

14
00:00:41.090 --> 00:00:46.360
of course is to be able to create user
accounts inside of Active Directory.

15
00:00:46.360 --> 00:00:49.769
So, we're gonna show you of course how to
do that not only using the graphical user

16
00:00:49.769 --> 00:00:51.740
interface tools that are available, but

17
00:00:51.740 --> 00:00:55.290
also PowerShell because that's the way
that the future's actually going.

18
00:00:55.290 --> 00:00:57.390
So that's where we want to
actually take the step and

19
00:00:57.390 --> 00:01:01.080
make sure that we understand that
that's what's gonna have to happen.

20
00:01:01.080 --> 00:01:03.410
So this is one of the more
common things that we'll do.

21
00:01:03.410 --> 00:01:06.270
It's a fairly routine task but
it is something that

22
00:01:06.270 --> 00:01:10.460
we need to make sure that we understand
what we're doing and how to do it, okay?

23
00:01:10.460 --> 00:01:11.840
So, when we start to take a look at that,

24
00:01:11.840 --> 00:01:15.320
we have to ask that very
obvious question then, okay?

25
00:01:15.320 --> 00:01:19.690
Why in the world do we need to be
able to do something like this?

26
00:01:19.690 --> 00:01:23.550
Well, remember that as your company
continues to grow, continues to actually

27
00:01:23.550 --> 00:01:27.600
change, more than likely you'll see
that you'll be adding user accounts in.

28
00:01:27.600 --> 00:01:30.740
And that means somebody has
to be able to create them.

29
00:01:30.740 --> 00:01:34.250
And if you're wondering why
well one is simple onboarding.

30
00:01:34.250 --> 00:01:37.830
The very fact that new users are going
to be hired inside of your company

31
00:01:37.830 --> 00:01:40.340
means that those accounts
have to be created.

32
00:01:40.340 --> 00:01:43.530
Now if you're like does that mean I
have to start watching everybody that's

33
00:01:43.530 --> 00:01:45.650
hired and then I go in and create that?

34
00:01:45.650 --> 00:01:47.580
More than likely not, right?

35
00:01:47.580 --> 00:01:50.740
Usually what ends up happening
is that your HR department will

36
00:01:50.740 --> 00:01:55.210
probably end up with a list of names if
you hire more than one person at a time.

37
00:01:55.210 --> 00:01:58.300
Then they'll send you a list or
if it actually is just a single hire,

38
00:01:58.300 --> 00:02:00.790
they'll send you
the information that you need.

39
00:02:00.790 --> 00:02:03.580
But the clear aspect of what
we need to do of course,

40
00:02:03.580 --> 00:02:07.260
is to make sure that we understand that,
hey, this is what's gonna happen and

41
00:02:07.260 --> 00:02:11.160
here's the information that you'll
need to have ready to go to do that.

42
00:02:11.160 --> 00:02:13.440
The other one of course
are special use cases.

43
00:02:13.440 --> 00:02:18.020
For example, it may be a contracting
basis where somebody's coming in to

44
00:02:18.020 --> 00:02:21.960
your organization for a bit of time and,
since they're gonna be there,

45
00:02:21.960 --> 00:02:24.320
they're gonna need access to
some of the network resources.

46
00:02:24.320 --> 00:02:26.490
But you might want to create an account,
and

47
00:02:26.490 --> 00:02:30.670
then have them disabled after
a period of time as well.

48
00:02:30.670 --> 00:02:33.230
>> Now Ronnie, that's an interesting
choice of word that you just

49
00:02:33.230 --> 00:02:34.710
used there when you said disabled.

50
00:02:34.710 --> 00:02:38.280
I've been in organizations that didn't
really have a good solid understanding of

51
00:02:38.280 --> 00:02:44.510
having a policy in place for those
contractual-based or temporary type users.

52
00:02:44.510 --> 00:02:48.610
So, why is that important do disable
an account rather than going ahead and

53
00:02:48.610 --> 00:02:50.030
just deleting that user?

54
00:02:50.030 --> 00:02:52.674
>> Well, there's a lot of things that will
end up going on especially when we start

55
00:02:52.674 --> 00:02:54.267
talking about that idea of disabling,
right?

56
00:02:54.267 --> 00:02:58.554
The very fact is that the user might
have access to some information and,

57
00:02:58.554 --> 00:03:03.267
even after they leave the organization,
that account may still be valuable and

58
00:03:03.267 --> 00:03:06.040
tied to the information that's there.

59
00:03:06.040 --> 00:03:09.230
We wanna make sure that we can
access the information that's

60
00:03:09.230 --> 00:03:11.300
tied to that account if we need to.

61
00:03:11.300 --> 00:03:15.060
If you delete it right away, you may also
end up deleting whatever's been encrypted.

62
00:03:15.060 --> 00:03:16.670
So it's not really a good policy.

63
00:03:16.670 --> 00:03:19.330
Normally we talk about this
idea of disabling it and

64
00:03:19.330 --> 00:03:22.330
allowing it to sit there for a while and
make sure that we can access everything

65
00:03:22.330 --> 00:03:27.080
that we need to before going to some other
permanent basis of doing what we need to.

66
00:03:27.080 --> 00:03:30.930
So when it comes down to
the idea of creating this,

67
00:03:30.930 --> 00:03:36.630
it's not really a difficult process but it
is something that if you are told you need

68
00:03:36.630 --> 00:03:39.900
to create a user account for somebody,
you've got to know how to do that.

69
00:03:39.900 --> 00:03:43.010
So the simplest way to get started here,
okay?

70
00:03:43.010 --> 00:03:46.690
Now, if we do this is to remember
that first of all you do have to

71
00:03:46.690 --> 00:03:50.170
plan a little bit or somebody has to give
you guidelines to be able to do this.

72
00:03:50.170 --> 00:03:54.280
So that means that you need to get the
information that you're expected to get

73
00:03:54.280 --> 00:03:56.630
for that user account to be created.

74
00:03:56.630 --> 00:04:00.670
Some organizations may just say look all
you need is a username, first name, and

75
00:04:00.670 --> 00:04:02.540
last name and that's pretty much it.

76
00:04:02.540 --> 00:04:04.458
You'll set the rest on your own.

77
00:04:04.458 --> 00:04:07.880
For example, if you're gonna create
an account for them, you may go ahead and

78
00:04:07.880 --> 00:04:11.470
just have a standard password
that you give to everybody.

79
00:04:11.470 --> 00:04:14.310
And you just select that
option to make sure

80
00:04:14.310 --> 00:04:18.390
that on the first time they login to
change whatever the password may be.

81
00:04:18.390 --> 00:04:22.310
So in other words, you may have
a chance to actually get a part of that

82
00:04:22.310 --> 00:04:23.930
where you're actually making it.

83
00:04:23.930 --> 00:04:27.000
But the other information such as
what department that they're in and

84
00:04:27.000 --> 00:04:29.340
job description that's
all actually part of it,

85
00:04:29.340 --> 00:04:33.030
you need to make sure that that's
on hand first when you do so, okay?

86
00:04:33.030 --> 00:04:35.150
Then you also have to be able
to create the account and

87
00:04:35.150 --> 00:04:37.520
once you create the account it
doesn't mean that you're done.

88
00:04:37.520 --> 00:04:41.530
You need to make sure that it can be
tested and verified that it's gonna work

89
00:04:41.530 --> 00:04:44.920
and it is actually gonna be
located where you want it to be.

90
00:04:44.920 --> 00:04:48.440
So those are some of the different things
that we want to consider when we start

91
00:04:48.440 --> 00:04:52.510
creating these types of accounts for
our active directory.

92
00:04:52.510 --> 00:04:57.260
Inside of active directory then, as we
begin, we of course want to show you.

93
00:04:57.260 --> 00:05:00.090
This is kind of the first way
that I actually learned to do it,

94
00:05:00.090 --> 00:05:02.600
was by using the active
directory users and computers.

95
00:05:02.600 --> 00:05:04.070
That's probably the easiest one,

96
00:05:04.070 --> 00:05:08.130
probably the one that most people end of
going to if you started learning this too.

97
00:05:08.130 --> 00:05:12.830
Now when you start to do this,
remember that we did

98
00:05:12.830 --> 00:05:18.050
a warning to you about going directly
to the domain controller itself.

99
00:05:18.050 --> 00:05:22.270
So you may think now that I have access
to being able to create user accounts,

100
00:05:22.270 --> 00:05:25.460
I should be able to log directly
into the domain controller and

101
00:05:25.460 --> 00:05:27.680
be able to create user accounts there, but

102
00:05:27.680 --> 00:05:30.620
Cherokee remind us again who can
login to domain controllers.

103
00:05:30.620 --> 00:05:34.040
>> So we're talking about administrators,
either the local admin for

104
00:05:34.040 --> 00:05:36.660
that server or a domain admin.

105
00:05:36.660 --> 00:05:40.010
And you really need to login
to that domain controller.

106
00:05:40.010 --> 00:05:45.690
Whenever we have the concept of a
multimaster replication within our domain.

107
00:05:45.690 --> 00:05:50.990
I could even login remotely,
as long as I have access to that

108
00:05:50.990 --> 00:05:54.650
Active Directory utility,
those management tools.

109
00:05:54.650 --> 00:05:56.750
>> Yeah, so
that's one of the things, right?

110
00:05:56.750 --> 00:05:59.870
If we're trying to do this remotely,
we may find out very quickly,

111
00:05:59.870 --> 00:06:04.810
especially if I'm a junior administrator,
I'm not gonna be a domain admin, so

112
00:06:04.810 --> 00:06:07.220
can I still create user accounts or not?

113
00:06:07.220 --> 00:06:10.690
Well yeah, you definitely can if you're
assigned those privileges to be able

114
00:06:10.690 --> 00:06:11.730
to do so.

115
00:06:11.730 --> 00:06:15.530
But just because you are, doesn't mean you
can go directly to the domain controller.

116
00:06:15.530 --> 00:06:18.670
So we also talked about
this in a previous episode

117
00:06:18.670 --> 00:06:21.920
that we're gonna be using remote
management tools a majority of the time.

118
00:06:21.920 --> 00:06:26.530
And that is a best practice for us to make
sure that we understand what we're doing.

119
00:06:26.530 --> 00:06:28.930
So lets go to my machine here and
will go ahead and

120
00:06:28.930 --> 00:06:31.230
show you what we're talking about, okay?

121
00:06:31.230 --> 00:06:34.510
Remember that, here it is, you can't
really tell just by me pointing out,

122
00:06:34.510 --> 00:06:35.860
but you'll have to trust me on this.

123
00:06:35.860 --> 00:06:38.120
I'm on a Windows 10 machine here and

124
00:06:38.120 --> 00:06:41.200
this Windows 10 machine is,
lets say, my particular computer.

125
00:06:41.200 --> 00:06:43.806
And when you start to do some
type of management like this,

126
00:06:43.806 --> 00:06:47.317
normally the best practice in terms of
administration right, is that you have

127
00:06:47.317 --> 00:06:50.746
a standard user account for everything
else that you're gonna log in to do.

128
00:06:50.746 --> 00:06:54.218
All the other daily work that you
do such as checking email and

129
00:06:54.218 --> 00:06:58.713
keeping access to your ticketing system
and doing all the other things that you

130
00:06:58.713 --> 00:07:02.184
need to do on a daily basis as you
surf the internet and look for

131
00:07:02.184 --> 00:07:05.070
kitten videos on YouTube,
whatever it might be.

132
00:07:05.070 --> 00:07:06.480
Cat videos on YouTube.

133
00:07:06.480 --> 00:07:10.140
Whatever it might be, right,
as you do that, you log in with that.

134
00:07:10.140 --> 00:07:13.080
But now let's say you got
a ticket in from HR that says,

135
00:07:13.080 --> 00:07:15.660
hey, we need details of
your accounts created.

136
00:07:15.660 --> 00:07:20.620
Well, the best practice
recommendation is that you log off and

137
00:07:20.620 --> 00:07:24.750
you log back in with the credentials that
you need to, to give you essentially that

138
00:07:24.750 --> 00:07:27.260
administrative type of
access that you need.

139
00:07:27.260 --> 00:07:30.450
Now, I've already done that,
I'm logged in as Joey here.

140
00:07:30.450 --> 00:07:34.090
Who's actually a domain administrator but

141
00:07:34.090 --> 00:07:37.510
instead, when I do that,
right, then now it sets me up.

142
00:07:37.510 --> 00:07:41.350
And I have installed on here
the remote administration tools,

143
00:07:41.350 --> 00:07:44.230
the remote server administration tools for
Windows 10.

144
00:07:44.230 --> 00:07:50.550
So if I click on the start button and
then I scroll down in my Start menu,

145
00:07:50.550 --> 00:07:54.770
all the way down to the administrative
tools here, Windows administrative tools.

146
00:07:54.770 --> 00:07:57.252
I can select this and here it is.

147
00:07:57.252 --> 00:08:00.013
It's Active Directory Users and Computers.

148
00:08:00.013 --> 00:08:03.294
That's the one that I'm going
to select and launch from there.

149
00:08:03.294 --> 00:08:05.412
When I do so,
it may ask me for credentials.

150
00:08:05.412 --> 00:08:09.653
I've already launched that up so that we
could get here a little bit easier and

151

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Ronnie continue to examine Active Directory user accounts. Depending on the task one may choose to ADUC, PowerShell or additional tools such as a CSV file to create, modify or delete objects. Ronnie shows while it may be cumbersome to type a long string of PowerShell syntax it will help save time in the long run.

>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

520
00:28:51.847 --> 00:28:59.515
[MUSIC]

521
00:28:59.515 --> 00:29:02.248
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie tackle some of the most common administrative duties one may encounter whilst working within Active Directory. The discuss some best practices that should be considered followed by Ronnie demonstrating how to configure the in both the GUI and via PowerShell. Tune in to learn how to set passwords, expiration options, unlock accounts and manage stale accounts.
episodes.title: Managing User Accounts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.099 --> 00:00:04.850
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:04.850 --> 00:00:06.489
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.489 --> 00:00:08.338
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.338 --> 00:00:12.151
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.151 --> 00:00:15.930
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to
your Microsoft Server 101 series.

6
00:00:15.930 --> 00:00:18.115
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.115 --> 00:00:19.590
So in previous episode,

8
00:00:19.590 --> 00:00:24.520
Ronnie showed us how to create different
users within Active Directory.

9
00:00:24.520 --> 00:00:27.860
But in this show we're really gonna be
taking a look at how we can go ahead and

10
00:00:27.860 --> 00:00:29.530
manage those users.

11
00:00:29.530 --> 00:00:32.030
Back in studios with us today,
we have Mr. Ronnie Wong.

12
00:00:32.030 --> 00:00:33.330
Thanks for joining use today, Ronnie.

13
00:00:33.330 --> 00:00:37.140
>> Well, thank you for having me back as
we continue on in taking a look at more,

14
00:00:37.140 --> 00:00:38.930
learning about Active Directory.

15
00:00:38.930 --> 00:00:43.321
And some of the skills and tasks that we
need to at least be familiar with if we

16
00:00:43.321 --> 00:00:48.010
get into that role where we are going to
be working with servers on a daily basis.

17
00:00:48.010 --> 00:00:52.138
>> Yeah so, Ronnie, when we talk about
administrative duties somethings like

18
00:00:52.138 --> 00:00:55.900
spitting up a particular server and
setting it up We do ever so often.

19
00:00:55.900 --> 00:00:58.750
But when we're working with and
Active Directory,

20
00:00:58.750 --> 00:01:03.700
there are probably a lot of repetitive
type task that we encounter, right?

21
00:01:03.700 --> 00:01:05.450
>> Yep, there pretty much are.

22
00:01:05.450 --> 00:01:09.530
And some of those different types of task,
especially in working with user accounts,

23
00:01:09.530 --> 00:01:12.830
are going to be things that you'll
just have to know how to do.

24
00:01:12.830 --> 00:01:15.400
And you'll have to be able to
do them quickly a lot of times,

25
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:16.820
because people are waiting.

26
00:01:16.820 --> 00:01:20.302
If they can't get logged into the machines
you'll need to do a little bit of

27
00:01:20.302 --> 00:01:24.021
troubleshooting and then you'll need to
be able to implement some type of fix.

28
00:01:24.021 --> 00:01:28.818
So for example, one of those types
managing task that we really have to do is

29
00:01:28.818 --> 00:01:32.104
something just as simple
as resetting a password.

30
00:01:32.104 --> 00:01:35.193
It's not difficult but
it is something we definitely need to do.

31
00:01:35.193 --> 00:01:39.035
>> So Ronnie, and I know I kept mentioning
this and it is very important for

32
00:01:39.035 --> 00:01:41.560
us to go ahead to reset those password.

33
00:01:41.560 --> 00:01:44.404
But what's the significance behind that?

34
00:01:44.404 --> 00:01:48.392
>> Well, you gotta think that there
are times which all of us have had happen,

35
00:01:48.392 --> 00:01:50.800
especially if we're new of the job.

36
00:01:50.800 --> 00:01:53.300
Even though a password has
been assigned to us and

37
00:01:53.300 --> 00:01:57.530
even though we might have actually
gone ahead and created a password

38
00:01:57.530 --> 00:02:02.430
according to the security policy of that
company and it requires anything complex.

39
00:02:02.430 --> 00:02:04.527
Probably within that first week or so,

40
00:02:04.527 --> 00:02:07.712
people have actually forgotten
their passwords already.

41
00:02:07.712 --> 00:02:11.342
So resetting that password is actually
something that we may have to do.

42
00:02:11.342 --> 00:02:14.397
Unless they're trying to use
a default password that we gave them,

43
00:02:14.397 --> 00:02:16.018
which is never a good idea anyways.

44
00:02:16.018 --> 00:02:19.482
But at least that idea is something
that we have to run across.

45
00:02:19.482 --> 00:02:22.256
So the reasons why we might reset
a password are things like people

46
00:02:22.256 --> 00:02:23.550
forgetting it.

47
00:02:23.550 --> 00:02:26.450
But, let's say that it's not
something that's forgotten, but

48
00:02:26.450 --> 00:02:28.150
all the sudden we're monitoring.

49
00:02:28.150 --> 00:02:29.710
And we're realizing something.

50
00:02:29.710 --> 00:02:33.680
That Cherokee is actually logged
into multiple different machines.

51
00:02:33.680 --> 00:02:36.141
But, when we go and
ask Cherokee about it, she says,

52
00:02:36.141 --> 00:02:38.241
I haven't been logging into anywhere else.

53
00:02:38.241 --> 00:02:42.690
And now, Cherokee begins to essentially
help us to raise a little bit of an alert.

54
00:02:42.690 --> 00:02:46.160
Saying hey, something else is going
on here besides what we need to do.

55
00:02:46.160 --> 00:02:49.384
We find out those machines,
of course we logged them out, but

56
00:02:49.384 --> 00:02:53.600
if we leave the password as set, that's
gonna allow for whoever might have taken

57
00:02:53.600 --> 00:02:57.589
advantage of her particular username and
password to be able to get back in.

58
00:02:57.589 --> 00:03:01.153
So resetting her password might actually
be something that we also want to take

59
00:03:01.153 --> 00:03:02.131
advantage of doing.

60
00:03:02.131 --> 00:03:05.664
Now, there's probably other conditions and
other situations that we might have.

61
00:03:05.664 --> 00:03:10.200
But, those are two good situations that at
least I can think of, off the top of my

62
00:03:10.200 --> 00:03:15.550
head, when we start talking about the idea
of resetting that password as well okay?

63
00:03:15.550 --> 00:03:21.890
Now, the unusual thing about it Is
that as a server administrator,

64
00:03:21.890 --> 00:03:27.220
or an active directory administrator,
we become so busy with other task.

65
00:03:27.220 --> 00:03:30.360
This is something that's just easy for
us to do.

66
00:03:30.360 --> 00:03:34.347
And if the same user continually
comes to us and says,

67
00:03:34.347 --> 00:03:39.146
I keep forgetting the password
cuz I keep making it too complex.

68
00:03:39.146 --> 00:03:41.319
Well, you don't really wanna tell
them to make it less complex

69
00:03:41.319 --> 00:03:42.650
than what they have it.

70
00:03:42.650 --> 00:03:44.850
But you don't wanna reset it all the time.

71
00:03:44.850 --> 00:03:49.520
So, Cherokee, if you were doing this or if
you've actually seen this happen, right?

72
00:03:49.520 --> 00:03:54.486
Would you actually just go, all right,
here's what I'm gonna do instead.

73
00:03:54.486 --> 00:03:57.610
Cuz Ronnie is obviously bad
at remembering passwords.

74
00:03:57.610 --> 00:04:01.950
What is an option I may choose to do as an
administrator that's really a bad option?

75
00:04:01.950 --> 00:04:04.089
>> So
a bad option would be to go ahead and

76
00:04:04.089 --> 00:04:07.471
give them the right to be able
to reset their own password.

77
00:04:07.471 --> 00:04:12.574
But something that you could do instead
with an Active Directory would be,

78
00:04:12.574 --> 00:04:16.383
maybe there is a site manager,
like an office manager.

79
00:04:16.383 --> 00:04:19.470
And you work for IT, and
you're not even there locally.

80
00:04:19.470 --> 00:04:23.969
So maybe you could go ahead and give some
delegation to that site manager to go

81
00:04:23.969 --> 00:04:28.137
ahead, perform some really basic
rudimentary type tasks like that.

82
00:04:28.137 --> 00:04:31.769
>> Right, and so when you do something
like that, and that's a good thing to do,

83
00:04:31.769 --> 00:04:34.152
but what does that manager
end up doing sometimes?

84
00:04:34.152 --> 00:04:37.045
Especially if Ronnie gets really bad at
it, he's coming to him every other day.

85
00:04:37.045 --> 00:04:43.529
As I am there's an option here that says,
password should never expire.

86
00:04:43.529 --> 00:04:47.134
Now what are the chances that somebody
else survive even delegated those

87
00:04:47.134 --> 00:04:50.340
to somebody to a supervisor that
might be what they end up doing.

88
00:04:50.340 --> 00:04:54.352
>> Yeah, I mean that could happen, if that
does happen you might wanna look at may be

89
00:04:54.352 --> 00:04:58.600
retraining that employee because it's not
something usually you wanna stick within

90
00:04:58.600 --> 00:05:01.805
your password policy or
your security policy and abide by that.

91
00:05:01.805 --> 00:05:03.583
But that doesn't always happen.

92
00:05:03.583 --> 00:05:06.530
>> Yeah, if you've delegated
the permissions off to them.

93
00:05:06.530 --> 00:05:08.920
Well, they have all
those options available.

94
00:05:08.920 --> 00:05:10.910
They might go Ronnie
is really bad at this.

95
00:05:10.910 --> 00:05:12.810
This is the third time this week.

96
00:05:12.810 --> 00:05:14.250
Let me just do this instead.

97
00:05:14.250 --> 00:05:15.890
And that way it doesn't.

98
00:05:15.890 --> 00:05:17.360
His password's never going to expire.

99
00:05:17.360 --> 00:05:18.820
So after a while.

100
00:05:18.820 --> 00:05:22.690
Let's just say that they do it with a good
intention of changing it after a week.

101
00:05:22.690 --> 00:05:26.010
We'll give them a whole week
of using that same password.

102
00:05:26.010 --> 00:05:28.924
And maybe that way,
he'll be able to do this.

103
00:05:28.924 --> 00:05:30.250
And then we forget it, right?

104
00:05:30.250 --> 00:05:34.360
And that person forgets it, whoever it
is that we delegated it to forgets that.

105
00:05:34.360 --> 00:05:39.700
And they leave it set there, well let's
think about some of the situations

106
00:05:39.700 --> 00:05:43.360
that that may actually end up causing and
bring it up as well.

107
00:05:43.360 --> 00:05:48.651
So for example, in that situation, whoever
the administrator is forgets to say,

108
00:05:48.651 --> 00:05:52.668
let me uncheck that after we fill out and
they've gotten that.

109
00:05:52.668 --> 00:05:56.659
Well, what's the big deal that I leave
that password there now for six months?

110
00:05:56.659 --> 00:06:00.713
>> Well, attackers,
really depending on their motive, but

111
00:06:00.713 --> 00:06:03.964
a good attacker will really
try to just lay low.

112
00:06:03.964 --> 00:06:08.560
And maybe their motive is blackmail, or
any kind of obtaining any information.

113
00:06:09.900 --> 00:06:13.410
So if an account has been compromised,
they may just wanna go ahead and

114
00:06:13.410 --> 00:06:18.040
lay low and eavesdrop for
that six months period of time.

115
00:06:18.040 --> 00:06:19.570
>> Yeah, it's really amazing, right?

116
00:06:19.570 --> 00:06:23.488
The very fact is we give an attacker
that's good at what he's doing, more

117
00:06:23.488 --> 00:06:27.800
opportunity and time, to realize something
that that account is not changing.

118
00:06:27.800 --> 00:06:30.876
So it's not like he's going ahead and
he's doing a bruteforce attack,

119
00:06:30.876 --> 00:06:34.180
and then we change the password,
and he has to start all over again.

120
00:06:34.180 --> 00:06:38.673
We're just saying just continue to do your
work and do that in the background and

121
00:06:38.673 --> 00:06:40.361
don't worry about it at all.

122
00:06:40.361 --> 00:06:44.633
So that's something we really don't want
to do and make sure that we don't do that.

123
00:06:44.633 --> 00:06:48.952
Now the other thing of course is that if
we also set this where the password never

124
00:06:48.952 --> 00:06:53.420
expires, it means that if now I delegate
that responsibility to somebody else.

125
00:06:53.420 --> 00:06:56.260
Let's say that that person that I
delegated to was really bad and

126
00:06:56.260 --> 00:06:58.170
I delegate it to somebody else.

127
00:06:58.170 --> 00:07:00.326
And they forget to remove that check mark.

128
00:07:00.326 --> 00:07:01.650
Now they go, simple.

129
00:07:01.650 --> 00:07:03.190
I'll just reset Ronnie's password, and

130
00:07:03.190 --> 00:07:05.700
he'll be able to actually
create a new one.

131
00:07:05.700 --> 00:07:07.774
Well now that that's checked, right?

132
00:07:07.774 --> 00:07:09.784
Password never expires and reset it.

133
00:07:09.784 --> 00:07:14.774
That password, can he actually end up
typing the same one again and still go?

134
00:07:14.774 --> 00:07:16.115
You better believe it.

135
00:07:16.115 --> 00:07:19.828
And so this actually causes
a very unusual conundrum here,

136
00:07:19.828 --> 00:07:22.511
something we don't want to happen right.

137
00:07:22.511 --> 00:07:25.455
So resetting passwords and
doing it effectively is the key,

138
00:07:25.455 --> 00:07:29.265
the problem that the administration side
is that I mentioned in another active

139
00:07:29.265 --> 00:07:31.188
directory show that we've just done.

140
00:07:31.188 --> 00:07:35.040
Is, well we get lazy as
administrators as well.

141
00:07:35.040 --> 00:07:39.415
When I reset somebody's password issues
lead to something that I'm going to

142
00:07:39.415 --> 00:07:42.509
remember and
even though I tell them to change that to,

143
00:07:42.509 --> 00:07:44.142
whatever that they need to.

144
00:07:44.142 --> 00:07:46.302
I've put that check mark there that says,

145
00:07:46.302 --> 00:07:49.981
make sure that they on the next log on
they have to change their password.

146
00:07:49.981 --> 00:07:52.884
Is still the same password that I have
been using now for the past five years.

147
00:07:52.884 --> 00:07:54.584
Cherokee was wrong with that?

148
00:07:54.584 --> 00:07:59.307
Well Ronnie, I can see a lot wrong with
that because if an attacker were able to

149
00:07:59.307 --> 00:08:04.033
compromise one of your accounts,
you probably have an affinity towards that

150
00:08:04.033 --> 00:08:07.972
password, especially if you've
been using it for five years.

151
00:08:07.972 --> 00:08:12.312
So they can take that password and
then really just kind of guess with other

152
00:08:12.312 --> 00:08:16.731
accounts or even use it as a pivot point
to try to break into another system.

153
00:08:16.731 --> 00:08:21.285
>> And there's no doubt that all of these
essentially lead to bad ways that we're

154
00:08:21.285 --> 00:08:24.940
mismanaging user accounts and
passwords in that way.

155
00:08:24.940 --> 00:08:26.760
So whether it's because we delegate it and

156
00:08:26.760 --> 00:08:29.489
somebody else took advantage of
the options that were there, or

157
00:08:29.489 --> 00:08:33.043
whether we're just bad at remembering
passwords, whatever it might be, right?

158
00:08:33.043 --> 00:08:34.226
Bad at resetting them and

159
00:08:34.226 --> 00:08:38.220
bad at actually understanding the options
before us we need to do better.

160
00:08:38.220 --> 00:08:41.770
So when we reset password there is one of
these unusual things that we have to think

161
00:08:41.770 --> 00:08:45.050
about, we really don't wanna reset it to
a very common password because of what

162
00:08:45.050 --> 00:08:46.340
Cherokee just said.

163
00:08:46.340 --> 00:08:49.420
We also don't wanna make sure that
that password never expires because

164
00:08:49.420 --> 00:08:52.470
we're giving the advantage
now to the attacker, right?

165
00:08:52.470 --> 00:08:55.091
So that's something that
we don't want to do,

166
00:08:55.091 --> 00:08:59.163
we also don't want the user to just
simply go okay they reset my password.

167
00:08:59.163 --> 00:09:01.523
Let me see if I can use
the exact same password again.

168
00:09:01.523 --> 00:09:03.540
That's something we
don't wanna do as well.

169
00:09:03.540 --> 00:09:06.125
The great thing is normally this
doesn't happen too often because

170
00:09:06.125 --> 00:09:09.420
it's controlled inside of
something called group policy

171
00:09:09.420 --> 00:09:11.860
which we'll be getting to
later on in this show.

172
00:09:11.860 --> 00:09:15.130
But overall though Is something
that we have to consider.

173
00:09:15.130 --> 00:09:18.440
So, when we start to do that we need to
understand where we go to reset those

174
00:09:18.440 --> 00:09:21.750
policies, and we need to know
what we can do about this idea

175
00:09:21.750 --> 00:09:24.550
instead of using the same
exact password again.

176
00:09:24.550 --> 00:09:25.920
So, let's go ahead and

177
00:09:25.920 --> 00:09:29.310
take a look inside of our active
directory users and computers.

178
00:09:29.310 --> 00:09:32.200
I went ahead and
pulled it up right here on my machine, so

179
00:09:32.200 --> 00:09:35.570
that we can take a look and
we can see up here at the very top.

180
00:09:35.570 --> 00:09:38.110
In the Active Directory Users and
Computers.

181
00:09:38.110 --> 00:09:40.550
I am logged on remotely to do this.

182
00:09:40.550 --> 00:09:45.470
So as soon as I did that, I went into
my Windows administrative tools.

183
00:09:45.470 --> 00:09:47.910
And when I clicked on it,
it asked me for credentials and

184
00:09:47.910 --> 00:09:49.530
it popped it up right here.

185
00:09:49.530 --> 00:09:52.356
So now I'm remotely connected
in the way that I should be,

186
00:09:52.356 --> 00:09:55.021
not using Remote Desktop
into the domain controller.

187
00:09:55.021 --> 00:10:00.133
But everything is actually where I want
it to be, so if I want to go ahead and

188
00:10:00.133 --> 00:10:03.850
reset a user's password,
well I can pick somebody.

189
00:10:03.850 --> 00:10:08.850
So let's pick for example right here,
let's just say Han Solo here.

190
00:10:08.850 --> 00:10:11.001
So if I select that, it's simple.

191
00:10:11.001 --> 00:10:14.710
I reset that particular password,
and there we go.

192
00:10:14.710 --> 00:10:18.350
We can go ahead and set his new password.

193
00:10:18.350 --> 00:10:21.040
That's available to doing that.

194
00:10:21.040 --> 00:10:21.910
So there it is.

195
00:10:21.910 --> 00:10:26.772
I set up my password and
now I start to see something right away.

196
00:10:26.772 --> 00:10:30.733
Now the great thing is most people will
actually understand in a lab environment

197
00:10:30.733 --> 00:10:33.350
we don't tend to set
very complex passwords.

198
00:10:33.350 --> 00:10:37.028
But in a production environment whatever
you set this to right it should be

199
00:10:37.028 --> 00:10:41.203
different it should be something that we
don't want it to be easily guessed at all.

200
00:10:41.203 --> 00:10:44.326
It's something that we wanna make sure
that we follow whatever the security

201
00:10:44.326 --> 00:10:46.960
policy is to make sure
that this doesn't happen.

202
00:10:46.960 --> 00:10:52.520
We wanna verify also that the user must
change his password at next login as well.

203
00:10:52.520 --> 00:10:57.040
And if the account, let me move that over,
if the account is actually locked,

204
00:10:57.040 --> 00:10:59.653
we of course want to
unlock the user account.

205
00:10:59.653 --> 00:11:01.780
And then they're off and ready to go.

206
00:11:01.780 --> 00:11:04.610
Now it may be that you
choose to keep it locked,

207
00:11:04.610 --> 00:11:08.520
because the user is really that
bad at not being able to do this.

208
00:11:08.520 --> 00:11:13.468
But overall, though, it's just as simple
to reset a particular password, and

209
00:11:13.468 --> 00:11:15.741
that's what we actually have to do.

210
00:11:15.741 --> 00:11:19.054
Now, the big thing that we can
do as the administrator, though,

211
00:11:19.054 --> 00:11:22.800
is really to come up with something
that is relatively unique.

212
00:11:22.800 --> 00:11:25.560
For this idea of these new passwords but

213
00:11:25.560 --> 00:11:30.910
it also requires them that the user be
able to type those password in too.

214
00:11:30.910 --> 00:11:35.020
So the recommendation here, just like
it has been as password policies have

215
00:11:35.020 --> 00:11:38.580
continued to change,
is no longer just about complexity, right?

216
00:11:38.580 --> 00:11:41.440
It's about the idea of
the length of it as well.

217
00:11:41.440 --> 00:11:45.710
So remember that length also includes
spaces, as well as everything else.

218
00:11:45.710 --> 00:11:47.950
So you may wanna come up
with let's say a line,

219
00:11:47.950 --> 00:11:50.663
of something that you actually do know and
understand.

220

446
00:24:37.780 --> 00:24:42.960
Computers first as we begin
to take a look as well, okay?

447
00:24:42.960 --> 00:24:46.420
Now to be able to find stale
accounts at this point,

448
00:24:46.420 --> 00:24:50.920
what we can do here is that if you are in
the Active Directory Users' computers,

449
00:24:50.920 --> 00:24:56.440
you want to go up to the actual domain,
which is right here, okay?

450
00:24:56.440 --> 00:25:00.600
And then I can right click on
that domain and select Find.

451
00:25:02.130 --> 00:25:06.730
Now when I select Find, it's under here
that you may actually choose to do,

452
00:25:06.730 --> 00:25:10.360
let me see here,
I wanna do a common query.

453
00:25:10.360 --> 00:25:12.352
Make sure I'm actually telling you right.

454
00:25:12.352 --> 00:25:15.640
And now,
you start to see some other things too.

455
00:25:15.640 --> 00:25:21.780
Notice this last option where it says
since days logged in, last logged in.

456
00:25:21.780 --> 00:25:26.810
So this is where you can go through and
instead of you having to define all this,

457
00:25:26.810 --> 00:25:30.560
you select let's say 30 days or
so if you haven't logged in.

458
00:25:30.560 --> 00:25:34.470
Tell it to find who hasn't
logged in in those 30 days.

459
00:25:34.470 --> 00:25:38.130
So this will give you that option to
be able to find those accounts and

460
00:25:38.130 --> 00:25:40.120
that's a manual option for us.

461
00:25:40.120 --> 00:25:43.520
But it does help us to be
able to do that as well.

462
00:25:43.520 --> 00:25:46.600
So using something like this,
it will at least help you identify that.

463
00:25:46.600 --> 00:25:50.220
Then of course, the process may be,

464
00:25:50.220 --> 00:25:53.300
depending on your security policy,
where you delete those accounts.

465
00:25:53.300 --> 00:25:54.370
Normally not.

466
00:25:54.370 --> 00:25:57.490
More than likely,
we're probably going to disable them.

467
00:25:57.490 --> 00:26:00.710
And, of course, that means you're gonna
contact whoever the supervisors are and

468
00:26:00.710 --> 00:26:03.700
say, hey,
is this account still active or valid or

469
00:26:03.700 --> 00:26:05.970
why hasn't this person
logged in in 30 days,

470
00:26:05.970 --> 00:26:10.060
or whether it might be that's something
you want to be able to do it as well.

471
00:26:10.060 --> 00:26:12.000
Now, the same thing is
true then in PowerShell.

472
00:26:12.000 --> 00:26:14.830
I'm not gonna worry about
the PowerShell so much right now.

473
00:26:14.830 --> 00:26:18.650
You will find, let's say on a command
that's similar in PowerShell,

474
00:26:18.650 --> 00:26:21.000
that you could run and do the same thing.

475
00:26:21.000 --> 00:26:24.000
Check out Brian's book once
again in this chapter and

476
00:26:24.000 --> 00:26:26.240
you'll find that command
right there as well.

477
00:26:26.240 --> 00:26:28.100
Setting up these days,

478
00:26:28.100 --> 00:26:33.140
the limitation that you have right here in
this, is you can't type in your number.

479
00:26:33.140 --> 00:26:35.360
So let's say days since logged in.

480
00:26:35.360 --> 00:26:38.050
Cherokee, what if I
wanted it to be 45 days?

481
00:26:38.050 --> 00:26:38.910
I can't change that.

482
00:26:38.910 --> 00:26:40.616
>> Yeah, you've got 30 to 60 and so

483
00:26:40.616 --> 00:26:43.050
maybe that's when PowerShell
would be a good tool.

484
00:26:43.050 --> 00:26:45.530
So I could really specify
that 45 day limit.

485
00:26:45.530 --> 00:26:46.170
>> Yeah.
So

486
00:26:46.170 --> 00:26:47.600
that's where PowerShell
would help you out.

487
00:26:47.600 --> 00:26:49.520
If your security policy says no.

488
00:26:49.520 --> 00:26:53.723
We're gonna make it six weeks,
which is gonna be seven times six.

489
00:26:53.723 --> 00:26:54.670
Yeah, that would work.

490
00:26:54.670 --> 00:26:56.235
That actually works, 42 days.

491
00:26:56.235 --> 00:26:58.570
[LAUGH] You can even do that.

492
00:26:58.570 --> 00:27:01.660
Whereas something like that, but that
would only be done through the PowerShell.

493
00:27:01.660 --> 00:27:04.750
And it's the same option that
you have available to you

494
00:27:04.750 --> 00:27:07.190
to be able to find that when you do it.

495
00:27:07.190 --> 00:27:12.040
Now normally, of course, once you disable
it the recommended practice is don't

496
00:27:12.040 --> 00:27:16.430
just disable it, because people begin
to wonder why is this account disabled?

497
00:27:16.430 --> 00:27:19.240
Always add a description
on why you disabled it.

498
00:27:19.240 --> 00:27:22.300
It may be that you found stale user or

499
00:27:22.300 --> 00:27:27.390
stale account here not logged in since
this and you disabled it on this day.

500
00:27:27.390 --> 00:27:31.230
That way it helps people that
are actually paying attention there,

501
00:27:31.230 --> 00:27:34.480
to figure out why instead of just
enabling all these accounts,

502
00:27:34.480 --> 00:27:37.060
they don't need to be
disabled at this point.

503
00:27:37.060 --> 00:27:38.520
This person still works here.

504
00:27:38.520 --> 00:27:40.670
Well make sure you add
something in there as well.

505
00:27:40.670 --> 00:27:43.130
Don't forget special use cases too.

506
00:27:43.130 --> 00:27:47.970
Somebody that may go on maternity leave
that may not be checking as well.

507
00:27:47.970 --> 00:27:51.230
Or they may be a reservist that's
just been called up to active duty.

508
00:27:51.230 --> 00:27:55.850
All these things are considerations that
we may also have to consider as well.

509
00:27:56.900 --> 00:27:58.550
Now even though I said
that was the last thing,

510
00:27:58.550 --> 00:28:02.600
I just remembered as I looked down here,
we need to talk about deleting accounts.

511
00:28:02.600 --> 00:28:06.720
Now, Cherokee, do you know when
you should delete an account?

512
00:28:06.720 --> 00:28:09.530
>> I would say following
your companies policy.

513
00:28:09.530 --> 00:28:13.490
So if you're by default let's
say we go ahead and set,

514
00:28:13.490 --> 00:28:18.470
maybe it's our company's policy to
disable that account after 45 days and

515
00:28:18.470 --> 00:28:21.210
then delete the account after 90 days.

516
00:28:21.210 --> 00:28:24.800
>> Yeah, you follow the actually
policy that's in place, and

517
00:28:24.800 --> 00:28:26.730
that's going to be the key for you.

518
00:28:26.730 --> 00:28:29.721
So some places will have it
where it's a very strict policy,

519
00:28:29.721 --> 00:28:31.666
where you go through and find all that.

520
00:28:31.666 --> 00:28:34.060
And they set it up in that way, too.

521
00:28:34.060 --> 00:28:36.960
Now if you're actually kind of one
of the two people that's doing it,

522
00:28:36.960 --> 00:28:38.590
you might find out something
a little bit differently.

523
00:28:38.590 --> 00:28:42.210
For example, like here,
I've worked with everybody at ITProTV,

524
00:28:42.210 --> 00:28:46.490
at least right at the beginning,
for probably a decade now.

525
00:28:46.490 --> 00:28:50.360
Now, that was before ITProTV came along,
but for a decade.

526
00:28:50.360 --> 00:28:51.360
And I found out something.

527
00:28:51.360 --> 00:28:57.630
That at least from the perspective of the
ones that have actually been the network

528
00:28:57.630 --> 00:29:02.010
administrators, to doing all this,
that we have never deleted an account.

529
00:29:02.010 --> 00:29:03.710
It didn't matter how many people do it.

530
00:29:03.710 --> 00:29:08.620
We simply disable it, and we move them
off to another OU that just says,

531
00:29:08.620 --> 00:29:11.000
disabled accounts, is what we do.

532
00:29:11.000 --> 00:29:14.950
And it's not that we have a fear of doing
it, but we also wanna make sure that

533
00:29:14.950 --> 00:29:18.211
if anybody ever questions whether or
not we've had it there,

534
00:29:18.211 --> 00:29:22.540
its' actually there and available and
it's not like they were never in existence

535
00:29:22.540 --> 00:29:26.209
inside of what we had available to us,
so being able to disable that.

536
00:29:26.209 --> 00:29:28.550
So some, why can't I say it?

537
00:29:28.550 --> 00:29:31.360
Some places then will
have you delete them.

538
00:29:31.360 --> 00:29:33.104
Some places will do
exactly like what we do.

539
00:29:33.104 --> 00:29:34.480
We just don't delete them.

540
00:29:34.480 --> 00:29:38.820
We just simply disable them, move them off
to an OU that we're not gonna really use.

541
00:29:38.820 --> 00:29:41.980
And we also make sure that we
put a policy on them that says,

542
00:29:41.980 --> 00:29:45.160
you have access to nothing,
is what we also do as well.

543
00:29:45.160 --> 00:29:46.490
>> So you bring up a good point, Ronnie.

544
00:29:46.490 --> 00:29:49.890
Because it's completely discretionary,
like we said of that company.

545
00:29:49.890 --> 00:29:52.320
But just keep in mind,
we've talked about this before,

546
00:29:52.320 --> 00:29:55.630
the particular security identifiers
that are attached with that object in

547
00:29:55.630 --> 00:30:00.460
Active Directory cannot be recreated, even
if, let's say, I deleted Ronnie's account.

548
00:30:00.460 --> 00:30:02.590
And his username was Ronnie Wong.

549
00:30:02.590 --> 00:30:04.550
And I deleted him and I'm like, oops, and

550
00:30:04.550 --> 00:30:06.907
then I'll just recreate
him in Active Directory.

551
00:30:06.907 --> 00:30:10.590
And that's,
it's really it's a one way street there.

552
00:30:10.590 --> 00:30:13.180
So it's not like I can ever
get that account back.

553
00:30:13.180 --> 00:30:15.430
So it really just depends
on your organization.

554
00:30:15.430 --> 00:30:16.730
>> It really does, but

555
00:30:16.730 --> 00:30:19.510
it is something that we definitely
want to pay attention to.

556
00:30:19.510 --> 00:30:21.870
You have some forgiveness a little bit,
right.

557
00:30:21.870 --> 00:30:25.390
There's that Active Directory recycle
bin that's actually there today.

558
00:30:25.390 --> 00:30:28.860
But at the same time, its' something
instead, that what you'll see today,

559
00:30:28.860 --> 00:30:32.120
to prevent from accidental deletions,
just like what Cherokee was talking about,

560
00:30:32.120 --> 00:30:34.060
you have that little check mark that says,

561
00:30:34.060 --> 00:30:36.990
prevent this object from
being deleted accidentally.

562
00:30:36.990 --> 00:30:39.430
And that's something that
apparently has happened so

563
00:30:39.430 --> 00:30:43.850
often that Microsoft said, we need to
include that into Active Directory now.

564
00:30:43.850 --> 00:30:44.830
So just take a look at it.

565
00:30:44.830 --> 00:30:46.000
Can you do it in Power Shell?

566
00:30:46.000 --> 00:30:46.620
Yes.

567
00:30:46.620 --> 00:30:47.460
Definitely.

568
00:30:47.460 --> 00:30:50.390
Can you do this inside of
the Active Directory user computers?

569
00:30:50.390 --> 00:30:51.010
Yes.

570
00:30:51.010 --> 00:30:54.410
Can you do this inside of
Active Directory Administration Center?

571
00:30:54.410 --> 00:30:55.560
Absolutely.

572
00:30:55.560 --> 00:30:57.400
All these are fairly simple things for

573
00:30:57.400 --> 00:31:02.360
us to do, but don't do them
unless you actually do have clear

574
00:31:02.360 --> 00:31:06.960
policy guiding you to do any one of those
things, especially on deleting accounts.

575
00:31:06.960 --> 00:31:10.703
Because messing with somebody's
security identifier,

576
00:31:10.703 --> 00:31:15.831
it can disconnect everything, that
whatever they actually needed, is gone.

577
00:31:15.831 --> 00:31:17.170
If it's encrypted, it's gone.

578
00:31:17.170 --> 00:31:18.740
You're just kind of in trouble.

579
00:31:18.740 --> 00:31:20.740
So it's not something we
would definitely want to do.

580
00:31:20.740 --> 00:31:24.600
But those are some of the common,
everyday types of tasks that we'll

581
00:31:24.600 --> 00:31:27.660
end up seeing when we start managing
user accounts in Active Directory.

582
00:31:27.660 --> 00:31:29.480
>> Well, Ronnie, thank you for
sharing those with us.

583
00:31:29.480 --> 00:31:33.380
However, I have a feeling we're not quite
finished with Active Directory yet.

584
00:31:33.380 --> 00:31:36.950
So ladies and gentlemen, stay tuned for
more information headed your way.

585
00:31:36.950 --> 00:31:38.310
This show, we'll go ahead and sign out.

586
00:31:38.310 --> 00:31:40.040
Remember, I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

587
00:31:40.040 --> 00:31:40.980
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

588
00:31:40.980 --> 00:31:43.975
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

589
00:31:43.975 --> 00:31:49.890
[MUSIC]

590
00:31:49.890 --> 00:31:53.517
Thank you for watching IT PRO TV.

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee explain how to manage computer accounts. They look at two different ways of doing so. First, they explain that computer accounts by default are created when a computer joins a domain or created manually when pre-staging an account before it is joined to a domain. They also show different ways to accomplish these tasks both in the GUI as well as PowerShell.
episodes.title: Manage AD Computer Accounts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.084 --> 00:00:01.082
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet-

2
00:00:01.082 --> 00:00:02.366
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:02.366 --> 00:00:08.191
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.191 --> 00:00:10.845
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.845 --> 00:00:15.568
>> Welcome to your Server 101 series,
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:15.568 --> 00:00:16.823
In this episode,

7
00:00:16.823 --> 00:00:22.022
we'll be taking a look at creating
Active Directory computer accounts.

8
00:00:22.022 --> 00:00:23.695
With us today back in studios we have Mr.

9
00:00:23.695 --> 00:00:25.957
Ronnie Wong, thank you for
joining us today Ronnie.

10
00:00:25.957 --> 00:00:29.640
>> Well, thank you for having me back
as we continue on taking a look at

11
00:00:29.640 --> 00:00:32.230
the idea of computer accounts today.

12
00:00:32.230 --> 00:00:34.080
And if you're watching this episode,

13
00:00:34.080 --> 00:00:38.670
you probably did see us in previous Active
Directory episodes where we talked about

14
00:00:38.670 --> 00:00:43.160
of course creating user accounts
as well as managing user accounts.

15
00:00:43.160 --> 00:00:45.400
And you're probably wondering,
like I am at times like,

16
00:00:45.400 --> 00:00:48.370
why did I just jump right into
managing computer accounts?

17
00:00:48.370 --> 00:00:51.950
You didn't talk about creating
computer accounts, and then do this?

18
00:00:51.950 --> 00:00:54.030
And that's because we're
combining it all into one show.

19
00:00:54.030 --> 00:00:57.912
So I probably could have called it
Creating and Managing Computer Accounts,

20
00:00:57.912 --> 00:01:00.314
but way too long of a name for
Active Directory.

21
00:01:00.314 --> 00:01:03.030
But that's what we're jumping into,
in this episode.

22
00:01:03.030 --> 00:01:06.760
Is that ability, not only to create
computer accounts in Active Directory, but

23
00:01:06.760 --> 00:01:10.600
also to manage them a way that
we actually need to, right?

24
00:01:10.600 --> 00:01:12.363
Every server administrator,

25
00:01:12.363 --> 00:01:16.358
one of the tasks that you're gonna
end up doing daily, a lot of times,

26
00:01:16.358 --> 00:01:20.720
is managing computer accounts throughout
your Active Directory network.

27
00:01:20.720 --> 00:01:24.557
Same thing with of course with user
accounts, but usually you deal with those

28
00:01:24.557 --> 00:01:27.970
a little bit more often than you
do with the computer accounts.

29
00:01:27.970 --> 00:01:31.082
But we do need to know some of
the different tasks and we have to

30
00:01:31.082 --> 00:01:35.120
actually develop our skill set there
with managing these computer accounts.

31
00:01:35.120 --> 00:01:36.820
And that's what we wanna do today.

32
00:01:36.820 --> 00:01:38.450
>> Now Ronnie,
throughout this series so far,

33
00:01:38.450 --> 00:01:42.150
you've shown us different ways to
execute certain functions or tasks.

34
00:01:42.150 --> 00:01:45.460
When we're talking about creating these
user accounts, what options do we have?

35
00:01:45.460 --> 00:01:48.840
>> Well, when it comes down to
Active Directory computer accounts,

36
00:01:48.840 --> 00:01:52.180
you really have two ways that
you're gonna create that entry or

37
00:01:52.180 --> 00:01:54.780
that object inside of Active Directory.

38
00:01:54.780 --> 00:01:59.650
One is, well, probably the most common
way, okay, is that when you end up taking

39
00:01:59.650 --> 00:02:02.700
a computer and
you make it a part of Active Directory.

40
00:02:02.700 --> 00:02:06.226
Usually the term you'll hear there
is what we call domain join or

41
00:02:06.226 --> 00:02:08.380
when you join a computer to the domain,

42
00:02:08.380 --> 00:02:12.064
it will then end up creating
an object inside of Active Directory.

43
00:02:12.064 --> 00:02:16.054
And that object by default is gonna end
up getting stored in the computer's

44
00:02:16.054 --> 00:02:18.560
container inside of Active Directory.

45
00:02:18.560 --> 00:02:21.080
So let me show you what
I'm talking about here.

46
00:02:21.080 --> 00:02:26.310
So on my screen, I've got the Active
Directory Users and Computers brought

47
00:02:26.310 --> 00:02:31.490
up here on my remote administration
machine inside of my domain.

48
00:02:31.490 --> 00:02:33.550
Normally when you end up doing this,

49
00:02:33.550 --> 00:02:38.670
where you create a computer inside of
Active Directory by joining it first.

50
00:02:38.670 --> 00:02:42.460
So you take a computer that's not joined
to the domain and you join it, you'll end

51
00:02:42.460 --> 00:02:48.370
up creating an entry here in this generic
Computers container that we have.

52
00:02:48.370 --> 00:02:51.125
And when you do that that's
perfectly fine and it works.

53
00:02:51.125 --> 00:02:54.020
It at least gets the computer
to be joined to that domain,

54
00:02:54.020 --> 00:02:57.870
establishes some security that we
want to actually end up happening.

55
00:02:57.870 --> 00:03:02.310
And so
that is an effective way to do this.

56
00:03:02.310 --> 00:03:03.250
And if you're like me,

57
00:03:03.250 --> 00:03:06.590
this was kind of the very first way
that I was ever introduced to this.

58
00:03:06.590 --> 00:03:09.810
Because when I first got
signed on to do some jobs,

59
00:03:09.810 --> 00:03:13.570
there were 50 computers that
needed to be joined to the domain.

60
00:03:13.570 --> 00:03:16.550
So I was essentially sent around
to different computers and said,

61
00:03:16.550 --> 00:03:18.520
just join this computer at the domain.

62
00:03:18.520 --> 00:03:21.160
I really didn't have access
to the Active Directory.

63
00:03:21.160 --> 00:03:23.850
I didn't really have a clue
where they ended up.

64
00:03:23.850 --> 00:03:27.271
But when I established my very
first Active Directory myself and

65
00:03:27.271 --> 00:03:28.866
then I started joining them.

66
00:03:28.866 --> 00:03:33.530
I realized that every account ended up
just by default getting created here.

67
00:03:33.530 --> 00:03:38.440
So once I get it here, the problem is
fairly simple, even in Active Directory.

68
00:03:38.440 --> 00:03:43.350
It's still not really managed as much
as it's just stored in one place.

69
00:03:43.350 --> 00:03:46.272
So there's no policies really set up here.

70
00:03:46.272 --> 00:03:49.600
If I'm actually gonna be moving those
computers to be controlled by any type of

71
00:03:49.600 --> 00:03:53.460
policy inside of Active Directory,
I'll need to, let's say for

72
00:03:53.460 --> 00:03:57.700
example, right-click on this computer and
then go to Move.

73
00:03:57.700 --> 00:04:01.000
And from there I would move
it into the proper OU for

74
00:04:01.000 --> 00:04:02.990
the management that I need to.

75
00:04:02.990 --> 00:04:05.620
So that's one of the ways that we can

76
00:04:05.620 --> 00:04:09.980
end up getting the computer account
inside of Active Directory.

77
00:04:09.980 --> 00:04:11.450
Now the other one, of course,

78
00:04:11.450 --> 00:04:16.770
is to actually do what we call
prestaging the computer account instead.

79
00:04:16.770 --> 00:04:21.240
So when we prestage a computer account,
this is when the computer account is

80
00:04:21.240 --> 00:04:29.140
created in Active Directory before we join
it to the actual Active Directory itself.

81
00:04:29.140 --> 00:04:30.000
So what do I mean by that?

82
00:04:30.000 --> 00:04:33.416

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee continue to look at how manage computer accounts. Ronnie shows two different methods to create computer accounts. First, he shows how computers accounts are generated when the computer joins a domain followed by pre-staging the computer account. Ronnie explains the benefits of creating pre-staged accounts as in addition to the various methods to get the job done.
episodes.title: Managing AD Computer Accounts Part 2

336
00:18:05.450 --> 00:18:08.450
Now remember when I told you
is that this also depends on

337
00:18:08.450 --> 00:18:13.650
what we call the Netlogon service, right?

338
00:18:13.650 --> 00:18:21.030
So if I do service.msc of services,
see, I can't spell, there we go, wow.

339
00:18:21.030 --> 00:18:24.075
Why is it doing this to me?

340
00:18:27.325 --> 00:18:31.400
I don't know why I'm getting, but
that may be just part of it, that'll work.

341
00:18:33.010 --> 00:18:37.350
We're looking for Netlogon services here.

342
00:18:37.350 --> 00:18:40.410
Okay, that is it right here, okay?

343
00:18:40.410 --> 00:18:44.340
This Netlogon service, it gives us
what we call that secure channel.

344
00:18:44.340 --> 00:18:48.820
Secure channel maintains it between this
computer and the domain controller for

345
00:18:48.820 --> 00:18:51.190
authenticating users and services, okay?

346
00:18:51.190 --> 00:18:55.720
If this is stopped, the computer may
not authenticate users and services and

347
00:18:55.720 --> 00:18:58.210
the domain controller cannot
register DNS records.

348
00:18:58.210 --> 00:19:01.950
If the service is disabled, well,
that's what you have, okay?

349
00:19:01.950 --> 00:19:04.690
Sometimes, if you try and log in to
the computer and it tells you the trust

350
00:19:04.690 --> 00:19:08.660
relationship is gone, they're saying,
I can't establish a secure channel.

351
00:19:08.660 --> 00:19:11.180
Remember that every time
that your computer runs,

352
00:19:11.180 --> 00:19:15.320
this is a service that automatically
comes up and begins to run.

353
00:19:15.320 --> 00:19:19.380
So if you ever get to this point where
you're going, look, I can log in locally,

354
00:19:19.380 --> 00:19:21.010
but I can't log in.

355
00:19:21.010 --> 00:19:28.107
Using the domain, you can always
bring up your PowerShell here.

356
00:19:28.107 --> 00:19:30.091
That's really small, isn't it?

357
00:19:30.091 --> 00:19:34.955
Gracious, let's change
that font size by 9,000.

358
00:19:37.180 --> 00:19:38.720
And make that a little bit bigger.

359
00:19:38.720 --> 00:19:39.422
>> Always considerate, Ronnie.

360
00:19:39.422 --> 00:19:40.900
>> There we go, I try.

361
00:19:42.290 --> 00:19:46.950
And then you can run test

362
00:19:46.950 --> 00:19:54.875
-ComputerSecureChannel -verbose.

363
00:19:54.875 --> 00:19:59.760
All right, so performing the operation on
the target, notice it says true, okay?

364
00:19:59.760 --> 00:20:02.950
So this actually tells us that the secure
channel between the local computer and

365
00:20:02.950 --> 00:20:05.580
the domain is in good condition.

366
00:20:05.580 --> 00:20:09.950
So that's a good thing to run without
you going is it the secure channel?

367
00:20:09.950 --> 00:20:12.232
Well this is a way to
actually prove whether or

368
00:20:12.232 --> 00:20:13.983
not everything is actually done.

369
00:20:13.983 --> 00:20:16.748
Now what if it doesn't, what if it tells
you that it's not true, it's false,

370
00:20:16.748 --> 00:20:17.922
that something else is going on?

371
00:20:17.922 --> 00:20:20.200
You have two options here, right?

372
00:20:20.200 --> 00:20:23.590
You can rejoin the computer domain, that's
usually the way that I do it, and why?

373
00:20:23.590 --> 00:20:25.430
It's something I know how to do.

374
00:20:25.430 --> 00:20:29.132
It's easy, I know how to actually
rejoin the computer domain.

375
00:20:29.132 --> 00:20:33.356
It's probably just second nature to me,
that that's what I end up doing.

376
00:20:33.356 --> 00:20:37.190
But if you wanna take the time, you can
also go into Active Directory Users and

377
00:20:37.190 --> 00:20:40.890
Computers and try and
just reset the computer account as well.

378
00:20:40.890 --> 00:20:43.850
When you reset the computer account and
you run the same command again,

379
00:20:43.850 --> 00:20:48.120
in that way, you can go ahead and
see if it actually is working or not.

380
00:20:48.120 --> 00:20:50.891
But I know, at least from my experience,

381
00:20:50.891 --> 00:20:55.813
rejoining the computer to the domain
has always worked on the resetting.

382
00:20:55.813 --> 00:20:58.194
There are sometimes I've
actually gotten them to work,

383
00:20:58.194 --> 00:21:01.566
sometimes where it didn't work, which
means it was something besides, what,

384
00:21:01.566 --> 00:21:04.930
the secure channel that ended up
causing the issue that you might have.

385
00:21:04.930 --> 00:21:07.750
So just kinda realize that there are some
issues when you start doing this

386
00:21:08.960 --> 00:21:11.380
too when you take a look, okay?

387
00:21:11.380 --> 00:21:15.230
Now, the great thing is, once we're
done with that, okay, just like we found

388
00:21:16.420 --> 00:21:20.440
stale user accounts, there is
a possibility that you may have stale

389
00:21:20.440 --> 00:21:25.800
computer accounts that you want to be able
to take a look at and find out as well.

390
00:21:25.800 --> 00:21:28.760
Now in that, the great thing is,
it can be done, okay?

391
00:21:28.760 --> 00:21:31.420
Just like we saw inside
of the user accounts,

392
00:21:31.420 --> 00:21:34.660
you can do kind of the same thing
in the computer accounts too.

393
00:21:34.660 --> 00:21:37.870
When you run something like that,
it's gonna be a fairly simple command for

394
00:21:37.870 --> 00:21:41.030
you, but you're no longer just
using PowerShell at that point.

395
00:21:41.030 --> 00:21:43.764
You can,
there are a couple of different utilities,

396
00:21:43.764 --> 00:21:47.977
we're not gonna get into it right now, but
you can actually look those things up.

397
00:21:47.977 --> 00:21:51.770
I normally don't find a lot of this,
but you can do this.

398
00:21:51.770 --> 00:21:53.806
So you can use a dsquery command,

399
00:21:53.806 --> 00:21:57.891
you can also end up doing a search
AD account inside of PowerShell.

400
00:21:57.891 --> 00:22:02.017
And all of that will actually allow you to
also try and find those stale accounts,

401
00:22:02.017 --> 00:22:06.890
based on that time limit if you choose to,
if nobody's actually used that computer.

402
00:22:06.890 --> 00:22:10.470
But as long as you can understand
the secure channel, do the domain join,

403
00:22:10.470 --> 00:22:15.100
understand how to create computer
accounts, you're probably very good,

404
00:22:15.100 --> 00:22:20.100
as far as your Active Directory skills,
in maintaining and managing those types of

405
00:22:20.100 --> 00:22:24.240
computer accounts, along with
your user account knowledge too.

406
00:22:24.240 --> 00:22:25.920
So that pretty much wraps it up for

407
00:22:25.920 --> 00:22:28.620

managing computer accounts.

408
00:22:28.620 --> 00:22:31.598
>> All right Ronnie, well, thank you for
taking the time to show us how to go ahead

409
00:22:31.598 --> 00:22:33.660
and create and
manage those computer accounts.

410
00:22:33.660 --> 00:22:36.710
For this show, we'll go ahead and
sign off, remember, I'm your host,

411
00:22:36.710 --> 00:22:37.480
Cherokee Boose.

412
00:22:37.480 --> 00:22:38.260
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

413
00:22:38.260 --> 00:22:41.376
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

414
00:22:41.376 --> 00:22:47.180
[MUSIC]

415
00:22:47.180 --> 00:22:50.367
>> Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach discuss what is a 'Group,' what are group managing tasks, how to access groups, regular duties for the server administrator, managing groups, group types, what is a 'Forest,' and permissions.
episodes.title: Managing Groups

Groups help us to be able to essentially

Now normally in terms of different groups

00:02:13.441 --> 00:02:16.690
what groups that you actually
end up creating as well.

So that's where we're gonna be jumping
into some of those details in this show.

40
00:02:20.200 --> 00:02:24.371
>> So groups can be local,
they can be global, domain, I mean,

anything you want to group or you need to.

>> Right, it just depends on the function
that we actually need to have and

be ready to go, and
we are gonna dive into that.

Now before we do that, and take a look

00:02:37.182 --> 00:02:41.197
we wanna make sure that we understand
that you, as a server admin,

00:02:41.197 --> 00:02:45.090
getting your access into
the Active Directory network.

47
00:02:45.090 --> 00:02:49.450
It also means that you are going to have
to be able, of course, to create groups.

48
00:02:49.450 --> 00:02:52.034
You're gonna have to be able
to manage those groups and

49
00:02:52.034 --> 00:02:55.700
understand what they're actually
applying for or being applied for.

50
00:02:55.700 --> 00:02:58.900
And then, of course, troubleshooting the

51
00:02:58.900 --> 00:03:02.270
Those are relatively common
tasks that we'll end up seeing.

52
00:03:02.270 --> 00:03:06.337
But when it comes down to creating groups,

00:03:06.337 --> 00:03:08.530
options that Zach has

Which we do need to think about

56

So let's go ahead and do that for right

I'm gonna launch up

Computers from my remote

By simply clicking on the Windows button,
and then from that point I'm

And under Administrative Tools,

This is by far the most commonly accessed

From here,

00:03:53.635 --> 00:03:56.883
If I can remember my
password as I'm talking,

which is almost difficult enough

00:04:00.982 --> 00:04:04.217
So in just a moment,

Now, the idea of grouping them

a portion of what we see here,
and say, hey,

00:04:44.752 --> 00:04:49.510
I want to essentially treat

So let's select where I have

which is inside this Office 365 container,

And it's in here that I can group and

Now, we can do that on anything

85
00:05:05.600 --> 00:05:08.350
Now when you do something like this,

So let's say, for

which might be concert crew, yeah, there

00:05:17.810 --> 00:05:21.800
And if I wanted to group a certain number

I simply right-click on the concert crew,

92

Now, when I do so,
it's not really super fancy, but

here's some of the options that

Is that you wanna be able to
actually have a name, and

96
00:05:40.248 --> 00:05:44.773
So let's say from here,
we'll actually create from the,

00:05:44.773 --> 00:05:49.208
make sure I'm seeing that right,
the concert crew here,

00:05:49.208 --> 00:05:53.570
we'll actually create,

99
00:05:53.570 --> 00:05:55.353
Now, once I do that, it went ahead and,

00:05:55.353 --> 00:05:57.720
I'm getting a little bit

00:05:57.720 --> 00:06:01.260
There we go, trying to make sure

102
00:06:01.260 --> 00:06:01.870
So here, and

00:06:01.870 --> 00:06:05.870
you'll notice that there's actually some

Let's talk about the idea of types first,
