00:06:09.080 --> 00:06:11.110
Since Zach actually did mention them,

106
00:06:11.110 --> 00:06:13.790
and we'll see what we're
actually going to do here.

107
00:06:13.790 --> 00:06:17.810
When it comes down to different types, the
default one is normally the one that you

108
00:06:17.810 --> 00:06:22.330
see right here, where it's actually
marked in, where it says Security.

109
00:06:22.330 --> 00:06:26.710
Now a security is our default type
of group that we have set up for

110
00:06:26.710 --> 00:06:28.260
Active Directory, and for

111
00:06:28.260 --> 00:06:32.780
everything else that we create when we
first create the idea of a group type.

112
00:06:32.780 --> 00:06:36.680
Now when you start to see this here,
this is normally going to

113
00:06:36.680 --> 00:06:40.490
really allow us to set up whatever types

Such as permissions,

116
00:06:46.990 --> 00:06:51.816
Now let me bring up something else to

119
00:06:58.540 --> 00:07:03.479
So let's take for an example right here on

So A, B, C, D, I probably could've

00:07:12.978 --> 00:07:16.916
I didn't do that, but now-

123
00:07:16.916 --> 00:07:17.632
actually.

124
00:07:17.632 --> 00:07:20.200
>> That would actually made good sense,

125
00:07:20.200 --> 00:07:23.366
So, the good things is that, we actually
did choose a male, so that would,

00:07:23.366 --> 00:07:24.160

00:07:24.160 --> 00:07:27.900
So, here it is, now we actually do have

Now, if all four of these users need that,

Well, without the idea of grouping It

I need to go to every application and

00:08:02.167 --> 00:08:05.980
attach every individual

138

139

00:20:17.380 --> 00:20:22.775
And this can now extend out to
become that forest too, okay?

368
00:20:22.775 --> 00:20:27.404
So this way we can actually do
something like this if we choose to.

369
00:20:27.404 --> 00:20:31.287
The majority of the time most of us will
probably end up seeing in the work place

370
00:20:31.287 --> 00:20:34.154
that we have, unless we work for
a really large company,

371
00:20:34.154 --> 00:20:37.590
we'll probably end up seeing our
forest is really only one domain.

372
00:20:37.590 --> 00:20:38.320
>> Just a domain.

373
00:20:38.320 --> 00:20:42.110
>> That's probably what we'll end up
seeing, but if you do extend it out,

374
00:20:42.110 --> 00:20:45.310
remember the key here is that they'll
share the same name space, so

375
00:20:45.310 --> 00:20:51.220
just like you see here, ITProTV, ITProTV,
ITProTV, these two are child domains.

376
00:20:51.220 --> 00:20:55.740
They've essentially added on an extra
prefix up here at the beginning,

377
00:20:55.740 --> 00:20:57.230
in terms of their domain names.

378
00:20:57.230 --> 00:20:59.491
They are separate domains but

379
00:20:59.491 --> 00:21:05.467
now the security boundary can go out a lot
further so this is why a global group.

380
00:21:05.467 --> 00:21:09.833
And the way that I described it,
let me make sure I read it correctly,

381
00:21:09.833 --> 00:21:14.470
permissions assigned to a group,
okay, from any domain in the forest.

382
00:21:14.470 --> 00:21:19.070
So even though I can create a global
group that has all members of the same

383
00:21:19.070 --> 00:21:22.650
individuals in one domain,
those can actually be assigned,

384
00:21:22.650 --> 00:21:25.720
again, to, well, or permissions from

385
00:21:25.720 --> 00:21:29.520
any domain that's actually in that
entire forest if we choose to.

386
00:21:29.520 --> 00:21:33.390
So that's what we have now, I'm starting
to, I was trying to see what was behind

387
00:21:33.390 --> 00:21:36.800
these arrows here, it's because
everything kind of went off the page.

388
00:21:36.800 --> 00:21:41.570
That's what I wanted, see if I pull that
up a little bit farther, there we go.

389
00:21:41.570 --> 00:21:43.680
So that's where we have
that security boundary.

390
00:21:43.680 --> 00:21:47.380
So with the group type of security,

391
00:21:47.380 --> 00:21:51.480
okay, that means its boundary
is what the whole forest.

392
00:21:51.480 --> 00:21:57.270
But in terms of the group scope right,
it is global and the very fact that

393
00:21:57.270 --> 00:22:01.930
means everybody that's part of that group
can only be from one of these domains.

394
00:22:01.930 --> 00:22:06.090
Okay, so that is a key for us to remember.

395
00:22:06.090 --> 00:22:09.610
Now, along with that notice that
there is also domain local.

396
00:22:09.610 --> 00:22:11.233
Oops, let me zoom in so
we can see it, geez.

397
00:22:11.233 --> 00:22:12.630
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

398
00:22:12.630 --> 00:22:15.058
>> Domain local here is another one that

399
00:22:15.058 --> 00:22:16.100
you see.

400
00:22:16.100 --> 00:22:21.464
Now domain local,
this is kind of an unusual one, okay.

401
00:22:21.464 --> 00:22:26.410
Domain local it sounds like, okay domain
locally does that mean it's limiting even

402
00:22:26.410 --> 00:22:28.900
further, want not necessarily.

403
00:22:28.900 --> 00:22:32.380
A domain local groups scope
that you create here,

404
00:22:32.380 --> 00:22:38.240
this can actually contain members from any
domain within the entire forest, okay?

405
00:22:38.240 --> 00:22:42.780
Now, once you actually have something like
that, this also means that other domain

406
00:22:42.780 --> 00:22:47.860
local groups can be members of other
domain local groups here, okay?

407
00:22:47.860 --> 00:22:52.210
But on this one though,
permissions that you assign to an object.

408
00:22:52.210 --> 00:22:55.850
So if you create a domain local group,
wherever you created that,

409
00:22:55.850 --> 00:22:57.608
if I created an ITProTV, okay?

410
00:22:57.608 --> 00:23:01.590
ITPro.TV and I had a printer
that we all want to access,

411
00:23:01.590 --> 00:23:05.170
that I want anybody in
that group to access.

412
00:23:05.170 --> 00:23:08.284
Well, wherever I created
that domain local group,

413
00:23:08.284 --> 00:23:11.478
that printer also has to be
in the same domain, okay?

414
00:23:11.478 --> 00:23:16.434
Now remember anybody and anyone of
those three domains that I had set up

415
00:23:16.434 --> 00:23:21.555
here inside, dang, there we go,
inside of Active Directory.

416
00:23:21.555 --> 00:23:25.690
Anyone of those three okay, they can be
part of that domain local group okay?

417
00:23:25.690 --> 00:23:29.350
But it's not going to
end up doing anything.

418
00:23:29.350 --> 00:23:33.730
If I don't have the resource in the same
domain as where this is created.

419
00:23:33.730 --> 00:23:37.921
Now, I have a better diagram to kind of
help us to explain this a little bit more

420
00:23:37.921 --> 00:23:39.676
but a little bit large here too.

421
00:23:39.676 --> 00:23:44.391
Now, let's zoom in and get a reminder
before we go out here, right?

422
00:23:44.391 --> 00:23:49.238
So traditionally here it is a global
group I've tried to color code this to

423
00:23:49.238 --> 00:23:50.106
help us out.

424
00:23:50.106 --> 00:23:54.898
Everybody in that particular group noticed
that they are all the same color which

425
00:23:54.898 --> 00:23:59.072
means that for us In this one,
in that light green one that we see here.

426
00:23:59.072 --> 00:24:03.883
As long as they're members of
that same domain, itpro.tv,

427
00:24:03.883 --> 00:24:07.220
then they will be able to access whatever.

428
00:24:07.220 --> 00:24:10.880
Now, we don't talk about permissions so
much, but let's say it's to this printer.

429
00:24:10.880 --> 00:24:15.437
That's fine, they can do that, but
remember that anybody, any other domain,

430
00:24:15.437 --> 00:24:18.466
can also assign some security
if they want to as well.

431
00:24:18.466 --> 00:24:22.693
In the domain local, let's take a look
down here if I can get this zoomed in down

432
00:24:22.693 --> 00:24:24.800
here a little bit more, okay.

433
00:24:24.800 --> 00:24:26.685
So this one is the domain local.

434
00:24:26.685 --> 00:24:29.800
Notice that you see two
different colors here.

435
00:24:29.800 --> 00:24:33.152
So I have somebody from this domain,
which is right here, and

436
00:24:33.152 --> 00:24:37.349
then somebody from the dev domain which
is over on the right hand side of this.

437
00:24:37.349 --> 00:24:42.455
They're part of this domain local group
and if this group is assigning permission

438
00:24:42.455 --> 00:24:47.930
to get access to this server over here for
a fall server for wherever it might be.

439
00:24:47.930 --> 00:24:52.142
Well as long as this domain group or
this domain local group is in

440
00:24:52.142 --> 00:24:55.966
the same domain as the resource
that will work just fine.

441
00:24:55.966 --> 00:24:59.298
It doesn't matter who else
you put in this group okay?

442
00:24:59.298 --> 00:25:02.178
As long as they're actually in that
same forest, you're perfectly fine.

443
00:25:02.178 --> 00:25:04.673
Now, can these actually
exist in the same domain?

444
00:25:04.673 --> 00:25:10.267
Yeah, you can create a domain global
group, as well as a domain local group,

445
00:25:10.267 --> 00:25:14.530
too, and
they can exist inside the same forest.

446
00:25:14.530 --> 00:25:18.818
Now, the last option that we saw,
and we'll come back to this

447
00:25:18.818 --> 00:25:23.374
very quickly here is of course
the universal group scope, okay?

448
00:25:23.374 --> 00:25:27.514
Now, with the universal group scope,
this is a little bit easier to understand,

449
00:25:27.514 --> 00:25:28.660
at least for me it was.

450
00:25:28.660 --> 00:25:30.619
It may not be for everybody.

451
00:25:30.619 --> 00:25:33.980
But let's say thea we have
a SharePoint site, okay.

452
00:25:33.980 --> 00:25:39.799
That everybody, so one in the ITProTV or
you're in the lab.itprotv domain or

453
00:25:39.799 --> 00:25:46.252
the dev.itprotv domain and you have people
that need access to that SharePoint site.

454
00:25:46.252 --> 00:25:49.350
But you're not as you're crediting
three different SharePoint sites.

455
00:25:49.350 --> 00:25:50.903
Well, we can do this.

456
00:25:50.903 --> 00:25:54.170
We can create what's called
a universal group and

457
00:25:54.170 --> 00:25:58.250
notice it doesn't matter
where the members are, okay?

458
00:25:58.250 --> 00:26:02.482
So they can be in any domain inside of
that forest, and we can create that.

459
00:26:02.482 --> 00:26:06.773
And then, they can get access to such
a core resource that we have available to

460
00:26:06.773 --> 00:26:09.670
everybody throughout the organization.

461
00:26:09.670 --> 00:26:14.429
So it doesn't matter if that SharePoint
site resides here, here, or here.

462
00:26:14.429 --> 00:26:19.451
I can actually say hey,
we want to make sure that everybody has

463
00:26:19.451 --> 00:26:25.310
that ability to do so to provide
that access and that permission.

464
00:26:25.310 --> 00:26:27.054
The whole goal behind this is so

465
00:26:27.054 --> 00:26:31.023
that I'm not assigning Zach every
level of permission that he needs.

466
00:26:31.023 --> 00:26:34.638
I can now actually remove Zack from the
universal group if he doesn't need that

467
00:26:34.638 --> 00:26:35.510
anymore.

468
00:26:35.510 --> 00:26:39.352
Or I could place him inside of this global
group to limit him access to what I need,

469
00:26:39.352 --> 00:26:41.288
or I can place him in domain local group.

470
00:26:41.288 --> 00:26:44.708
I'm not changing every time
that Zack happens to move or

471
00:26:44.708 --> 00:26:47.420
happens to not be in part of the group.

472
00:26:47.420 --> 00:26:50.541
I just simply remove him from that group
and that takes away his permissions or

473
00:26:50.541 --> 00:26:53.230
I add him into that group it gives
him permissions into that group is

474
00:26:53.230 --> 00:26:53.825
what we have.

475
00:26:53.825 --> 00:26:57.790
>> So that is, in essence, like having
groups, within groups, within groups.

476
00:26:57.790 --> 00:26:59.797
>> It can be, yeah, it can be.

477
00:26:59.797 --> 00:27:02.606
The very fact is it depends
on the context that we need.

478
00:27:02.606 --> 00:27:04.686
So we can nest groups if we want to.

479
00:27:04.686 --> 00:27:05.385
>> Nesting groups, right.

480
00:27:05.385 --> 00:27:08.790
>> Yeah, you can create these
global groups here, okay?

481
00:27:08.790 --> 00:27:09.406
So, just like we have.

482
00:27:09.406 --> 00:27:13.560
Let's say that this global group up here
in itpro.tv, it's for the HR department.

483
00:27:13.560 --> 00:27:17.545
And this one down here In lab
is also the HR department.

484
00:27:17.545 --> 00:27:19.970
This one over here in dev
pro is the HR department.

485
00:27:19.970 --> 00:27:25.397
Well, we can make that group a part
of this universal group here.

486
00:27:25.397 --> 00:27:29.680
And that means everybody in those groups
will get access to that SharePoint site.

487
00:27:29.680 --> 00:27:31.442
So we can do that.

488
00:27:31.442 --> 00:27:35.744
Even though I only have users here,
we can actually again create those groups

489
00:27:35.744 --> 00:27:40.044
that will give us the ability to add
in users, computers, as well as groups,

490
00:27:40.044 --> 00:27:41.480
if we choose to.

491
00:27:41.480 --> 00:27:43.144
So that is kinda the key for

492
00:27:43.144 --> 00:27:47.693
us in understanding at least the basics
in terms of groups that we have.

493
00:27:47.693 --> 00:27:52.725
Now, when we start to see this here,
there is some basic guidelines

494
00:27:52.725 --> 00:27:58.810
on the group creation that we want to
make sure that we understand, okay?

495
00:27:58.810 --> 00:28:03.660
Now, when we start saying, all right,
when I need to create a global group,

496
00:28:03.660 --> 00:28:07.036
what should I actually think
about when I create one?

497
00:28:07.036 --> 00:28:09.555
Is it just because I wanna name one pink?

498
00:28:09.555 --> 00:28:12.510
No, that's not the whole goal and idea.

499
00:28:12.510 --> 00:28:13.120
>> Pink's not a bad color.

500
00:28:13.120 --> 00:28:16.974
>> It's not a bad color, but the idea
of creating groups is because there's

501
00:28:16.974 --> 00:28:19.102
a functionality that you need, right?

502
00:28:19.102 --> 00:28:19.952
In other words,

503
00:28:19.952 --> 00:28:24.220
think about a role, when people have
similar roles together that they're doing.

504
00:28:24.220 --> 00:28:29.132
So, for example, Zach and I, we're part
of the host group here at ITProTV.

505
00:28:29.132 --> 00:28:33.747
And when we do that right, that means that
we're actually doing it because we believe

506
00:28:33.747 --> 00:28:37.976
that all the people that are hosts here
at ITProTV, or educators I should say,

507
00:28:37.976 --> 00:28:39.280
at ITProTV.

508
00:28:39.280 --> 00:28:42.244
It's because we are actually created for
that role, okay.

509
00:28:42.244 --> 00:28:46.008
So that group, as long as we need to
be able to apply security just to those

510
00:28:46.008 --> 00:28:49.620
roles, well that's what we're
normally thinking about.

511
00:28:49.620 --> 00:28:54.267
So that is a thumb, a rule of thumb,
if you want to take a look at it that way.

512
00:28:54.267 --> 00:28:57.422
Grouping users together that
have similar job roles,

513
00:28:57.422 --> 00:29:00.810
pretty much the key idea
in terms of global groups.

514
00:29:00.810 --> 00:29:02.772
For the domain local group,

515
00:29:02.772 --> 00:29:07.677
you wanna make sure that as you actually
you do use domain local groups,

516
00:29:07.677 --> 00:29:12.337
normally the best practice here is
that when you do have a resource,

517
00:29:12.337 --> 00:29:16.870
that you want to assign permissions so
that people can access it.

518
00:29:16.870 --> 00:29:19.590
So you create a resource,
let's say like a printer.

519
00:29:19.590 --> 00:29:23.862
And then you create a domain local group,
and you make that as being one of

520
00:29:23.862 --> 00:29:27.365
the groups that are actually
part of the permissions list,

521
00:29:27.365 --> 00:29:28.924
the ACL on that resource.

522
00:29:28.924 --> 00:29:32.645
And that way, it doesn't matter
who you assign inside that forest.

523
00:29:32.645 --> 00:29:34.134
They’re gonna be able to get access to it.

524
00:29:34.134 --> 00:29:37.837
If you don’t, you're gonna put that into a
global group which means you have to make

525
00:29:37.837 --> 00:29:40.040
them a member of the domain
before you can do that.

526
00:29:40.040 --> 00:29:41.344
When they're not a member of the domain,

527
00:29:41.344 --> 00:29:43.310
well that becomes a little
bit more confusing.

528
00:29:43.310 --> 00:29:47.043
So if you do have resources,
clearly the idea here- try and

529
00:29:47.043 --> 00:29:49.067
use a domain local group for it.

530
00:29:49.067 --> 00:29:52.480
But global groups are probably
what we're gonna see more often.

531
00:29:52.480 --> 00:29:56.715
And really, at the beginning level, right,
like here at Server 101, global groups

532
00:29:56.715 --> 00:30:00.506
are probably the scope that you and I are
probably gonna use more often than not.

533
00:30:00.506 --> 00:30:04.410
But there's still plenty to go

Managing Groups Windows Server 101 and

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach continue discussing managing groups beginning in this episode with what default groups are, different types of default groups we should be familiar with, how to add members to a group using ADUC & ADAC & Powershell, and how to remove members from using ADUC & ADAC & Powershell.

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce Group Policy. First, Ronnie explains the differences between Policies and Preferences and why one may choose one setting over the other. They also speak about inheritance and ways in which inheritance can be blocked. Lastly, Ronnie cover link order to set policy priority.
episodes.title: Working with Group Policy Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie introduce the idea of implementing security with via group policy. First, Ronnie walks us through six different policy setting and explains how each one can be used. They continue their conversation but take an unusual twist to explain a a non-group policy settings called fine-grained password and account lockout policies.

00:24:03.880 --> 00:24:07.340
And it also limits them to the number
of attempts that they have, too.

428
00:24:07.340 --> 00:24:12.200
So this is where the combination
of both the password policy and

429
00:24:12.200 --> 00:24:17.490
the account lockout policy
together provide relatively strong

430
00:24:17.490 --> 00:24:22.140
types of policies that we can
begin to take a look at to

431
00:24:22.140 --> 00:24:26.740
provide better security for
our domain that we have.

432
00:24:26.740 --> 00:24:30.690
Now, remember that this is good as
long as you're still using passwords.

433
00:24:30.690 --> 00:24:33.440
If you've moved on to
multifactor authentications,

434
00:24:33.440 --> 00:24:35.690
it probably isn't going to help too much.

435
00:24:35.690 --> 00:24:36.490
But overall, though,

436
00:24:36.490 --> 00:24:39.930
you'll probably still see organizations
that are going to be using this.

437
00:24:39.930 --> 00:24:44.210
>> Now, Ronnie, I see what's next on our
list, and that's going to be user rights.

438
00:24:44.210 --> 00:24:47.160
Now, I know there are quite a few here,
and looking at the time,

439
00:24:47.160 --> 00:24:49.550
I'm almost wondering,
do we have enough time to cover them?

440
00:24:49.550 --> 00:24:51.390
Are we going to cover all of them?

441
00:24:51.390 --> 00:24:55.040
>> Nope, we're definitely not gonna have
enough time to even get into user rights.

442
00:24:55.040 --> 00:24:56.180
And not only that, though,

443
00:24:56.180 --> 00:24:59.970
I still have some fine grain
policies I need to take a look at.

444
00:24:59.970 --> 00:25:01.180
>> Okay.
>> As well.

445
00:25:01.180 --> 00:25:03.424
And that's what happens when
you forget like I just did.

446
00:25:03.424 --> 00:25:06.056
Look, account lockout policies,
I forgot that one.

447
00:25:06.056 --> 00:25:09.701
So what we'll probably end up doing is
we'll go to a part two on this one.

448
00:25:09.701 --> 00:25:10.348
>> Okay.

449
00:25:10.348 --> 00:25:12.742
>> And that will help us
cover what we need to and

450
00:25:12.742 --> 00:25:16.270
we'll move on into the user rights as well
>> Sounds like a plan.

451
00:25:16.270 --> 00:25:17.110
Thank you for that.

452
00:25:17.110 --> 00:25:20.190
And thank you for joining us,
but as Ronnie said, stay tuned.

453
00:25:20.190 --> 00:25:22.110
We have more information headed your way.

454
00:25:22.110 --> 00:25:23.630
For this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

455
00:25:23.630 --> 00:25:25.600
Remember, I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

456
00:25:25.600 --> 00:25:26.430
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

457
00:25:26.430 --> 00:25:28.291
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

458
00:25:28.291 --> 00:25:35.570
[MUSIC]

459
00:25:35.570 --> 00:25:38.273
>> Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: This episode picks up from the previous the conversation where Cherokee and Ronnie discuss implementing password policies. First, they delve deeper within fine-grained password policies via group policy management console (GPMC).
episodes.title: Securing Server with Group Policy Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:03.568
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.568 --> 00:00:08.267
[CROSSTALK]
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.267 --> 00:00:11.912
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.912 --> 00:00:14.420
>> Welcome to your Server 101 series.

5
00:00:14.420 --> 00:00:16.660
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:16.660 --> 00:00:19.530
In this episode we'll continue
looking at how we can

7
00:00:19.530 --> 00:00:22.240
secure Windows by using group policy.

8
00:00:22.240 --> 00:00:24.900
And with us today, back in studios,
we have Mr. Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:24.900 --> 00:00:26.240
How's it going Ronnie?

10
00:00:26.240 --> 00:00:30.670
>> It's going better, we are back
here taking a look at part 2 of

11
00:00:30.670 --> 00:00:35.010
using group policy to help
us secure Windows servers.

12
00:00:35.010 --> 00:00:39.783
And in our first episode, right, we took
a look at the idea of using password

13
00:00:39.783 --> 00:00:43.755
policies, and even the idea of
the account lockout policies.

14
00:00:43.755 --> 00:00:49.270
But remember that what we saw there,
right, is very categorical.

15
00:00:49.270 --> 00:00:54.450
In other words, very much it had to
fall in this particular context.

16
00:00:54.450 --> 00:00:56.300
There wasn't anything easy for us to do.

17
00:00:56.300 --> 00:00:58.760
We had to go into multiple
places to do this.

18
00:00:58.760 --> 00:01:01.700
But today, we want to begin by
talking about something I know even

19
00:01:01.700 --> 00:01:04.180
though the show is actually talking
about securing with group policy,

20
00:01:04.180 --> 00:01:06.920
I want to talk about something
that's not in group policy.

21
00:01:06.920 --> 00:01:12.040
Which is actually what we call
fine-grained password policies

22
00:01:12.040 --> 00:01:15.950
that are out there for
us to be able to work with and use.

23
00:01:15.950 --> 00:01:19.110
And what we're going to end up seeing in
all those settings where we had to go to

24
00:01:19.110 --> 00:01:24.020
at least two different locations inside
of group policy to be able to manage

25
00:01:24.020 --> 00:01:25.310
a separate location, of course,

26
00:01:25.310 --> 00:01:30.600
from the account lockout policies, a
separate location for the password policy.

27
00:01:30.600 --> 00:01:32.570
We can manage it all in one location and

28
00:01:32.570 --> 00:01:35.690
even get some additional
benefits out of it as well.

29
00:01:35.690 --> 00:01:40.050
And that´s by using the active directory
administrative center to help us out.

30
00:01:40.050 --> 00:01:42.820
So that is what we´re
actually taking a look at.

31
00:01:42.820 --> 00:01:47.050
Now, when we start to do this inside
of the active directory administrative

32
00:01:47.050 --> 00:01:51.930
center, it kind of help us out because
we´ll see a couple of different things

33
00:01:51.930 --> 00:01:54.040
that may end up happening.

34
00:01:54.040 --> 00:01:59.820
You may end up, because of what we call
the idea of inheritance that happens

35
00:01:59.820 --> 00:02:05.450
with group policy objects where one
object may actually be influenced by

36
00:02:05.450 --> 00:02:12.258
what multiple group policies objects that
are set on that one particular OU, okay?

37
00:02:12.258 --> 00:02:16.930
Well, with fine-grained policies
that can also happen as well.

38
00:02:16.930 --> 00:02:18.320
But when this one happens,

39
00:02:18.320 --> 00:02:23.010
there is what we call an order of
precedence inside of the administrative

40
00:02:23.010 --> 00:02:27.160
center that we can actually say
what is going to override what.

41
00:02:27.160 --> 00:02:29.760
So we can actually change that as well.

42
00:02:29.760 --> 00:02:35.360
Now, the other benefit of being able to do
this with fine-grain policies is unlike

43
00:02:35.360 --> 00:02:39.740
the group policy,
where we can set it on an OU, and

44
00:02:39.740 --> 00:02:44.520
on a domain, and
a child OU pretty much and the site.

45
00:02:44.520 --> 00:02:45.680
Well, on those,

46
00:02:45.680 --> 00:02:50.830
that´s perfectly fine, but what if you
wanted to put this on an individual user?

47
00:02:50.830 --> 00:02:52.038
You can´t do that.

48
00:02:52.038 --> 00:02:58.480
But with fine-grained types of policies,
you can also apply it to users.

49
00:02:58.480 --> 00:03:02.350
But even so, it should probably
be used with groups as well.

50
00:03:02.350 --> 00:03:04.930
So this is something else that
we can also be able to do.

51
00:03:04.930 --> 00:03:08.120
Now, if we're going to make
sure these apply to groups,

52
00:03:08.120 --> 00:03:13.260
you also have to make sure that there's
at least one member to a group.

53
00:03:13.260 --> 00:03:17.300
So don't just create a group that says,
hey, this is the IT group and

54
00:03:17.300 --> 00:03:18.540
you don't have any members in it.

55
00:03:18.540 --> 00:03:22.420
It's not gonna work until you apply
at least a single active user to

56
00:03:22.420 --> 00:03:23.370
the group as well.

57
00:03:23.370 --> 00:03:25.800
All right, so
that's what we're gonna end up seeing.

58
00:03:25.800 --> 00:03:31.040
So let's take a look at how
we can use this instead.

59
00:03:31.040 --> 00:03:32.750
So here it is on my machine.

60
00:03:32.750 --> 00:03:34.750
I've went ahead and connected in.

61
00:03:34.750 --> 00:03:38.900
And what we have here is the Active
Directory Administrative Center.

62
00:03:38.900 --> 00:03:44.560
For us, we need to be able to get access
to those settings that we need to.

63
00:03:44.560 --> 00:03:48.680
But it's not as intuitive as it seems
if you're not used to doing this.

64
00:03:48.680 --> 00:03:52.170
So over here on the left-hand side, let
me expand this out a little bit more so

65
00:03:52.170 --> 00:03:54.890
that everybody can see what
I'm talking about here.

66
00:03:54.890 --> 00:03:59.000
So over here in the navigation pane,
there's actually two different views here.

67
00:03:59.000 --> 00:04:02.790
And it's very difficult for
us to see if you're not looking for it.

68
00:04:02.790 --> 00:04:07.050
And the way that you do that, and let me
zoom in right up here for us to see this.

69
00:04:07.050 --> 00:04:09.480
Is right here this is
called the List View, and

70
00:04:09.480 --> 00:04:12.060
then over here is called the Tree View.

71
00:04:12.060 --> 00:04:14.120
Well, in the list view,
you will not find it.

72
00:04:14.120 --> 00:04:17.090
If you're like me, you search for
it all day and all night.

73
00:04:17.090 --> 00:04:20.090
And it didn't actually ever pop up
where I found anything that said

74
00:04:20.090 --> 00:04:22.230
password policies or settings like that.

75
00:04:22.230 --> 00:04:23.820
It just didn't happen, okay?

76
00:04:23.820 --> 00:04:27.690
>> Not a very friendly UI,
or user interface, there?

77
00:04:27.690 --> 00:04:30.010
>> Yeah, it's not the easiest,
right, to try and

78
00:04:30.010 --> 00:04:32.290
find this if this is
your first time doing it.

79
00:04:32.290 --> 00:04:35.510
>> Okay.
>> So you have to go to the tree view.

80
00:04:35.510 --> 00:04:39.400
And even then, in the tree view,
Cherokee, we can see

81
00:04:39.400 --> 00:04:44.000
it doesn't really look a lot different
than what we saw in the list view.

82
00:04:44.000 --> 00:04:46.220
But it does kind of order
things a little bit more.

83
00:04:46.220 --> 00:04:48.710
Let me expand out, and
let's say the domain, right,

84
00:04:48.710 --> 00:04:51.060
which is our Office Pro democo.

85
00:04:51.060 --> 00:04:55.620
And now this begins to look, well,
almost like Active Directory users and

86
00:04:55.620 --> 00:04:57.650
computers for a moment, okay?

87
00:04:57.650 --> 00:05:02.190
But there are some other things in here
that we don't normally see, such as Keys,

88
00:05:02.190 --> 00:05:09.740
and LostAndFound down here,
Managed Service Accounts, Program Data.

89
00:05:09.740 --> 00:05:16.050
And what we're looking for underneath all
of this TPM devices is actually System.

90
00:05:16.050 --> 00:05:18.260
So if you didn't know where system was,

91
00:05:18.260 --> 00:05:20.690
know that that's what you
are supposed to look under,

92
00:05:20.690 --> 00:05:24.500
it would have been very difficult for
us to even think about trying to set this.

93
00:05:24.500 --> 00:05:30.380
Now, once I have system selected, well,
its still not easy as we take a look

94
00:05:30.380 --> 00:05:34.950
at what we find underneath that system
container that you have right there.

95
00:05:34.950 --> 00:05:39.229
Notice that even on all of this,
right, AdminSDHolder,

96
00:05:39.229 --> 00:05:44.457
ComPartitions, Dsf-Configuration,

97
00:05:44.457 --> 00:05:47.830
DFSR-GlobalSettings.

98
00:05:47.830 --> 00:05:51.010
I don't even know if I'm actually
in the right location yet.

99
00:05:51.010 --> 00:05:55.975
But if I scroll down toward the bottom,
there it is, finally, okay?

100
00:05:55.975 --> 00:06:01.500
As you start seeing it,
Password Settings Container.

101
00:06:01.500 --> 00:06:06.070
When you talk about not being easy to
find and being able to set this up,

102
00:06:06.070 --> 00:06:10.940
the recommendation, of course, it really
does help you out if you use this.

103
00:06:10.940 --> 00:06:13.680
Because all those settings
are gonna be located in one place.

104
00:06:13.680 --> 00:06:17.210
But it doesn't look like that they
actually designed it to make it like,

105
00:06:17.210 --> 00:06:19.400
of course, you wanna use this very easily.

106
00:06:19.400 --> 00:06:23.000
They really did bury this in some place
that, if you really don't have help,

107
00:06:23.000 --> 00:06:24.740
it's not gonna be easy to find at all.

108
00:06:24.740 --> 00:06:27.010
>> And, Ronnie,
how did you get this interface as well?

109
00:06:27.010 --> 00:06:31.240
You're using your R set tools, and so
you're working on a remote system, and

110
00:06:31.240 --> 00:06:35.280
this is kind of, maybe if you're
familiar or working within Office 365,

111
00:06:35.280 --> 00:06:38.350
is this something that we should
acclimate ourselves with?

112
00:06:38.350 --> 00:06:41.650
If this is sort of the trend or
the way that they're moving us towards?

113
00:06:41.650 --> 00:06:43.830
>> Right, if you think about it, right?

114
00:06:43.830 --> 00:06:46.180
The very fact that even though
group policy is there and

115
00:06:46.180 --> 00:06:49.000
has been there for a long time,
the management of it

116
00:06:49.000 --> 00:06:52.760
is a little bit clunky where you have to
kind of compare both of those options

117
00:06:52.760 --> 00:06:56.020
in two different locations to make sure
that they're actually working right.

118
00:06:56.020 --> 00:06:59.550
And usually, the only way for us to do
that in an effective, I'm not gonna say

119
00:06:59.550 --> 00:07:04.300
the only way, but usually an effective
way for us to do that is we apply it,

120
00:07:04.300 --> 00:07:07.770
we put a test account into an OU,
and then we see if it takes setting.

121
00:07:07.770 --> 00:07:12.250
And then when it doesn't, then we go back,
start modifying and changing it.

122
00:07:12.250 --> 00:07:15.010
But here,
we can see everything in one location.

123
00:07:15.010 --> 00:07:19.320
We have a direct comparison to all those
settings that we did see right there so

124
00:07:19.320 --> 00:07:22.880
it's easier for us to kinda troubleshoot
back and forth between them.

125
00:07:22.880 --> 00:07:26.020
So this is a recommended way, but

126
00:07:26.020 --> 00:07:30.140
there's no official Microsoft way that
says yes, you should do this, right?

127
00:07:30.140 --> 00:07:34.240
But I know that as you read Brian's book,
right, you'll actually see he says

128
00:07:34.240 --> 00:07:37.930
I recommend that you use these and don't
worry about the regular group policy.

129
00:07:37.930 --> 00:07:39.680
But just when we say that, right?

130
00:07:39.680 --> 00:07:41.660
And I know that that's
a great recommendation,

131
00:07:41.660 --> 00:07:45.530
cuz I know Brian and he wouldn't lead
us wrong, he wouldn't do it on purpose.

132
00:07:45.530 --> 00:07:48.730
But I know that everybody's gonna
have to deal with the very fact that

133
00:07:48.730 --> 00:07:51.580
they're working with their
own security policies.

134
00:07:51.580 --> 00:07:55.550
And if it says set up the actual group
policy in the way that it's supposed to-

135
00:07:55.550 --> 00:07:56.424
>> That traditional interface-

136
00:07:56.424 --> 00:07:57.628
>> Then, you're gonna have to do it

137
00:07:57.628 --> 00:07:58.532
in the traditional way.

138
00:07:58.532 --> 00:08:00.086
Now, it doesn't always make that way,
right?

139
00:08:00.086 --> 00:08:01.394
If you can show a better reason,

140
00:08:01.394 --> 00:08:04.410
do it You might be able to convince
whoever's in charge of that to change.

141
00:08:04.410 --> 00:08:05.692
But just kind of remember,

142
00:08:05.692 --> 00:08:08.940
you do have to follow whatever
policies that you have in place there.

143
00:08:08.940 --> 00:08:12.710
All right, so let's go ahead and
set this up a little bit more, all right.

144
00:08:12.710 --> 00:08:18.280
So now that I have the Password Settings
container, well, if I right-click on it,

145
00:08:18.280 --> 00:08:22.070
notice it's easy to select New,
and then I can see Settings.

146
00:08:22.070 --> 00:08:26.390
Now, if you don't like, if you're not
a habitual right clicker, like I am.

147
00:08:26.390 --> 00:08:30.300
You do have over here in the right
hand side the task pane, where notice,

148
00:08:30.300 --> 00:08:32.160
Password Settings Container.

149
00:08:32.160 --> 00:08:35.930
Now, you can select New from there,
and there it is.

150
00:08:35.930 --> 00:08:37.880
Same location it's gonna bring you to.

151
00:08:37.880 --> 00:08:41.680
It gives you multiple options to be
able to do this if you choose to.

152
00:08:41.680 --> 00:08:47.240
So let me select the Password Settings,
and now, here you can see the details.

153
00:08:47.240 --> 00:08:51.110
Remember that inside, if we compare it to
the group policy, let me bring that up,

154
00:08:51.110 --> 00:08:52.710
just to make a comparison.

155
00:08:52.710 --> 00:08:54.910
So here is the Group Policy
management center and

156
00:08:54.910 --> 00:08:59.650
I'm gonna expand out
the default domain policy, and

157
00:08:59.650 --> 00:09:05.210
expand out policies, and
window settings here, security settings.

158
00:09:05.210 --> 00:09:09.950
So even that, right, is already a little
bit clunky on how to get access to it.

159
00:09:09.950 --> 00:09:14.760
And it's under here, under
Account Settings, under Account Policies.

160
00:09:14.760 --> 00:09:18.340
And I’m doing this on purpose right now,
so as I scroll through,

161
00:09:18.340 --> 00:09:21.715
I have to set this up first,
and then set these up.

162
00:09:21.715 --> 00:09:26.990
So to go back and forth and
just to compare them after setting them,

163
00:09:26.990 --> 00:09:30.220
that is a little bit clunky as
you start to do stuff like that.

164
00:09:30.220 --> 00:09:35.290
We compare that to what we saw here,
let me see if I can bring it up here,

165
00:09:35.290 --> 00:09:36.390
there we go.

166
00:09:36.390 --> 00:09:40.650
All those settings essentially appear
right here under Password Settings.

167
00:09:40.650 --> 00:09:42.130
Enforce the minimum length,

168
00:09:42.130 --> 00:09:45.990
enforce the password history, password
must meet complexity requirements.

169
00:09:45.990 --> 00:09:48.550
Those are things we did see
in the password settings.

170
00:09:48.550 --> 00:09:50.870
The same thing on the age
options as well and

171
00:09:50.870 --> 00:09:54.020
then the lockout options
that are also available.

172
00:09:54.020 --> 00:09:55.910
Those are all the same utility and

173
00:09:55.910 --> 00:10:01.390
settings that we normally see inside
of the group policy management center.

174
00:10:01.390 --> 00:10:05.150
So the only other thing that you have
is that when you do select to do this,

175
00:10:05.150 --> 00:10:08.920
it really requires at least two
things from you which of course,

176
00:10:08.920 --> 00:10:12.360
is a name that should be unique for
how you're gonna do this.

177
00:10:12.360 --> 00:10:17.087
So let's say that I'm gonna do like
office three, let's do this instead.

178
00:10:17.087 --> 00:10:18.480
Let's do road crew.

179
00:10:21.151 --> 00:10:25.600
Roadcrew-PP for password policy.

180
00:10:25.600 --> 00:10:27.880
And notice this preference setting.

181
00:10:27.880 --> 00:10:31.080
Now, if I hover over it and
you're not sure, well it kind of gives us,

182
00:10:31.080 --> 00:10:32.129
it says here, right?

183
00:10:32.129 --> 00:10:33.880
It says password.

184
00:10:34.970 --> 00:10:38.570
Password setting with a lower precedence
number will overwrite one with

185
00:10:38.570 --> 00:10:39.830
a higher numbers.

186
00:10:39.830 --> 00:10:43.080
So this gives you the ability
not to actually worry about

187
00:10:43.080 --> 00:10:46.350
the idea of the order of,
>> Precedence.

188
00:10:46.350 --> 00:10:48.160
>> Precedence, which I can't say.

189
00:10:48.160 --> 00:10:49.940

that we are actually going to dive

00:23:00.940 --> 00:23:04.390
much more in depth in a little
bit later on as we manage

418
00:23:04.390 --> 00:23:06.890
the actual Windows services
that are available.

419
00:23:06.890 --> 00:23:07.430
But right here,

420
00:23:07.430 --> 00:23:12.500
it says this security setting allows a
security principal to log on as a service.

421
00:23:12.500 --> 00:23:16.650
Services can be configured to run
as local system, local service,

422
00:23:16.650 --> 00:23:22.060
network service accounts, which have
built in rights to log on as a service.

423
00:23:22.060 --> 00:23:25.640
Any service that runs under a separate
user account must also be assigned

424
00:23:25.640 --> 00:23:26.190
that right.

425
00:23:27.380 --> 00:23:32.720
So on this one, it is not set for us and
it's probably something we really do not

426
00:23:32.720 --> 00:23:38.250
need to use if we'll end up creating
what we call service accounts here.

427
00:23:38.250 --> 00:23:43.040
Or manage types of services accounts,
that normally replaces this need.

428
00:23:43.040 --> 00:23:45.510
What normally ends up happening
at the very beginning, and

429
00:23:45.510 --> 00:23:48.120
I don't wanna say this,
for everybody, right?

430
00:23:48.120 --> 00:23:51.910
But as somebody is learning
how to do this on their own,

431
00:23:51.910 --> 00:23:54.580
instead of trying to
create a service account,

432
00:23:54.580 --> 00:24:00.060
usually they just take their own account
and they assign it as this, right?

433
00:24:00.060 --> 00:24:05.240
Because certain applications do need
to have an account that they run under.

434
00:24:05.240 --> 00:24:06.660
So instead of them coming
up with a new one,

435
00:24:06.660 --> 00:24:11.070
they just go and let me type in my own
username and credentials and that works.

436
00:24:11.070 --> 00:24:12.480
And you can do something like that,

437
00:24:12.480 --> 00:24:14.860
you can add it in right here
to make sure that happens.

438
00:24:14.860 --> 00:24:18.630
But there are issues that are gonna come
along that we're gonna ned up seeing.

439
00:24:18.630 --> 00:24:22.870
But one of the issues is, let's say we
choose Cherokee's account to do this.

440
00:24:22.870 --> 00:24:24.340
And then Cherokee says, my gosh,

441
00:24:24.340 --> 00:24:28.650
my password, I need to change it
because I think it's been compromised.

442
00:24:28.650 --> 00:24:33.710
Well if Cherokee changes it on her
particular now logged onto the service.

443
00:24:33.710 --> 00:24:37.440
If it doesn't get updated there,
that service is not gonna run,

444
00:24:37.440 --> 00:24:38.990
it's gonna end up failing.

445
00:24:38.990 --> 00:24:44.500
So when taking a look at the idea of user,
writes assignments and

446
00:24:44.500 --> 00:24:49.350
also this idea of taking a look at

447
00:24:49.350 --> 00:24:53.780
the settings that we've been talking
about here, with the fine grain policies.

448
00:24:53.780 --> 00:24:58.000
There is a ton of information
that we do have available.

449
00:24:58.000 --> 00:25:02.031
So a lot of settings here under Group
Policy, a good server admin is gonna take

450
00:25:02.031 --> 00:25:05.891
the time to learn about some of these
different settings that you can see.

451
00:25:05.891 --> 00:25:09.250
That's gonna be common in just
about every network that you go to.

452
00:25:09.250 --> 00:25:12.844
But Cherokee, speaking of that,
there's a lot more for us to do but

453
00:25:12.844 --> 00:25:13.799
not a lot of time.

454
00:25:13.799 --> 00:25:14.960
>> That's right, Ronnie.

455
00:25:14.960 --> 00:25:16.350
We do have a lot more to cover.

456
00:25:16.350 --> 00:25:19.340
And as a matter of fact, looking at
everything that you've shown us so

457
00:25:19.340 --> 00:25:22.800
far, we need to even take a look at how
we can check our work and go back and

458
00:25:22.800 --> 00:25:24.450
audit those policies.

459
00:25:24.450 --> 00:25:28.140
But we are out of time for this show,
so ladies and gentlemen, stay tuned.

460
00:25:28.140 --> 00:25:30.120
We have more information heading your way.

461
00:25:30.120 --> 00:25:31.110
We'll go ahead and sign out.

462
00:25:31.110 --> 00:25:32.998
Remember, I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

463
00:25:32.998 --> 00:25:34.119
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

464
00:25:34.119 --> 00:25:36.290
>> See you next time here at ITPro.TV.

465
00:25:36.290 --> 00:25:43.516
[MUSIC]

466
00:25:43.516 --> 00:25:46.478
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show Ronnie and Cherokee continue to discuss how group policy can secure servers. They show how Windows Firewall can be incorporated to apply and manage rules.
episodes.title: Securing Server with Group Policy Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.867
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:03.867 --> 00:00:08.222
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.222 --> 00:00:09.298
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:09.298 --> 00:00:16.350
>> Welcome back to your Server 101
>> I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

5
00:00:16.350 --> 00:00:19.560
So we've actually made it to part three
and we are gonna continue to looking at

6
00:00:19.560 --> 00:00:24.320
how we can use group policy to help us
secure our Windows operating system.

7
00:00:24.320 --> 00:00:27.010
With us today, back in studio,
we have Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:27.010 --> 00:00:28.100
How's it going Ronnie?

9
00:00:28.100 --> 00:00:33.330
>> It's going well, as we continue on to
take a look here at the idea of securing

10
00:00:33.330 --> 00:00:36.300
our servers here with group policy.

11
00:00:36.300 --> 00:00:39.260
So if you remember in
the first couple of sections,

12
00:00:39.260 --> 00:00:41.290
first couple of episodes
that we've done on this.

13
00:00:41.290 --> 00:00:42.863
>> We didn't just looked at group policy.

14
00:00:42.863 --> 00:00:46.829
>> Yeah, we did kind of looked at it
a little bit in terms of security and

15
00:00:46.829 --> 00:00:49.410
we delved into a little bit in depth.

16
00:00:49.410 --> 00:00:51.940
And now we are continuing along with a few

17
00:00:51.940 --> 00:00:55.460
additional settings that
we have to take a look at.

18
00:00:55.460 --> 00:00:59.330
So we are going to start
here by talking about

19
00:00:59.330 --> 00:01:02.870
something that we really need to also
consider in terms of group policy,

20
00:01:02.870 --> 00:01:08.010
which is the idea of auditing our
systems that we have available to us.

21
00:01:08.010 --> 00:01:10.860
It's great to be able to set things up and

22
00:01:10.860 --> 00:01:16.270
to know that things are actually done, but
we also need to have the ability at times.

23
00:01:16.270 --> 00:01:20.390
To verify to be able to confirm that
things are actually happening or

24
00:01:20.390 --> 00:01:21.900
not happening, right?

25
00:01:21.900 --> 00:01:26.270
So, group policy gives us that ability
to set up what we called different

26
00:01:26.270 --> 00:01:31.590
audits that we can do so that we can tell
when an event has actually occurred.

27
00:01:31.590 --> 00:01:34.920
We can even at times tell
how long the event took.

28
00:01:34.920 --> 00:01:39.070
And even possibly when it ended or
when something actually didn't work.

29
00:01:39.070 --> 00:01:44.180
So those are nice things for us because
there's times when we set it up,

30
00:01:44.180 --> 00:01:47.410
not an easy confirmation except
to wait for something to happen.

31
00:01:47.410 --> 00:01:49.000
And if nobody complains about it,
we kind of go okay.

32
00:01:49.000 --> 00:01:51.270
Well, maybe that's not
should a good theory.

33
00:01:51.270 --> 00:01:54.620
To actually follow, but we might need
a little bit more detail on that.

34
00:01:54.620 --> 00:01:57.760
>> So Ronnie you're talking about
like routine maintenance auditing.

35
00:01:57.760 --> 00:02:01.870
We're not just reserving auditing for
any kind of like forensic incident or

36
00:02:01.870 --> 00:02:03.090
security incident.

37
00:02:03.090 --> 00:02:07.100
We're doing this, we have the ability to
do this to make sure that our systems

38
00:02:07.100 --> 00:02:11.270
are configured properly and functioning
the way that we think they should be.

39
00:02:11.270 --> 00:02:15.143
>> Yeah,
that's kind of an unusual standard, right?

40
00:02:15.143 --> 00:02:19.000
When you measure everything against some
type of investigation that we're doing.

41
00:02:19.000 --> 00:02:21.780
We're trying to make sure that we
set everything up for forensics.

42
00:02:21.780 --> 00:02:23.750
That's important, don't get us wrong,

43
00:02:23.750 --> 00:02:28.250
but day to day operations right
these are also part of something.

44
00:02:28.250 --> 00:02:31.790
That we wanna make sure that's going on
that's actually doing what we wanna do.

45
00:02:31.790 --> 00:02:34.990
When we set up security policies
we definitely wanna make sure

46
00:02:34.990 --> 00:02:39.580
that we are configuring them to be able
to work the way that they need to.

47
00:02:39.580 --> 00:02:43.949
And group policies helps us to be
able to at least sees some of that.

48
00:02:43.949 --> 00:02:48.471
Now, when we start to do this really it
depend on what it is that you're willing

49
00:02:48.471 --> 00:02:51.296
to see and
how much you actually need to see here.

50
00:02:51.296 --> 00:02:53.230
So there's a couple of different settings.

51
00:02:53.230 --> 00:02:57.880
Let's go ahead and take a look inside
of my Group Policy Management Editor.

52
00:02:57.880 --> 00:03:01.560
This is the default domain policy
that I have now expanded out and

53
00:03:01.560 --> 00:03:05.090
opened, so that we're actually taking
a look at the editing of that.

54
00:03:05.090 --> 00:03:06.930
So let me verify that right there.

55
00:03:06.930 --> 00:03:08.570
So there is, Default Domain Policy.

56
00:03:09.780 --> 00:03:14.661
And then I've expanded that Computer
Configuration on the Policies Windows, and

57
00:03:14.661 --> 00:03:17.600
then of course the Windows Settings,
excuse me.

58
00:03:18.610 --> 00:03:24.030
From there the Security Settings,
and then under Local Policies here.

59
00:03:24.030 --> 00:03:28.680
In our previous episode, we just finished
looking at user rights assignment.

60
00:03:28.680 --> 00:03:32.170
Since we're talking about auditing,
it's natural to actually take a look and

61
00:03:32.170 --> 00:03:36.510
realize right above that is
gonna be the audit policy.

62
00:03:36.510 --> 00:03:41.730
And I click right there, I can see
inside the details of that policy.

63
00:03:41.730 --> 00:03:48.090
There are nine different categories of
settings that we can actually used for us.

64
00:03:48.090 --> 00:03:51.640
Notice there's account audit logon events,
account management,

65
00:03:51.640 --> 00:03:57.140
directory service access,
which I can't say, audit logon,

66
00:03:57.140 --> 00:04:02.000
and then as it goes on, yes,
you see there's several of them here.

67
00:04:02.000 --> 00:04:06.050
Now we're not going super in depth in
terms of the combination of these things.

68
00:04:06.050 --> 00:04:07.890
As you go on towards your MCSA,

69
00:04:07.890 --> 00:04:11.480
you'll actually be able to kind of
see what each of these things do.

70
00:04:11.480 --> 00:04:13.330
So some of them do sound similar, right?

71
00:04:13.330 --> 00:04:15.170
So if we take a look at this, and

72
00:04:15.170 --> 00:04:18.810
notice right here one says
audit account logon events.

73
00:04:18.810 --> 00:04:22.000
And then another one just
says audit logon events.

74
00:04:22.000 --> 00:04:25.450
So even that can be a little bit
confusing, but we're not really worried

75
00:04:25.450 --> 00:04:29.700
about jumping into those and describing
what those are all about right now.

76
00:04:29.700 --> 00:04:32.970
But what I really want you to see,
and I'll show a couple of these so

77
00:04:32.970 --> 00:04:37.200
that you can see this,
is that if I select let's say this one.

78
00:04:37.200 --> 00:04:42.665
You'll notice that the policy itself is
not really defined in much depth at all.

79
00:04:42.665 --> 00:04:46.640
Okay, so for example, if I want to
implement this I define these policy

80
00:04:46.640 --> 00:04:48.973
settings that I'm putting a check mark.

81
00:04:48.973 --> 00:04:53.930
And when I do an auditing,
notice it says audit these attempts.

82
00:04:53.930 --> 00:04:58.040
So I can actually say that on
the account logon events, I want to

83
00:04:58.040 --> 00:05:03.360
know when somebody's account logon is
successful, okay, so that makes sense.

84
00:05:03.360 --> 00:05:07.360
Or I can uncheck it and
then I want to actually be notified

85
00:05:07.360 --> 00:05:11.500
By this audit here and
actually send me some type of event here.

86
00:05:11.500 --> 00:05:13.130
That tells me when it's failed.

87
00:05:13.130 --> 00:05:15.770
Or I can choose to do both if I want to.

88
00:05:15.770 --> 00:05:19.260
But notice that there's
really nothing else

89
00:05:19.260 --> 00:05:25.080
on this big gigantic dialog box here
except for the word Apply and OK.

90
00:05:25.080 --> 00:05:30.690
It really isn't anything spectacular as
far as what this event tells us, okay?

91
00:05:30.690 --> 00:05:31.810
Now, if we go on and

92
00:05:31.810 --> 00:05:35.450
let's just take a look at something
a little bit different here, right?

93
00:05:35.450 --> 00:05:39.600
Notice the audit object access, and
this is a very important one as well.

94
00:05:39.600 --> 00:05:42.330
Which says hey,
you've got access to something, right?

95
00:05:42.330 --> 00:05:45.610
But look,
it looks almost like a cookie cutter.

96
00:05:45.610 --> 00:05:48.580
Notice that we're still
seeing the same things.

97
00:05:48.580 --> 00:05:52.960
We're either making sure that we know that
somebody's actually been successful at

98
00:05:52.960 --> 00:05:57.560
getting access to this, or they failed,
or we can do a combination of both, okay.

99
00:05:57.560 --> 00:05:59.330
So that's what we're starting to see.

100
00:05:59.330 --> 00:06:03.007
>> Okay, and by looking at those it is
kind of interesting that they give you

101
00:06:03.007 --> 00:06:05.318
the option to select either, or, and both.

102
00:06:05.318 --> 00:06:07.728
Although it's only three settings here,
but

103
00:06:07.728 --> 00:06:11.866
it's not like really one of those two
options is more important than the other,

104
00:06:11.866 --> 00:06:14.296
so you might want to go ahead and
select both.

105
00:06:14.296 --> 00:06:16.285
Because those successful,

106
00:06:16.285 --> 00:06:20.070
those failed logins can tell you just as
much as the successful ones can right?

107
00:06:20.070 --> 00:06:23.750
>> Right, and again it all depends
on your security context and

108
00:06:23.750 --> 00:06:26.760
what it is that you're
really looking to do, okay?

109
00:06:26.760 --> 00:06:31.160
If you're trying to make sure, let's take
for an example that there is something

110
00:06:31.160 --> 00:06:35.350
that only a certain group of
people can access certain objects.

111
00:06:35.350 --> 00:06:39.750
What you may want to take a look at, who
is actually not successful at logging in.

112
00:06:39.750 --> 00:06:44.390
So in other words you know who should be
logging in, but you not really caring

113
00:06:44.390 --> 00:06:47.880
if anybody else is logging in but
you wanna see who attempts it.

114
00:06:47.880 --> 00:06:51.910
So maybe just auditing those
failures will actually help instead.

115
00:06:51.910 --> 00:06:54.450
But you can actually take
a look at both if you chose to.

116
00:06:54.450 --> 00:06:57.990
Now you might be saying Ronnie,
why would you do one or the other,

117
00:06:57.990 --> 00:06:59.920
if you can actually do both?

118
00:06:59.920 --> 00:07:02.290
Well, remember that even
though this is small,

119
00:07:02.290 --> 00:07:05.390
there's also other settings that
we might have put in place.

120
00:07:05.390 --> 00:07:09.720
Not just with this auditing, but with
all the other options that we have here,

121
00:07:09.720 --> 00:07:11.650
and available for us.

122
00:07:11.650 --> 00:07:12.970
All of these, after a while,

123
00:07:12.970 --> 00:07:17.090
they can generate a little bit
of volume on your computer.

124
00:07:17.090 --> 00:07:19.920
To where you have to consider space.

125
00:07:19.920 --> 00:07:23.660
Now, on a single machine in lab
environment, I'm not gonna generate enough

126
00:07:23.660 --> 00:07:29.190
to actually really impact the overall
volume of the drive that I have.

127
00:07:29.190 --> 00:07:33.208
But maybe in a real production
environment, if I have a very active

128
00:07:33.208 --> 00:07:38.043
network, and everybody's accessing this
one particular object that I have.

129
00:07:38.043 --> 00:07:42.011
Such as an application or a folder,
whatever it might be, well that might

130
00:07:42.011 --> 00:07:46.800
generate so much more traffic that each
of these logs begins to add up in volume.

131
00:07:46.800 --> 00:07:50.660
So do make a consideration also for
space, so instead of actually doing both,

132
00:07:50.660 --> 00:07:54.007
you're actually gonna say,
let me just audit these instead.

133
00:07:54.007 --> 00:07:56.142
So it really does depend on the context.

134
00:07:56.142 --> 00:07:58.899
Now the reason why I also
wanted to show this, right?

135
00:07:58.899 --> 00:08:02.979
Is that you're starting to sizzling
that That sounds like a real

136
00:08:02.979 --> 00:08:04.273
audit of some sort.

137
00:08:04.273 --> 00:08:08.108
Ronnie, at the beginning, you were saying
you can find out when an event started.

138
00:08:08.108 --> 00:08:10.751
You could find out how long
an event actually goes on,

139
00:08:10.751 --> 00:08:12.583
when it actually possible stopped.

140
00:08:12.583 --> 00:08:15.210
You noted something like that, right?

141
00:08:15.210 --> 00:08:17.740
You can actually find all this stuff out.

142
00:08:17.740 --> 00:08:21.779
Well it actually, you can,
but not through here, okay?

143
00:08:21.779 --> 00:08:25.051
So this is where it's a little
bit more tricky, right?

144
00:08:25.051 --> 00:08:27.741
Normally this is the first
place that we are introduced,

145
00:08:27.741 --> 00:08:29.890
especially when we go into the MCSA.

146
00:08:29.890 --> 00:08:33.430
We start to take a look at these
audit policies right here.

147
00:08:33.430 --> 00:08:37.720
But they are very blocky,
they are very categorical in what they do.

148
00:08:37.720 --> 00:08:42.020
They are not as fine grained
as we would expect them to be.

149
00:08:42.020 --> 00:08:46.317
But we do have that ability, like we
also saw with the password policies.

150
00:08:46.317 --> 00:08:49.375
Where we can get a little bit
more fine grained as well,

151
00:08:49.375 --> 00:08:53.740
to be able to actually do much more
than what we just showed you here.

152
00:08:53.740 --> 00:08:56.390
So let's take a look at that aspect too.

153
00:08:56.390 --> 00:09:00.642
Now, unlike the fine grain password
policies, where we can set all that

154
00:09:00.642 --> 00:09:04.488
up along with the account policies
all together in one location.

155
00:09:04.488 --> 00:09:09.079
If we're gonna remain right here inside
of the group policy settings, and what

156
00:09:09.079 --> 00:09:13.688
we'll notice is, over here on the left
hand side, as we continue to navigate.

157
00:09:13.688 --> 00:09:19.779
We will also, as we scroll down, you'll
see something else right here at the end,

158
00:09:19.779 --> 00:09:23.709
where it says
Advanced Audit Policy Configuration.

159
00:09:23.709 --> 00:09:28.280
And this is where we get more fine
grained opportunities to actually set

160
00:09:28.280 --> 00:09:31.510
auditing the way that we want to as well.

161
00:09:31.510 --> 00:09:35.168
So when we start to take a look
at the Advanced Audit Policies.

162
00:09:35.168 --> 00:09:39.107
These are gonna be much more granular
in their nature than simply giving us

163
00:09:39.107 --> 00:09:42.990
the ability to say, all right,
somebody accessed something.

164
00:09:42.990 --> 00:09:46.765
Somebody was able to logon
successfully whatever it might be,

165
00:09:46.765 --> 00:09:49.710
ao that is what we wanna take a look at.

166
00:09:49.710 --> 00:09:53.339
If I click on this little right pointing
arrow here on the left hand side.

167
00:09:54.590 --> 00:09:58.150
I expand that out and
notice it has a nice little icon here,

168
00:09:58.150 --> 00:10:02.520
Audit Policies, and I click on that and
I expand that down.

169
00:10:02.520 --> 00:10:07.820
Now I can go into the details pane and
see some of the other information.

170
00:10:07.820 --> 00:10:11.450
Let's go ahead and take a look at
what it says as we get started with
