00:22:49.370 --> 00:22:54.190
it really does look like the same
settings firewall that open up directly.

397
00:22:54.190 --> 00:22:56.750
You'd actually see these kind of things.

398
00:22:56.750 --> 00:23:00.210
So there's the three domain
profiles on this particular

399
00:23:00.210 --> 00:23:02.210
instance that we're actually seeing.

400
00:23:02.210 --> 00:23:06.740
So here domain, private, whatever,
notice it says it's not configured,

401
00:23:06.740 --> 00:23:10.180
well you can go in here and
then configure those properties

402
00:23:10.180 --> 00:23:14.160
to be able to make sure that it's
actually on or off or not configured.

403
00:23:14.160 --> 00:23:16.940
Now the reason why this one's not
configured is cuz I'm not managing it

404
00:23:16.940 --> 00:23:18.340
through group policy.

405
00:23:18.340 --> 00:23:19.360
But if you were to,

406
00:23:19.360 --> 00:23:23.400
this is where you would go to
do the domain, private profile,

407
00:23:23.400 --> 00:23:28.390
public profile, and even on the IP set
defaults you can actually change that.

408
00:23:28.390 --> 00:23:32.800
So those are some of the things probably
at the minimum and not the basic.

409
00:23:32.800 --> 00:23:34.880
If I knew that people were
turning off the firewall,

410
00:23:34.880 --> 00:23:36.890
I would probably at least set that.

411
00:23:36.890 --> 00:23:41.260
I may not set all the other things here,
but I may at least set that.

412
00:23:41.260 --> 00:23:44.714
Now, the other ones of course
might be right here on creating

413
00:23:44.714 --> 00:23:47.096
these firewall rules and managing them.

414
00:23:47.096 --> 00:23:51.110
Outbound rules by default,
it allows everything to travel outbound.

415
00:23:51.110 --> 00:23:54.230
What you're really worried about
the majority of the time is right here

416
00:23:54.230 --> 00:23:54.958
under inbound.

417
00:23:54.958 --> 00:23:59.438
What is allowed to get in to your
computer and you might think well,

418
00:23:59.438 --> 00:24:03.520
my network has a firewall at the edge,
why do I care?

419
00:24:03.520 --> 00:24:07.140
Well, if your network is more
open than you think it is,

420
00:24:07.140 --> 00:24:10.230
in other words you have vendors that
come on to your network that you give

421
00:24:10.230 --> 00:24:14.150
them access to your wireless network
even though you don't think that you do.

422
00:24:14.150 --> 00:24:15.100
>> They're already behind that firewall.

423
00:24:15.100 --> 00:24:16.820
>> Somebody's already behind the firewall.

424
00:24:16.820 --> 00:24:20.531
Somebody plugs in their own home laptop,
they're ready behind the firewall.

425
00:24:20.531 --> 00:24:22.783
You wanna make sure that
these come in and, or

426
00:24:22.783 --> 00:24:26.518
these come into play when you have
Inbound Rules that says reject any of this

427
00:24:26.518 --> 00:24:29.950
traffic even though it's already
behind another firewall.

428
00:24:29.950 --> 00:24:33.320
If it comes in even from the same network,
go on and do that.

429
00:24:33.320 --> 00:24:37.500
So the Windows firewall really does act
like an intrusion prevention system,

430
00:24:37.500 --> 00:24:39.540
a host based intrusion
prevention system for

431
00:24:39.540 --> 00:24:43.110
us that works relatively effectively,
right.

432
00:24:43.110 --> 00:24:44.970
If we actually do use them.

433
00:24:44.970 --> 00:24:48.279
So do take a look,
let me just click on this Inbound Rules so

434
00:24:48.279 --> 00:24:51.737
that we can see here just for
a moment there is nothing shown.

435
00:24:51.737 --> 00:24:56.010
So I wanna create one, I just simply
right click on the Inbound Rule,

436
00:24:56.010 --> 00:24:57.200
select a New Rule.

437
00:24:57.200 --> 00:25:00.937
And now you'll see that it's the same
wizard that you walked through based on

438
00:25:00.937 --> 00:25:03.940
program, port, something defined,
or even a custom rule.

439
00:25:05.100 --> 00:25:08.580
And you go through, and you create these
types of rules to help you out, okay?

440
00:25:08.580 --> 00:25:12.700
So that's the same thing that you'll
see with the outbound rules as well,

441
00:25:12.700 --> 00:25:16.840
same utility, and
you'll be able to configure those.

442
00:25:16.840 --> 00:25:19.670
Don't overdo it,
because you have a security policy

443
00:25:19.670 --> 00:25:23.950
that's in place that tells you,
what you can do, what you can't do.

444
00:25:23.950 --> 00:25:27.050
Just make sure you follow that
policy as you set this thing up.

445
00:25:27.050 --> 00:25:30.070
But the primary reason
again is accidentally,

446
00:25:30.070 --> 00:25:32.240
or again I won't say accidentally.

447
00:25:32.240 --> 00:25:37.870
Somebody believes helpful, well intended
person that says let's just do this.

448
00:25:37.870 --> 00:25:39.560
And if you're like me,
right, you're forgetful.

449
00:25:39.560 --> 00:25:40.774
And when you're doing it for

450
00:25:40.774 --> 00:25:43.107
testing though,
I'll turn this thing right back on.

451
00:25:43.107 --> 00:25:47.340
10 minutes later I'd forgotten that
I even messed with the firewall.

452
00:25:47.340 --> 00:25:49.820
So that's never a good thing.

453
00:25:49.820 --> 00:25:52.720
If you really inside of
a production network

454
00:25:52.720 --> 00:25:55.780
this is something that may
actually help you out tremendously

455
00:25:55.780 --> 00:25:59.100
when you're starting to see unusual
settings across your network like that.

456
00:25:59.100 --> 00:26:03.050
Whereas something that you don't want to
happen, so do pay attention there and

457
00:26:03.050 --> 00:26:05.995
all of these will help secure
your computing environment.

458
00:26:05.995 --> 00:26:09.140
Much better using group
policy much more effectively.

459
00:26:09.140 --> 00:26:10.740
>> Well Ronnie, thank you for
taking the time.

460
00:26:10.740 --> 00:26:15.530
I know we rounded out a whole
three 30 minute episodes there for

461
00:26:15.530 --> 00:26:16.980
different types of group policy.

462
00:26:16.980 --> 00:26:20.100
There's always a lot to learn when
we're working with group policy, so

463
00:26:20.100 --> 00:26:21.280
thank you for that.

464
00:26:21.280 --> 00:26:22.930
And thank you for joining us, but

465
00:26:22.930 --> 00:26:25.510
stay tuned we have more
information headed your way.

466
00:26:25.510 --> 00:26:27.090
For this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

467
00:26:27.090 --> 00:26:28.900
Remember, I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

468
00:26:28.900 --> 00:26:29.760
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

469
00:26:29.760 --> 00:26:33.039
>> See you next time, here at ITProTV.

470
00:26:33.039 --> 00:26:38.858
[MUSIC]

471
00:26:38.858 --> 00:26:42.594
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie explain what services are and how managing them correctly can improve system and network performance. Ronnie demonstrates how to navigate through the services management console using services.msc, the primary management tool. He also demonstrates other ways to start and stop a service through the GUI and PowerShell.
episodes.title: Managing Windows Services

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie continue to discuss ways to manage services. First, Ronnie explains the purpose of a service account, which accounts one should use and explains issues you may encounter. Next, they look at group managed service accounts and describe ways to work across multiple servers, schedule tasks, and provide application support.
episodes.title: Managing Windows Services Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce working with local storage.  Cherokee reviews of the basic storage and terminology concepts.  She reviews basic disk redundancy and performance technology like RAID, 0, 1, and 5.  She distinguishes partitioning technology of MBR and GPT.
episodes.title: Working with Local Storage
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:05.958
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:05.958 --> 00:00:08.299
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.299 --> 00:00:10.966
>> You are watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.966 --> 00:00:15.040
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.040 --> 00:00:18.520
You are watching
the Windows Server 101 show.

6
00:00:18.520 --> 00:00:20.040
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

7
00:00:20.040 --> 00:00:23.100
today we're taking a look at
working with local storage.

8
00:00:23.100 --> 00:00:26.480
And here to help us out as we continue
on with some server knowledge

9
00:00:26.480 --> 00:00:28.020
is gonna be Cherokee Boose.

10
00:00:28.020 --> 00:00:28.869
Cherokee welcome back to the studios.

11
00:00:28.869 --> 00:00:30.587
>> Thank you for having me Ronnie,
how is it going?

12
00:00:30.587 --> 00:00:31.469
>> It is going well.

13
00:00:31.469 --> 00:00:35.855
So, Cherokee, when we first start
talking about the idea of local storage,

14
00:00:35.855 --> 00:00:37.980
this may be a little bit confusing.

15
00:00:37.980 --> 00:00:40.790
Most of us if we've been at
the desktop technician level,

16
00:00:40.790 --> 00:00:42.170
we really talk about hard drives.

17
00:00:42.170 --> 00:00:46.410
What are we normally talking about when we
start moving in server and local storage?

18
00:00:46.410 --> 00:00:51.230
>> So here's the thing, Microsoft really
does have a lot of information for

19
00:00:51.230 --> 00:00:52.190
us to think about here.

20
00:00:52.190 --> 00:00:56.270
There's lots of layers of complexity when
you're talking about server side storage.

21
00:00:56.270 --> 00:00:58.810
So I'm gonna try to break it down for
you as much as I can.

22
00:00:58.810 --> 00:01:01.220
I wouldn't get to hung up
on all the terminology.

23
00:01:01.220 --> 00:01:03.768
I'll tell you which ones I would
not worry about so much and

24
00:01:03.768 --> 00:01:05.333
which ones you should worry about.

25
00:01:05.333 --> 00:01:07.893
Because a lot of times,
even in the industry, Ronnie,

26
00:01:07.893 --> 00:01:10.835
you'll hear terms that people,
just depending on who you are or

27
00:01:10.835 --> 00:01:14.392
what background you came from,
they might call things slightly different.

28
00:01:14.392 --> 00:01:18.874
And the way that Microsoft even
shows things within the interface,

29
00:01:18.874 --> 00:01:23.433
they sometimes are slight details
between the names that people will

30
00:01:23.433 --> 00:01:25.870
understand what you're saying.

31
00:01:25.870 --> 00:01:30.720
So, the first concept that I wanna
convey here is the difference between

32
00:01:30.720 --> 00:01:35.400
a physical disc versus a virtual disc.

33
00:01:35.400 --> 00:01:40.600
So here is the thing, a physical disc is
a disk that you can hold, it's tangible.

34
00:01:40.600 --> 00:01:45.730
And a virtual disc is going to
be software based either VHD or

35
00:01:45.730 --> 00:01:50.300
VHDX, if we're in a Windows environment,
those are gonna be the file extensions for

36
00:01:50.300 --> 00:01:55.160
that type of intangible disk, all right?

37
00:01:55.160 --> 00:01:59.240
And you also don't wanna get that confused
with, there's a wizard whenever we're

38
00:01:59.240 --> 00:02:02.590
working, and we'll get to this part here,
but we'll be working in storage pools, and

39
00:02:02.590 --> 00:02:09.420
they also call it a virtual disk
once you create a contiguous or

40
00:02:09.420 --> 00:02:13.440
a space of disks within storage pools.

41
00:02:14.590 --> 00:02:16.090
They call that a virtual disk as well.

42
00:02:16.090 --> 00:02:18.550
So like I said,
don't get hung up on the details.

43
00:02:18.550 --> 00:02:21.090
We'll go ahead and
talk about all of those individually.

44
00:02:21.090 --> 00:02:25.720
>> Now Cherokee, remember that for us,
as we get started and for you as you

45
00:02:25.720 --> 00:02:30.720
start watching this, it's easy to get hung
up on the term physical versus virtual.

46
00:02:30.720 --> 00:02:32.940
But remember what we just
described at the show as being,

47
00:02:32.940 --> 00:02:34.755
which is working with local storage.

48
00:02:34.755 --> 00:02:38.906
We're really saying it doesn't matter in
terms of that as the way that we're gonna

49
00:02:38.906 --> 00:02:41.767
be managing and
administrating the idea of our storage.

50
00:02:41.767 --> 00:02:45.144
Whether it's virtual or local,
we're gonna kinda treat it as the same.

51
00:02:45.144 --> 00:02:47.893
So even today,
the term is no longer really about

52
00:02:47.893 --> 00:02:51.070
whether it's a physical drive or
a virtual hard drive.

53
00:02:51.070 --> 00:02:54.470
We just call it storage today,
is pretty much what we end up seeing.

54
00:02:54.470 --> 00:02:56.730
So, Cherokee,
when we start to deal with that and

55
00:02:56.730 --> 00:03:00.100
understand that there are differences but
it's really not in terms of

56
00:03:00.100 --> 00:03:03.760
the administrator side of it that's really
any different, where are we gonna begin?

57
00:03:03.760 --> 00:03:06.700
>> So we're gonna go back
to the physical drives and

58
00:03:06.700 --> 00:03:10.550
let's start there because I have some
concepts that I want you to understand

59
00:03:10.550 --> 00:03:13.920
in a physical sense before we move
towards that intangible concept.

60
00:03:13.920 --> 00:03:17.325
So if you can take a look at my screen,
I'd like to show you something here.

61
00:03:17.325 --> 00:03:20.450
So we talk about a RAID, RAID stands for

62
00:03:20.450 --> 00:03:24.620
Redundant Array of,
it used to be Inexpensive Disks but

63
00:03:24.620 --> 00:03:28.640
a lot of times people would
just say Independent Disks now,

64
00:03:28.640 --> 00:03:32.920
because the cost to storage
ratio has really gone down,

65
00:03:32.920 --> 00:03:38.450
so RAID, Redundant Array of Inexpensive or
Independent Discs.

66
00:03:38.450 --> 00:03:40.480
And you hear the term redundant.

67
00:03:40.480 --> 00:03:45.220
So that implies that we're using
this concept for redundancy,

68
00:03:45.220 --> 00:03:47.328
which most of the time we are.

69
00:03:47.328 --> 00:03:51.710
There are a slight instances like the
example that we're looking at my screen

70
00:03:51.710 --> 00:03:56.410
where you would use it for performance
instead of actual redundancy here.

71
00:03:56.410 --> 00:04:02.180
So array just meaning multiple right and
so we have multiple drives.

72
00:04:02.180 --> 00:04:07.920
So if we look at a RAID 0,
a RAID 0 you have to have at least 2 or

73
00:04:07.920 --> 00:04:10.080
more disks when we're
talking about a RAID 0.

74
00:04:10.080 --> 00:04:12.890
There is no redundancy here.

75
00:04:12.890 --> 00:04:17.440
So striping, there are different
strips sizes that you can go ahead and

76
00:04:17.440 --> 00:04:22.700
configure, but
let's just say I had some data.

77
00:04:22.700 --> 00:04:26.006
And now we're gonna be, defending
on my stripe size, I had a file and

78
00:04:26.006 --> 00:04:27.600
I wanted to save my file.

79
00:04:27.600 --> 00:04:30.205
Well, defending on
the size of that stripe,

80
00:04:30.205 --> 00:04:33.910
x amount of that file would go to disk A.

81
00:04:33.910 --> 00:04:38.860
Let's say this first one is A, the second
one is B, and this third disk is disk C.

82
00:04:38.860 --> 00:04:43.630
So x amount of that file would go to
disk A and then it would go ahead and

83
00:04:43.630 --> 00:04:45.650
stripe and go through.

84
00:04:45.650 --> 00:04:50.570
So you see how it's listed here,
1, 2, 3, 4.

85
00:04:50.570 --> 00:04:54.440
And what that does and especially when
we're talking about our spindle drives,

86
00:04:54.440 --> 00:04:57.680
and you think about the little actuator
and that head that has to move back and

87
00:04:57.680 --> 00:05:00.290
forth to perform those read and
write functions.

88
00:05:00.290 --> 00:05:03.829
You're essentially increasing
the speed of those read and

89
00:05:03.829 --> 00:05:07.734
write functions exponentially by
the number of drives you have.

90
00:05:07.734 --> 00:05:11.407
So at minimum you would have to have
at least two physical drives and

91
00:05:11.407 --> 00:05:14.105
we really see that
performance increase there.

92
00:05:14.105 --> 00:05:21.335
And talk about large even data centers,
that's where you see a huge benefit here.

93
00:05:21.335 --> 00:05:23.975
But note that there is no redundancy

94
00:05:23.975 --> 00:05:26.655
involved with this kind
of a configuration.

95
00:05:26.655 --> 00:05:30.700
So, you really have to use this
in a situation in which you're

96
00:05:30.700 --> 00:05:33.890
not too concerned about the information
that's stored on these drives.

97
00:05:33.890 --> 00:05:39.250
Let's say at a large data center, maybe
Amazon, browsing through their catalog,

98
00:05:39.250 --> 00:05:44.270
you as an end user, you're not actually
browsing through the read write

99
00:05:44.270 --> 00:05:47.220
copy of the information that
you see on that web page,

100
00:05:47.220 --> 00:05:51.670
you're just looking at a read only
copy of Amazon's information there.

101
00:05:51.670 --> 00:05:54.510
So if one of those drives come down
with some read only information,

102
00:05:54.510 --> 00:05:56.330
it's not a big deal to them.

103
00:05:56.330 --> 00:05:58.370
So you just have to keep
that in mind there.

104
00:06:00.140 --> 00:06:02.590
If one of these drives were to fail,
though,

105
00:06:02.590 --> 00:06:06.328
you're gonna lose all that
information because, let's just say,

106
00:06:06.328 --> 00:06:12.518
oops, If we delete all of this,

107
00:06:12.518 --> 00:06:17.710
that information is not,
what's the word I'm looking for here?

108
00:06:17.710 --> 00:06:21.810
It does us no good, because you
can't fill in the blanks here and

109
00:06:21.810 --> 00:06:24.180
just assume that you know what
the rest of that information is,

110
00:06:24.180 --> 00:06:26.370
once it's gone,
it's gone there with RAID 0.

111
00:06:26.370 --> 00:06:29.900
>> All right, Cherokee,
now you've just introduced a concept of

112
00:06:29.900 --> 00:06:32.360
the idea of RAID and
trying to understand it.

113
00:06:32.360 --> 00:06:37.100
How does this go about, do I just simply
add another hard drive into my server and

114
00:06:37.100 --> 00:06:39.600
automatically recognizes and
gives us RAID, or

115
00:06:39.600 --> 00:06:42.790
is there some other hardware
component that I need to have set up?

116
00:06:42.790 --> 00:06:44.120
>> Okay, that's a great question, Ronnie.

117
00:06:44.120 --> 00:06:48.310
And it really depends on, there are a lot
of different options out there for you.

118
00:06:48.310 --> 00:06:52.560
So, that example that I was
mentioning there with the Amazon.

119
00:06:52.560 --> 00:06:58.470
So, they are typically gonna be using
dedicated hardware in order to ahead and

120
00:06:58.470 --> 00:07:00.250
then use a RAID configuration.

121
00:07:00.250 --> 00:07:01.830
So, for example,

122
00:07:01.830 --> 00:07:06.540
you could have like a PCI-E card,
and it's called a RAID controller.

123
00:07:06.540 --> 00:07:09.140
So it's just like a card that
you'd actually put into on your

124
00:07:09.140 --> 00:07:10.460
motherboard, right?

125
00:07:10.460 --> 00:07:14.710
And then that card will be
handling all of these computations

126
00:07:14.710 --> 00:07:19.740
instead of having it handled
on your computer's CPU.

127
00:07:19.740 --> 00:07:24.400
Now there are motherboards that have
integrated chip sets that will allow you

128
00:07:24.400 --> 00:07:27.550
to have an on board RAID configuration.

129
00:07:27.550 --> 00:07:31.410
But those are really more
geared towards the home user.

130
00:07:31.410 --> 00:07:36.060
They don't handle smaller size stripes.

131
00:07:36.060 --> 00:07:37.520
And let me,
if you can look at my screen here,

132
00:07:37.520 --> 00:07:39.080
let me just kind of
explain what that means.

133
00:07:39.080 --> 00:07:42.138
Because it really depends when you're
choosing the size of your stripe,

134
00:07:42.138 --> 00:07:44.573
it depends on what kind of
files you're gonna be storing.

135
00:07:44.573 --> 00:07:49.123
Because if you're choosing files that
are smaller than you stripe size, and

136
00:07:49.123 --> 00:07:53.814
they go to write to each one of those
drives, you really won't see a performance

137
00:07:53.814 --> 00:07:58.084
increase if it's only gonna be Filling
up on one drive, if this file is so

138
00:07:58.084 --> 00:08:02.448
small that it only goes into one drive and
you don't have to spread it out.

139
00:08:02.448 --> 00:08:07.296
So larger organizations are probably
gonna have the capability

140
00:08:07.296 --> 00:08:10.087
to have really small stripes there.

141
00:08:10.087 --> 00:08:14.009
And you also wanna think about single
points of failure because a lot of times,

142
00:08:14.009 --> 00:08:18.112
not in this particular one, but we'll look
at others that are really designed for

143
00:08:18.112 --> 00:08:18.836
redundancy.

144
00:08:18.836 --> 00:08:20.663
And a lot of times companies and

145
00:08:20.663 --> 00:08:25.920
organizations implement RAID arrays
because they wanna have that redundancy.

146
00:08:25.920 --> 00:08:30.820
But if you think about, like I said, the
PCI-E card, that's a piece of hardware.

147
00:08:30.820 --> 00:08:34.600
So that individual card could also
pose as a single point of failure.

148
00:08:34.600 --> 00:08:35.838
So in some instances,

149
00:08:35.838 --> 00:08:40.081
you also want to add additional RAID
controllers to those additional cards.

150
00:08:40.081 --> 00:08:43.071
And if you had, let's say,
two RAID controller cards,

151
00:08:43.071 --> 00:08:45.637
then you would go ahead and
call that duplexing.

152
00:08:45.637 --> 00:08:49.295
And there are different ways you could
configured that so that if one of

153
00:08:49.295 --> 00:08:53.139
those were to fail you wouldn't have
to wait to go grab another RAID card,

154
00:08:53.139 --> 00:08:54.990
RAID controller and set that up.

155
00:08:54.990 --> 00:08:57.420
And you could just have
business continuity and

156
00:08:57.420 --> 00:08:58.450
not have to worry about that.

157
00:08:58.450 --> 00:08:59.710
Because after all,

158
00:08:59.710 --> 00:09:03.430
that's really what a lot of companies are
trying to achieve with this configuration.

159
00:09:03.430 --> 00:09:07.367
There are a lot of different types
of RAID configurations out there.

160
00:09:07.367 --> 00:09:09.740
In Brian's book, he only calls out three.

161
00:09:09.740 --> 00:09:11.060
So that's what we'll stick to here.

162
00:09:11.060 --> 00:09:13.083
These ones are pretty common.

163
00:09:13.083 --> 00:09:17.592
Actually, I was looking at the book and
one of his quotes he said that he's never

164
00:09:17.592 --> 00:09:22.465
worked in an organization before where
they haven't actually implemented Raid 1.

165
00:09:22.465 --> 00:09:26.720
So let's talk about Raid 1 for
a second if we could look at my screen.

166
00:09:26.720 --> 00:09:32.550
Raid 1 is very common and
it is going to be mirroring, okay?

167
00:09:32.550 --> 00:09:37.460
So let me jump back, I do wanna ask you
a question here, point something out.

168
00:09:37.460 --> 00:09:42.200
When I look at these drives, I want you to
understand, let's say each one of these

169
00:09:42.200 --> 00:09:46.680
drives with a RAID 0,
are equivalent to one terabyte each.

170
00:09:46.680 --> 00:09:50.450
I can theoretically fill up
all of the storage space,

171
00:09:50.450 --> 00:09:55.950
so I have three terabytes of usable
storage on this particular diagram, okay?

172
00:09:55.950 --> 00:09:59.110
And the reason I wanted to point that
out is because if we look at a Raid 1,

173
00:09:59.110 --> 00:10:03.370
you lose 50% of your storage
utilization space here.

174
00:10:03.370 --> 00:10:08.060
Because what you're dealing with
is you have hard drive A, and

175
00:10:08.060 --> 00:10:11.380
hard drive B is an exact replica.

176
00:10:11.380 --> 00:10:15.760
So, every time you go write
to a particular drive here,

177
00:10:15.760 --> 00:10:20.990
it's actually making an exact
duplicate on that secondary drive.

178
00:10:20.990 --> 00:10:25.760
Now, you're not limited to
having only one extra drive.

179
00:10:25.760 --> 00:10:28.680
You can have as many as
your budget allows for.

180
00:10:28.680 --> 00:10:36.000
But just know this is somewhat of
a costly method because you're paying for

181
00:10:36.000 --> 00:10:40.840
double the storage, but you're only
getting 50% of that utilization there.

182
00:10:40.840 --> 00:10:46.720
But the benefit here would be,
if one of these drives were to go down,

183
00:10:46.720 --> 00:10:50.040
have a hardware failure,
you still have all your data intact.

184
00:10:50.040 --> 00:10:53.490
So that's probably one of
the reasons why it's so

185
00:10:53.490 --> 00:10:58.150
popular, even though there's a larger
expense associated with that.

186
00:11:00.778 --> 00:11:04.272
I really like this one, this is RAID 5,
and it's kind of interesting.

187
00:11:04.272 --> 00:11:07.606
This was a very first RAID
failure that I had to deal with

188
00:11:07.606 --> 00:11:09.500
in a production environment.

189
00:11:09.500 --> 00:11:13.080
I was working as a network admin and
I just started with the company.

190
00:11:13.080 --> 00:11:16.230
And I was still getting acclimated,
trying to figure out everyone's names.

191
00:11:16.230 --> 00:11:19.920
And then all of a sudden, I had a drive
go down in a particular server.

192
00:11:19.920 --> 00:11:23.780
So that was fun right off the bat.

193
00:11:23.780 --> 00:11:26.450
But it's really not difficult to
deal with, and I'll tell you why.

194
00:11:27.520 --> 00:11:30.910
So here in this particular situation,
we have three drives, right?

195
00:11:30.910 --> 00:11:37.310
So A, B and C, if I'm going to
implement striping like we spoke about

196
00:11:37.310 --> 00:11:41.950
with that RAID 0, we have a little
bit of extra protection here.

197
00:11:41.950 --> 00:11:44.270
This is called striping with parity.

198
00:11:44.270 --> 00:11:49.750
And parity is simply going to be a
mathematical algorithm that is performed.

199
00:11:49.750 --> 00:11:55.207
And it looks at the bits and
determines if they're even or odd, and

200
00:11:55.207 --> 00:12:02.142
it'll be able to tell if that information,
if it should be even or odd to rebuild it.

201
00:12:02.142 --> 00:12:06.524
So what I'm trying to say here is,
let's say one of these drives,

202
00:12:06.524 --> 00:12:10.280
I have three drives,
if one of these drives were to fail,

203
00:12:10.280 --> 00:12:13.047
then I could plug in an additional drive.

204
00:12:13.047 --> 00:12:17.840
Or I might even have one already
in that disk enclosure sitting

205
00:12:17.840 --> 00:12:22.580
there as a hot spare and
it might automatically kick in.

206
00:12:22.580 --> 00:12:25.310
And guess what?
Because of these parity bits that

207
00:12:25.310 --> 00:12:29.944
are spread out amongst the drives,
it'll start to go ahead and

208
00:12:29.944 --> 00:12:34.157
rebuild the new drive when you
put it in there, the data.

209
00:12:34.157 --> 00:12:38.720
It'll start to rebuild the data, but
there are some things to consider.

210
00:12:38.720 --> 00:12:41.990
So I'm striping, so you see,
let's say, I had a file and

211
00:12:41.990 --> 00:12:44.980
I go to save my information
across these three disks.

212
00:12:44.980 --> 00:12:49.242
I save it onto disk A,
disk B, every third bit, so

213
00:12:49.242 --> 00:12:52.499
to speak, is going to be a parity bit.

214
00:12:52.499 --> 00:12:56.155
So here I put parity, so
that file gets number three,

215
00:12:56.155 --> 00:13:00.600
you see the rest of that data is
actually being written here on A.

216
00:13:00.600 --> 00:13:03.829
And it goes through that process and
you can see how it's striped.

217
00:13:03.829 --> 00:13:05.606
That's where that name comes from there.

218
00:13:05.606 --> 00:13:09.360
But you're using these parity bits and

219
00:13:09.360 --> 00:13:14.320
they're actually one-third
of your storage.

220
00:13:14.320 --> 00:13:18.400
So that takes up 33% of your disk space.

221
00:13:18.400 --> 00:13:21.046
So you're looking at
about a 67% utilization,

222
00:13:21.046 --> 00:13:23.565
that's something that you
wanna account for here.

223
00:13:23.565 --> 00:13:28.085
So I'm seeing better utilization
than I did see with my mirroring.

224
00:13:28.085 --> 00:13:32.778
I get that parity, so
I don't have as big of an expense here and

225
00:13:32.778 --> 00:13:35.141
I still have that redundancy.

226
00:13:35.141 --> 00:13:39.685
So this is why RAID 5 is so common.

227
00:13:39.685 --> 00:13:44.680
But you have to have a minimum of three
drives like this example I have here

228
00:13:44.680 --> 00:13:47.900
to be able to tolerate one drive loss.

229
00:13:47.900 --> 00:13:52.660
You can add additional drives and
that will give you greater loss, but

230
00:13:52.660 --> 00:13:54.740
it just depends on your organization.

231
00:13:54.740 --> 00:14:00.600
>> Now Cherokee, with RAID 5,
we do have to be careful on that 33% idea.

232
00:14:00.600 --> 00:14:05.080
It really is the equivalent of one volume
or one particular hard drive for us.

233
00:14:05.080 --> 00:14:06.540
>> Yeah.
>> Normally, with RAID 5 you can have

234
00:14:06.540 --> 00:14:08.730
a maximum of 32 disks.

235
00:14:08.730 --> 00:14:13.690
And even with that, right, it protects
you but only with the loss of one drive.

236
00:14:13.690 --> 00:14:17.430
If you lose two drives,
RAID 5 is not going to help you.

237
00:14:17.430 --> 00:14:21.200
So two drives going down simultaneously,
it is not gonna help.

238
00:14:21.200 --> 00:14:23.810
There's enough parity,
even across thirty-two drives,

239
00:14:23.810 --> 00:14:27.660
to really rebuild only
the space of one drive.

240
00:14:27.660 --> 00:14:31.550
So in this instance, with Cherokee's,
where there was only three drives,

241
00:14:31.550 --> 00:14:35.920
she is absolutely correct here,
where it does take about a third of that.

242
00:14:35.920 --> 00:14:39.290
But if you have thirty-three,
like I said, thirty-two of them, though,

243
00:14:39.290 --> 00:14:43.250
you're only really wasting the space of
one drive [INAUDIBLE], I say wasting.

244
00:14:43.250 --> 00:14:47.790
You're not able to use the space of
one drive to help you to rebuild that.

245
00:14:47.790 --> 00:14:50.660
So you do want to make sure
that you understand that.

246
00:14:50.660 --> 00:14:55.470
There's a lot of times where you will
see the idea of RAID 5 implemented, but

247
00:14:55.470 --> 00:14:58.790
today there's actually even more
different types of RAID arrays out there.

248
00:14:58.790 --> 00:15:02.200
But for us, at least at the very
basics of the beginning

249
00:15:02.200 --> 00:15:07.150
Cherokee's showing us at least RAID-0,
RAID-1, and RAID-5.

250
00:15:07.150 --> 00:15:10.590
These are kind of a meat and
potatoes, the foundational

251
00:15:10.590 --> 00:15:14.540
notes that you really have to make sure
that you understand as we proceed for.

252
00:15:14.540 --> 00:15:17.080
All right, so Cherokee what
else do we need to know about?

253
00:15:17.080 --> 00:15:19.890
>> Let me just go ahead and
say a few more things about these,

254
00:15:19.890 --> 00:15:23.102
I know this isn't a RAID show,
we have shows on that.

255
00:15:23.102 --> 00:15:27.470
So A+, I know Don's done some, so
I would encourage you to go ahead and

256
00:15:27.470 --> 00:15:31.040
take a look at those if you're not
too familiar with this concept.

257
00:15:31.040 --> 00:15:32.064
There is a lot to learn there.

258
00:15:32.064 --> 00:15:34.816
You do have to install additional drivers
and things of that sort of nature.

259
00:15:34.816 --> 00:15:38.674
I do wanna note that that
paroty bit does because

260
00:15:38.674 --> 00:15:43.000
you are utilizing that
mathematical algorithm.

261
00:15:43.000 --> 00:15:45.186
It takes a little bit of time,
computational power.

262
00:15:45.186 --> 00:15:50.250
So you see a slight performance
degradation there, but

263
00:15:50.250 --> 00:15:56.294
you're happy to trade off there for
that safety net, if you will.

264
00:15:56.294 --> 00:15:59.686
And I'm trying to think, I feel like there
was something else I wanted to say here.

265
00:15:59.686 --> 00:16:04.658
Depending on the size of your
drives as well, so when, let's say,

266
00:16:04.658 --> 00:16:10.244
you do have a drive go down and fail,
you'll always want to try to rebuild and

267
00:16:10.244 --> 00:16:15.336
use that parity bit to rebuild that
failed drive as soon as possible.

268
00:16:15.336 --> 00:16:16.953
Because, like Ronnie said,

269
00:16:16.953 --> 00:16:20.310
you're not gonna be able to
tolerate another drive loss.

270
00:16:20.310 --> 00:16:24.444
And when we're talking about RAID arrays,
and this is also important,

271
00:16:24.444 --> 00:16:28.643
I should mention, you wanna get hard
disk drives that run at the same RPM,

272
00:16:28.643 --> 00:16:30.908
that are gonna be the same size drives.

273
00:16:30.908 --> 00:16:34.967
Because if we could look
at my screen again here,

274
00:16:34.967 --> 00:16:38.631
let's say I have a one
terabyte drive here,

275
00:16:38.631 --> 00:16:43.680
a one terabyte drive here and
a two terabyte drive here.

276
00:16:43.680 --> 00:16:44.630
Well, guess what?

277
00:16:44.630 --> 00:16:48.620
On drive C, then I'm gonna be
wasting one terabyte because

278
00:16:48.620 --> 00:16:50.230
they all have to be the same size as well.

279
00:16:50.230 --> 00:16:56.360
That rate is only going to be striping
against the same size drives.

280
00:16:56.360 --> 00:17:00.183
So you wanna keep that in mind, so
normally, I would recommend to someone to

281
00:17:00.183 --> 00:17:04.710
get almost identical drives from the same
manufacturer, same RPMs, same size.

282
00:17:04.710 --> 00:17:08.096
So you're kind of structured in that way.

283
00:17:08.096 --> 00:17:11.728
And a lot of times, if you do purchase
drives that are very similar,

284
00:17:11.728 --> 00:17:14.938
they've probably been
manufactured from the same batch.

285
00:17:14.938 --> 00:17:19.079
And they're seeing the same amount
use in that machine, and so

286
00:17:19.079 --> 00:17:23.454
the likelihood if you are working
on a machine, powering it down,

287
00:17:23.454 --> 00:17:26.367
powering it up, that can tax those drives.

288
00:17:26.367 --> 00:17:30.892
And if they're within the same life
span of that drive that just failed,

289
00:17:30.892 --> 00:17:34.091
there may be a chance that
another drive will fail.

290
00:17:34.091 --> 00:17:38.048
You don't wanna take that chance
in a production environment,

291
00:17:38.048 --> 00:17:42.528
so you always wanna try to repair that
damaged drive as soon as possible.

292
00:17:42.528 --> 00:17:45.046
And depending on the size of the drive,

293
00:17:45.046 --> 00:17:50.008
how much information was actually stored
on the drive, that will all dictate

294
00:17:50.008 --> 00:17:55.100
how long it will take to rebuild the new
drive that you replaced it with.

295
00:17:55.100 --> 00:18:00.096
And don't expect to really be utilizing
that machine during that rebuild time

296
00:18:00.096 --> 00:18:05.106
because it significantly impacts
performance during that rebuild process.

297
00:18:05.106 --> 00:18:06.349
But that's RAID,

298
00:18:06.349 --> 00:18:11.590
I just wanted to throw that out there
because we're gonna be moving forward.

299
00:18:11.590 --> 00:18:14.930
Talking about other ideas and

300
00:18:14.930 --> 00:18:19.090
concepts that we can use to implement
a software based style RAID,

301
00:18:19.090 --> 00:18:23.680
and that's kind of what
Microsoft has to offer us, okay?

302
00:18:23.680 --> 00:18:28.278
But before we do that, I do wanna cover
some additional terms because like

303
00:18:28.278 --> 00:18:31.551
Ronnie had alluded to,
there are a lot to know here.

304
00:18:31.551 --> 00:18:35.541
And I said I'll let you know and
let you know which ones to worry about, so

305
00:18:35.541 --> 00:18:37.579
let's take a look at my screen here.

306
00:18:37.579 --> 00:18:43.341
And one that I do wanna mention
is these two concepts here, okay?

307
00:18:43.341 --> 00:18:47.937
When you're configuring your drives,
you're gonna be questioned and

308
00:18:47.937 --> 00:18:51.625
say hey, would you like this
drive to be formatted as MBR,

309
00:18:51.625 --> 00:18:56.830
Master Boot Record, or GPT,
which stands for GUID Partition Table?

310
00:18:56.830 --> 00:18:59.150
So let's talk about MBR for a second.

311
00:18:59.150 --> 00:19:01.380
It's been around for a very long time.

312
00:19:01.380 --> 00:19:05.940
This is going to be an older, I mean,
this is even before I was born.

313
00:19:05.940 --> 00:19:08.830
They were using this particular format for
drives.

314
00:19:08.830 --> 00:19:12.585
And you're able to go ahead and
create three primary partitions,

315
00:19:12.585 --> 00:19:17.360
and if you don't know what a partition is,
don't worry, we're gonna cover that.

316
00:19:17.360 --> 00:19:19.527
And then one extended partition,

317
00:19:19.527 --> 00:19:23.867
but people would be able to get
around that by adding logical drives.

318
00:19:23.867 --> 00:19:28.780
We really saw some limitations with
that particular type of drive,

319
00:19:28.780 --> 00:19:32.150
and there was an issue
here also with the size.

320
00:19:32.150 --> 00:19:34.420
If you look at that,
you've got a 2 TB max.

321
00:19:34.420 --> 00:19:41.160
So back in the early 80s,
2 TB was almost like a fantasy.

322
00:19:41.160 --> 00:19:45.010
But nowadays, it's for
organizations and businesses.

323
00:19:45.010 --> 00:19:47.900
It's almost impractical for
some use cases.

324
00:19:47.900 --> 00:19:52.480
So we do have that 2 TB limitation there.

325
00:19:52.480 --> 00:19:57.100
Now also, with MBR, it creates a boot

326
00:19:57.100 --> 00:20:00.730
sector at the beginning that points to
the locations of the partitions and

327
00:20:00.730 --> 00:20:03.990
provides a boot loader for
the operating system.

328
00:20:03.990 --> 00:20:09.146
What that means is if I have the sector
that contains that boot information,

329
00:20:09.146 --> 00:20:12.288
if that sector on that
drive becomes corrupt,

330
00:20:12.288 --> 00:20:16.820
I'm on that a lot because that
provides a single point of failure.

331
00:20:16.820 --> 00:20:22.102
An improvement, a huge improvement, and
one of the many that our GPT formats offer

332
00:20:22.102 --> 00:20:27.386
us is going to be that instead of just one
sector containing that boot information,

333
00:20:27.386 --> 00:20:31.405
it's spread out, so
that you have a redundancy there as well.

334
00:20:31.405 --> 00:20:34.997
So you're not just relying on one
individual sector because let's face it,

335
00:20:34.997 --> 00:20:37.261
sectors, they can go bad,
and once they go bad,

336
00:20:37.261 --> 00:20:39.770
there's nothing you can do
at that particular time.

337
00:20:39.770 --> 00:20:43.978
So machines, about Windows 2003 SP-1 and

338
00:20:43.978 --> 00:20:48.493
beyond, should be able to go ahead and
support GPT,

339
00:20:48.493 --> 00:20:53.330
the operating systems,
we're talking Windows here.

340
00:20:53.330 --> 00:20:56.363
Now it's gonna be
recommended obviously for

341
00:20:56.363 --> 00:20:59.170
drives that are larger than 2 TB in size.

342
00:20:59.170 --> 00:21:04.700
You can have up to 128 partitions on
each disc, and remember, whereas before,

343
00:21:04.700 --> 00:21:08.810
I said you had that three partition limit
there for those primary partitions,

344
00:21:08.810 --> 00:21:13.840
you can have up to 18
exabytes per volume in size.

345
00:21:13.840 --> 00:21:17.210
So that's pretty significant,
just looking at that alone.

346
00:21:18.740 --> 00:21:22.880
BIOS has to support the GPT for
the boot partition.

347
00:21:22.880 --> 00:21:27.780
So you may wanna take a look at that and
look at your motherboard because if you're

348
00:21:27.780 --> 00:21:33.230
running GPT is part of UFI,
which is kind of like that face lift for

349
00:21:33.230 --> 00:21:37.530
older BIOS systems there, so those
are gonna be two options that you have.

350
00:21:38.610 --> 00:21:43.090
Some other terms that I want to mention
here, let's take a look at file systems.

351
00:21:44.530 --> 00:21:49.458
This is gonna be something that you will
also be prompted and asked about, right?

352
00:21:49.458 --> 00:21:53.920
So the system's gonna say, hey,
what kinda file system do you want?

353
00:21:53.920 --> 00:21:56.360
Well, there are a lot of
different file systems out there.

354
00:21:56.360 --> 00:21:59.260
When we're talking about
a Windows environment,

355
00:21:59.260 --> 00:22:01.810
we have only a few that we
really should even consider.

356
00:22:03.210 --> 00:22:06.007
Our FAT file systems,
this is the older legacy FAT.

357
00:22:06.007 --> 00:22:11.474
Even FAT 32 has significant limitations,
which I wouldn't recommend, unless you're

358
00:22:11.474 --> 00:22:16.760
working with a legacy system, and you
need to go ahead and use FAT 32 system.

359
00:22:16.760 --> 00:22:21.270
Most likely, you'll be working with NTFS,
New Technology File System,

360
00:22:21.270 --> 00:22:23.790
this has been around for a very long time.

361
00:22:23.790 --> 00:22:30.450
It includes metadata for indexing, which
will also allow you to implement ACLs.

362
00:22:30.450 --> 00:22:32.530
It also provides encryption.

363
00:22:32.530 --> 00:22:37.418
You have your encrypting file system and
compression as well.

364
00:22:37.418 --> 00:22:41.075
You can set disk quotas and
perform inspections.

365
00:22:41.075 --> 00:22:45.485
So it's probably the preferred
file system here.

366
00:22:45.485 --> 00:22:49.605
As a matter of fact,
there is a newer file system, but

367
00:22:49.605 --> 00:22:53.099
it's called REFS, resilient file system.

368
00:22:53.099 --> 00:22:59.245
But you're not able to boot off of REFS as
of yet, so that's kind of what Microsoft,

369
00:22:59.245 --> 00:23:03.327
I think, is striving for,
is for REFS to replace NTFS.

370
00:23:03.327 --> 00:23:07.892
But at the time of this recording,
which what year are we in here,

371
00:23:07.892 --> 00:23:11.968
Ronnie, 2017,
you're gonna be using NTFS, okay?

372
00:23:11.968 --> 00:23:16.361
So [LAUGH] I'm glad you set that
straight for me there, Ronnie.

373
00:23:16.361 --> 00:23:16.975
>> I know.

374
00:23:16.975 --> 00:23:21.313
>> [LAUGH] But yeah, so
resilient file systems, pretty cool.

375
00:23:21.313 --> 00:23:24.158
And so you might think, well, Cherokee,

376
00:23:24.158 --> 00:23:29.391
if you just told me that I can't have
a bootable drive, what could I use it for?

377
00:23:29.391 --> 00:23:32.710
REFS formatted volumes
here would be great for

378
00:23:32.710 --> 00:23:37.571
any kind of additional drive space,
like storage, file storage.

379
00:23:37.571 --> 00:23:40.978
And it's cool because with NTFS,

380
00:23:40.978 --> 00:23:45.912
if I had any kind of immediate shut down,
okay, so

381
00:23:45.912 --> 00:23:51.562
not a graceful shutdown, but
maybe I had a loss of power.

382
00:23:51.562 --> 00:23:56.587
Well, It's highly likely that I could
see data corruption with the way

383
00:23:56.587 --> 00:24:02.560
that that file system handles those
prompt shut-downs, unplanned shut-downs.

384
00:24:02.560 --> 00:24:05.560
With ReFS,
it has that resilient file system,

385
00:24:05.560 --> 00:24:09.780
it has a self-healing capability there,
right?

386
00:24:09.780 --> 00:24:14.680
It doesn't even have certain types
of discrete pair functions because

387
00:24:14.680 --> 00:24:15.950
it auto heals.

388
00:24:15.950 --> 00:24:17.550
So that's pretty cool there.

389
00:24:17.550 --> 00:24:19.820
It is backward compatible with NTFS but

390
00:24:19.820 --> 00:24:23.880
it doesn't allow those permissions,
it doesn't have compression.

391
00:24:23.880 --> 00:24:28.270
It does have increased data
verification and error collection.

392
00:24:28.270 --> 00:24:31.620
Supports larger files,
directories, volumes.

393
00:24:31.620 --> 00:24:34.690
Lower functionality as compared to NFS,
because, like I said,

394
00:24:34.690 --> 00:24:39.350
it has no EFS, compression, and
different types of assignments.

395
00:24:39.350 --> 00:24:41.020
But, they're still working on it,

396
00:24:41.020 --> 00:24:44.500
still trying to develop it, so
definitely keep your eye out for that.

397
00:24:45.990 --> 00:24:47.812
All right,
what else do we wanna cover here?

398
00:24:50.867 --> 00:24:53.130
File systems, I'm just checking.

399
00:24:53.130 --> 00:24:59.940
Now, you'll also see something whenever
I go in to show you how to set this up,

400
00:24:59.940 --> 00:25:04.750
an option,
it'll say basic versus dynamic disks.

401
00:25:04.750 --> 00:25:09.580
So if we take a look at my screen here,
I did wanna show you this.

402
00:25:09.580 --> 00:25:13.640
We will come back to it when we're
actually performing this function, but

403
00:25:13.640 --> 00:25:18.560
your basic disks, like the name implies,
pretty straight forward, pretty basic.

404
00:25:18.560 --> 00:25:21.929
It's the same structure as in
the previous Windows systems,

405
00:25:21.929 --> 00:25:25.680
you still got that 4 partition,
3 primary and 1 extended.

406
00:25:25.680 --> 00:25:29.370
It doesn't provide integrated
software resistance to damage and

407
00:25:29.370 --> 00:25:30.560
it allows us to boot.

408
00:25:30.560 --> 00:25:35.280
So if you're ever in a conundrum and
you're like, am I able to boot?

409
00:25:35.280 --> 00:25:38.870
This is a safe bet here when you're
dealing with basic disks because when we

410
00:25:38.870 --> 00:25:40.450
talk about dynamic disks,

411
00:25:40.450 --> 00:25:46.400
some configurations will allow you to boot
in a dynamic disk but not all of them.

412
00:25:46.400 --> 00:25:49.860
So just to be safe if you are not
too familiar with that there.

413
00:25:49.860 --> 00:25:52.450
I do wanna note that there is

414
00:25:52.450 --> 00:25:57.030
a one way conversion that Microsoft
does support from basic to dynamic.

415
00:25:59.610 --> 00:26:05.830
It's not going to be able to be reversed
as far as dynamic to basic without

416
00:26:05.830 --> 00:26:10.290
the removal of your data, so just keep
that in mind that is important to note.

417
00:26:10.290 --> 00:26:14.440
When you're working in the operating
system, it will remind you of that if

418
00:26:14.440 --> 00:26:18.740
you're using the graphical user interface
and I'll show you how that will happen.

419
00:26:18.740 --> 00:26:22.620
A lot of the information that we've
covered here will make more sense as we

420
00:26:22.620 --> 00:26:25.090
continue and walk through this process.

421
00:26:25.090 --> 00:26:28.800
But just know dynamic disks
they can expand functionalities

422
00:26:28.800 --> 00:26:30.610
when there are more disks.

423
00:26:30.610 --> 00:26:35.340
If I want to take advantage of a lot of
these configuration settings that we'll

424
00:26:35.340 --> 00:26:40.230
take a look at, I will need to
use a dynamic disk configuration.

425
00:26:40.230 --> 00:26:44.080
Basic, very straightforward,
very basic, right?

426
00:26:44.080 --> 00:26:46.860
And also with your dynamic disks,
it may involve volumes

427
00:26:47.990 --> 00:26:52.370
which join multiple partition and physical
disks, and we'll take a look at that.

428
00:26:52.370 --> 00:26:56.408
And it may provide solutions to offer
resistance to damage with no hardware,

429
00:26:56.408 --> 00:26:58.880
without adding additional hardware.

430
00:26:58.880 --> 00:27:04.390
And currently, it is going to be replaced
with a storage space's functionality.

431
00:27:04.390 --> 00:27:08.200
And we will get there as well,
but baby steps, baby steps.

432
00:27:08.200 --> 00:27:11.989
So a lot of this information I've covered,
these terms,

433
00:27:11.989 --> 00:27:14.631
if they don't make sense that's fine.

434
00:27:14.631 --> 00:27:19.104
Let's go ahead and take some time getting
in the actual operating system, and

435
00:27:19.104 --> 00:27:21.828
if you still don't understand,
then go back.

436
00:27:21.828 --> 00:27:24.735
And I've provided links and
the show notes as well for

437
00:27:24.735 --> 00:27:27.650
additional information to
help you with that there.

438
00:27:28.910 --> 00:27:30.930
>> All right, Cherokee,
well, thank you again for

439
00:27:30.930 --> 00:27:33.835
helping us to get started with
the idea of local storage here.

440
00:27:33.835 --> 00:27:38.560
Where we did take a look at some of the
differences between RAID implementation,

441
00:27:38.560 --> 00:27:41.180
that we have RAID0, RAID1, RAID5.

442
00:27:41.180 --> 00:27:44.800
And also Cherokee helped us a little bit
with the difference between basic and

443
00:27:44.800 --> 00:27:46.050
dynamic disk.

444
00:27:46.050 --> 00:27:49.540
As well as talk about the partitioning
information as well, GPT,

445
00:27:49.540 --> 00:27:54.550
as well as the MBR which I couldn't
remember I right off top of my head.

446
00:27:54.550 --> 00:27:56.830
But there is a lot more to come,
and a lot more to actually see,

447
00:27:56.830 --> 00:27:58.770
now that we have got
some of the basic terms.

448
00:27:58.770 --> 00:28:01.300
So, that's what we want to do is we
want to save that for a part two.

449
00:28:01.300 --> 00:28:04.500
So, it's a great place for
us to sign off for this episode.

450
00:28:04.500 --> 00:28:06.990
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Ronnie Wong.

451
00:28:06.990 --> 00:28:07.950
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

452
00:28:07.950 --> 00:28:10.817
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Windows Server 101 shows.

453
00:28:10.817 --> 00:28:17.949
[MUSIC]

454
00:28:17.949 --> 00:28:20.558
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue with storage concepts.  Cherokee distinguishes between Volumes and Partitions.  She demonstrates how to create volumes using the Disk Management utility built into the Windows Server Environment.
episodes.title: Working with Local Storage Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.017 --> 00:00:01.290
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.290 --> 00:00:02.451
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.451 --> 00:00:06.448
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.448 --> 00:00:08.245
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.245 --> 00:00:12.280
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.280 --> 00:00:15.464
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.464 --> 00:00:18.182
You're watching
the Windows Server 101 show.

8
00:00:18.182 --> 00:00:19.682
I am your host Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:19.682 --> 00:00:23.512
And today we're taking a look
at part two on working with

10
00:00:23.512 --> 00:00:27.356
local storage inside of our
very first part that we did.

11
00:00:27.356 --> 00:00:30.621
We've talked about some of the basic
terminologies that we need to be familiar

12
00:00:30.621 --> 00:00:31.665
with the server admins.

13
00:00:31.665 --> 00:00:33.825
When we start dealing with
the idea of storage and

14
00:00:33.825 --> 00:00:36.467
now in part two we're actually
gonna see a little bit more.

15
00:00:36.467 --> 00:00:38.400
And here to help us out is
gonna be Miss Cherokee Boose.

16
00:00:38.400 --> 00:00:39.853
Cherokee, welcome back to the studio.

17
00:00:39.853 --> 00:00:40.932
>> Thanks for having me Ronnie.

18
00:00:40.932 --> 00:00:41.953
That's exactly right.

19
00:00:41.953 --> 00:00:44.749
We've learned quite a bit so
far in that first show and

20
00:00:44.749 --> 00:00:47.671
it's okay if you don't fully
understand those terms,

21
00:00:47.671 --> 00:00:51.853
because we're gonna spend extra time and
really dive into it within this show.

22
00:00:51.853 --> 00:00:54.499
So let's go ahead and take a look here.

23
00:00:54.499 --> 00:00:59.213
So if we think about all the things that
we've discussed in the previous episode,

24
00:00:59.213 --> 00:01:03.397
Disk Management is a great place to
go ahead and well manage those disks.

25
00:01:03.397 --> 00:01:04.277
And it gives you,

26
00:01:04.277 --> 00:01:08.161
provides a graphical user interface in
which you can perform this functions.

27
00:01:08.161 --> 00:01:12.135
You can go ahead and initialize,
put your disks online and

28
00:01:12.135 --> 00:01:16.529
you can format them and
even create different types of volumes.

29
00:01:16.529 --> 00:01:18.333
So that's what we will
be doing in this show.

30
00:01:18.333 --> 00:01:22.876
You do of course have other options
that Microsoft does leaning towards.

31
00:01:22.876 --> 00:01:27.582
So for instance,
we'll be speaking later on storage pools.

32
00:01:27.582 --> 00:01:32.132
You also have a couple command line
interfaces that we'll introduce as well.

33
00:01:32.132 --> 00:01:36.831
So you guys are already familiar with
PowerShell you can manage disks via

34
00:01:36.831 --> 00:01:40.298
PowerShell, as well as
the disk part.exe utility,

35
00:01:40.298 --> 00:01:43.009
which is command line interface as well.

36
00:01:43.009 --> 00:01:45.880
So let's go ahead and
get started with our GUIs.

37
00:01:45.880 --> 00:01:49.977
And I wanna introduce disk management and
show you where you can go ahead and

38
00:01:49.977 --> 00:01:50.833
pull that out.

39
00:01:50.833 --> 00:01:54.083
I actually already have it pulled up but
let me just close out of here.

40
00:01:54.083 --> 00:01:57.952
You could use your run line or
you could go ahead and

41
00:01:57.952 --> 00:02:02.112
just right-click and
here you see Disk Management.

42
00:02:02.112 --> 00:02:08.564
And the actual run line would just be
diskmgmt.msc and we'll go ahead and

43
00:02:08.564 --> 00:02:14.407
we'll hit OK, and this will pull
up our Disk Management console.

44
00:02:14.407 --> 00:02:17.640
Give it a second for
this information to load, and you'll see

45
00:02:17.640 --> 00:02:22.009
that I already have some disks that have
been added into this particular computer.

46
00:02:22.009 --> 00:02:23.184
So let's take a look.

47
00:02:23.184 --> 00:02:26.515
The volumes are indicated
in this top pane, but

48
00:02:26.515 --> 00:02:31.352
I'm just gonna pull this up to give
us a little more room to work with.

49
00:02:31.352 --> 00:02:34.997
All right, Disk 0, Disk 1,
Disk 2, Disk 3, and

50
00:02:34.997 --> 00:02:39.390
let's see how many disks do we got here,
we've got quite a few.

51
00:02:39.390 --> 00:02:43.746
We've got Disk 4 and
then we also have some CDs,

52
00:02:43.746 --> 00:02:47.055
which are considered disks as well.

53
00:02:47.055 --> 00:02:52.687
And if you look at these CDs the CD Rom 0,
CD Rom 1, up in this top pane here,

54
00:02:52.687 --> 00:02:57.892
you can see the file system associated
with each one of those volumes.

55
00:02:57.892 --> 00:03:00.999
For instance here for volume C,

56
00:03:00.999 --> 00:03:06.074
you can note that we're
using the NTFS file system.

57
00:03:06.074 --> 00:03:09.614
And in the last episode, we spoke
about the different file systems and

58
00:03:09.614 --> 00:03:12.445
why you would or
would not want to be using certain ones.

59
00:03:12.445 --> 00:03:16.479
UDF is actually a file system that's
designed, what did we say that was,

60
00:03:16.479 --> 00:03:17.008
Ronnie?

61
00:03:17.008 --> 00:03:18.891
You told me before the show,
it's been a while.

62
00:03:18.891 --> 00:03:20.283
>> Universal disk format.

63
00:03:20.283 --> 00:03:22.025
>> Universal disk format.

64
00:03:22.025 --> 00:03:26.435
Yes, so that's one of the different
formats that you can use to go ahead and

65
00:03:26.435 --> 00:03:28.475
file systems for like CDs, DVDs.

66
00:03:28.475 --> 00:03:32.801
But NTFS, remember we said that was
the only file system currently within

67
00:03:32.801 --> 00:03:37.074
a Windows operating system that could
hold that boot information here.

68
00:03:37.074 --> 00:03:41.186
So our C drive is going to
be our bootable disk here.

69
00:03:41.186 --> 00:03:43.422
So let me go ahead and zoom out,

70
00:03:43.422 --> 00:03:48.067
and you can see our C drive is
noted here as NTFS, it's healthy.

71
00:03:48.067 --> 00:03:49.851
We also see something else.

72
00:03:49.851 --> 00:03:53.739
If you're performing a clean installation
of the server operating system, and

73
00:03:53.739 --> 00:03:56.440
with other operating systems
like client side as well.

74
00:03:56.440 --> 00:04:02.401
You also see the system reserved partition
here and you can see if 500 megabytes.

75
00:04:02.401 --> 00:04:06.899
It's healthy and the information that's
contained there is going to be some

76
00:04:06.899 --> 00:04:11.673
overhead information that the operating
system can use such as your boot sector or

77
00:04:11.673 --> 00:04:14.041
your boot configuration information.

78
00:04:14.041 --> 00:04:19.156
You've got Bitlocker information,
if you're also going to be utilizing that,

79
00:04:19.156 --> 00:04:23.297
and then you also have,
what was the other thing here for that?

80
00:04:23.297 --> 00:04:25.305
Your recovery,
your Windows RE environment.

81
00:04:25.305 --> 00:04:29.335
So those are gonna be some different
overhead utilities that are stored there

82
00:04:29.335 --> 00:04:29.838
as well.

83
00:04:29.838 --> 00:04:34.274
Now, you'll notice then I have disk 0,
so we said that we had,

84
00:04:34.274 --> 00:04:36.174
it went all the way up to 4.

85
00:04:36.174 --> 00:04:40.719
So within this particular machine I
actually have five physical hard disk

86
00:04:40.719 --> 00:04:41.379
drives and

87
00:04:41.379 --> 00:04:46.085
remember we spoke about what a physical
hard disk drive was in the last show.

88
00:04:46.085 --> 00:04:49.144
These are drives that are tangible,
I can touch them.

89
00:04:49.144 --> 00:04:53.905
Now it doesn't really matter if they're
going to be regular spindle optical

90
00:04:53.905 --> 00:04:56.995
drives, or
if you're using solid state drives.

91
00:04:56.995 --> 00:05:02.530
So, it just depends on the cost, and
if you can afford that or not, really.

92
00:05:02.530 --> 00:05:06.746
But, you'll also notice something here,
differences in color.

93
00:05:06.746 --> 00:05:09.721
So, they kinda have a color
coding thing going on,

94
00:05:09.721 --> 00:05:13.337
there's a lot of different that
this interface can give you.

95
00:05:13.337 --> 00:05:18.671
On this first drive, Disk 0,
I can see that there's something that says

96
00:05:18.671 --> 00:05:23.762
17 gigs of unallocated space within
this last partition over here.

97
00:05:23.762 --> 00:05:28.110
And, okay, that leaves a couple questions
like number one, what's a partition, and

98
00:05:28.110 --> 00:05:30.368
number two, what's unallocated, right?

99
00:05:30.368 --> 00:05:33.941
So, a partition if we think about it,

100
00:05:33.941 --> 00:05:39.191
we can see on Disk 0,
this particular hard disk drive,

101
00:05:39.191 --> 00:05:44.465
I have three separate spaces
within this disk, right?

102
00:05:44.465 --> 00:05:50.409
So, I have 500 megabytes for
that system reserved partition, all right?

103
00:05:50.409 --> 00:05:54.687
I've got about 22 and
a half gigs on my C drive here for

104
00:05:54.687 --> 00:06:00.194
that particular partition, and
then I have 17 gigs of extra space.

105
00:06:00.194 --> 00:06:03.731
So unallocated means it
hasn't been formatted,

106
00:06:03.731 --> 00:06:08.709
it hasn't been configured in any way,
it's just extra space there.

107
00:06:08.709 --> 00:06:11.992
So the terminology with Microsoft
can get a little murky at

108
00:06:11.992 --> 00:06:16.758
times when they're talking about the
difference between partitions and volumes.

109
00:06:16.758 --> 00:06:21.670
So for now I think it's just best
if you understand that a partition

110
00:06:21.670 --> 00:06:24.477
is almost like a unit of measurement,

111
00:06:24.477 --> 00:06:28.974
as a way to indicates space that
is being used within a drive.

112
00:06:28.974 --> 00:06:31.880
But whenever you hear
me say the term volume,

113
00:06:31.880 --> 00:06:36.485
it means I've configured it,
I've selected a file system to choose.

114
00:06:36.485 --> 00:06:38.891
And I've also assigned a drive letter or

115
00:06:38.891 --> 00:06:41.736
I've either mounted
that particular volume.

116
00:06:41.736 --> 00:06:45.229
So after I've configured it,
Microsoft likes to use the term volume.

117
00:06:45.229 --> 00:06:48.670
So just so we're clear on that,
don't get hung up on it though.

118
00:06:48.670 --> 00:06:53.332
>> Cherokee, you make a very good point on
this particular type of terminology here.

119
00:06:53.332 --> 00:06:56.907
Remember that for us, a partition
essentially helps us to chop up

120
00:06:56.907 --> 00:07:01.067
whatever hard drive that we have into
the useable space that we want it to do.

121
00:07:01.067 --> 00:07:06.310
But the term volume, when it boils down
to the kinda the basic thing is if you

122
00:07:06.310 --> 00:07:11.470
need to store data onto it, you're not
storing it on a partition per say,

123
00:07:11.470 --> 00:07:14.318
you are gonna now store it onto a volume.

124
00:07:14.318 --> 00:07:16.505
The difference between the partition and

125
00:07:16.505 --> 00:07:20.752
the volume is that now we actually have a
file system, we can now actually use it in

126
00:07:20.752 --> 00:07:24.145
the structure with the file system
to be able to store data on it.

127
00:07:24.145 --> 00:07:26.829
So, the partitioning is
about dividing up space.

128
00:07:26.829 --> 00:07:30.861
The idea of volume is now logically being
on the store down on it that we can now

129
00:07:30.861 --> 00:07:31.684

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue working with local storage.  They show how to configure multiple hard drives for usage in storage spaces.  This is another way to dynamically manage and configure storage within the Windows Server OS.  Cherokee demonstrates how to configure multiple options for storage space depending on the demands.  The team emphasize the ease and use of this technology when working with local storage.
episodes.title: Working with Local Storage Part 3

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie explain how NTFS permissions can be used on a system running an NTFS file system. Ronnie shows the default standard permission setting options and suggests avoiding the deny option whenever possible.
episodes.title: Managing NTFS Permissions

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee continue talking about NTFS permissions. First, they look at a more tailored  approach to configure permissions using the advanced option. Ronnie also demonstrates how to change ownership, encrypt files and folders, as well as implementing auditing.
episodes.title: Managing NTFS Permissions Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee explain how to manage access control across shared folders and files. First, they explain how share permissions affect NTFS permissions and even advise against combining the two. They discuss the purpose of hidden shares and demonstrate how to create one.
episodes.title: Managing Shared Folders and Files

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie continue to discuss shared folders and files.  first, they discuss Access-Based Enumeration (ABE) a way to implement the principle of least privilege and only display folders and files to which the user has been granted permission. They also look at how to enable shadow copies to store multiple versions of a folder or file. Lastly, they look at File Server Resource Manager as a way to implement quotas, screen files and generate reports.
episodes.title: Managing Shared Folders and Files Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee look at utilizing print services. They discuss and demonstrate how to provide correct drivers for end users in an environment. They also Look at management functions such as managing print permissions and managing print queues.
episodes.title: Managing Print Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie continue to discuss Print Services. Specifically, the look at why and how to configure printer pooling. Don't miss the import considerations to keep in mind for your printer pooling design.
episodes.title: Managing Print Services Part 2
